HEADLINE: U.S. Maps Ways to Assist Russia, Though Roadblocks May Remain

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Almost since Boris N. Yeltsin climbed atop a tank in 1991 and hastened the end of the Soviet Union, Western nations have been talking about sending money to help him create a democratic Russia.
But in dollars and cents, the aid offered has never been as big as the talk of support. And the amount delivered has been even smaller, by far. 
 Now Mr. Yeltsin faces his biggest crisis since the failed coup of 1991, and the Clinton Administration is pushing an aid program from the major industrial countries of perhaps $30 billion that is considerably larger than last year's package and goes off in a different direction.
 
Past, Alas, May Be Prologue
 This approach, however, could go awry for many of the same reasons that last year's aid package did. The principal problems then -- chaos in the Russian Government and Moscow's hesitance about pushing through painful austerity measures -- persist.
To overcome those obstacles, the Administration is combining two types of aid: symbolic and financial.
The first involves some small concrete ideas that have been floated for years, like sending American farmers to teach about private agriculture and retired executives to teach about management. The point is to provide visible support for Mr. Yeltsin and show the Russians the benefits of working with the West.
But the Administration also wants to expand the big-money side, including a $6 billion fund to stabilize the value of the ruble against western currencies, a prerequisite ift Russia is to increase trade and foreign investment.
Also contemplated is a program to supply billions of dollars to protect Russians from economic hardship, and vastly increased loans by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to help pay for imports, modernize industry, repair deteriorating oil wells and shore up Russia's hard-currency reserves.
The new approach aims at making Russia's economy less dependent on foreign aid in the long run.
Administration officials say the program last year did not help nearly enough. Not only did Russia receive just two-thirds of the $24 billion promised, but much of that involved grain credits. While helping to feed hungry Russians, the credits increased the country's mountain of debt without fostering long-term solutions.
Administration officials say President Clinton wants Mr. Yeltsin to explain Russia's financial needs in detail when the two leaders meet in Vancouver, British Columbia, this weekend.
Mr. Clinton plans to present a $400 million package of direct aid from the United States, officials say. This would include food grants, housing-loan guarantees and financing to help new business, and it would expand to $700 million or more in the next fiscal year.
 
The International Effort
 The far larger commitment -- perhaps $30 billion -- will be sought from the leaders of the major industrial powers known as the Group of Seven. Foreign and finance ministers from the group are to meet April 14 and 15 in Tokyo.
The international package focuses on these items:
*$11 billion in credits for imports of food, machinery and spare parts.
*More than $9 billion in loans from the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
*A $6 billion fund to stabilize the ruble, contingent on Russia's bringing down inflation.
*Deferral of more than $4 billion in debt payments due in the next year by rescheduling some of the $80 billion that Russia owes to banks and governments.
Much of this aid may never arrive for many of the reasons that aid fell short of promises last year: Russia's Central Bank may not be any more successful in cutting inflation, now running at 25 percent a month. Graft and poor coordination between Moscow and local governments could recur.
For example, Germany said it would provide $3 billion in direct bilateral credits last year, but officials in Bonn said they provided less than half that, mainly because Russia's bureaucracy and enterprises were so disorganized.
The Administration's new approach is intended to some extent to bypass bureaucrats and provide aid directly to the people, for example, by setting up a fund run by foreign officials to provide seed money for new businesses.
 
A More Willing I.M.F.
 The Administration is also planning to pressure the I.M.F. to act more like an engaged partner than a conservative banker. The hope is that the fund will work harder -- and be somewhat less strict -- in negotiating an accord in which Russia would receive billions of dollars in exchange for agreeing to tame inflation and make other reforms.
Part of the Administration's vision is a grand pact in which the fund promises billions of dollars in aid, perhaps more than $10 billion, and in exchange Russia's central bank stops printing so many rubles, the main cause of the current inflation.
Such aid could help finance industrial restructuring and a social safety net, which would reduce pressure on the central bank to churn out new rubles to help the poor and keep foundering enterprises afloat.
"Aid is not a reward," said Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard professor advising Russia. "It's one of the things that makes reforms possible. There's no way to have the aid come only after stabilization."
Professor Sachs, a strong critic of the bilateral aid programs in the last year, said most export credits failed to help because they have to be repaid too quickly and were poorly coordinated. He said credits often were for the purchase of equipment that Western companies wanted to sell but Russia often did not need.
In a letter to the other Group of Seven nations, Lawrence H. Summers, Under Secretary-designate of the Treasury, set out a list of options under which the I.M.F. might provide up to $7.5 billion in aid in addition to the $6 billion ruble fund.
The options include $4 billion more in loans, contingent upon Russia's making certain economic reforms. Then the I.M.F. might lend another $3 billion under an emergency program for nations hurt by unexpected declines in exports.
In addition, the World Bank might provide close to $2 billion this year. It has approved -- but not disbursed -- $760 million in loans to finance imports, help privatization and strengthen the welfare system.
World Bank officials are also expected to approve a $500 million loan for the energy industry and a $500 million loan to help Russian agriculture.
The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is planning to provide more than $500 million in aid.
 
Reducing Debt Repayments
 In addition to the $16 billion that might come from the International Monetary Fund and other multilateral institutions, Western officials say the Group of Seven will promise about the same amount of bilateral aid as last year -- $11 billion -- in grants, and credits to buy grain, machinery or spare parts.
The final part of the package would involve setting easier terms for the repayment of Russia's $80 billion in debts. According to the Institute for International Finance, a group of international banks, Russia is supposed to make $15 billion in debt payments this year, including about $4.2 billion in interest and $10.7 billion in principal.
Many officials say that after a rescheduling agreement, Russia will probably pay only a few billion dollars this year; such rescheduling, some Western officials say, could push this year's financial aid to Russia to over $30 billion.

HEADLINE: U.N. Approves Plan to Enforce Bosnia Flight Ban

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 31

 BODY:
The United Nations Security Council stepped up its campaign to force Bosnia's Serbs to end their war in Bosnia and Herzegovina today by authorizing NATO to shoot down any planes violating its ban on flying over that country.
This means that NATO radar planes and fighters will soon begin patrolling Bosnian airspace looking for aircraft or helicopters violating the no-flights zone the Security Council imposed over Bosnia and Herzegovina in October. 
 The move has little military significance, diplomats say, since the United Nations says there has been only one verified combat violation of the ban since it was enacted.
But the enforcement decision today, supported by all Council members except China, which abstained, is seen as a warning to Bosnia's Serbs that the Council is now determined to put increasing pressure on them to agree to the peace settlement that an international mediation team headed by Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen has persuaded Bosnia's Croatian and Muslim leaders to accept.
 
'Should Send a Message'
 "The resolution should send a message that if the Bosnian Serbs want to rejoin the family of nations their behavior must conform to international norms," the deputy United States representative here, Edward S. Walker, told the Council after today's vote. Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, said the prospects of the Serbs would be "grim indeed" unless they make peace.
The next step in the campaign to press the Serbs into making peace is expected to come early next week when the Council plans to adopt a resolution giving them 15 days to accept the Vance-Owen plan. If they still refuse, the new resolution would sharply tighten the trade embargo the Council has already imposed on the Yugoslav federation, which is composed of Serbia and Montenegro.
The calculation is that the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, is the only person capable of making Bosnia's Serbs capitulate by threatening to cut off the vital supplies of fuel, food and military equipment he sends them, and that the prospect of Serbia's virtually total economic and political isolation will force Mr. Milosevic to use that influence.
While the resolution clearly threatens the Serbs with new sanctions if they refuse to make peace, France and Britain wanted it to endorse the Vance-Owen proposals unambiguously. But the United States objected and the resolution merely "commends" the peace plan. France and Britain say this risks encouraging the Serbs to think the Council is not fully committed to the plan.
American officials say the Clinton Administration does not want to get into a position where it is asked to enforce a Bosnian settlement that is being imposed on the parties to the dispute instead of being accepted by them voluntarily. The Americans say they also want to give the mediators some flexibility in their dealings with the Serbs by making clear that the plan is not yet cast in concrete.
But Mr. Vance and Lord Owen made clear today that they would have preferred a ringing endorsement of their proposals by the Security Council. And some diplomats suspect that one of the reasons the Clinton Administration does not want the Council to demand that the Serbs accept the Vance-Owen plan is because this might create a precedent that could be applied to Israel.
The draft resolution would ban transshipment of supplies through Yugoslavia to other countries without Security Council permission. It would also ban all movements of goods along the Yugoslav part of the Danube River unless captains obtain Security Council permission and an observer is stationed on each vessel.
It would freeze overseas Yugoslav financial assets, and it would order countries to impound all Yugoslav ships, aircraft, trucks and rolling stock on their territory.
The new resolution comes at an awkward time for President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, who is locked in a power struggle with a strongly nationalistic parliament that sides with the Serbs and that has already asked him to use Russia's veto to stop the Security Council fromo punishing them any further.
But a senior American officials predicted that Moscow would go along with the resolution in the end in return for some minor changes in the text making it clear that the trade embargo will be relaxed as Bosnia's Serbs comply with the Vance-Owen peace proposal.
The leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, has convened his parliament this Friday to discuss his rejection of the Vance-Owen plan in New York last week after the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government finally accepted it in its entirety.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits New Low Versus Yen

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The dollar fell to record lows against the Japanese yen yesterday as traders tested how far the currency would fall while the United States put pressure on Tokyo to cut its bloated trade surplus.
In late New York trading, the yen was at 114.79 to the dollar, slightly above its low of 114.55 reached earlier in the day but well below its Tuesday close of 116.55. The dollar fell to a similar level today in Tokyo. 
 The dollar also fell against other leading currencies, including the British pound and the German mark.
The dollar began its decline in Tokyo early yesterday -- the end of the quarter and Japan's fiscal year -- and the rush to sell dollars to buy yen was probably exaggerated by traders seeking to balance their books.
But the sharp drop in the dollar served only to accelerate a trend: over the last three months, the dollar has fallen more than 8 percent against the Japanese currency.
 
'Repatriation of Yen'
 "I think much of what happened yesterday was due to a fairly dramatic repatriation of yen," said Robert A. White, a senior vice president at Standard Chartered Bank in Los Angeles, "But I am inclined to believe the overall downward direction has to get down to trade."
Since President Clinton took office, Japan has come under increasing pressure to cut its trade surplus with the United States. Various Administration officials -- most notably Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen -- have said they would like to see the yen rise to make American exports cheaper in Japan and Japanese imports more expensive.
Given the continuing problems in the Japanese economy, the yen's current value against the dollar is difficult to justify on a fundamental basis even with Tokyo's huge trade surplus, Mr. White and other analysts said.
At the same time, they acknowledged that market and political pressures were likely to push up the yen even further against the dollar.
"From a purely fundamental viewpoint, it is hard to understand why the yen is doing so well," said Liliana Nealon, an executive vice president at FX Concepts Capital Market, a research and fund management firm in New York.
"But we could go to 113, or the psychologically critical level of 110," she said, referring to the number of yen to the dollar. "And even if it falls below that level, with all this trade friction, I don't think the Bank of Japan would make much of an effort to support their currency."
Ms. Nealon and others said a decline in the dollar to 110 yen or lower would elicit heavy protests from Japanese exporters, who would likely try to pressure the Bank of Japan to stem the yen's rise.
The Bank of Japan could accomplish that by buying huge amounts of dollars in the foreign exchange market or, less overtly, by pushing down Japanese interest rates.
 
 
Talks With Clinton
 But with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa due in Washington this month for talks with President Clinton, pursuing either course seems highly unlikely.
"The Japanese want the dollar to be in a better position against the yen when he comes," said Simon Fischer, a yen trader at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
An appreciating yen is not only justified but also represents the best, "least difficult step" for Japanese authorities to cut their huge trade surplus, said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
"Every 1 percent rise in the trade-weighted value of the yen cuts $4 billion to $5 billion off their current account surplus," Mr. Bergsten said. "To my knowledge, none of the Japanese authorities have opposed a considerably stronger yen. They have objected to the pace of the rise, but not the magnitude."
Mr. Bergsten, noting that Japan's global trade surplus would approach $150 billion this year, said that the dollar could fall another 10 percent percent in value against the yen and that the yen could appreciate against other major currencies.
"The yen is undervalued against everybody," he said. "The Japanese trade surplus sticks out like a sore thumb, because every other major industrialized country's trade account is in deficit."

Gold Prices Rise Again
By The Associated Press
Gold prices gained more ground yesterday following Tuesday's surge. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery -- which jumped $4.80 an ounce Tuesday -- rose another 60 cents to settle at $337.60. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $336.75 an ounce, up 40 cents from Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin Called Stronger After Congress Showdown

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 31

 BODY:
President Boris N. Yeltsin will be leaving for his weekend summit talks with President Clinton in Vancouver in a stronger position after his showdown with the Congress of People's Deputies, the Russian Foreign Minister said in an interview today.
The minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, who took his share of political heat at the turbulent four-day session, said Mr. Yeltsin faced "no problem" in leaving the country at this stage in its political crisis. "The situation is firmly under control," he said. 
 "What really happened at the Congress was a showdown, and it clarified things," Mr. Kozyrev said. "What is important is to clearly see who stands for what and where is democracy. This is much better position for Yeltsin, especially before a referendum."
Mr. Kozyrev, speaking in his office on the seventh floor of the Foreign Ministry, said the events of the last week, which culminated in a vote that narrowly failed to oust Mr. Yeltsin from office, showed that at this stage in the battle over economic and political change in Russia there was no middle ground. "Unfortunately there is no center in those who pretended to be centrist forces," he said.
Until now, the majority in the Congress, which opposes Mr. Yeltsin, could argue that it only wanted to "make corrections on the path to reform," he said.
"This kind of mythology was there before the Congress," he said. "Now it is absolutely clear that the alternative to Yeltsin's policy is really a reversal, something very dark and frightening."
In the current political atmosphere, Mr. Kozyrev said, the chances are practically nonexistent any time soon for a ratification in the Russian Parliament of the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty -- a sweeping agreement signed here with great fanfare last January by President Bush and Mr. Yeltsin. But, he said, if the results of the referendum on April 25 give Mr. Yeltsin a solid victory, then the parliament, which is made up of members of the larger Congress, may swing back toward a more conciliatory position, both toward the Government and the West.
"After the referendum, there will be a new political situation in the country," he predicted. "Until the deputies realize they were led further to the reactionary side than society itself, it will be very difficult to persuade them to ratify anything positive."
Before the referendum, Mr. Kozyrev said, factions that support Mr. Yeltsin and reforms will regroup either as a political movement or even as a party to try to refashion the coalition of forces that elected him President in June 1991.
Since the Congress adjourned Monday, its battle against Mr. Yeltsin has gone into a holding pattern, as his top aides decide their strategy in what one called "a war of referendums." Sergei M. Shakhrai, a top Yeltsin adviser, told journalists on Tuesday that the referendum rules approved by the Congress, which would require the President to win with a majority of eligible, as opposed to participating, voters, left the President with no choice but to hold his own national vote of confidence.
"The Congress resolution envisages conditions for the referendum which make its results negative for the President before the voting even starts," Mr. Shakhrai said.
Mr. Kozyrev said today that the summit meeting in Vancouver should reinforce Mr. Yeltsin's image back home at a time when he is representing himself as a democratic leader doing battle with "red-browns," as Mr. Kozyrev habitually refers to the Communist-nationalist opposition.
"It is important that the democratic, first popularly elected leader of Russia, who reiterates his power not through tanks, but by again appealing to the people, meets with the democratically elected leader of one of the greatest democracies of the world," he said.
Mr. Kozyrev, who was in Washington recently to prepare for the summit meeting, said he had told officials that Moscow was not looking for more foreign assistance but for more cooperation, on trade issues as well as debt relief.

HEADLINE: Nasdaq Share Prices Show Renewed Spirit

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
Over-the-counter stocks, having languished behind the Dow stalwarts for the last two months, finished the quarter yesterday with renewed spirit.
The Nasdaq biotechnology and computer issues, normally the most flighty growth stocks, now seem to represent firmer values than the weighty industrial shares, some money managers said. The American Stock Exchange, also the province of secondary stocks, rose to a record. 
 At the end of each quarterly reporting period, money managers normally point to window-dressing -- the buying of winners and selling of losers (by other money managers, never the one speaking). In recent days, however, investors have tossed out some of the recent favorites -- deep cyclicals especially -- and bought such previous outcasts as the biotechs.
According to David Evans, research director for the Robertson, Stephens Emerging Growth fund, "There's less of, 'I want to buy this because it will make me look au courant.' "
The Nasdaq composite index continued its recent advance yesterday by gaining 3.88 points, to 690.13, even as the Dow Jones industrial average lost 22.16 points to end at 3,435.11. For the quarter, the Dow finished up 4 percent and the Nasdaq up 2 percent.
Big Board volume of 279.2 million shares yesterday was up substantially from the halting pace of recent days.
Microsoft, the largest Nasdaq issue, added another 1 1/2 yesterday to a gain of 4 on Tuesday, closing at 92 1/2. Several other computer technology stocks followed, with Cisco Systems up 1, to 44 3/4; Autodesk up 2 1/4, to 43 1/2, and Synoptics up 2 1/8, to 90 5/8. Apple Computer and Intel retreated.
Nasdaq medical stocks also generally advanced, although not with Tuesday's broad strides. US Healthcare added 1 1/2, to 46 1/4, and Stryker gained 1 1/2, to 26 3/4.
The biotechnology issues have fallen to levels that even attracted some buyers who look to buy earnings potential on the cheap, said Peter J. DaPuzzo, who manages over-the-counter trading at Cantor Fitzgerald. "I know it's amazing, but they are very close to being value stocks," he said.
The flashiest arrival at the Nasdaq market party was Gymboree, the chain of children's clothing stores. The company's initial public offering, first set to come out at 13 to 15 a share, instead hit the market at 20, then soared to close at 31 1/2.
The Dow list showed no such cheer, as General Electric, Alcoa, Caterpillar and Du Pont each lost at least a point. Stocks most sensitive to the economy, among the market's leaders this year, have faltered in recent days on evidence that growth has slowed. The Government reported a healthy rise in its chief forecasting index yesterday, but this index seldom moves the stock market since most of its components are known in advance.
Lawrence P. Keblusek, director of investment counseling at the Northern Trust Company, said that the economy was not strong enough to sustain the deep cyclicals at their present prices.
The broader market, as reflected in the Standard & Poor's 500, finished nearly even yesterday, with losses among cyclical stocks balanced by gains among medical and retailing issues.

HEADLINE: Aide Pleads Guilty in House Post Office Case

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
In what may be a breakthrough in the long-running investigation of the House post office, a Congressional aide pleaded guilty today to three felony counts and agreed to cooperate with Federal investigators.
The aide, Gerald W. Weaver 2d, who had worked for former Representative Joe Kolter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, for more than four years, pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice, conspiracy, and possession and distribution of cocaine. 
 Under today's plea agreement, Mr. Weaver promised to provide information and testimony about his work as administrative assistant to Mr. Kolter, "including information he may have on the embezzlement of Government property, misappropriation of stamps and misuse of campaign funds."
 
Improprieties Denied
 Mr. Kolter has been under investigation along with two other Democrats, Representatives Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois and Austin J. Murphy of Pennsylvania. Mr. Kolter, a member of the House committee that supervised the post office, was defeated last year in a primary. He has said he did nothing improper.
In a Federal courthouse here today, the 37-year-old Mr. Weaver acknowledged that he had obstructed justice by impeding a Federal grand jury. He said he had asked a former business associate, who was not identified, to write a letter that maintained that $2,900 worth of checks he wrote to the Postmaster from 1989 to 1991 were for postage. In fact the checks were used to buy cocaine from a post office employee, who deposited the checks and then took the equivalent amount in cash from the post office.
Mr. Weaver also admitted that he had sold cocaine from 1987 to 1992 to other Congressional aides and lobbyists whom he did not identify. His main supplier was Wendell Magruder, a former clerk in the post office who has pleaded guilty to drug charges.
Mr. Weaver had been scheduled to be tried next week on 21 criminal counts and today became the first Congressional official outside the post office to be convicted. Six employees of the post office have already been convicted of criminal charges stemming from the scandal.
 
Reduced Sentence Possible
 Mr. Weaver will be sentenced on June 28. The charges he pleaded guilty to carry a maximum sentence of five years in prison and $250,000 in fines on the obstruction count, and 20 years and $1 million in fines on each of the two drug charges. A Federal judge may reduce the sentence if Mr. Weaver provides significant assistance in other related criminal cases.
People involved in the investigation said today's plea agreement was intended to serve two purposes: to gain the cooperation of Mr. Weaver in possibly building a case against Mr. Kolter, who has been subpoenaed and has refused to testify before a grand jury, and to send a signal to other Congressional aides under investigation that it would be to their benefit to reach similar arrangements.
The most closely watched part of the yearlong investigation is the possible indictment of Mr. Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee whose help is crucial for President Clinton to get his economic package through Congress. If he were indicted, Mr. Rostenkowski would have to step aside as head of the committee.
Today's action shed no light on the case against Mr. Rostenkowski; accusations that he improperly took Federal funds and violated Federal election and tax laws have been under investigation. He has denied any wrongdoing and accused prosecutors of conducting a political witch hunt.
United States Attorney Jay B. Stephens, the Republican appointee who is heading the investigation, has been forced by the Clinton Administration to step down. He said today that he would leave office on Friday.
Mr. Stephens has said that the Justice Department had denied him a four-week extension to make the crucial decision about whether to prosecute Mr. Rostenkowski.
Mr. Stephens's successor has not been named, and some officials involved in the post office investigation said today that they could not say when it could reach a conclusion.
"Because we don't know who Jay's replacement will be, all bets are off," said one official.

HEADLINE: Freshman Democrats in House Make a Modest Proposal to Reform Congress

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Charging that special interests wield undue influence on Congress, the freshman class of House Democrats issued its long-awaited reform package today, proposing to trim the wings of lobbyists and toughen campaign finance laws.
The recommendations of the 63 freshmen culminated a three-month effort to stage what critics of Congress hoped would be a rebellion against pork and perks. 
 After two nights of debate, negotiations and some well-timed lobbying by Congressional leaders, the class pulled back from some of the strongest proposals and couched those it passed in broad and modest language.
But the freshmen did call for a 25 percent cut in the budget for the legislative branch over five years, a position resisted mightily by the Democratic leadership, and they presented a long list of proposed restrictions on lobbyists and fund raising that could improve the chances of campaign reform legislation passing this year.
 
A Different Drummer
 "This may not be a revolution," said Representative Nathan Deal, Democrat of Georgia. "But at least we're marching to our own drummer and not necessarily to that of the leadership."
Among the bold ideas that were dropped were some that had inspired derisive resistance from their elders, including term limits on committee chairmen, the abolition of free parking at Washington National Airport and a limit of $50 on gifts that members can receive each year.
Mr. Deal and a few other freshmen had also wanted to challenge the seniority system. But their efforts were resisted by a coalition of minority members and lawmakers from strongly Democratic districts who hope to become chairmen someday. In the end, most freshmen were more concerned with pushing the Clinton economic program than causing divisions within the Democratic caucus.
At crucial moments in the last few weeks, Democratic leaders took freshmen members aside one by one to lobby against certain proposals, like one eventually dropped that would have linked Congressional pay increases to cuts in the deficit.
"Our job is to strengthen, not weaken, to build up, not tear down, to empower, not erode," said Representative Karen Shepherd of Utah, co-leader of the freshman reform task force, trying to distance her class from Republican freshmen who consistently attack the House as an effete institution.
Still, the Democratic reform package offered some stinging criticism of the way politics is conducted on Capitol Hill. "In election campaigns and in the halls of Congress, special-interest money consistently undermines representative government," the freshman manifesto states. "Well-financed special interests use their considerable clout to distort the message or drown out the voices of the people."
 
Crackdown on Lobbyists
 To alleviate the abuses of special interests, the freshmen called for legislation to require lobbyists to itemize expenses on their taxes and eliminate tax deductions of lobbying expenses.
On campaign finance, they stopped short of calling for public financing because more than 20 Democratic freshmen opposed the concept or were undecided on the issue. But they called for voluntary spending limits on campaigns, limitations on contributions from political action committees and tight restrictions on money that individuals give to party organizations, known as "soft money."
The freshman proposals received a lukewarm response from the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington. "All of them will not be rejected," he said, "and probably all of them will not be accepted."
The recommendations will first be considered by the Organization and Review Study Committee, a Democratic leadership group that considers procedural matters, and will then face a vote by the Democratic caucus and full House in the next two months.
As modest as the freshman reforms may be, the backbenchers hope that their package will finally galvanize them into an effective caucus.
During the new lawmakers' efforts to iron out their statement on Tuesday, their leaders confronted Mr. Foley with the demand that he consider making sweeping cuts in the legislative budget later this year. They backed up their plea with the threat that the class would desert the leadership on a bill authorizing a meager 5 percent cut in committee spending.
Congresswoman Shepherd said six freshmen told the Speaker that "we can't support this unless we get a serious crack" at a 25 percent cut in spending over five years. Mr. Foley reluctantly agreed, and the bill passed Tuesday by a mere 28 votes with the support of all but nine of the freshmen.
Senior lawmakers have not gotten accustomed to such freshman arm-twisting. Representative Tony P. Hall of Ohio, the Democratic chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger, which was abolished this week under heavy freshman pressure, went on a fast today in protest.
"A lot of the freshmen don't know of the work we have done," he said, referring to his panel's efforts to publicize famines in Africa and alleviate hunger in Appalachia. "And they don't care."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Democratic freshmen representatives issued recommendations for reform yesterday, including a large budget cut in the legislative branch. At a news conference were, from left, Carolyn Maloney of New York, Eric Fingerhut of Ohio, Maria Cantwell of Washington and Ron Klink of Pennsylvania. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HOUSE APPROVES BUDGET PACKAGE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
Its eye on a spring recess that starts Friday, the House began tying up the loose ends of President Clinton's budget package this evening with a final vote to approve the five-year proposal. The Senate was simply tied up.
Snarled by a long string of mostly Republican amendments, the Senate spent most of the day arguing over the final piece of Mr. Clinton's budget, a plan to spend $16.3 billion on unemployment benefits and jobs programs. 
 Republicans, who contend that the spending is both unneeded and laden with pork-barrel projects, were threatening to delay the Senate's scheduled vacation in hopes of forcing Democratic leaders to scale back the package.
"It's a giant game of chicken," said one Senate Republican aide.
The House, by contrast, voted nearly along party lines, 240 to 184, to approve the final broad outline of Mr. Clinton's budget, a melding of almost identical measures passed earlier by both the House and the Senate.
 
Boundaries on Spending
 The outline, called a budget resolution, sets the general boundaries of spending throughout the Government, allotting $1.5 trillion next year and a total of about $8 trillion through 1998. If it is put into effect as planned, the measure would be an attempt to cut the annual Federal deficit by a total of about $500 billion over the next five years, from the current figure of about $300 billion to about $200 billion in 1997.
About $300 billion of the deficit reduction would result from higher taxes, and about $200 billion would come from reduced Federal spending, mostly for the military.
The Senate interrupted its dispute over the jobs bill tonight to begin debating the measure, and is expected to approve the budget package on Thursday, probably on a party-line vote.
Senate Democratic leaders used parliamentary tactics today to skirt another political fracas with Republicans over another measure that must be passed before the spring break: an increase in the Federal debt limit.
The increase in the debt limit would allow the Government to raise enough money, through sales of bonds, to keep operating through the fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30.
Republicans have promised to load that measure with controversial amendments, including one calling for a constitutional amendment to require a balanced budget. But Democratic leaders structured the measure in a way that prevents it from being hamstrung either by a filibuster or by amendments, insuring that it will be brought to a quick vote by week's end.

HEADLINE: Off-the-Books Advisers Giving Clinton a Big Lift

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
When Bill Clinton took his show on the road, pitching his economic plan to audiences from Atlanta to Santa Monica, Calif., Paul Begala rode along on Air Force One to polish speeches and advise the President on the tactics of persuasion.
Mandy Grunwald, another political consultant, selected the East Room setting for the President's first formal news conference. She helped brief members of the Cabinet the night before the President presented his economic plan to Congress. 
 Stan Greenberg, a poll taker, has been tracking the allegiances of people who voted for Ross Perot and advising the President on how to bring them into his fold. And James Carville, who is Mr. Begala's partner, has been playing attack dog, threatening Democrats who do not fall in line with the President's plan.
All four have especially close relationships with Mr. Clinton and enjoy frequent and easy access to the White House. None are Government employees.
 
Veterans of the Campaign
 Instead, they are part of a tightly knit group of campaign veterans who work at the White House without portfolio, without Government pay and without the legally binding inconvenience of being forced to abide by Government ethics rules.
Mr. Greenberg said recently that the informal arrangement allowed them to advise the President without being "bureaucratically bound."
"We don't have day-to-day responsibility for making the Government work, which is extraordinarily time-consuming," Mr. Greenberg said.
But their link to the White House, forged when they were campaign strategists in Little Rock, Ark., and cemented when they stepped in to rescue the President after his first stumbling weeks in office, has raised eyebrows among some ethicists here.
"A President is entitled to have people come in and advise him," said Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a nonprofit group. "But if you're going to bring in people and have them act as de facto public officials, than you should have full disclosure."
Federal ethics rules require high-level officials to disclose much personal and business financial information and restrict their business activities after they leave the Government.
Other Presidents have also retained outside advisers as political consultants. Charles Black and James Lake, both Washington lobbyists, did that for President George Bush and were heavily involved in Republican Party politics and campaigns.
 
Contracts Reported Rejected
 But Mr. Begala and his counterparts nervously and voluntarily draw a distinction between their work and that of their Republican predecessors. All four have pledged to forsake corporate clients and they say they have collectively turned down millions of dollars in contracts from groups seeking to hire them for White House access.
"A lot of clients I would have taken in the past, environmental or women's groups," Ms. Grunwald said. "Because they have a specific agenda or point of view they want communicated to influence the President, now we just turn down that work."
Mr. Black and Mr. Lake continued to work actively for corporate clients and foreign entities while advising the White House and earned millions of dollars doing it. Patrick J. Buchanan, who challenged Mr. Bush in Republican primaries last year, ran television commercials citing the work Mr. Black and Mr. Lake did for the foreign companies.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director and the main point of West Wing entry for the outside consultants, said the distinction for the Clinton consultants is important. "They don't lobby," he said. "That's a huge difference. That's all the difference in the world."
All four are working for the Democratic National Committee or soon will be under contracts that do not prohibit corporate or foreign lobbying, party officials said. "It would be an insult" to include such language in the contract, one party official said.
Mr. Begala said, "I distinguish a lot between helping the President pass his economic plan and helping a private interest advance their private agenda." He added that he considered his usefulness to be limited to politics and communications, not policy.
"Frankly, I don't think the President of the Bundesbank is waiting on pins and needles to hear from me," he said. "Neither is the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, for that matter."
 
Other Adviser Arrangements
 The White House counsel's office has not formally prohibited any of the political consultants from exploiting their relationships with the White House in the future. Other, looser arrangements also exist at the White House.
Susan Thomases, a close friend of Hillary Rodham Clinton's who had an active role in personnel and scheduling matters in the campaign and transition, has special ty access to the second-floor West Wing offices where the First Lady does her work.
Unlike the politicos, who attend almost every critical meeting on speeches, public appearances and sales strategy, Ms. Thomases is now nearly invisible to the public. She continues to work at her New York office, where she is a partner in the law firm of Wilkie, Farr & Gallagher.
But it is unclear what direct influence Ms. Thomases has over policy, and it would be a difficult task to regulate a personal friendship in any case. "She is not a consultant," said Neel Lattimore, a spokesman for Mrs. Clinton. "She's a longtime personal friend of both the President and the First Lady."
 
Performing Special Projects
 Another friend of the Administration is Skip Rutherford, an Arkansan who worked for Thomas F. McLarty 3d, the White House chief of staff, when he ran Arkla Inc., an energy concern. Officially, Mr. Rutherford is a new senior vice president for Cranford, Johnson, Robinson & Woods, an advertising agency in Little Rock. Less officially, he travels to Washington to perform special projects for Mr. McLarty and is paid by the Democratic National Committee.
Seventeen consultants and 82 temporary employees are also assisting Mrs. Clinton's health care task force. The work of the political consultants overshadows the work of the people who are formally employed to run the White House political operation. Although Rahm Emanuel, the political director, runs the daily 5 P.M. political meeting, both he and David C. Wilhelm, the Democratic national chairman, focus on political outreach more than on daily strategy.
"We're not legislative affairs and we're not communications, so there's this overlap," Mr. Emanuel said. "We're wedged, or snuggled, within these two departments."
While Mr. Wilhelm speaks at state party dinners and Mr. Emanuel schedules appearances for members of the Cabinet or determines White House involvement in affairs like the upcoming Gay Rights March in Washington, the outside consultants handle a range of other decisions.
How should the President counteract the expected negative reaction to new military base closings? What are the most salable parts of Mr. Clinton's health care plan? Of his economic plan?
Whatever the critics might say of the partnership between the consultants and Mr. Clinton, Mr. Begala, for one, is not losing sleep over it.
"He's the President of the United States," said Mr. Begala, who was designated during the first two months of the Administration as a temporary employee, complete with desk and telephone. "I'm a citizen of the United States. I'm giddy about it."

HEADLINE: U.S. TO URGE ASIA TO BUILD SECURITY

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
In a reversal of the Bush Administration policy that opposed steps by Southeast Asian countries to solve their regional security problems, the Clinton Administration will both encourage and take part in such efforts, Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State-designate for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said today.
The new approach reflects a realization that as the United States reduces its military presence in the region, there is an increased need for the Asian countries to solve their diverse security problems on their own. 
 "We must develop new mechanisms to manage or prevent emerging concerns," Mr. Lord told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee during his confirmation hearings. He added that planned security talks by the Association of South East Asian Nations can help the members to "share information, convey intentions, ease tensions, resolve disputes and foster confidence."
 
Baker Rejected an Umbrella
 In an effort to keep a degree of control over Asian security goals, the Bush Administration strongly opposed regional arrangements for Asia. Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d wrote in Foreign Affairs in late 1991 that Washington preferred a "loose network of bilateral alliances," not an overarching security umbrella.
But Mr. Lord said today that Asian nations need their own security structure and that the United States now is "open minded" on how to best help. As an illustration of Mr. Clinton's commitment to help, Mr. Lord said he would participate in regional security talks in Singapore in May.
"I don't see us coming up with a grand scheme or master plan for Asia," a senior Administration official said. "On the other hand, we are less worried than the Bush Administration about an alternate security system without an organizational relationship to the United States."
Mr. Lord dodged repeated questions on the policy toward Vietnam, saying no decisions had been made.
Even some of the most conservative members of Congress have urged the Administration to make a concrete gesture toward Hanoi, by ending the economic embargo and a ban on international bank lending, even by normalizing diplomatic relations.

HEADLINE: Eye on Ball For Israel;
Peace and Terror: Search for Balance

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 31

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin has repeatedly said since he took office last July that talking peace with the Arabs is one thing and fighting Arabs who shoot and stab Israelis is something else entirely. His slogan is "We shall fight terrorism as if there is no peace process, and pursue the peace process as if there is no terrorism."
To Mr. Rabin, Israelis have to keep their eye on the ball, which means not letting bursts of Arab violence get them so hysterical that they lose sight of the bigger objective they have pursued for years: a peace treaty. 
 But that ball has been awfully elusive for many here after a violent March that came in like a lion and went out the same way, with 15 Israeli soldiers, policemen and civilians killed by Palestinian assailants -- the highest monthly toll in several years. About twice as many were wounded.
It does Israelis no good to hear that, by the traumatic standards of American big cities, 15 deaths in a month may not seem startling for a population of 5 million. New York City, with a population of about 7 million, often has 10 homicides in a single weekend. It certainly does them no good at all to hear that many more Palestinians, at least 26 in March, died in conflicts with Israeli soldiers.
 
Sense of Vulnerability
 There is an easily inflamed sense of vulnerability in this country born of the Nazi Holocaust, and with the press and television showing vivid images of spilled Jewish blood, no national leader could let the death count rise as it has without doing something.
On Tuesday, Mr. Rabin acted. He was not nearly as dramatic as in December, when he responded to another spurt of killings by expelling more than 400 accused Islamic militants from the territories to Lebanon. But he did enough so that, despite his own slogan, he may have wrapped the fight against terrorism and the Middle East peace talks into a tighter bundle.
Starting today, for an indefinite period, the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip are closed, meaning that military checkpoints have been set up to turn Palestinian vehicles around, including those carrying the 120,000 Arab workers with jobs in Israel. Jewish settlers in the territories and other Israelis, whose cars bear different license plates from those of Arabs, can drive past the checkpoints.
Even for Palestinians, however, the West Bank borders are porous, and the police today rounded up several hundred of them who were found to be in Israel in violation of the new orders.
 
Tightening Controls
 Military operations and hunts for wanted fugitives are to be intensified, Mr. Rabin said, and loosened regulations permit soldiers now to shoot at any armed Palestinian, whether or not he presents an immediate threat.
A main goal, the Prime Minister said, is to separate the two populations for a while so that tensions can subside. Indeed, the policy appeals to many Israelis on both the political right and left: the right because it makes it more difficult for would-be Arab killers to maneuver, the left because it means de facto recognition of the line separating the territories from pre-1967 Israel.
When asked by a television interviewer how long the closing will last, Mr. Rabin replied that it is up to the Palestinians.
"Dear friends, if you want to solve the problem, the place is around the negotiation table," he told them. "It is permissible for me to keep the territories closed for as long as is required."
That response was an example of how Israelis and Palestinians listen with different ears. Many Israelis heard the call to the peace table, and sensed a reasonable gesture. To many Palestinians, it sounded like a threat: If you don't talk to us, the crackdown will continue.
"This is not going to be helpful," said Elias Freij, the Palestinian mayor of Bethlehem. "I don't think our people will go to the peace talks under duress." As it is, Palestinian delegates have been hesitant about going because the issue of the December deportations is still not resolved to their satisfaction. This latest Israeli action seems unlikely to soften their position.
 
Israel's Vietnam?
 Hundreds of thousands of Palestinians and their families depend on Israel for their livelihood. Even without a curfew imposed on individual towns, residents of the northern part of the West Bank are effectively cut off from the southern sector because they must pass through Jerusalem, which is now off-limits to them. Rather than a cooling off, resentments could fester. And the only winners could be the militants on both sides who want the peace negotiations to fail.
The latest killings have also forced Israelis to begin rethinking some fundamental ideas that have shaped national policy since they captured Gaza and the West Bank in the 1967 war.
One question is how committed they are to holding on to the territories, especially turbulent Gaza, the source of much of the violence. When it comes to Gaza, the six-day triumph of 1967 is beginning to look to many uneasy Israelis like their Vietnam. A rising chorus says that the coastal strip should be given up, now.
Another issue is whether Israelis are prepared to change how they live. Despite high unemployment, veteran Israelis and new immigrants from the former Soviet Union are no more eager than, say, Germans to do back-breaking, low-paying work. Here, gastarbeitern are called Arabs.
And although Mr. Rabin wants to reduce the country's dependence on Palestinian labor, and although there are calls by others to bring in workers from Southeast Asia as replacements, forces in the Labor Party of Mr. Rabin oppose the idea.
More immediately, the Prime Minister must get past a crisis that may have limited his maneuvering room in the peace talks.
 
A Delicate Balance
 Given the present Israeli dark mood, it is hard to imagine, for example, how Mr. Rabin could bend much further on the December expulsions -- concessions demanded by the Palestinians as the price for resuming the talks.
In December, 5 Israelis were killed and Mr. Rabin deported 400 people. Now there are 15 dead, three times as many. What is he going to do? Expel 1,200? Fresh expulsions on any scale seem out of the question because they would be devastating not only to the peace talks but also to the good relations with the Clinton Administration that he has cultivated.
So Mr. Rabin's main hope is that the worst will blow over quickly, perhaps aided by the Passover and Easter holidays next week. What he has prescribed thus far is "extra-strength aspirin," the newspaper Maariv said today, adding, "Rabin has not yet declared 'Emergency.' "

HEADLINE: Mercedes Close to Selecting U.S. Site for Assembly Plant

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 31

 BODY:
Mercedes-Benz A.G., the German luxury auto maker, appears close to making a decision on building an assembly plant in the United States, where it would produce a new four-wheel-drive family car.
Mercedes would become the latest German auto maker to try to cut costs and expand by assembling vehicles in this country. Speculation had been strong in trade journals and among economic development officials in the Southeast that Mercedes has selected a site near Charlotte, N.C., but A. B. Shuman, a spokesman, said yesterday that "a decision hasn't been made yet." 
 Mercedes, based in Stuttgart, Germany, today scheduled a news conference for Monday in Detroit where top executives, including Werner Niefer, its chairman, will address automotive reporters.
In an interview last week, Edzard Reuter, the chairman of Daimler- Benz A.G., which owns Mercedes-Benz , said that "very concrete negotiations are under way on a plant site in the United States.
"One of the possibilities is the Carolinas, where we have an existing plant that belongs to our Freightliner subsidiary," Mr. Reuter said. "We are examining other places as well." Freightliner is the United States' largest producer of heavy trucks, and has three North Carolina plants, in Mount Holly, Cleveland and Gastonia.
The Carolinas are attractive because of lower levels of unionization and pay scales than in other parts of the country. It is also familiar turf for corporate Germany. More than 100 German companies already have subsidiaries in the two states, including the chemical giants Hoechst A.G. and BASF A.G.
Mr. Reuter said that several company objectives argued for a plant in the United States: "It ranges from our plans to broaden our product palette with a new vehicle, a fun car that will find a market in the United States, to wanting to not to be dependent on unstable exchange rates."
Mr. Reuter said Mercedes planned a new sport utility vehicle or station wagon-type vehicle, possibly with four-wheel drive. Production would be between 50,000 and 100,000 units annually, he said; that would be about half or less than the output of a typical car plant. The vehicle would be produced for the American market but likely for export as well.
Last year BMW A.G. selected Greer, a suburb of Spartanburg, S.C., for an assembly plant that is scheduled to start production by 1995. Almost all Japanese auto makers already build cars or light trucks at one or more plants in North America. Volkswagen A.G., which built cars in New Stanton, Pa., until the mid-1980's is considering an American plant again for its Audi division.
Mercedes's review indicates how the dollar's weakness and soaring labor costs abroad -- and the competitive threat of Japanese auto makers -- have compelled car makers worldwide to consider the United States as a low-cost manufacturing venue.
The new assembly plants will add more automotive capacity to a North American market that is already oversaturated, putting additional pressure on the Big Three and the United Automobile Workers union to cut their own costs quickly. On Tuesday, construction unions demonstrated outside BMW's North American headquarters in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. to protest BMW's hiring of a non-union contractor to build its United States plant. BMW has also made clear that it does not want the U.A.W. to represent its workers.
The U.A.W. which has not organized any of the auto plants independently owned by Japanese auto makers, however, has scored a notable victory already against Daimler-Benz, having organized its Mount Holly plant in 1990 and won a contract for workers in 1991.
Automotive analysts believe that Mercedes would export aggressively from its American plant, a tactic that could help this nation's trade deficit as well as provide employment for thousands in a region hit by cuts in military spending.
Mercedes's worldwide sales fell to about 530,000 in 1992 from 580,000 in 1991. But in the United States the company was able to reverse a downward trend of the last few years, raising sales to 63,312 from 58,868.

HEADLINE: Companies Issued Securities At Record Pace in Quarter

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
With interest rates at their lowest levels in 20 years and stock prices near record highs, corporations issued new securities at a record rate in the first three months of 1993, according to figures released yesterday.
The lower rates also caused homeowners to refinance mortgages, keeping Wall Street firms well supplied with new issues of mortgage-backed securities. 
 The heavy activity kept Wall Street firms busy and profitable, collecting nearly $2.1 billion of fees from new corporate securities issues in the first quarter, compared with an average of about $1.7 billion a quarter last year.
 
 
High Stock Prices
 Corporations have benefited as high stock prices have helped them sell new equity issues to strengthen their financial condition, at the same time that low interest rates have helped them replace high-interest debt issued in the 1980's and early 1990's with lower-interest debt.
While the record pace of securities sales is well above the record rate of 1992, securities dealers say no letup is in sight -- at least as long as interest rates remain at current levels and stock prices stay high.
Richard B. Dubusc, a managing director at the First Boston Corporation, said that talks with large corporations showed that their desire to issue new securities remained high, despite the high amount of financing that had already occurred. With interest rates at current levels, he noted, companies "can profitably refund their old issues, or do strategic financings, at rates which are terrifically low" compared with recent years.
All kinds of domestic financings totaled $262.4 billion in the first quarter, up from last year's quarterly average of $213 billion, according to the Securities Data Company. Most of the increase was in bond offerings, which totaled $122.7 billion, up from last year's quarterly average of $77.4 billion.
New offerings of common stock in the American market totaled $22.2 billion, of which $11.5 billion were initial public offerings, or new issues for companies that did not have stock outstanding. Last year, an average of $18.1 billion of new stock was issued per quarter, of which $9.9 were initial public offerings.
 
 
Leading Underwriters
 Among the leading underwriters in the first quarter was Merrill Lynch, the leader, which has occupied that position for the last three years. It was followed by Lehman Brothers; Goldman, Sachs; First Boston; Salomon Brothers, and Kidder, Peabody, according to the Securities Data compilation.
While new stock and bond financings are generally beneficial to corporations, making it easier for them to finance new investments for growth, the benefits are not as great as lower interest rates, according to a study by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The study, published earlier this month, said that in 1991 and 1992, the drop in interest rates reduced corporate interest payments by $27.3 billion, while new securities issuance saved only $2.8 billion. The Fed noted that many financings actually increased interest rates as companies sold bonds at interest rates of 5 percent to 8 percent to repay short-term borrowings costing as little as 3.25 percent.

HEADLINE: Suffolk Approves Extension Of 1 Increase in Sales Tax

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAUPPAUGE, L.I., March 31

 BODY:
A penny increase in the Suffolk County sales tax, adopted last year and scheduled to expire in December, would continue for two more years under a plan approved early this morning by county legislators.
The 10-to-7 vote was welcomed by County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, who boarded the 8:05 flight from Islip to Albany this morning to begin lobbying the State Legislature to approve the extension so the county can avoid a $120 million property-tax increase. 
 "As soon as some of the economic problems created by the recession are cleared away, we can remove the sales-tax increase," Mr. Gaffney said. "But right now, the economic times make that unrealistic."
The one-cent sales-tax increase, to 8.5 percent, was enacted by Albany temporarily last year to help Suffolk resolve a fiscal crisis.
 
Democrats Outvoted
 Faced with a choice between dropping the penny or raising property taxes at least 30 percent, Suffolk legislators voted early this morning to keep the sales tax at 8.5 percent through Dec. 31, 1995, rather than let it drop back to 7.5 percent.
The vote followed several hours of debate and behind-the-scenes maneuvering among Mr. Gaffney, a Republican, and legislators on both sides of the aisle. In the end, a majority Republican-Conservative coalition outvoted the Democratic minority, despite some last-minute defections.
This was a sharp reversal from last summer when Mr. Gaffney, after only a few months in office, was deserted by several Republicans and was forced to forge a fragile Republican-Democratic coalition to win initial approval of the sales-tax increase. his time around the Democrats refused to join him, complaining that he had not followed through with promised fiscal changes and spending cutbacks.
With the Legislature up for re-election this fall, they expect their vote on the sales tax to be a major issue in November. Michael J. Caracciolo, the only Republican to desert Mr. Gaffney and to vote against the extension, said he was not convinced that it was the only answer.
"We've talked in the past about restructuring county government and streamlining it, but it just hasn't happened," he said.
 
Revenues Called Needed
 Michael D. O'Donohoe, a Conservative who supported the tax extension, said the county could not afford to give up the revenues from the tax.
"We've been streamlining to where this county is at the point of absolutely collapsing," Mr. O'Donohoe said. "You can't streamline $120 million."
Before the vote, several speakers expressed their opinions during a public portion of the meeting. Some held signs that read, "It's the sales tax, stupid," indicating that voters would remember the issue in November.
Among them was Carol Cris, vice president of Tax-Pac, a citizens group against tax increases. "I don't favor the sales-tax extension and I don't believe for one minute you won't raise my property taxes.
Donald R. Blydenburg, presiding officer of the Legislature, and other Republican legislators have said they would roll back the sales tax when neighboring Nassau County rolls back its 8.5 percent sales tax, which has been in effect since 1977.
The debate over the sales-tax extension began in December when Suffolk legislators approved a 5.8 percent property-tax increase for 1993 to balance the county's $1.5 billion budget. Without the extension, the budgets for 1994 and 1995 would each be short $120 million and require additional property-tax increases.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Shake-Up in Underwriting Ranks

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The results of the first-quarter underwriting sweepstakes are in: Merrill Lynch toppled Goldman, Sachs & Company as the leading municipal bond underwriter, as its business jumped 49 percent from a year earlier, according to figures released yesterday. Goldman fell to No. 2, although its volume increased by 11 percent. The First Boston Corporation was third.
The battle for fourth place went down to the wire, as an aggressive bid by Lehman Brothers yesterday on a $780 million issue of California general obligation bonds moved it up from fifth place, edging out Smith Barney. 
 The California issue was a competitive bid deal and the results show that Lehman bid aggressively. Its bid averaged 5.640 percent for the entire issue.
The No. 2 bid, which came from Bank of America, was 5.677 percent, making it more than three basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, higher than Lehman's. But Stan Ciemniecki, managing director of the municipal syndicate desk, said the aggressive bidding had nothing to do with the rankings.
The California deal also pushed Lehman to No. 1 from No. 4 on the list of competitively bid deals, outdueling Prudential Securities. Competitively bid deals are one of the two procedures for selling new municipal bonds. The other, and more often used, is negotiated deals where the pricing is worked out between the underwriters and the issuer and by testing investor response.
Merrill Lynch had a substantial lead on all its competitors, according to the numbers compiled by the Securities Data Company. With the $758 million deal for the City of New York for which Merrill was lead manager on Tuesday, the company was the lead manager on $7.37 billion worth of new issues in the first quarter. That is 11.4 percent of the market, compared with a market share of 10.3 percent, or $6.66 billion, for Goldman and 10.2 percent, or $6.57 billion, for First Boston. Lehman had a 7.9 percent market share, or $5.12 billion, in lead manager credits, and Smith Barney, had a 7.2 percent share, or $4.63 billion.
While Goldman fell to No. 2, the situation could have been worse. Preliminary data through Monday had it third, behind First Boston. But deals in the last two days inched Goldman up, and it edged out First Boston by $93.4 million.
Securities Data also reported the final numbers for the total of new issues in the tax-exempt market in the first quarter. The total of the new issues was a record $64.6 billion, up 29 percent from $50.2 billion in the first quarter of 1992. Of this, a stunning $42.75 billion, or 66 percent, was new issues designed to pay off older, higher interest-rate debt.
 
Treasury Markets

Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed yesterday in light trading as investors and traders continued to mark time until the March employment data are released tomorrow.
The price of the 30-year bond was down 7/32 as the yield rose to 6.93 percent, from 6.91 percent on Tuesday. The prices of Treasury notes were also off a little, but as has been the case all week, traders saw little significance in the price and yield moves.
Inflation seemed to be on investors' minds again. The Commodity Research Bureau index of commodities rose during the day and other data indicated that some prices were rising.
Although inflation has been the concern in the fall of the market in the last several weeks, it is not clear if the employment data will give a clear enough picture of the economy to enable investors to decide how much of an inflation problem there might be.
Late in the day a Treasury spokesman said that a decison on delaying the $14.25 billion one-year bill auction scheduled for today will be made this morning.
Last week, when the auction details were announced, the Treasury said that it would delay the auction if it did not have assurances that an increase in the Federal debt ceiling would be approved before Congress begins a two-week recess today.
The House and Senate were planning to act before the recess, but it was not clear late yesterday if there would be enough assurance of action for the Treasury to go ahead with the auction today.
The Treasury has said it will reach the borrowing limit and will be out of cash to pay bills on April 7.

HEADLINE: ABC Gains in Effort to Expand Upper West Side Studios

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Capital Cities/ABC won unanimous approval yesterday from the New York City Planning Commission for a major expansion of its studio complex on West End Avenue, a project that would be accompanied by two 33-story apartment towers.
The ABC proposal is the third large-scale project to be approved by city planners for the former Penn Yards site along the Hudson River, from 59th to 72d Street. The other two are Riverside South and Manhattan West. 
 Both Community Board 7 and the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, opposed the original ABC proposal, which called for 937 apartments. The network subsequently reduced the number to 507 units and made other concessions.
Ms. Messinger said yesterday that "the changes made in the proposal have clearly reduced many of the residential project's potential negative impacts."
And the chairwoman of the community board, Hope L. Mason, said the concessions had resulted in a project that "made a lot more sense."
The project goes next to the City Council, which has 50 days to review and vote on the matter.
At the northwest corner of West End Avenue and 64th Street, ABC would build two 15,000-square-foot television studios, designated Nos. 25 and 26. One would be used by the soap opera "All My Children." The other, which would accommodate an audience, could be used for a talk show, game show or situation comedy. The cost is estimated to be $100 million.
These new studios would adjoin two existing soap-opera studios, 23 and 24, at 320 West 66th Street, as well as ABC's 125 West End Avenue building, which houses its radio networks and scenery shops.
The network would sell development rights for the apartment complex, which would wrap around Studio 25 in an L shape. Structurally independent, it could be built before, during or after the development of the studios.
In negotiations with city planners, ABC eliminated one of the three apartment towers that it had proposed, reduced the height of the buildings from 39 stories and agreed to set aside at least 12 percent of the apartments for low- and middle-income occupants.
ABC is also to restore the outdoor pool in the municipal recreation center at 533 West 59th Street, as well as renovate the indoor lockers and replace filtration pumps.
No decision has been made yet about how the development will proceed, said Bruce E. Phillips, the vice president for design and development at Capital Cities/ABC. Under the approval granted yesterday, ABC would have up to six years to begin.
"Our studios are driven by our business," Mr. Phillips said yesterday, "and the residential portion is driven by the market. Both are difficult to predict."
Mr. Phillips said that the network was happy to have reached an agreement and that the negotiations had yielded a "good project -- in part because of City Planning, in part because of us."
Richard L. Schaffer, the chairman of the City Planning Commission, said "ABC was responsive to the concerns of the commission" and had "earned our support."
"We made a very substantial cut in the density," he said, "we reaffirmed the importance of affordable housing and we also got their commitment for a significant amount of work on the 59th Street recreational center."

HEADLINE: Connecticut Towns Report Drop in Crime

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 31

 BODY:
Most Connecticut towns have reported decreases in crime for the last quarter of 1992, defying projections that the recession would create a surge in crime, the state police said today.
Hartford recorded a 13.3 percent drop, the state's biggest decrease. The number of homicides in the city dropped by almost half to 13 in 1992. There was a slight increase in burglaries, larcenies and automobile thefts. 
 Crime in New Haven dropped by 8.2 percent, followed by a 4.1 percent drop in Bridgeport, a 3.5 percent dip in Stamford and a 3.3 percent drop in Waterbury.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Nestle to Sell Its Stouffer Hotel Unit

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Nestle S.A., the giant Swiss food manufacturer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Stouffer Hotel Holdings Inc. for an undisclosed amount to a private Hong Kong company.
Stouffer, with headquarters in Solon, Ohio, owns or operates 39 hotels and resorts in North America and one in St. Thomas, in the United States Virgin Islands. Most of the properties are upscale and several, including resorts in California, Hawaii and Mexico, are in the luxury category. 
 Nestle, which had 1992 sales of $36.5 billion, acquired Stouffer Hotels in 1973 as part of the acquisition of the Stouffer Corporation, a maker of frozen foods. It said yesterday that selling the hotels was part of its strategy to focus on its food business.
Toward that end, Nestle had withdrawn from a hotel joint venture with Swissair in 1989, explaining that it did not fit into its future business plans. Earlier this month, Nestle purchased Perrier for $2.8 billion, and last week it increased its stake in Italy's San Pellegrino mineral water company from 20 to 25 percent.
Michael J. Branca, the food and beverage analyst for NatWest Securities, said that by agreeing last week to publish operating profits by major product divisions and by geographical region, Nestle was positioning itself for its shares to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Publication of its results in that format," Mr. Branca said, "clears one of the last hurdles that had been holding back an N.Y.S.E. listing."
Stouffer is considered an industry anomaly. Although it has grown from five hotels in 1981, it has focused on the high-end market, eschewing the industry's trend of adding properties in several price niches.
 
Scattering of Its Properties
 Instead, Stouffer has segmented by location, scattering its properties in downtowns in suburbs like White Plains, at airports in gateway cities like Atlanta and in resorts. It has six Presidente hotels in Mexico, including ones in the resorts of Cancun and Cozumel.
Stouffer also bucked the industry trend by growing largely through outright ownership or joint ventures, rather than by franchising properties and managing them. Two-thirds of the 15,000 rooms marketed under the Stouffer and Presidente names are wholly or partly owned by the company.
But hotels in most price levels have been hard hit by the recession. And although Stouffer has hotels in 19 states, it does not have any in New York City or Boston, cities that are especially important to hotel companies that cater primarily to business travelers.

HEADLINE: Slow Recovery Seen in Two Reports

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The Government today reported gains for February in two key economic barometers, fresh evidence that a slow but sustainable recovery was under way.
The Commerce Department said its chief forecasting index rose five-tenths of 1 percent, the fifth advance in six months, and that orders to factories increased 1.4 percent, to a new record. 
 The leading indicators index is designed to forecast the overall economy six to nine months in advance. Factory orders are a key gauge of future manufacturing activity.
 
 
'All Systems Are Go'
 "In a sense, all systems are go" for continued, but modest growth, said David Jones, economist with Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a New York securities dealer.
But the economy has grown slowly following the end of the recession in March 1991, and most economists predict growth of just 3 percent this year, half that of previous recoveries.
Only 6 of the 11 forward-looking statistics in the predictive index were positive in February. Four pointed down and another was virtually neutral.
Although the index showed an improvement from January, when it was unchanged, the rise was far less than a 1.7 percent surge in December.
Stephen S. Roach, an economist with Morgan Stanley & Company in New York, said the report confirmed that the rapid pace of growth in late 1992 was one that could not be sustained. "The combination of the two reports say the recovery is still intact, but the rate of advance is likely to slow," he said.
 
 
Backlog of Unfilled Orders
 Among the statistics contributing to the rise in the leading index was a growing backlog of unfilled orders, which meant current production facilities and manpower were unable to keep up with demand, suggesting the possibility of hiring.
Other positive contributors were an increase in orders for new plants and equipment, fewer new claims for unemployment insurance, rising prices for raw materials -- which suggested growing demand -- rising stock prices and a longer average workweek.
Offsetting the advance were a smaller money supply, a decline in building permits, falling consumer confidence and a drop in new orders to factories for consumer goods.
Virtually unchanged were product delivery times, a measure of business ability to meet demand.
The various changes left the index at a seasonally adjusted 153.6, up 4.3 percent from a year ago and 2.3 percent from three months ago.
 
 
Record Level of Factory Orders
 In its other report, the Commerce Department said factory orders totaled a seasonally adjusted $258.6 billion, up from $255.0 billion in January and breaking the previous record of $258.3 billion set last December. It was the fourth increase in the last six months. Orders dropped 1.3 percent in January.
Orders for durable goods -- items like aircraft and appliances expected to last more than three years -- rose 2.4 percent, to a record $135.3 billion, even more than the 2.2 percent in the department's initial estimate last week.
Transportation orders shot up 10.8 percent, erasing an 8.3 percent drop a month earlier. The department said commercial aircraft orders represented more than half of the 10.8 percent advance.
But if this volatile category were excluded, orders would have been unchanged from January.
Factory inventories inched up one-tenth of 1 percent, the first increase since last August. Smaller inventories mean factories may have to step up production to meet new orders.
