HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields of Money Funds Up As Investor Demand Sags

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds rose smartly in the latest week, according to the most recent survey by IBC's Money Fund Report.
And as in the previous three reporting periods, tax-exempt yields were up sharply in the seven-day period ended Tuesday. Analysts note that the supply of new municipal issues continues to outpace investor demand, but with a difference. While yields had been pushed up earlier by a heavy supply of new issues, they are now rising as a result of weak investor demand. 
 Assets of the tax-exempt funds grew to $102.2 billion this week. The flow of new cash into the tax-exempt money funds this week totaled $33 million, which did little to recoup the $546 million that flowed out of the funds the week before.
"Usually when yields move up, you'll see some flow of new cash come into the funds, but yields may still be too low to stir investor interest yet," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at the Money Fund Report.
The IBC/Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a tax-exempt fund rose 10 basis points, to 2.02 percent, with the average seven-day simple yield up by 10 basis points, to 2 percent. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.) Over a 30-day period, the compounded yield is averaging 1.87 percent and the simple yield 1.85 percent.
Among the tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, the Money Fund Report said that the Dreyfus Basic Municipal Money Market Fund outperformed other funds in its group with a yield of 2.75 percent, 7 basis points higher than its yield last week.
 
Taxable Assets Drop
 For the week ended yesterday, assets of taxable money market funds fell by $18.9 billion, to $470.1 billion, with institutional fund assets accounting for $15.2 billion of the drop, to $156.4 billion, and retail assets down $3.7 billion, to $313.7 billion.
"The bulk of the outflow from large institutional investors was due in part to the stock market stabilizing and again attracting investment money," Mr. Frank said.
IBC/Donoghue's average seven-day compounded yield on a taxable fund rose 2 basis points, to 2.70 percent, with the seven-day simple yield up a basis point, to 2.66 percent.
Money Fund Report analysts think that yields will now bounce around at this level until the Federal Reserve Board changes its monetary policy, which is not expected anytime soon.
The Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund had the highest return among general-purpose taxable money funds, with a yield of 3.50 percent, up a basis point from last week.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Pacific timber industry isn't really on the endangered list.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
WILL the northern spotted owl drive Pacific timber cutters to ruin and housing prices into the stratosphere?
Give the bird a break. Reports of the industry's imminent demise, Topic A at tomorrow's timber meeting in Portland, have been much exaggerated. But the owl, immortalized by President Bush as the "little furry-feathery guy," has become a symbol of a conflict with no obvious middle ground. 
 The issue, as Jeff Olson of the Wilderness Society puts it, is whether Federal forests "will be managed as tree farms or ecosystems." And since environmentalists hold most of the political cards, lumber prices are unlikely to return to 1980's levels anytime soon.
In February 1991 the 15,800 board feet of lumber used to frame the average house cost $3,200 at the sawmill gate. Today, the same quantity costs $7,000. What happened?
Ross Gorte of the Congressional Research Service notes that lumber prices typically rise by 30 percent during economic upswings. Add bad weather in timber regions along with a possible accumulation of logs in anticipation of rising demand from Japan, and you can explain some of the price increase.
Some, but not much. Al Goetzl, an economist for the American Forest and Paper Association, points out that the recovery in home building has been modest. Sales of lumber are not even close to the 1987 peak, when the price was half what it is today.
The smoking gun, Mr. Goetzl argues, is the decline in harvests from Federal forests. In 1987, 35 percent of America's softwood lumber came courtesy of Uncle Sam. Five years later, the figure was down to 25 percent. Annual Western production from Federal lands plummeted from 11.4 million board feet to just 5.7 million, the loss of enough timber to build 400,000 average-size houses.
Harvests have collapsed because legal complaints about casual environmental management of Federal forests -- especially old-growth forests with the biggest, most valuable trees -- have begun to receive a sympathetic hearing.
The courts have virtually stopped Federal timber sales. And the inventory of trees awaiting the chain saw is rapidly depleting: Federal timber under contract fell from 27 million board feet in 1987 to 11 million in 1992.
The little furry-feathery guy has certainly played a part in forest gridlock. Logging is barred within cursing range of the owls' nests, blocking access to millions of acres.
But Michael J. Bean of the Environmental Defense Fund notes the owl is just the leading edge of a legal assault based on broad forestry management statutes requiring full environmental disclosure and protection of species balance. A return to harvesting as usual in Western old-growth forests, he argues, would damage the habitat of a variety of animals ranging from the salmon to the marbled murrelet, a sea bird.
The industry might yet soften the Endangered Species Act, but it does not have the political muscle to overturn the statutes setting standards for public land. And while President Clinton might be in a mood for compromise, environmentalists are not: "The sustainable harvest from Federal forests, said Brock Evans of the National Audubon Society, "is less than the harvest now."
Canada will not fill the gap: British Columbia is under pressure to reduce harvests from forests that on average, have been more aggressively cut than their American counterparts. Siberia could. However, it would take billions of dollars' worth of roads and sawmill capacity -- and a stable business environment -- to make Russia a major producer.
Fast-growing pine from private lands in the American Southeast may eventually replace declining output from old-growth Pacific forests. And a variety of "engineered wood" products -- composites made from wood scraps and smaller trees -- are just now gaining market acceptance. But nobody expects these substitutes to ever sell for as little as the old-growth timber harvested in the 1980's.
Apocalypse? No. The Northwest, with its growing, diversified economy, is better poised than other regions to absorb displaced timber workers. Many lumber companies will actually end up winners, since their losses from smaller public harvests are more than offset by the higher value of trees on their own land: the giant Weyerhaeuser is posting near-record profits. And although there is no comparable silver lining for the construction industry, the damage begs for perspective.
Lumber represents just 10 to 15 percent of the cost of building a house, and construction represents just half the cost of the total retail package. Thus the near doubling of lumber prices should add only about 5 percent to housing costs. The Congressional Research Service figures this would increase the typical monthly mortgage payment by about $40 -- less than the impact of a one percentage point increase in interest rates.
Of course, $40 a month here, there and everywhere adds up to real money. But there are intangible values that some people think are worth every penny: "We're deciding the fate of our ancient forests," Mr. Evans said.

HEADLINE: She May Be Decorating The White House. Shh!

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.

 BODY:
WEDGED among the coffee-table magazines in Kaki Hockersmith's decorating shop is a Newsweek cover story that asks, "Hillary's Role: How Much Clout?"
Ms. Hockersmith should know. Although it has yet to be announced and has been shrouded in a swag of secrecy here and in Washington, the identity of the Little Rock decorator's latest clients can be gleaned from a big cardboard box in the back of her office labeled "WHITE HOUSE." 
 Ms. Hockersmith isn't talking about the work she is supposedly doing on the private quarters of the White House. Neither is the White House, which will not confirm anything. According to Lisa Caputo, Hillary Rodham Clinton's press secretary, the First Lady is planning to make an announcement about her mystery decorator and the work she may or may not be doing at the White House when the project that-isn't-really happening is completed any day now, not before.
But other people are talking. "It's the job of a lifetime," said Edwin W. Bitter, the chairman of Scalamandre, the New York fabric house, who has worked Ms. Hockersmith in the past. "But I can't say anything. Remember, you're dealing with two lawyers at the White House. One word and poof! She'll be gone like a pumpkin."
In conversations with more than a dozen of her friends and clients last week, a portrait emerged of a 42-year-old decorator with Gidget-like effervescence and a penchant for unusual accessories, like the lamp stand with whole tortoise shells at her shop.
One thing that seems to distinguish Ms. Hockersmith's work is that she does not come with a distinctive "look," a quality that some rivals criticize but her clients see as a plus. "You can't tell a Kaki interior," said Lee Moore, a longtime client. "Many times you can go into a wonderful house and know immediately who the decorator was. Kaki isn't like that. She tries to get a clear fix on the person she's working for. My house feels like mine."
Ms. Hockersmith herself has fended off requests for interviews -- albeit reluctantly, friends say. The extent of her work at the White House, as well as the cost, is not clear, although it is said by one White House official to involve choosing paint colors, fabrics and wallpaper in the family's personal quarters on the second and third floors.
"It has been, in all honesty, intense," said Pat Pennebaker, "Kak's" assistant, while rearranging shelves in Ms. Hockersmith's shop last week, behind a sign that said "Pardon Our Mess." Choosing Ms. Hockersmith -- the latest Little Rock import to hit Washington -- fits in with the way the Clintons operate, she said. "She's someone who knows them who they can totally trust," she said. "They have more important things to do than decorating."
First families have access to a $50,000 appropriation from Congress for refurbishing the living quarters. That amount, which has to cover dozens of rooms, has often been supplemented with private donations, said Rex Scouten, the White House curator.
Trifling as it may appear, the politics of White House decorating is never trivial, as Nancy Reagan discovered upon ordering $209,508 worth of red Lenox china even though the purchase was privately financed.
"The redecoration of the White House has always been a flash point," said Lewis Gould, a historian on the Presidency at the University of Texas at Austin. "Whatever you do in the White House you are likely to offend somebody."
As explained by Ms. Caputo, it was Mrs. Clinton's desire to wait to unveil the designer's name and her plans until the project is finished, something "she is really looking forward to," she said. The announcement has been further delayed because of Mrs. Clinton's vigil at the bedside of her father, who had a stroke on March 19, a White House spokesman said.
But in decorating, as in politics, image and appearances -- as well as timing -- are important, particularly when the President is pushing his economic program and Mrs. Clinton is redefining the role of the First Lady. Remember the chocolate chip cookies and the headband.
Whatever is done at the White House, Professor Gould said, "is apt to raise questions of Arkansas culture versus the East Coast elite and whether the Clintons are bringing sufficient taste to the White House."
White House decor, like everything else, is also a way for first families to convey an image. "It shores up the traditional side of the First Lady," said Professor Gould. "When she is seen as too assertive on health care reform," he said, as in Mrs. Clinton's case, "they can balance it with pretty pictures of decorating."
Should Ms. Hockersmith indeed be the anointed one, she is a fairly logical choice. Her clients include Clinton cronies like Webster Hubbell, Mrs. Clinton's former law partner. She did extensive work on the Clinton's private quarters at the Governor's Mansion (although Betty Tucker, the wife of President Clinton's successor as Governor, Jim Guy Tucker, has already banished some of her paint colors, which, she said, "needed to be quieter" to accommodate their art collection).
Although not considered one of the society decorators, Ms. Hockersmith has a young-ish, voraciously devoted clientele, and her work has long been a mainstay of the Symphony Designer Showhouse, the Kips Bay of Little Rock.
For this year's showhouse, which opens April 16 at the Ragland House, a Queen Anne mansion, Ms. Hockersmith is designing a dining room with burgundy damask draperies, an Aubusson rug, and a papered ceiling with coffered medallion patterns. The sudden national interest in the showhouse has resulted in the un-Little Rock-like spectacle of organizers carrying beepers.
Ms. Hockersmith's nondescript storefront is next to Country Club Drugs in a mini-design district in the fashionable Pulaski Heights section. It is, to use a favorite decorator term, eclectic. The shop is filled with tasseled chintz footstools, silk calla lilies in urns and a mix of old oil paintings and lithographs by contemporary artists like Thomas McKnight, who, a label announces, "graduated cum laude from Wesleyan."
The adjoining "design room," where Ms. Hockersmith confers with clients, has whirring ceiling fans and is painted a deep, rubber plant green.
Ms. Hockersmith is no minimalist, preferring what Mrs. Moore calls a "busy look," often grouping a collection of silver picture frames together (or perhaps the Clintons collection of frog paperweights).
She likes bold floral patterns, vibrant colors and animal prints, according to those who know her work, and has been partial to crimson and deep green. Julie Newsum, a client, told Ms. Hockersmith that "I wanted my house to look like my yard and that's exactly what she did." For Mrs. Newsum's 1930's colonial, Ms. Hockersmith selected raspberry colors for the dining room and yellow draperies, playing off "the crape myrtles blooming and the strong southern light," Mrs. Newsum said.
It seems likely that Ms. Hockersmith will try to incorporate favorite Clinton objects -- like the throw pillow embroidered with 'Raise and Spend' -- into the White House decor and perhaps work with Mrs. Clinton's stated love of "big kitchens you can eat in."
Neither her shop nor the White House would release any biographical information. But according to close friends, who politely refused to show a reporter their Hockersmith interiors until her name is proclaimed by 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, Ms. Hockersmith attended the University of Central Arkansas in Conway and is a former schoolteacher.
She got her start in design arranging furniture vignettes for Dillard's department store, and then opened her own decorating shop, originally in North Little Rock, about eight years ago. She is partial to outfits reminiscent of those in "Annie Hall," friends say, and favors bold accessories. She is an allied member of the American Society of Interior Designers. Her husband is Max Mehlburger, a lawyer and sailing enthusiast.
Described as "a real personable gal" by her friend Joyce Landgren, Ms. Hockersmith is perhaps best known in Little Rock as a creative party-giver, cooking every dish herself and giving each one -- "Hillary's Hibiscus" for instance -- a name.
At a fund-raising event she held for the Clinton campaign early in the primaries, when the name of Gennifer Flowers was in the air and things looked bleak, she decorated her house with red, white and blue flowers and picture frames draped with American flags, according to her friend Martha Markland, who attended. She was wearing a red, white and blue spangled sweater. Outside, patriotic music wafted from speakers hidden in the bushes.
It was the quintessential Little Rock event, with a beleaguered Bill Clinton on a telephone hookup from New Hampshire and the Arkansas Razorbacks on the television.
"You walked in wanting to sing 'The Star-Spangled Banner,' " said Mrs. Markland. "It's very hard to be down around Kaki."
In the gabby field of decorating, in which decorators get to know the intimate details of their clients' lives, Ms. Hockersmith's reputation for discretion may be her most important qualification.
"This is not a big town," explained Mrs. Newsum, echoing the opinion of many. "Kaki doesn't talk."

HEADLINE: Time to Play Fair on School Aid

 BODY:
New York State's Legislature lurches toward its budget deadline with one of the most contentious items, the state's grossly unfair system of school financing, unresolved.
To their credit, Gov. Mario Cuomo, the State Board of Regents and New York City officials are pushing for reform more aggressively than they have in years. It's time for the state's legislators to join the fight for fairness. 
 The state's needier school districts, including those in New York City, have long complained that Albany denies them their fair share of support. School aid is distributed on the basis of complex formulas that reflect each district's average attendance and relative wealth. Those formulas have been changed over the years in order to channel more operating aid to poor school districts and less aid to rich ones.
But in practice, wealthier districts still manipulate the system to secure a disproportionate share for themselves as suburban and upstate legislators wield political clout, particularly in the State Senate. Thus New York City, which educates 37 percent of the state's students, consistently receives about 34 percent of state aid.
The Board of Regents has called for an ambitious overhaul of state school funding that would gradually redress inequities. But the Regents' plan depends on a $500 million increase in school aid. That's probably unrealistic when the state is still so strapped economically.
Governor Cuomo offers a more promising plan that would consolidate complex school aid formulas and reallocate the state funds more fairly, giving New York City about 36 percent of the total. For the next school year, Mr. Cuomo officially proposes a decrease in state aid of $52 million. But the unofficial talk in Albany is of a $200 million to $300 million increase in aid, with about 40 percent of new money going to New York City.
The city, meanwhile, has taken an aggressive step of its own. It has filed a lawsuit charging that the school aid disparities favor districts with largely white enrollments over districts like New York City with largely non-white enrollments, in violation of Federal civil rights law.
But the outcome of the suit remains uncertain. The most likely solution is political. New York and other districts have to provide many more services, like remediation and teaching English as a second language, to give their students even a chance at success.
Having enriched their constituent districts over the years at the poor schools' expense, the legislators from wealthier communities can now well afford to play fair.

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton Heads for the Timber

 BODY:
A man of lofty aims, Bruce Babbitt began his tenure as Secretary of the Interior hoping to reverse a century of federally sponsored exploitation of public lands by striking a sensible balance between commerce and environmental stewardship. He knew he would face obstacles, but probably the last thing he expected was that one of them would turn out to be the man who gave him the job, President Clinton.
Mr. Babbitt wanted to raise the fees for grazing livestock on 280 million acres of public rangeland. He also wanted to charge royalties on gold, silver and other metals now mined from Federal land at no cost. The money would be used for a host of worthy purposes, like lowering the deficit, restoring damaged lands and improving the badly stressed national park system. 
 The proposals were tucked into the budget resolutions passed by the House and Senate. Then, however, a powerful cadre of Western senators had second thoughts about what they had done. They threatened to torpedo Mr. Clinton's entire economic package -- the centerpiece of his Presidency to date -- if the mining and grazing provisions survived. Mr. Clinton agreed to drop them.
His cave-in was reminiscent of his behavior as Governor of Arkansas, when he often favored the economic welfare of the chicken industry over strict regulation of its adverse effects on the environment. It also set many to wondering about his future commitment.
"I don't think I've ever seen a white flag get put up so fast," said an official at the Wilderness Society -- which, like other environmental groups, has invested high hopes in the new Administration.
The President's spokesmen say his retreat is purely tactical. The budget plan is so important, they say, that losing a few little skirmishes here and there is incidental to winning the larger war. For his part, Mr. Babbitt stoically insists that he can still get his grazing fees and mining royalties through administrative action and separate legislation.
Maybe so. But the President's stated determination not to yield to special interests suddenly seems negotiable. His reversal must surely send a frisson of pleasure through other influential opponents of Mr. Clinton's budget proposals, like farmers threatened with the loss of their cherished subsidies.
"This is absolutely spoon-feeding the special interests," complained Representative George Miller, a Democrat from California. "The decision to defer these reforms . . . sends the message that business as usual has lived to fight another day."
The timing of Mr. Clinton's volte-face is equally unsettling. It arrives fresh on the heels of his decision to accept a toxic waste incinerator in Ohio that Vice President Al Gore -- Mr. Clinton's putative conscience on environmental matters -- had pledged to keep closed pending further study.
It also arrives virtually on the eve of tomorrow's "forest summit" in Portland, Ore., a brief media extravaganza that seeks to address a very serious question: how to protect a treasured environmental resource (in this case the old-growth forests, where lives the spotted owl) without putting thousands of people on unemployment lines.
That, too, is a matter dear to Mr. Babbitt's heart. He hopes both to protect the forests and put thousands of loggers back to work restoring the land hit hardest by past logging practices -- by, for example, repairing watersheds and streams that nurture salmon, one of the forests' most valuable and commercially important species.
But it will not be easy to ram even that compromise past hostile lawmakers from the Pacific Northwest, and Mr. Clinton's retreat on grazing and mining has environmentalists wondering whether he has lost his will to fight for the forests as well.
Mr. Babbitt's cause is not wholly lost. Under the law, he can raise grazing fees by administrative order, which he intends to do after careful consultation with ranchers large and small. He also promises to protect smaller ranchers who might be vulnerable to a sharp rise in grazing costs. Imposing royalties on mining companies, however, will require new law and, probably, a bruising legislative struggle. He will need the support of his wavering boss to succeed.
Mr. Babbitt's chances of defeating influential lobbying interests were much better as long as his proposals were linked to the larger budget package. Now, according to Mr. Clinton, they aren't. Running for protective cover, the President has removed Mr. Babbitt's.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A New 'Red Menace' Scam

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
With the cold war won and gone, you thought you had heard the last of pols and policy experts using the Moscow menace to justify excessive military spending. Think again.
Many in Washington are now arguing that if Russian hard-liners topple President Yeltsin, they'll unearth their old military Frankenstein, quickly charge him up and dispatch him once again to terrorize the world. 
 The chances of the "bad" Russians being able to do this by the end of the century are, to be charitable, remote. Russia is in the poverty pits, and its military is in near-total disarray. It will take many years for even the nuttiest Russian nationalists to put the Monster together again.
Yet the argument about the new Russian threat goes largely unexamined in Washington for a very unusual reason: Conservatives and liberals both find it very useful, for very different ends.
Legislators, especially conservatives, love the argument because it gives them a brand new way to defend the defense budget and preserve jobs. Conservatives also like to feel muscular, just in case.
Liberals and moderates, especially in the Clinton Administration, embrace the argument because it's the easiest way to sell increased aid to Russia. They want to save Mr. Yeltsin (don't we all?) and are prepared to do so the old-fashioned way -- by scaring the hell out of the American people.
It's fine for Washington power brokers to warn about coming gas pains over Russia's foreign policy. The pains are already evident in places like the Balkans and Iraq. They will grow more severe as conservatives amass power in Moscow and force Mr. Yeltsin to assert traditional Russian interests. And if hard-liners actually take over, things could get tense in the United Nations and elsewhere.
But such foreign policy disputes are a far cry from military confrontations. In the first place, there's a good deal of evidence that many Russian military leaders desire good relations with the U.S.
And those looking for trouble would have a hard time making it. Air and naval crews can't train for lack of fuel. Draft-dodging has reached pandemic proportions. Much of the equipment from the old Red Army has been dispersed among the 12 new states of the ex-Soviet Union. Troops are far more concerned about a place to live than a war to fight.
As for nuclear weapons, there is a worry that Russian hard-liners might not carry out arms reduction treaties already signed. But let's not be crazy. Even these guys wouldn't dream of starting a nuclear war.
Defense Secretary Les Aspin, no dove himself, seems perfectly aware of the mountains Russian hard-liners would face. "The Warsaw Pact is gone -- there's no way that Humpty Dumpty's gonna be put back together again," he says. "The former Soviet Union is broken into lots of republics -- there's no way that's gonna be pulled back together again."
Yet he and others in the Administration are now starting to hedge on future U.S. defense cuts, even though they know quite well that the U.S. could gear up for battle far faster than Russia. And everyone in the Administration from President Clinton on down continues to drive home the argument that Mr. Yeltsin's political demise would require the U.S. to spend billions more on defense.
This help-Yeltsin-or-else argument is not only a gross exaggeration, but also self-destructive.
If Mr. Yeltsin fails or falls, Mr. Clinton will end up in a political trap he is setting for himself. Having cried wolf, he will have to forsake his precious domestic priorities and throw extra dollars at the Pentagon.
Most likely, he will be forced to keep the dumbest weapons, namely nuclear arms, just to show he's tough. He's already deferred decisions to cancel nuclear attack subs and to cut back on President Bush's missile defense programs.
And by hedging his nuclear bets he's bound to provoke the very nationalistic reaction in Russia he seeks to avoid. Russian hawks will use his hedges to scare up support for their own military demands.
The American people don't need phony arguments about new Russian military threats to justify more aid to Mr. Yeltsin. They are quite smart enough to support democracy in Russia for its own sake -- unless Bill Clinton is foolish enough to convince them otherwise.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Follow Canada's Health Example;
Americans Wake Up To Toxic Pollution

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In my research on toxics for the Environmental Exchange, a national nonprofit group, I have discovered a "wave of environmentalism" different from the one you report in "New View Calls Environmental Policy Misguided" (front page, March 21). 
 The new environmentalism I have found is also made up of homeowners, farmers and local officials; it also sweeps through universities, city halls, state capitols and the highest levels of the Environmental Protection Agency, and parts of the business community as well. But this new environmentalism does not call for more expert verification of the dangers of toxics or more cost-benefit analysis of environmental protection measures. It calls for pollution prevention, to minimize the risk to ourselves and our children by looking for alternatives to toxic chemicals.
Your reporter spoke with "scientists, economists, and government officials," and representatives of companies like Monsanto -- a notorious polluter. I have been speaking with citizens, local and state officials, and representatives of companies that embrace pollution prevention.
These are not tree-hugging environmentalists. They are dentists, housewives, schoolteachers and managers, who believe it doesn't make sense to pollute our environment with substances we don't fully understand -- especially when the evidence indicates they are harmful.
Residents of Louisiana's Cancer Alley and Sumter County, Alabama (home of the largest hazardous waste landfill in the country), don't need scientists to tell them toxic pollution is harmful. They see it every day.
One Georgia resident put it well at a hearing on a proposed incinerator: "I may not be an expert in chemistry or hydrogeology, but there are two things in which I am an expert. From my experience, I know I need clean air to breathe and clean water to drink."
 
KRISTIN S. SCHAFER
Washington, March 29, 1993

HEADLINE: Vance to Resign as U.N. Mediator on the Balkans

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 31

 BODY:
Cyrus R. Vance will step down in the next few days as the special United Nations mediator in the Balkan crisis.
His replacement is expected to be the Norwegian Foreign Minister, Thorvald Stoltenberg, who called on the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, this morning to discuss the appointment. Mr. Stoltenberg is now returning to Oslo to consult his Government about taking the post.
Mr. Vance, a former Secretary of State, turned 76 last Saturday. He told Mr. Boutros-Ghali last December that he could not continue indefinitely as the United Nations mediator on the Balkans, and in recent weeks he has indicated he would probably give up his post at the end of the round of peace talks that began here in February. 
 Mr. Vance and Lord Owen, the European Community's mediator, had put forward a peace plan to end the fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina that called for dividing the republic into 10 ethnic-based semi-autonomous regions under a central government in Sarajevo, the Bosnian capital.
The New York round of peace talks ended last week with President Alija Izetbegovic, the head of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government in Sarajevo, signing an amended version of their peace plan. Croatian leaders in Bosnia had already signed the plan and Mr. Izetbegovic's acceptance left only the Bosnian Serbs, under the leadership of Radovan Karadzic, refusing to agree to it.
The United Nations Security Council is now preparing to tighten the economic embargo it has already imposed on federal Yugoslavia, which now consists only of Serbia and Montenegro. The Council hopes this will persuade the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosovic, to bring pressure on the Bosnian Serbs to agree to the peace plan.
The likelihood that Mr. Stoltenberg will replace Mr. Vance surprised many diplomats who said today that they had not known of the Secretary General's intention to appoint him.
Several diplomats expressed disappointment with the choice, arguing that the joint peace effort of the United Nations and the European Community would have appeared more credible if the Secretary General had chosen another senior American statesman with ties to the Clinton Administration to work alongside Lord Owen, a former British Foreign Secretary.
Mr. Stoltenberg served for 10 months in 1990 as United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees before abruptly resigning to become Foreign Minister in the Norwegian Government of Prime Minister Gro Harlem Bruntland, and knows the Balkans well. He has recently been conducting mediation efforts there on behalf of the Socialist International.
Mr. Vance, who has also represented the United Nations Secretary General on fact-finding missions to South Africa and the Nagorno-Karabakh dispute between Azerbaijan and Armenia, has told the Secretary General he will remain available for other particular assignments but wants to base himself in New York and devote most of his time to his law firm of Simpson, Thacher and Bartlett.
Mr. Vance's public career began in 1958 when he was a consultant for the Special Committee on Space and Astronautics of the Senate. From 1962 to 1964 he was Secretary of the Army, and he served as Deputy Secretary of Defense from 1964 to 1967 in the Johnson Administration.
In the Cyprus crisis of 1967 and in Korea in 1968, he was President Johnson's special envoy. And in 1967 he was also designated the President's special representative dealing with the civil disturbances in Detroit. Mr. Vance was appointed Secretary of State by President Carter. He resigned in April 1980 following his disagreement with the failed military operation to rescue the hostages being held by Iran in the United States Embassy in Teheran.
He serves on a number of panels and commissions, including the New York State Judicial Commission on Minorities and the Commission on Government Integrity of the State of New York. He is a director of The New York Times Company and the General Dynamics Corporation. Mr. Vance graduated from Yale University in 1939 and from Yale Law School in 1942 and was admitted to the New York Bar in 1947.

HEADLINE: HURT IN EXPANSION, AIRLINES CUT BACK AND MAY SELL HUBS

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Hobbled by overcapacity, a slowdown in travel and bruising fare wars, the nation's leading airlines are laying off workers, delaying plane orders and, in the most drastic measures to date, taking steps to dismantle the elaborate hub systems they spent the last decade building.
Industry experts say their actions could alter air service substantially, opening the door for low-cost carriers to thrive and perhaps bringing back the price competition and no-frills service that existed when People Express packed planes with low fares in the early 80's. 
 It is unclear how the industry will ultimately be shaped. Even Robert L. Crandall, the visionary chairman of American Airlines, the largest American carrier, has drawn a blank on what to do about the largely unprofitable hub-and-spoke systems the airlines built after deregulation.
 
Huge Unrecovered Costs
 The hub systems, in which airlines built expensive regional terminals into which they could fly passengers for transfer to short flights to medium-size cities, were meant to protect against feisty low-cost regional carriers. But the big airlines, which eventually fought long fare wars that kept prices low at the same time passenger traffic declined, were never able recover the huge costs involved in building the systems. "I don't know my way out of this," Mr. Crandall said recently.
What may develop is a two-tier system under which the big airlines control heavily traveled international and national arteries while smaller carriers carve out regional niches and feed the broader systems. Southwest Airlines, one of the few no-frills upstarts not to be run out of business by its larger rivals, is emerging as a model regional carrier.
Such a two-tier system, in fact, may be helped by the Clinton Administration's seeming willingness to protect airline newcomers. In the first intervention into the industry since deregulation in 1978, Federico F. Pena, the Secretary of Transportation, last week forced Northwest Airlines to abandon plans to start new routes in competition with an upstart, Reno Air, which had complained that Northwest wanted to destroy it.
 
Encouraging New Carriers
 "This could encourage new entry," said Marvin Cohen, a former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, who nevertheless worries about the potential danger of reregulation.
The costliness of the hub-and-spoke system was largely brought to light by the recession, which reversed the rise in travel the industry had counted on to pay for its expansion. In the downturn, companies began asking the airlines for steep discounts for business travel and increasingly relied on video conferences, faxes and electronic mail instead of meetings to communicate with their far-flung staffs.
To survive, American carriers have begun concentrating on solidifying their positions abroad, where competition is not yet as keen. The nation's two largest airlines, American and United Airlines, are expected to form closer alliances with big European lines and eventually Far Eastern carriers, just as some of their smaller counterparts have already done. Northwest has teamed with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, USAir with British Airways and Continental with Air Canada.
At the same time, airlines have begun cutting costs at home. American and United say they may soon go so far as to sell domestic hubs and turn over short routes that are unprofitable to lower-cost carriers or large commuter airlines. "We simply feel we have no choice," Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman of United, told analysts recently.
American Airlines, for instance, is considering the sale of its new terminal and hub serving Raleigh and Durham, N.C., which it spent $150 million to build just five years ago. Delta said on Monday that it would cut service on some domestic and international routes to help offset its overexpansion on international routes.
The changes could mean lower fares on international and short-haul routes. Because they lack the sprawling overheads and burdensome union contracts of their larger rivals, small carriers can undercut fares and still make a profit.
For instance, Southwest offers one-way fares of $59 between Cleveland and Chicago. Before it started service recently, the one-way fare on the same route among major carriers was $390. Yet Southwest is among the few airlines making money.
 
Fares May Go Up
 Still, fares on coast-to-coast routes dominated by the big airlines may continue to move higher. Some analysts predict that as airlines like United and American scale back plane deliveries, a shortage of seats could develop early in 1994, allowing them to push up fares.
"The low discount fares of today will be a memory," in most coast-to-coast and international flights, Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst at Salomon Brothers, predicted.
The turmoil in the industry is a direct outgrowth of the aggressive expansion strategies airlines devised to cope with deregulation. The big lines thought that by building elaborate hub systems they could make customers captive to their services, thereby suffocating upstarts. The free-market policies of the two previous Republican administrations encouraged these practices.
Under the hub-and-spoke system, the country was split into regions dominated by single carriers. USAir was king at Pittsburgh, Northwest at Minneapolis, American at Dallas and United at Chicago and Denver. Eventually these networks included international routes as the strong airlines bought operations of collapsing or weak international carriers like Pan American World Airways, Trans World Airlines and Eastern.
As a result, the nation's three largest carriers, American, United and Delta Air Lines, have doubled in size since deregulation. Unable to match the expansion and offer the range of alternatives to customers, new carriers died out in the early 1980's, defeating one of deregulation's goals. People Express, for instance, foundered when it sought to develop major hubs.
The airlines had counted on high fares they could command because of their dominance and steady growth in traffic to pay for this elaborate mass transit air system. For a while they did and the airlines flourished.
But rather than improving service by offering customers more options, the decentralization actually created more inconveniences, reducing the number of nonstop flights and increasing the chances for disruption and safety problems.
Hubs operate by having all flights arrive at two-hour periods in the mornings, afternoons and evenings, putting severe pressure on traffic controllers, ground crews and baggage handlers.
 
Shopping for Bargain Fares
 "It's become traumatic to travel," said Laurie Goulet, a sculptor who recently spent eight hours on USAir getting from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to La Guardia Airport by way of Charlottesville, Va. "The industry has lost sight of what they are supposed to be."
The increased options also put customers in a better position to bargain shop, leading to intense fare wars and behind-the-scenes negotiations by corporations for discounts. This has reduced the industry's fare structure to a jumble of rates and restrictions, which further alienated customers.
Passengers have begun voting with their feet, flocking to low-cost carriers like Southwest. "The American public is finding that Southwest is not only the least expensive way to fly but it is chic because it is financially prudent," Mr. Wolf of United said.
If the erosion of the fare structure was draining, two other factors were devastating. The recession choked off travel and forced corporations to permanently alter their spending habits, and the Persian Gulf war added to airline costs by increasing fuel prices.
Deep cuts in white-collar employees reduced the number of business travelers, who account for about 55 percent of the industry's traffic and 65 percent of its revenues. What's more, most companies now contract with travel agencies to find the lowest fares.
 
Biggest Loss Last Year
 Mr. Maldutis, the Salomon analyst, said the industry had seen almost no growth in travel since 1987. It had its biggest loss last year.
While fuel prices have moderated and traffic has recovered, profitablity has not. And the industry says an economic recovery will not be enough to bring back profits.
Mr. Crandall stressed in a recent meeting with reporters that the industry must shrink and shift its strategy to deliver lower-cost service. The question is how.
Corrective steps like scaling back on fleet expansions and abandoning unprofitable routes alone cannot turn the industry around. While this reduces costs, it cuts the base of revenue even more.
Unions are reluctant to grant further concessions without gaining a stake in the airlines and a role in management.
Selling off major hubs, many of which have new terminals and a base of customers, is also risky. New carriers like Kiwi International Air Lines at Newark have sprung up by hiring skilled workers who have been laid off, leasing planes at low rates and finding gates and slots open at airports where the big carriers have pulled back.

HEADLINE: Networks Gain Program Rights; Producers Lose

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
The Federal Communications Commission reversed itself today and said the television networks should be allowed to own the rerun rights to the prime-time shows they carry.
The decision, which infuriated Hollywood producers, was a victory for ABC, NBC and CBS. Putting aside its ruling of two years ago, the commission said the networks should not be restricted from owning a financial stake in programs they broadcast. 
 The commission also set the stage for eliminating rules that limit the networks' ability to actively market the rerun rights to hits like "The Cosby Show" and "Roseanne." These syndication rights are typically the most profitable part of television production, and have generated hundreds of millions of dollars of revenue for especially successful shows like "M*A*S*H."
 
 
Little Effect on Viewers
 The battle -- which has been called a struggle between the rich and the very wealthy -- has virtually no direct impact on television viewers.
But the decision could have big implications for the future of the television industry. The worldwide market for syndicated TV programming is roughly $5 billion -- a pot of money that the networks have long coveted. And beyond that, today's action could eventually clear the way for the networks to merge with or acquire some of the big movie studios.
The television networks buy most of their prime-time shows from outside producers, and much of the financing is provided by the studios. The money paid by the networks for the first showings of the programs is often not enough to cover production costs. Most producers derive their real profits from fees paid by individual stations for the right to show reruns of these programs.
Today's ruling is certain to be appealed by Hollywood interests, so its future remains in some doubt. In addition, the networks must receive approval from a Federal court in Los Angeles overseeing an antitrust decree involving the same restrictions.
The Justice Department has already asked the court to lift the restrictions, and a decision is expected within a few months.
The restrictions have been defended by a coalition of movie studios, producers, writers and independent television stations. Writers and producers say that the networks still monopolize access to prime-time audiences and can force them to make unfair financial concessions.
But the networks, supported by a growing number of economists and Government officials, argued that the rules were outdated and were being used by the studios to insulate themselves from competition.
 
 
Anger in Hollywood
 Hollywood lobbyists reacted angrily to today's action. "It's a travesty -- it's theater of the absurd," charged Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America. "The decision uncages the three networks. Now they'll own prime time as they once did before the U.S. Government charged them with anti-competitive behavior."
Network executives were elated, but added that they had not won everything they wanted. "It's a big step in the right direction," said Robert Wright, the president of NBC. "Nonetheless, I was surprised that some critical restrictions were kept intact and others were actually increased."
The F.C.C. regulations, known as the Financial Interest and Syndication Rules, were adopted in 1970 in the wake of an antitrust case against the three networks. At that time, ABC, CBS and NBC held more than 90 percent of the nightly prime-time audience, and the Justice Department documented a persistent pattern of anticompetitive behavior toward producers and independent stations.
But the three networks have seen their share of the prime-time audience drop to 59 percent in 1992, as competition has grown from cable television, independent television stations, the Fox Broadcasting's fledgling network and videocassette recorders. Meanwhile, some of the nation's biggest movie studios, including MCA and Columbia, have been acquired by foreign companies.
As such, the Justice Department, Commerce Department and Federal Trade Commission all argued in 1991 that the rules ought to be abandoned.
After one of the nastiest bouts of political lobbying and internal bickering in its history, a bitterly divided F.C.C. sided with Hollywood's forces in April 1991, voting to relax the rules but to keep many restrictions.
But that order was struck down late last year by the United States Court of Appeals in Chicago, in a verdict that assailed the F.C.C.'s action as unreasonable and unsupported by evidence. The court ordered the commission either to change the rule or justify it more thoroughly.
The acting chairman, James H. Quello, has long favored removing the restrictions entirely, but the two other commissioners voting today had favored continuing the restrictions. One of them, Andrew C. Barrett, said today that he had changed his mind. The other, Ervin S. Duggan, voted with his colleagues but said he would have preferred to argue the issue out in court again.
 
 
Eliminated 40% Rule
 That set the stage for the commission's unexpected 3-to-0 vote today to strike the most important restrictions. It eliminated a rule that prohibited television networks from producing more than 40 percent of their prime-time programming in-house. It also eliminated a rule that sharply restricted the networks' ability to negotiate a financial stake in shows developed by outside producers.
Under that provision, a network could not even begin discussing an investment until 30 days after it had signed a license agreement with the producer. Network executives argued that this rule effectively made it impossible to conduct any negotiations, because producers need to line up financing before they produce the pilot programs for new series.
But the commissioners did not give the networks everything they had sought. In a compromise that was worked out Wednesday, the agency continued to exclude the networks from participation in what are called "first-run syndications" -- shows like "Donahue" and "Oprah" that are developed only for use outside the networks' prime-time schedule.
The commission also expanded a rule that restricted the networks from selling or distributing shows themselves. Under today's action, the networks can act as syndicators in foreign markets but cannot do the same within the United States.

HEADLINE: F.C.C. ORDERS CUTS IN CABLE TV RATES; EASES RERUN RULE

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
In the Government's toughest single consumer-protection action in decades, the Federal Communications Commission today ordered sweeping cuts of cable television prices that could total well over $1 billion nationwide annually. The lower prices could show up in customer bills by this summer.
The cuts, whose depth stunned some industry analysts, will force about two-thirds of the nation's cable systems to reduce their prices for most services by 10 percent. In addition, the agency ordered cable companies to reverse any price increases they imposed since Congress passed a law last fall to regulate the industry. 
 The recent increases are estimated to average about 5 percent, and the combined rollbacks would add up to price cuts of 15 percent or more. They would affect the vast majority of cable television offerings -- from Cable News Network and the Discovery Channel to Nickelodeon and the Arts & Entertainment networks.
 
Premium Channels Unregulated
 The only services that would be entirely free of regulatory oversight would be "pay cable" channels like HBO that are sold individually rather than as part of packages.
The F.C.C. gave consumer groups, local governments and the cable industry 120 days to respond to its order, and said that prices would be frozen at current levels during this period.
The regulations affect about $16 billion of the cable industry's $20 billion in annual revenues. F.C.C. officials estimated that the 10 percent rollback would add up to about $1.2 billion a year nationwide. Beyond that, the industry will have to cancel rate increases adopted since last fall, which together would have totaled about $400 million.
 
Part of Broader Policy
 The rollbacks are only part of a much broader regulatory regime adopted today that could cut deeply into cable television profits for many years. The commission also left ample room for consumers and local governments to demand additional rate cuts in the future, put new restrictions on the prices for set-top boxes and remote-control devices and force the nation's biggest cable companies to change some basic business practices.
In one particularly big blow to the industry, the commission made it virtually impossible for a cable television operator to evade strict rate regulation by shifting basic programming to premium packages that would be more lightly governed. Defying industry pleas, the commission ruled that prices for a bare-bones package of services, like those including only local broadcast stations, would be regulated essentially the same as "enhanced" packages that include movie channels and CNN.
Today's actions did not go as far as many consumer advocates and local government officials had proposed. Since cable rates were deregulated in 1987, prices have risen twice as fast as the general inflation rate and have doubled or tripled in some cities. A wide range of government studies has indicated that prices of the few cable systems that face head-to-head competition are about a third cheaper than the vast majority of systems that have no competition.
"They have only given a slap on the wrist," Gene Kimmelman, legislative director for the Consumer Federation of America and one of the new law's principal supporters, said of the cable companies. "However, it is a savings and the commission left it open for people to bring more data and perhaps get bigger rate reductions."
Cable industry officials reacted to the F.C.C.'s orders with dismay.
"At minimum, it appears that these rules will make it very difficult for us to satisfy the expectations of our subscribers," said James P. Mooney, president of the National Cable Television Association. "If the commission's action exceeds the authority under the statute, I have no doubt these issues will ultimately end up in the courts."
 
Monthly Bills of $20 to $25
 On average, consumer groups estimate, customers spend $20 to $25 a month for the cable offerings that will be regulated, and most of these will probably receive a rate cut of $2 to $3 each month. In New York state, customers typically pay about $22 a month for basic cable service. New York City officials and state regulators said that they would immediately seek the reductions and that most cable customers in New York would probably be eligible for them.
Of potentially greater long-term impact to the industry, the F.C.C. also imposed unexpectedly tough rules that force large cable operators that also produce popular programming to make those shows available on the same prices and conditions to satellite and microwave systems that compete against local cable operators.
These new competitors to traditional cable television systems have argued that giant cable companies like Telecommunications Inc. of Denver have choked off competition because they own stakes in many of the most popular channels and discriminate against distributors that compete against traditional cable operators.
Today's action by the F.C.C. was in response to a law passed in October after a bruising, three-year battle in Congress and over a veto by President Bush. But the law itself was open to a wide range of interpretations, and the regulations adopted today provide the crucial fine print that determines what the actual impact on customers will actually be.
 
 
Details Not Disclosed
 The rate cuts are not automatic, however, and the F.C.C. refused to disclose several key details. Each local government must first ask the F.C.C. to certify it as a legitimate regulatory authority over its cable systems, and the local government will then be able to regulate the price of basic cable service using a benchmark for "reasonable" prices set by the commission. Under previous law, cities were not allowed to regulate prices.
For the broader packages of service, consumers or local government officials must complain to the commission and ask for a rollback and refund. In both cases, however, the commission will use the same benchmarks to determine "reasonable" prices.
The commission refused to say today just what those benchmarks were, though they will be published within a few weeks. But they said that based on price data accumulated during the last six months, from two-thirds to three-quarters of all systems would have to roll back rates at least 10 percent.
Under the law passed last fall, Congress said broadly that "reasonable" charges would be similar to those charged by the few cable systems that face head-to-head competition. More than 99 percent of cable operators enjoy exclusive franchises and are largely free from competition.
 
Systems 27% Cheaper
 Indeed, F.C.C. officials noted today that their data showed that systems facing head-to-head competition were on average 27 percent cheaper than those that have exclusive franchises.
But F.C.C. officials said they were constrained, because the law defines "effective competition" to include cable systems that have signed up fewer than 30 percent of the households in their region. Those systems typically do not face any competition and may simply be expensive. By including the prices of these systems in determining a benchmark for "competitive prices," the disparity between "competitive" and "uncompetitive" drops to only 10 percent.
But even some of those who had pushed for tougher measures praised the commission. "The F.C.C. did its part today on behalf of the nation's cable consumers," said William F. Squadron, Commissioner of Telecommunications and Energy in New York City. "They struck a good balance."

HEADLINE: BUDGET IN ALBANY IS POLITICAL PACT, NOT DETAILED PLAN

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 1

 BODY:
New York State's multi-billion dollar budget agreement, hammered out early this morning, would increase aid to New York City schools, scale back proposed cuts in medical care for the poor, raise cigarette taxes and keep the city's bus, subway and commuter railroad fares intact until 1995.
The deal, announced just after the midnight deadline and described by everyone involved as a "handshake" agreement, leaves many details unresolved, including the total spending for the next fiscal year, which began today. But for political reasons, it was critically important, particularly for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, to declare that at least the broad outline was in place by April 1. [News analysis, page B4.] 
 For the most part, the spending plan seems to follow the fiscal principles established by Mr. Cuomo in January.
 
School Aid Still Faulted
 Lawmakers said the roughly $32 billion budget agreement would increase school aid about $346 million over last year's levels, with about 42 percent of that going to New York City in the next school year. The increase would be paired with a refiguring of the complicated school-aid formula, and would funnel more money to schools with a higher concentration of poor students, including those in New York City.
But Steve Allinger, a lobbyist for the New York City Board of Education, said that the revised formula would not answer the complaint raised by the city in a recent lawsuit: Although it has 37 percent of the students, it receives just 34.9 percent of state aid to schools. The proposal would raise that figure just a few tenths of a percentage point. "The new formula is not earth-shattering," he said.
The budget would also eliminate a plan by Governor Cuomo to save $111 million by limiting personal care at home for Medicaid recipients to 120 hours a month. Instead, budget negotiators said they had settled on a plan to wrest close to $50 million in savings by requiring some patients to share personal-care services and by firming up guidelines to evaluate how much personal care patients really need.
 
M.T.A. Fare to Stay $1.25
 The spending plan would supply virtually all the five-year, $9.6 billion re-building plan that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has contended is critical to the health of the subway and bus system. And it would do so without increasing the $1.25 subway and bus fare.
The transportation money is to be spent on rebuilding subway stations and tracks, expanding an automated fare card system and buying a new fleet of city buses. But the agreement leaves unresolved $126 million in financing, intended to come from New York City, that the city says it cannot afford.
While Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders emerged from a meeting at 12:01 A.M. today to cheerfully announce that they had the broad outlines of a deal, negotiators admitted they had much to do and, indeed, had for the ninth year in a row failed to complete a budget by the start of the fiscal year. "There are still a lot of stray cats and dogs," said one top legislative aide.
 
Relies on Improving Business
 Even after all the details are known, it will be difficult to determine whether the budget is balanced. At first glance, it seems to spend more than the state is expected to receive. But if, as many officials anticipate, New York's economy improves faster than in recent projections, tax collections will increase and the extra revenue will help to avert a deficit.
The budget represents a rise of at least $810 million over Governor Cuomo's original $31.5 million spending plan, attributed in part to taxes the state received earlier than expected and to a one-time $200 million Medicaid payment from the Federal Government. The additions gave lawmakers an irresistable opportunity to restore aid to programs that had been severely cut in the Governor's plan.
And lawmakers, who have been roundly criticized in the past for the state's reliance on questionable borrowing practices to raise money, were also able to win agreement on a new plan to change the way the state does its borrowing.
Under the agreement, the state's voters would consider a constitutional amendment that would provide for a variety of measures: letting the state put more than one bond act on the ballot at a time, requiring a new method of reviewing capital projects and capping the amount of new revenue-backed debt to 5 percent of the state's total personal income.
The budget agreement would devote $100 million to a reserve fund that could be used toward the $311 million that New York might owe Delaware and several states after a Supreme Court ruling earlier this week. Lawmakers said that it was unclear when the bill would be due or what the total would be, but that more than $100 million more could be raised by refinancing the state's debt to obtain more favorable rates.
Some of the earlier tax and fee proposals fell by the wayside during the negotiations. Governor Cuomo had suggested rescinding the state's $70-million-a-year tax on hotel rooms that cost more than $100 a night; the tax stayed. He had also proposed starting a new state lottery game that would have generated $25 million this year, but that proposal was rejected.
Another Cuomo proposal, to raise $64 million by increasing taxes on hospitals and nursing homes and to raise $42 million more by imposing a new tax on pharmacies, was also rejected. But the state will continue to impose the existing taxes on the hospitals and nursing homes, which raise about $259 million a year.
The budget would also raise cigarette taxes by 17 cents a pack, to 56 cents, down from Governor Cuomo's original proposal of a 21-cent increase.
State legislators spent most of today digesting details of the budget, which they expect to vote on over the weekend unless something happens to derail the agreement. Many said that while they could live with the broad outlines of the plan, they were disappointed about individual pieces.
For instance, state leaders agreed to restore $10 million that was to be cut from drug prevention programs in New York City schools. But other drug treatment programs still face cuts of $20 million. And while some money has been restored to the state's probation department, the current cuts look to total about $14 million, mostly in New York City, leaving officials worried about a potential breakdown in the program.

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
PRESIDENT URGES AMERICA TO BACK HELP FOR MOSCOW

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 1

 BODY:
Declaring that the United States "cannot stop investing in the peace now that we have obtained it," President Clinton today began the arduous task of convincing Americans preoccupied with domestic woes that it is also necessary to help restore the economy of Russia.
Mr. Clinton, in a speech to the American Society of Newspaper Editors, laid the groundwork for the summit meeting he will hold with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia this weekend by signaling that he does not intend to neglect concerns at home. 
 The latest New York Times/CBS News poll shows that American support for aid to Russia is lukewarm at best, but Mr. Clinton asserted that helping Russia to regain its footing on the path to democratic reforms would ultimately benefit Americans.
 
'America's Broader Purposes'
 "In a time of dramatic global change, we must define America's broader purposes anew," he said. "And part of that purpose clearly consists of reviving economic growth here at home, for the opportunity to do well here at home is the ultimate basis of our influence abroad." [Excerpts, page A6.]
The President said democratic change in Russia would help the United States by reducing the chance of nuclear engagement, allowing Congress to reduce military spending and giving Western nations access to resources there through enhanced trading opportunities.
Such aid would not be charity, he said, but "an investment in our own future."
"Our ability to put people first at home requires that we put Russia and its neighbors first on our agenda abroad," he said.
But according to the poll results, Mr. Clinton may have a tough sell. In a telephone survey of 1,368 adults conducted Sunday through Wednesday, 52 percent of those polled said they were willing to support aid to Russia if it meant averting civil war there, but that support fell to 41 percent when the economic aid was intended to "help Russia reform its economy."
And only 29 percent favor offering such support if its aim is to keep Mr. Yeltsin, who is viewed uncertainly by many Americans, in power. Thirty percent of those polled said it was "very important" that Mr. Yeltsin remain in power. In 1990 and 1991, similar polls found that between 55 and 60 percent of respondents thought it "very important" for former President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to remain in charge.
The poll has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Its results also demonstrate that Mr. Clinton has an opening to sell his plan to Americans. Among the distinct minority who said they have been following developments in Russia "very closely," one-seventh of the sample, many more favored giving aid to Russia than did the public at large.
Among these people, 66 percent favored aid to help Russia reform its economy, as against 41 percent of the sample generally. And they were 25 percentage points more in favor of aid to help Yeltsin remain in power than was the general public.
 
Case for Helping Yeltsin
 Such findings suggest that the more people learn about the situation in Russia the more likely they are to support greater American involvement. Mr. Clinton's goal, in today's speech and in the coming weeks, will be to make a compelling case that American self-interest is bound up in Russia's.
"During the cold war, our foreign policies largely focused on the relations among nations," Mr. Clinton said to the newspaper editors today. "Our strategies sought a balance to keep the peace."
"Today our policies must also focus on relations within nations, on a nation's form of governance, on its economic structure, on its ethnic tolerance," he continued. "These are of concern to us for they shape how these nations treat their neighbors as well as their own people, and whether they are reliable when they give their word."
In his address today, Mr. Clinton offered new and unequivocal support for Mr. Yeltsin, who has struggled in recent weeks to retain his grip on power in spite of the efforts of rebellious members of the Russian Parliament to oust him.
In his prepared remarks, Mr. Clinton said that America's "interests lie with Russian reform and Russian reformers." When he spoke he added, "Led by Boris Yeltsin."
 
Stormy Early History
 "We must be concerned over every retreat from democracy, but not every growing pain within democracy," Mr. Clinton said. "Let me remind you of our own early history. It was marked by a revision of our governing charter and fist fights in Congress."
"As long as there are reformers in the Russian Federation and the other states leading the journey toward democracy's horizon, our strategy must be to support them," he said. "And our place must be at their side. Moreover we and the Russian people must not give up on reform simply because of the slow pace of economic renewal."
Mr. Clinton and his aides have said that they plan to propose a package of aid that will focus less on the infusion of cash into the Russian economy and more on the exchange of goods, expertise and training. "Russia's economic vessel is too large and leaky for us to bail her out," he asserted.
Instead, the Clinton Administration has indicated that it will push other nations to join in a $30 billion package of aid that would be complemented by American efforts to help Russian farmers and entrepreneurs. White House officials have also said they would appeal to the World Bank and International Monetary Fund to help stabilize Russian currency and curb inflation.
 
A Taste of Freedom
 "The burning question today is whether Russia's economic progress, whether Russia's democratic progress, will continue or be thwarted," Mr. Clinton said. "I believe that freedom, like anything sweet, is hard to take from people once they've had a taste of it. The human spirit is hard to bottle up again. And it will be hard to bottle up again in Russia."
Mr. Clinton acknowledged the difficulty he will have convincing Americans that aid to a volatile foreign nation would be money well spent at a time when the American economy is lagging in job creation.
"For most Americans these events, while dramatic, are still very remote from their immediate concerns," the President said.
But he added, "I would argue that we must -- that we must do what we can, and we must act now -- not out of charity, but because it is a wise investment, a wise investment building on what has already been done, and looking to our own future."

HEADLINE: Japan, Still in Slump, Plans 2d Public Works Program

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, April 2

 BODY:
Facing a stagnant economy and heavy pressure from the Clinton Administration to reduce Japan's yawning trade surplus, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa has pledged to push for a huge new public works program to get the economy rolling again and to rescue a battered financial system.
Mr. Miyazawa said at a news conference Thursday that the new plan, which will include heavy spending on telecommunications "superhighways" and computers for schools, will be larger than last year's supplementary budget of 10.7 trillion yen, currently the equivalent of $93 billion. There has been speculation it will run as high as $130 billion. 
 The announcement helped send stock prices soaring. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 507.64 points, or 2.73 percent, at 19,099.09, on Thursday, the highest level in nearly a year. And stocks continued to advance today, rising 347.85 points, or 1.82 percent, to 19,446.94.
"At this point, you can't find anyone who is willing to bet against the Government," said Jesper Koll, an economist here with S. G. Warburg Securities
The timing of the announcement was excellent, since Mr. Miyazawa is planning to visit Washington in two weeks for a meeting with President Clinton at which he reportedly hopes to deliver evidence of a stronger economy. The United States has pressed Japan to revive domestic demand so the country will export less and import more, reducing its huge trade surpluses.
But some analysts warned that the prospects for an economic revival and a recovery in the deeply depressed stock market were still fragile.
"We still have some worries about the economy's recovery," said Yuichi Matsushita, a stock market strategist here with the Nikko Securities Company. "It is not certain yet. But psychologically there is some improvement."
Economists say that Japan's economy grew by 1 percent or less in the fiscal year that ended March 31 and that many indicators, like consumer spending and corporate investment, remain anemic. The Government is forecasting growth of 3.3 percent in the fiscal year that just began, but private forecasts range from less than 1 percent to 2.5 percent.
The outcome of the stimulus plan could have a major political impact on Japan because of the pressure being applied by the Clinton Administration. The President and various American officials have issued threats and exhortations to get Japan to reduce its record trade surpluses through any means, including retaliatory trade actions.
The two countries have permitted the dollar to decline in value against the yen, which makes Japan's exports more expensive and makes it less expensive for the Japanese to import American products. The dollar fell to 114.50 yen in Tokyo Thursday, a postwar low.
In addition, the Clinton Administration has encouraged the Japanese Government to take strong measures to end the recession here, which has been caused at least in part by a plunge in stock and real estate prices over the last three years.
 
Some Warnings
 Many economists warned that the new spending program was not as drastic as it seemed to be.
"It's always the same with these packages," said Susumu Kato, the chief economist here with CS First Boston (Japan). "The Government just includes everything, which makes the numbers look large."
Mr. Koll of S. G. Warburg said: "Once again, the Government is doing an excellent job of promoting their new package even before there's a formal package. They are giving the impression of a whole New Deal in Japan."
