HEADLINE: Thunder of Debate on Owls and Jobs Rings in Forests as Opponents Face Off

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., April 1

 BODY:
A propaganda frenzy, a lobbying blitz in the forest mist, has prevailed for days in anticipation of President Clinton's timber conference here on Friday.
On the ground and in the air, people in catalogue-fresh khaki pants and stiff boots have been hustled around the forests of the Northwest. They hop from chainsaw-ravaged ridge to shaggy-topped forest, escorted by timber representatives or environmentalists trying to show off the trees and stumps that make their political points. 
 For any of the President's four touring Cabinet members or other Federal officials who may still think "clearcut" describes a bad day at the barber, a fleet of helicopters, light planes and four-wheel-drive vehicles stand ready. Radio advertisements sponsored by the opposing sides fill the airwaves, aimed at influencing the visitors from the East.
Given all that is at stake, the bustle is understandable. The Federal courts have kept logging operations on millions of acres of national forests shut down for almost two years. The courts have acted under laws intended to protect the northern spotted owl and other threatened wildlife, but in doing so they have posed their own threat, to tens of thousands of timber workers who stand to lose their jobs if the restrictions continue.
Now, in his effort to break the impasse, Mr. Clinton is coming here for a round-table talk with the competing sides that is aimed at bringing peace to the woods and fulfilling his campaign assertion that it is possible to protect a rare natural resource like the forests of the Pacific Northwest without putting a lot of people out of work.
 
Lobbying With Help of Forest
 Little wonder that the Federal officials who have been touring the region in preparation for the President's arrival have had little trouble getting someone to keep them company. Or that at night, courtesy of the nation's major environmental groups, they can dine on cuisine featuring the bounty of the Northwest: venison, salmon, fiddlehead ferns, mushrooms, hazelnut biscotti, Oregon ale and pinor noir.
"Actually, the hazelnuts were grown near the forest, not in it," said Jim Middaugh, a spokesman for the Ancient Forest Alliance. "And the wine demonstrates what you can do by transforming low-value, cut-over private forest land to vineyards."
The rank and file of the timber industry is not being left out of the lobbying. On Friday, all the timber mills in Oregon are giving their workers the day off and busing them to Portland, where they will presumably mingle with an international gathering of environmentalists who are being entertained tonight by Neil Young, Bonnie Raitt and other singers.
At all hours, it seems, radio stations here are broadcasting advertisements. For some, pronunciation has been a problem. "In ORE-uh-gone . . ." went the voice-of-God announcer in one advertisement for a timber group. As any Northwesterner will tell you, it is pronounced "ORE-uh-gun." The advertisement was sponsored by the Oregon Lands Coalition, part of the New York-based Alliance for America.
The forests, usually lonely and rather wet, have been crowded with opinions this week.
 
Environment vs. Jobs
 Standing on a logging road in Oregon's Willamette National Forest, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt gazed over a patchwork of cut and replanted timberland.
"You see that ridge," said Lynn Burditt, a district ranger with the Forest Service, which manages the national forests. She pointed to a pair of weathered, dying trees left standing in an area that had been cleared of clear cut. "That is a radical concept, Mr. Secretary, the idea that you leave something behind for wildlife after a timber harvest."
Nearby, Representative Peter A. DeFazio, the Oregon Democrat whose district includes the Willamette forest, tried to keep from laughing. The two snags poking out of the cleared area were nothing to behold, he said in an aside.
Mr. DeFazio pointed to the erosion from the logging road, the blackened ground from a Forest Service "slash burn," and the snags. Then he rolled his eyes. "This is not a good example of the future of forestry," he said.
North, across the Columbia River, Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy took off in a plane that also carried Jim Pissot of the National Audubon Society and Representative Norm Dicks, Democrat of Washington. The plane banked over the log-loading docks of Longview, Wash., where a veritable forest of logs cut from private land are shipped overseas every day. Environmentalists say exports are the reason small mills are having trouble getting timber, while the industry blames efforts to save the spotted owl.
"Norm was trying to stand between the windows as we flew over the export docks," Mr. Pissot said, telling a version of the story that Mr. Dicks's staff members dispute. "I stepped to the front of the plane and pointed out that there were five ships loaded with logs -- all of them bypassing American mills."
When the group landed and visited a grove of 500-year-old cedar trees in the Gifford Pinchot National Forest, Mr. Espy, who as Agriculture Secretary oversees the Forest Service, seemed sympathetic to environmental concerns. He said he was from the Mississippi Delta area and had never seen trees the size of the Northwest giants.
"This is God's hand," Mr. Espy said. "I don't think it should be touched except by God."
 
A Different Perspective
 But after a visit to a timber town and a helicopter tour of Weyerhaeuser Company lands, where corn rows of Douglas firs grow fast and straight, very much at the hand of man, Mr. Espy seemed to be leaning with the other side.
"I'm sitting with people who have lost their jobs," he said, sipping coffee at Duffy's Restaurant in the timber town of Aberdeen, Wash. "This is real life."
Mr. Pissot, of the Audubon Society, acknowledged that there was ample hyperbole from both sides in their efforts to influence the touring officials. "We want them to see the worst of the clearcuts; the other side wants them to go to a food bank in a mill town," he said. "That's the value of the summit."
Sometimes the tours can backfire. Recently Weyerhaeuser, the world's largest timber company, flew a helicopter loaded with journalists over its land, trying to show how the company can accommodate wildlife within its tree farms. But then the helicopter pilot buzzed right over an eagle's nest full of eaglets. The mother bird squawked; the Weyerhaeuser tour director frowned.
Lighthawk, a group that calls itself the environmental air force, has perhaps the greatest presence in the air. It has been using five planes and a helicopter to fly the powerful and influential over lands that had been stripped of trees.
"Most people have an incredible conversion experience, as we call it, after flying with us," said Les Welsh, the Northwest director of Lighthawk. "No matter what amount of information you get from the timber industry or the environmental community, nothing gives you a more precise view than seeing it with your own eyes."
Although Lighthawk was able to persuade Representative Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, to fly over the Colville National Forest in his eastern Washington district, it has been unsuccessful in its attempt to fly Katie McGinty, the White House director of environmental policy. A native of Philadelphia, Ms. McGinty is still trying to learn all the trees in the forest.
The view from the air is misleading, say logging advocates. "We are replanting six trees for every one harvested," said Evelyn Badger of the Oregon Lands Coalition. "There are more trees in the Pacific Northwest now than there were 40 years ago."
Environmentalists, of course, disagree on the last point. But then, such is the nature of the timber word war. Whole forests have been felled to print the competing assertions.
 
Hearing All Sides
 At times, the timber industry has contended that saving the forest in which the northern spotted owl lives would put 100,000 people out of work, a figure that is three times as large as the highest Government estimate.
On the other hand, environmental groups have left the impression that very little old forest is left, less than two million acres. The Forest Service counts six million acres, fragmented though it is.
Mr. Clinton says one reason for holding the forest conference is to bring all the competing voices into one room, so that truth, common ground or something in between can emerge from a day of round-table talk.
That, at least, is the hope of the President and his entourage, which includes Mr. Babbitt, Mr. Espy, Vice President Al Gore, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich. To keep exaggeration and spin doctors at bay, only "local" people from each side of the issue were invited to the table.
But already White House aides are despairing at reports that many of these unschooled local types spent Wednesday in an intensive course on how to speak in sound bites.
 
Poll Reflects Clinton Balancing Act
 In the public eye, President Clinton has managed to balance his concern for jobs and the environment. Americans think he cares about both, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Asked whether Mr. Clinton preferred protecting jobs or protecting the environment, 47 percent said jobs, 33 percent said the environment and 5 percent said both. The nationwide poll, in which 1,368 adults were interviewed by telephone, was conducted from Sunday through Wednesday. It has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Respondents were also asked whether they agreed with the statement "We must protect the environment, even if it means jobs in your community are lost because of it." Sixty percent agreed, and 31 percent disagreed. When the same question was asked during the Presidential election, a time of public worry about the recession, 45 percent agreed and 45 percent disagreed. The question was also asked in April 1990 before the recession began, when 56 percent agreed that the environment must be protected, even at the cost of local jobs, and 36 percent disagreed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Presidential conference on timber today in the Northwest has generated much attention from news organizations. Steve Slocum, left, an Associated Press photographer, and Scott Sonner, a reporter, boarded a plane yesterday in Portland, Ore., for a flight over the Mount Hood National Forest. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A Balancing Act for Haiti;
Developing the Plan for Aristide's Return Is Proving a Delicate and Complex Puzzle

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 1

 BODY:
For months, diplomats who have negotiated here say, close supporters of Haiti's ousted President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, have focused on little beyond the legitimacy that comes from his having won 67 percent of the vote. Whenever ready, mediators have often heard, Washington could restore their President with a simple phone call.
Father Aristide's foes in the military and economic elite convinced themselves long ago, however, that Haiti's first democratically elected President is a populist demon bent on avenging his violent overthrow by soldiers 18 months ago. They had hoped that the outside world would come to accept their view and let them get on with their lives, unworried by the prospect of his return. 
 Now United Nations negotiations aimed at restoring Father Aristide are entering a decisive phase. Diplomats involved in the effort are working hard to convince all sides in this deeply fragmented society that rather than to persist in holding such starkly two-dimensional views of the situation, all must be prepared for dramatic give and take to find a solution that will save this country from an impending catastrophe.
 
Three-Dimensional Chess
 In a country where politics have traditionally been a brutal winner-take-all affair, diplomats have likened the complexity of fashioning the necessary compromises to three-dimensional chess. "It is like building a prefabricated house in which all the pieces must snap together simultaneously or the whole thing falls apart," one diplomat said.
In recent days, diplomats involved in the negotiating effort say, they have felt strongly that -- with the acceptance by most here of the principles that Father Aristide will return to power soon and that his bitterest foes in the army and Government will be removed from office -- resolution of the country's crisis is near.
Raising the many necessary buttresses, nearly all at once, diplomats close to the negotiations say, is the complicated trick required to complete the effort.
Guarantees for the safety of Father Aristide's foes must be put in place rapidly. Many say this will require not only some form of amnesty or pardon for army leaders to induce them to surrender their power, but also a quickly beefed-up international presence in the country to preserve the peace once they do so.
 
More Observers
 Already the United Nations has about 150 human rights observers in Haiti. Though negotiators are not yet saying so, it is widely believed here that their number could be rapidly increased or even supplemented by a highly visible peacekeeping contingent.
Almost simultaneously, diplomats say, a new Government must be formed that not only gives the ousted President a real sense of influence over the country's direction, but reassures others -- from outright opponents to political leaders who have supported his return -- that a true consensus is being forged for the first time in Haiti.
Furthermore, new leadership for the army and for a new civilian police force that is projected must be selected, most likely from a military corps that in the past has shown neither professionalism nor discipline.
 
A Time Line for Return
 Should all of these elements come together, supported by large-scale economic aid, Father Aristide's return to Haiti would occur within six months.
The daunting nature of carrying off so many objectives before the paralysis of political infighting -- almost a certainty here -- sets in, or mischief aimed at derailing the whole process takes over, is apparent to both diplomats and to Haitian political experts.
"There is tremendous pressure from the international community right now," said one mainstream businessman who supports Father Aristide's negotiated return. "For the last year and a half all we had was mixed signals. Now there is a clear path, and that is quite a change, but knowing my own country, I just don't know how it is all going to work out."
 
Little Sign of Consensus
 The difficulties are illustrated by the discord already apparent over the relatively limited task of choosing a new Prime Minister to head the next government. Although the process calls for Father Aristide to select a "consensus" figure, there is little sign of consensus building here, even among the ousted President's supporters.
Diplomats and Haitian political analysts have said that one of the factors that contributed to Father Aristide's ouster after nearly eight months in office was that the President, a political neophyte, failed to bring many of his pre-election allies into positions of responsibility. Even fewer attempts were made to build new alliances.
"They are going to have do a lot better than that this time," one diplomat said. "If they can't, this whole thing is going to take off like a lead balloon."

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
In Clinton's Words: We Need Yeltsin

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 1

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's speech today to the American Society of Newspaper Editors, which met at the United States Naval Academy:
Russia's economic recovery may be slow, but it is in the interests of all who seek more robust global growth to insure that, aided by American business and trade, Russia rises to her great economic potential. 
 The burning question today is whether Russia's economic progress, whether Russia's democratic progress, will continue or be thwarted. I believe that freedom, like anything sweet, is hard to take from people once they've had a taste of it. The human spirit is hard to bottle up again. And it will be hard to bottle up again in Russia.
Yet if we cannot be certain of how Russia's affairs will proceed, we are nonetheless certain of our own interests: The interests of all Americans like with efforts that enhance our security and our prosperity. That's why our interests lie with Russian reform and with Russian reformers led by Boris Yeltsin.
 
Support Must Be Broad
 I won't describe today all the specific ideas that I plan to discuss with him, and of course I don't know all those that he will discuss with me. But I want to tell you the principles on which our efforts to assist reform will rest.
First, our investments in Russian reform must be tangible to the Russian people. Support for reform must come from the ground up, and that will only occur if our efforts are broadly dispersed and not focused just on Moscow.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Our goal must be to insure that the Russian people soon come to feel that they are the beneficiaries of reform, and not its victims. We must help them to recognize that their sufferings today are not the birth pangs of democracy and capitalism but the death throes of dictatorship and communism.
Second, our investments in Russian reform must be designed to have lasting impact. Russia's economic vessel is too large and leaky for us to bail it out; that's not what's at issue here. Our challenge is to provide some tools to help the Russians do things that work for themselves.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Third, our people must do what we can to have people-to-people initiatives, not just government-to-government ones.
 
Approach Must Be Personal
 We've entered a new era in which the best way to achieve many of our goals abroad is not through diplomats or dollars, but through private citizens who can impart the skills and habits that are the life blood of democracy and free markets.
We intend to expand efforts for retired American business executives to work with Russian entrepreneurs to start new businesses.
We intend to work so that our farmers can teach modern farming practices, so that our labor leaders can share the basics of trade unionism, so that Americans experienced in grass roots activities can impart the techniques that ensure responsive government, so that our armed forces can engage in more exchanges with the Russian military. And so that thousands and thousands of young Russians who are reform's primary beneficiaries and reform's primary constituency, so that they can come to our country and study our government, our economy, and our society -- not because it's perfect, but because it's a great example of a democracy at work.
And fourth, our investments in reform must be part of a partnership among all the newly independent states and the international community. They must be extended in concert with measures from our allies, many of whom have at least as much stake in the survival of Russian democracy as we do.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Fifth, we must emphasize investments in Russia that enhance our own security. I want to talk with President Yeltsin about steps we can take together to insure that denuclearization continues in Russia and her neighboring states.

 	 	 		. . .	 	And I'll suggest steps both of us can take to stem the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, something that will be a major, major cause of concern for years to come.
 
Vision Must Be Long-Term
 Sixth, we must recognize that our policies toward Russia and the other states comprise a long-term strategy that may take years to work completely. That was the key to our success in the cold war. We were in it for the long run -- not to win every day, not to know what every development in every country would be. We had clear principles, clear interests, clear values, a clear strategy, and we were in it for the long run.

 	 	 		. . .	 	As long as there are reformers in the Russian federation and the other states leading the journey toward democracy's horizon, our strategy must be to support them. And our place must be at their side.

HEADLINE: Coca Output Stayed Level in '92 For the 3d Year, State Dept. Says

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
Last year, for the third year in a row, there was no significant increase in the cultivation of coca, the plant from which cocaine is derived, the State Department said today.
But it said the fight against narcotics trafficking was hampered by political instability, particularly in the Middle East, Asia, Peru and the republics of the former Soviet Union. 
 In its annual International Narcotics Control Strategy Report, the State Department said worldwide cultivation of coca rose about 3 percent in 1992. In the years up to 1989, production had been growing by 10 percent to 20 percent a year.
The report praised the efforts against drug trafficking in the Bahamas, which has been a major transit point for drugs flowing into the United States, and Mexico, which remains a major source of cheap brown heroin but has waged a concerted campaign to root out Government corruption related to drugs.
 
The Troubles That Remain
 But the report noted disturbing developments in the international fight against drug traffickers, including:
*The decision by President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru to suspend the judiciary and congress in April. This led to a cutoff of most United States economic assistance, including funds for programs to combat drug trafficking and to promote other crops. Peru's efforts to curb coca production was also hampered by Shining Path guerrillas.
*The diversion of manpower and money to combat Colombia's coca cultivation to the manhunt for Pablo Escobar, the drug lord whose escape from prison in July embarrassed the Government.
*The failure by the military Government of Burma to halt the cultivation of opium. Burma is estimated to account for more than 50 percent of illicit opium production worldwide.
*A 12 percent rise in cultivation in Afghanistan, the second-largest producer of opium, because political instability hindered anti-drug efforts.
State Department officials also expressed concern that the economic chaos that has accompanied the breakup of the Soviet Union is leading to an increase in opium-poppy production in Tajikistan and Uzbekistan and is providing fertile ground for drug-trafficking rings in Russia.
The report was issued as the Clinton Administration is conducting a wide-ranging review of United States anti-drug policy and, according to reports, is consider diverting funds from drug-eradication programs in producing countries to efforts to reduce demand in the United States.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Filibuster Stalls Passage Of Clinton's $16 Billion Jobs Bill

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
Capping a week of cable-televised harangues and threats, the Senate's 43 Republicans got serious today and decided to block passage of President Clinton's $16.3 billion jobs program with a filibuster.
The Senate's 57 Democrats met privately, and then pledged to keep the Senate in session until the Republican hammerlock was broken, even if that meant delaying a two-week vacation and fund-raising opportunity set to begin Friday. 
Democrats filed a motion tonight to cut off debate on the bill, but there was little expectation that it would succeed. Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, said the Senate would meet on Saturday and again on Monday to vote on ending the debate, and other lawmakers said they would not be surprised if the dispute stretched well into next week.
"I don't see any way out of this impasse," Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, said as the Senate recessed late tonight.
 
Bruising Political Animus
 Mr. Dole's comment ended a day of bruising political animus over the jobs measure, a comparatively small spending bill that has provoked an early test of wills between the two parties.
Democrats accused their opponents of plunging Congress back into a despised state of political gridlock, and suggested that the Republicans wanted to humiliate Mr. Clinton as he flew to Canada for a meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
"The problem is they're trying to embarrass the President, to pull the rug out from under him at a critical moment," Senator Mitchell said.
The Republicans denied the accusation and said they were taking a stand against adding another $16.3 billion to the Federal deficit -- much of it, they charged, in the form of pork-barrel payoffs to election-year backers. "Gridlock?" Senator Dole said on Wednesday. "Pork-lock, pork-lock!"
Today, Mr. Dole's aides brandished a letter, signed by all 42 of his Republican colleagues, stating that they would not allow a vote on the jobs bill because it is "contrary to demands from taxpayers all across America."
The Democrats need only 51 votes to pass the bill, but first they need 60 votes to end the debate over it, something they cannot muster without Republican help.
Mr. Mitchell vowed that there would be no compromise, but at least one Republican Senator, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said he had already been called by a White House official looking for suggestions to end the standoff. He declined to identify the official.
 
Willing to Bargain
 Several Republicans seemed willing to bargain, too, suggesting they might support a pared-down bill that retained about $6 billion of the most politically salable programs: jobless benefits, inner-city summer jobs and childhood immunizations. And a few Democrats, none rabid fans of Mr. Clinton's proposal, predicted that sooner or later that will happen.
"I think we're probably going to end up going back to where we started -- passing those things that are needed, delaying those that aren't," said Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma, who tried but failed last week to put off spending about half the money the President is seeking. "The people want deficit reduction."
The President's proposal would create the equivalent of about 200,000 jobs by providing hundreds of programs to build sewer systems, repair dams, run inner-city summer schools and perform other public works. It also allots large sums to programs that would create few jobs, including $1.9 billion to make up a shortfall in a college-student loan program and about $700 million to buy computers and telephone switches for Federal agencies.
 
It's Power Politics
 Whatever the merits of the programs, the Senate debate is largely over power politics. Democrats want to preserve Mr. Clinton's series of legislative victories, and Republicans want to bring him down a notch.
Since last Thursday, Democrats have excoriated the Republicans daily on the C-Span cable network, saying they are strangling the economy and leaving the jobless empty-handed for political gain.
But the Republicans clearly feel they have gotten the best of the televised fight. They have repeatedly lambasted clauses they say would allot money for canoe-racing courses and warming huts at ice rinks.
"It's as close as we're going to get in the 103d Congress to a vote on the defining issue of government waste and pork," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas.

HEADLINE: NEWSPAPERS TOLD: SIMPLIFY, SIMPLIFY

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, April 1

 BODY:
American newspapers are dull and difficult to read. But different ways of writing news articles could help newspapers attract some of the readers they have lost.
That was the conclusion of a major study made public here this week at the annual convention of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. The study suggests that newspapers must challenge many of the rules that have governed journalism for generations. 
 The study was prepared by the group's literacy committee, which was formed partly because of growing alarm that young Americans do not read well enough to understand newspapers and are abandoning them.
The literacy panel challenged the fundamental form used for newspaper articles, the "inverted pyramid," in which the the top is heavy with important facts.
The panel's work is part of growing efforts by news professionals to grapple with the effect of limited literacy and to try to re-invigorate newspapers.
 
More Than Just Esthetics
 The study's conclusions appear to bolster efforts at some newspapers to increase the quality of writing and to vary the writing styles. But to the esthetic reasons that have been advanced in the past as reasons for these changes, the report adds an economic incentive: survival.
"The basic conservatism and frantic pace of our profession keep us from enlarging our repertoire of forms," the study said. "So year by year, we keep boring and confusing our readers and driving them away."
Experimenting with articles published in The St. Petersburg Times this January, researchers had reporters try four different writing approaches. Each of the four differently written articles about the same event was printed in some copies of the St. Petersburg newspaper and researchers then interviewed readers.
Younger and less frequent newspaper readers favored techniques other than the common inverted-pyramid style article, the study found, suggesting that newspaper writing could be altered to attract new readers.
 
Examples of Writing
 One form tried by the researchers was traditional style. ("Pets remain a popular gift despite the advice of animal advocates," one of the St. Petersburg Times articles began.)
Another tried to be more narrative, telling a tale. ("Just before Christmas three years ago, Lesly Stevens was forced to play Scrooge. But the result was a better life for Pumpkin, a 9-week-old kitten.")
A third type of article attempted to respond to what the study said was a typical newspaper reader's problem: that typical articles assume readers understand more than they do. In this writing approach, reporters attempted "radical clarity," arranging material in order and explaining everything. ("Imagine yourself in this situation: You get an adorable puppy as a holiday gift.")
The fourth approach to writing made the writer's point of view obvious. ("They are the little animals the holiday season purports to adore: The puppies with the big eyes and floppy ears.")
The study found that the articles with the writer's point of view were least effective to readers.

HEADLINE: Economy Stressed Over Trade

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1

 BODY:
The Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, said today that while the Clinton Administration was determined to win Congressional approval of the free-trade pact with Mexico this year, Congress should wait to act until it has completed work on the President's economic program in the fall.
In one of the first interviews he has granted since he took office, Mr. Bentsen said he did not want Congressional opposition to the North American Free Trade Agreement to spill over onto the economic package. Mr. Bentsen is not only President Clinton's main spokesman on economic matters but also one of the Administration's chief political and legislative strategists.
 
 
'One Thing at a Time'
 "We must not be too diffuse in our effort," he said. "We really have to concentrate on one thing at a time in terms of legislative effort." 
 Still, at a time when the Administration sometimes seems to talk with several different voices on trade issues, Mr. Bentsen left no doubt that he stood behind the agreement with Mexico and also wanted to bring worldwide trade negotiations to a successful conclusion by the end of this year. The pact is scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 1.
Over a fruit-salad lunch, the Treasury Secretary addressed these other matters:
*The Administration will continue to advocate a tax credit for new business investments, despite the lack of enthusiasm in Congress and among many business executives. "It gives you a big bang for the buck" in terms of creating jobs, he said.
*The United States must support Russia's offer to repay only $3.5 billion of the roughly $15 billion in interest and principal it owes this year to Western creditors. It is not realistic to expect larger payments this year, he said.
*The Administration is weighing various new taxes to pay for Mr. Clinton's health-care program. "People are willing to pay for health insurance reform," he said. "The questions are how much, how far you go and how fast you do it, and those decisions have sure not been made."
*The Administration will conduct "a very thorough investigation" into the operations of the Treasury's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms as soon as the standoff in Waco, Tex., is resolved.
Mr. Bentsen is clearly relishing his new job, with a big office overlooking the White House and the opportunity to display executive skills that he said were honed during nearly 30 years in Congress and about 20 years in business.
He said he had not anticipated that the preliminary budget measures would be approved so quickly by Congress with such strong unity among Democrats.
So far, he said, "things are going damn well." But he said he understood that the honeymoon would end sooner or later and that dealing with Congress would become tougher when lawmakers had to vote on which taxes to raise and which ones to cut and on how much money to spend on each Government program.
 
 
Mexico's President a Factor
 On the matter of trade, Mr. Bentsen was asked why, given the political perils involved, the Administration did not want to delay even longer Congressional consideration of the trade agreement with Mexico and Canada. Mr. Bentsen, a former Senator from Texas whose home is in the Rio Grande Valley, initially answered with one word: "Salinas."
President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's term as President of Mexico ends next year, and he cannot run for re-election. "We don't know who his successor is going to be," Mr. Bentsen continued. "I grew up on that border. The United States was always the colossus of the North, and Mexican politicians got elected attacking the United States. Now the country wants to work with us, and that is an incredible change. We can't lose the opportunity."
While the Administration is asking Congress to delay acting on the agreement with Mexico, the President wants quicker action on renewed authorization for him to negotiate trade agreements under a procedure called "fast track." The current authorization, allowing trade pacts to be submitted to Congress for rapid consideration with no amendments allowed, is expiring.
Mr. Bentsen said the new authorization was important as a signal to America's main trading partners that the United States was serious about completing a worldwide trade agreement under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
A Summit With an Ocean View, 3-Star Dining and Even a Woods to Walk In

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 1

 BODY:
Dr. David W. Strangway and his wife, Alice, had to give up their rambling, 7,000-square-foot Mediterranean-style home on a magnificent promontory above the sea in western Vancouver this week. But they have no hard feelings.
"We're actually thrilled," said Dr. Strangway, an Ontario-born geophysicist who studied moon rocks for NASA and is now the president of the University of British Columbia. "What a privilege to be able to say it happened here." 
 Their tawny, stucco house with red-tile roof, surrounded by gardens of heather, cedar and ginko trees and rhododendrons, has been taken over by the advance parties from the White House and the Kremlin for President Clinton's first meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.
The summit meeting is to be held on Saturday and Sunday in Canada's third largest city, a shimmering enclave tucked between mountain wilderness and the Pacific Ocean, and home for 1.6 million people.
For reasons of security as well as scenic majesty, the first lunch and talks will be in the city's more secluded western precincts, at the official residence for presidents of the 78-year-old provincial university. Later the two leaders will see some of the city center.
 
Yeltsin Gets the Penthouse
 Both men are sleeping downtown -- Mr. Yeltsin in the penthouse of the sparkling white Pan Pacific Hotel Vancouver with a panoramic view of the harbor and Mr. Clinton at the somewhat less prestigiously situated Hyatt Regency, about half a mile inland. A Canadian organizer said "the President insisted on staying at an American-owned, unionized hotel, and the Hyatt fit the bill."
Mr. Yeltsin not only will look out over the water but ride the waves as well. On Saturday he is to be the guest of skipper Jack Charles on the $3 million motor cruiser Hotei, named after the Buddhist god of happiness and laughter, for a tour of the harbor, Canada's largest port with its bustle of seaplanes, heli-jets, tugboats and freighters.
Practically all the grain Canada exports to Russia begins its sea journey from Vancouver. Mr. Charles, who is the chief executive officer of Arrow Transportation Systems, a local land and marine hauling company, said he was told by port authorities that Mr. Yeltsin "wants to see the harbor, and if there are any Russian freighters with Canadian wheat he'd like to stop and have a look."
The university residence is called the Norman MacKenzie House, but it was it was known as Dave's Bed and Breakfast this week on the Larry and Willy Show, a comedy interlude on one of the most popular rock stations, C-Fox FM 99.3.
 
Is Socks Coming?
 Someone impersonating President Clinton, but sounding more like Elvis Presley, called in to ask Dr. Strangway, who appeared as a guest on the show, whether there was a deep frier in the house and where the nearest McDonald's was. Dr. Strangway, playing along in the spoofing, asked whether the caller was bringing along Socks, the Clintons' cat. A painting of a golden saxophone, called Sax Inc. by Canadian artist Eric Metcalfe, hangs prominently in the house.
Mr. Clinton and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, who as the host of the meeting will welcome the visitors, are expected to announce new forms of economic aid to Russia this weekend and raise the possibility of rescheduling $80 billion of Moscow's debt. Canadian newspapers are saying an "alms race" has replaced the arms race.
 
Mounties Saddle Up
 For Vancouver, this is the biggest international event since Expo 86 drew 21 million visitors from more than 50 countries seven years ago. In terms of global political interest, nothing in the city's past can compare to the attention this meeting is likely to draw.
The huge harborfront Vancouver Trade and Convention Center, beneath the gleaming white sails that are the civic emblem, is preparing for a flood of 2,500 to 3,000 media personnel. The center has just been coverted into the press center and will be the site of a joint news conference Sunday afternoon.
Tactical squads of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police are gearing up as well. "This will be the highest level of security the R.C.M.P. can provide," said Sgt. Peter Montague, a liaison officer for the Mounties. "We will be prepared for any possibility."
Between the Mounties and local Vancouver police, a force of 1,500 has been mobilized, together with several helicopters. In addition, special security personnel have come from Washington and Moscow, estimated at about 100 from each capital.
Police motorcycle escorts have been interrupting traffic almost daily as they go through dry runs for transportating the leaders to points within the city.
The summit meeting will cost Canadian taxpayers about $1 million, said Len Edwards, Canada's Ambassador to South Korea, who is acting as the summit coordinator. Canada pays for the accommodations of the two leaders and their delegations, for the special security and for the press sites.
According to the official summit program, most of the activity Saturday is at Dr. Strangway's house. The only scheduled break is an after-lunch digestive stroll, weather permitting, to the Museum of Anthropology, a place with towering totem poles and huge feast dishes and other objects from the aboriginal cultures of the northwest.
The museum is next door to the house and an easy walk in the woods.
Dinner on Saturday is to be at one of the stellar Vancouver restaurants, Seasons in the Park (three stars in Vancouver Magazine), which is in Queen Elizabeth Park, the highest point of land (500 feet) in the metropolitan area and affording spectacular views.
Pierre Delacote from Alsace, the executive chef of the restaurant, said he had been asked to prepare a "very Canadian" meal and would oblige with local Dungeness crabs, British Columbia salmon, a Romaine lettuce salad and blueberries with maple ice cream.
 
Jogging With the Owls
 Although it's not on the official schedule, a Canadian summit organizer said President Clinton may jog early Sunday morning in Stanley Park, a recreational area along Vancouver harbor and home of many sea birds and owls.
Several months ago Vancouver papers carried reports of joggers having to fend off assaults from young, hungry owls mistaking bobbing heads and pony tails for squirrels and other prey.
Dick Cannings, a naturalist who is curator of the university's Cowan Vertebrate Museum, said the incidents are a regular occurrence in late summer when the young birds are first out on their own away from their parents.
But he added they do not pose a serious security concern for the Secret Service because these birds live in the deep woods of Stanley Park, not along the sea wall where the President will likely jog.
Arrangements have also been made for Mr. Clinton to attend the 9:15 A.M. service Sunday at the First Baptist Church, several blocks from his hotel.
The Rev. Bruce Milne, the senior pastor, said he will stick with the regular Palm Sunday service because the President "is coming as a worshiper."

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
To Hear Stars, Pay $50 or Take Their Bus

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins

DATELINE: CLIFTON, N.J.

 BODY:
THE gentleman on the bus could be seriously disturbed. Warped, maybe. To be sure, he looks familiar enough, with his curly gray locks and moustache. It's a big, friendly face: avuncular, lovable. But he is muttering to himself. Gesticulating wildly, alone by the window. He's sitting toward the back of a half-full No. 66 bus that is booming through Clifton on its way toward Route 3, the concrete alley to the Lincoln Tunnel and the Big Apple.
Wait now. Isn't that a script in the man's hand? That face -- isn't it Louis Zorich, the actor, who starred as Jules Berger, the grandpa in "Brooklyn Bridge," the television series? 
 "People see me rehearsing," Mr. Zorich responded to a query, "and they think they're looking at a maniac." His voice was calm, buttery. "And they are. They're looking at an actor."
On any other form of public transportation just about anywhere, a muttering, gesticulating citizen in a secluded rear seat would be categorized as yet another inhabitant of the great American transit outpatient system. An object of pity. Or fear.
Not on the 66. On this DeCamp Bus Company line that travels 14 miles from West Orange to Manhattan, a mutterer is more likely to be asked for an autograph. Statistical science is sure to calculate soon that the 66 route has more actor patronage per paid passenger mile than any other suburban bus line in America. (The M104 in Manhattan, the Broadway line, surely must top the urban list.)
"Some riders pass me pieces of paper to sign, and there goes my concentration," said Olympia Dukakis, who was reached at home. Ms. Dukakis, who won an Oscar for playing the mother in "Moonstruck," has been Mr. Zorich's wife for 31 years and has lived in Montclair for 21 of them.
"I got so practiced through the years that I'd use the bus to have breakfast, put on my makeup and study my script," she said. "After 'Moonstruck,' people couldn't believe I still took the 66."
Anthony Heald, another player who uses the 66 as a rehearsal room, feels that actors are "the in-bus entertainment on the DeCamp lines." Mr. Heald (who starred in the play "Lips Together, Teeth Apart" and appeared in the film "The Silence of the Lambs" as the digestible doctor) was encountered recently in Montclair between jaunts to California for work.
"What I hate about L.A.," he said, "is that when you have to drive to an audition, you don't have as much chance to prepare. You can't focus, as you can on the 66."
Montclair has the 66 bus route's most sizable acting community, although a cry of players live in Clifton, West Orange and Glen Ridge. Among the others who have ridden the 66 to auditions in Manhattan are Tonya Pinkins (who won a Tony Award for her role in "Jelly's Last Jam"), Frederick Rolf, Frankie Faison, Elaine Bromka, W. B. Brydon, W. T. Martin, Ed Blake and Gordon Jacoby, the dialect coach.
There are professional hazards, to be sure. "You might be all ready to rehearse, and then you'll meet another actor," said Mr. Zorich. "Then you have too much fun gossiping, and you forget your lines."
And passengers are not always entertained. "Once I was rehearsing a script on the 66 with a good deal of profanity in it, and I kind of forgot where I was," said Tom Brennan, who recently appeared in "Salome" with Al Pacino at the Circle in the Square. "In the middle of a string of curses I suddenly realized that everyone on the bus was looking at me. Appalled."
Once in a while, "groups of actors in the back of the bus will rehearse pretty loudly, but no one ever complains about them," said Sal Siano, a DeCamp bus driver for 23 years who ought to have an Actors Equity card himself. He has been known to announce "Welcome to beautiful Cancun!" upon arrival at the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
Actors being actors, they can't help but think about the show-business capability of the 66. Mr. Heald wondered wistfully whether the bus company might be interested in compensating out-of-work actors for entertaining passengers. "And it would be nice if DeCamp would install a soundproof booth in the back of the 66," he said, deadpan, "so actors could really emote, and see how it sounds."
Louis Nigro, DeCamp's general manager, commented carefully, "It would be very interesting to try to justify that particular expense to my boss." Mr. Nigro has fielded quite enough furious calls lately from cost-conscious bus patrons who are incensed that DeCamp has raised its rates (yet again!) in a time of low inflation and stable gas prices.
So, before DeCamp gets the idea to impose an entertainment surcharge on the actors' bus line, just one more 66 story: The time the bus broke down on Route 3. Five actors -- all of whom had been so absorbed by their scripts they hadn't been aware of one another's presence -- found themselves stranded out on the shoulder of the highway, waiting to board a rescue 66.
Mr. Zorich, who was there, remembers a long silence. Then someone said: "Well, DeCamp has just managed to shut down Broadway."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Sliding U.S. Dollar Reaches Another Low Against Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar sank to another record low against the yen yesterday as its two-month slide intensified amid signs that industrialized nations might seek a stronger yen to push down Japan's huge trade surplus.
News of a faltering American economic recovery contributed to the pessimism about the dollar. 
 Gold prices, meanwhile, continued to rise. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery gained $1.10 an ounce, to $338.70. The Republic National Bank quoted a late price for spot gold of $338.20 an ounce, up $1.45.
The dollar hit a post-World War II low of 113.70 yen in early New York dealings yesterday, but later firmed to close at 114.04 yen, down from 114.79 yen on Wednesday.
The dollar also fell to 1.5905 German marks in New York, down from 1.6085 marks on Wednesday. Meanwhile, the British pound rallied in New York to $1.5310, from $1.5123 on Wednesday.
Traders said the failure of central banks to support the dollar was a signal that the currency's fall had the approval of the Group of Seven industrialized nations.
Moreover, Japan is facing growing pressure from President Clinton to strengthen the yen to make American goods less costly abroad, thereby increasing American exports.
"Officials have basically given the go-ahead for a yen rally," said Siobahn Lakey, foreign exchange trader at Julius Baer.
In Tokyo, the Economic Planning Agency's minister, Hajime Funada, said the yen's recent rise against the dollar had been too rapid. But dealers said they did not think the Bank of Japan would actually move to halt the trend.
The dollar's first blow yesterday came when the latest weekly jobless claims rose unexpectedly. Further disappointment came when the National Association of Purchasing Management's March index fell to a five-month low, suggesting a slowing of economic growth. Moreover, the increase in February construction spending was below expectations.
"Some of the cozy assumptions about the recovery in the States will now be challenged," said David Coleman, Treasury adviser at the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce.

HEADLINE: German Labor Police Round Up Illegal Workers

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKFURT

 BODY:
Ante Kundid, a 43-year-old refugee from Croatia, thought he had landed a job as an electrician on a housing construction site in Fechenheim on a Monday morning.
But the German labor office and the police took it away from him less than 24 hours later in a raid of a kind that is fast becoming a daily occurrence here. 
 "We're being encouraged to make these raids, but they usually don't turn up much," said Bernhard Gorg, an investigator of the Frankfurt labor office in charge of combating illegal employment.
Pressure to crack down on illegal employment is intense in a country racked by rising joblessness, frustrated by a steady influx of foreign asylum-seekers and refugees who are not supposed to take jobs at all, and angry at native Germans who cheat the welfare system out of an estimated $6.2 billion every year, politicians say.
 
Voters Are Angry
 Many German voters are angry at their politicians for being seemingly unable to do anything about these problems, and in local elections here in March the right-wing Republicans, who promised more effective action, won 9.3 percent of the vote.
So federal, state and local government authorities, following the election returns, are cracking down on welfare abuses. The crackdown, they say, will save the taxpayers billions of dollars that would otherwise come from income tax increases or budget cuts, for the reconstruction of the shattered economy of the formerly Communist eastern Germany.
But wage levels and fringe-benefit costs in Germany are among the highest in the world, driven up by decades of welfare-state expansion comfortably protected by the United States and other NATO allies during the cold war.
For the first two decades after World War II, Germany had a labor shortage, and invited hundreds of thousands of Italians, Yugoslavs and Turks to come and work, at German wage levels, as "guest workers." Recruitment stopped with the economic slowdown of 1973, but nearly three million people from these areas still live in Germany.
New pressures arose after the collapse of Communism and the rise of nationalism in eastern Europe. Nearly 100,000 workers from East Europe are legally employed in Germany, the labor authorities say, working for Romanian, Polish and Bulgarian subcontractors in the construction industry.
These subcontractors often underbid German companies, and suspicion is widespread that they can do it because they pay their workers less than minimum German wages, though they are not legally allowed to.
But there are also tens of thousands more workers from East Europe who come here ostensibly as tourists -- but who end up painting ceilings, repairing washing machines, and doing carpentry, charging far less money than German workers because they do not pay health or social security benefits.
 
Workers' Markets
 There are a workers' markets in many German cities. Here in Frankfurt, it is under a railroad bridge just past the wholesale food market, on the eastern fringes of the city near the Main River.
Mr. Gorg and his colleagues passed it on their way to the housing construction site -- a group of about 30 young men in jeans, waiting for people in cars to stop and hire them at four to six marks ($2.50 to $3.75) an hour, cash, to do gardening or repair jobs that would cost twice as much if anyone could find Germans willing to do the work.
According to the city authorities in Frankfurt, many of them are Poles. But Mr. Gorg was not concerned with them. His assignment was to check out the construction site.
"We know there are Romanian subcontractors on this job, and we just want to check the working papers of their employees to make sure they have employment permits," he said.
 
Raid by Job Police
 At the construction site on Konstanzer Strasse, a mile or two down the road from the Poles, Mr. Gorg and his colleagues donned plastic helmets and walked toward a group of men in blue overalls cleaning up debris.
"Frankfurt labor office," he addressed one of the men. "May we see your papers?"
None spoke German.
Mr. Gorg went in search of the office of the German contractor in charge of the project. Shortly after, Mr. Kundid came in. The only identification he could produce was a Croatian passport with no visa or work permit in it.
"Where is your work permit?" Mr. Gorg asked. "Where do you live?" Mr. Kundid did not speak German, either.
His supervisor, another Croat, did. Which subcontractor did Mr. Kundid work for? No clear answer emerged. Where does he live? The supervisor gave his own address, and said Mr. Kundid lived with him.
 
Police Make Arrest
 Two German policemen in green uniforms arrived and searched Mr. Kundid. They found a little over 100 marks (about $60) and took him away.
"He won't be under arrest for long," Mr. Gorg said. "They'll ask him for a cash bail deposit and tell him to go home and not to try to work again. If we can find out which company hired him, they'll be fined."
The fine would amount to about 1,000 marks, about $600.
Daniel Cohn-Bendit, the 1960's radical who is now the city official in charge of multicultural affairs, laughed at the labor office's raids.
"These are pathetic attempts to appear to be coming to grips with the situation," he said. "The politicians are afraid of seeming to be incapable with dealing with the situation, so they order actions like this."

HEADLINE: A Broad-Stroke Budget

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 1

 BODY:
Even for a place where the symbols of the trade are the press release and the closed door, the scene in the Capitol early this morning set new standards for both secrecy and spin.
It became clear in the dreary light after sunrise -- not that there was much question even in the darkness of midnight -- that the $32 billion budget deal that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proclaimed as a great "cause for celebration" at 12:01 A.M. was a deal in broad outline, with many details outstanding. 
 But none of that mattered at midnight. For political reasons, it had become critically important, particularly to the Governor, to declare that at least a "handshake deal" was in place by April 1.
 
The Measure of Leadership
 If Mr. Cuomo seeks re-election to a fourth four-year term next year, the measure of his leadership will be his stewardship of the state during some of its most difficult fiscal years.
To make an effective case, Mr. Cuomo must be able to showcase budgets that are on time and in balance. An increase in the state's credit rating during the 1994 election year would not hurt.
While state leaders agreed Wednesday on basic principles on issues like aid to schools, new debt practices and Medicaid, weary budget negotiators conceded today that there still was a great deal of work ahead.
They spent the day shuttling between meetings, just as they have every day for the last two weeks. Budget bills were still being written. Details were still hard to come by.
 
Still Selling the Package
 Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, still were trying to sell the budget package to disgruntled members. Even if things go smoothly, legislative aides said, they probably could not pass the budget before Sunday, four days after the April 1 start of the fiscal year.
The Legislature passed last year's budget only two days late. The state finished the year with a surplus tentatively estimated at $483 million, although some state officials believe the number will grow even higher after a final accounting. Now Mr. Cuomo needs a second year of such success to establish a record of consistency.
"I think that more than any year the Governor wanted timeliness this year," said one Cuomo aide. "The economic situation is strengthening and if you are on time you can go to the financial community and say we've really turned the corner. If you can get a bond upgrading next year, you can make a strong argument to the people that New York has come through a very tough time."
 
No Details
 So it was early this morning that Mr. Cuomo ushered reporters into the Red Room, his seldom-used ceremonial office, and announced that an agreement had been reached. He clasped hands with Mr. Weprin and Mr. Marino, declined to discuss details and went home.
Because Mr. Cuomo did not make his announcement until just after midnight -- reporters and lobbyists had already completed a Times Square-style countdown in the hallway outside his office -- the Governor's press secretary, Anne W. Crowley, maintained that an earlier handshake had taken place behind closed doors. The handshake in the Red Room apparently was just a re-enactment for the cameras.
By refusing to discuss details at the most dramatic moment in a long budget process, Mr. Cuomo may have passed up his best opportunity to promote the substance of the deal, which seems to follow the fiscal principles he established in January.
 
Cuomo's Victories
 Mr. Cuomo won his fight against increases in broad-based taxes, despite an effort by Mr. Weprin to raise income tax rates for the wealthy. He pushed through a heavy increase in cigarette taxes, despite opposition from Mr. Marino.
He apparently succeeded in changing the state's complicated school aid formula so that school districts with large proportions of poor children, like New York City, will receive more assistance. Negotiators were still ironing out details of the plan today, making it difficult to know how much real reform the Governor won.
Mr. Cuomo also persuaded the Legislature to help fill a $3 billion budget gap by diverting $516 million from a fund that was supposed to be dedicated to transportation.
He helped broker a compromise on a huge transportation financing plan, although it was larger than the plan he wanted. He successfully pushed through a package of measures aimed at giving the public greater control of state borrowing, although only after one final splurge of backdoor borrowing for the transportation plan.
 
The Issue of Soundness
 The issue of whether the budget is soundly balanced also remains. Many officials, both in the Legislature and the Cuomo administration, concede that at first glance the budget seems to spend more money than the state is projected to receive this year.
But there is a sense among some in Albany that the state's economy is improving faster than expected and that unanticipated revenues, both from this year and last year, will allow the state to avoid a deficit.
If Mr. Cuomo runs next year, the budget's balance will be as important as its timeliness. No candidate wants to face a budget deficit that might require tax increases or heavy spending cuts in a campaign year.

HEADLINE: Decline in Smoking Levels Off And Officials Urge a Tax Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ATLANTA, April 1

 BODY:
After 25 years of decline in the number of smokers compared with nonsmokers, the overall rate was virtually unchanged from 1990 to 1991 as more and more American blacks and women started smoking, Federal health officials reported today.
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said discount cigarettes and tobacco advertising, which is about $3.9 billion a year, were to blame for the reversal and called for cigarette tax increases. 
 "We need to look at bold steps because we're not making the progress we need to make," said Dr. Michael Eriksen, director of the Centers for Disease Control's Office of Smoking and Health.
The figures for 1991, the latest statistics available, probably mean that the United States will not meet a goal of having only 15 percent of Americans smoking by the year 2000.
"It's taken us off our year 2000 pace," Dr. Eriksen said. "At the current rate, we'll only reach 19 percent."
Discount cigarettes, which can cost as much as $1 less a pack than national brands, and promotions like free samples and $5-off coupons for cartons make smoking more affordable, he said.
 
People Who Might Have Quit
 "That is contributing to people continuing to smoke who in the past otherwise would have quit," he said.
The agency based its figures on an annual national survey of about 43,000 people. It found that 25.7 percent of Americans, 46.3 million people, smoked in 1991. In 1990, 25.5 percent smoked, the lowest level since the Government began counting in 1955.
But more blacks smoked in 1991 (29.2 percent against 26.2 percent in 1990), and more women smoked (23.5 percent versus 22.8 percent), the agency said.
The agency said it could not explain the increase among women except to point to advertising that features slender models to aim at women's fears of weight gain if they stop smoking.
"This is particularly disturbing because more women today die of lung cancer than die of breast cancer," Dr. Eriksen said, "and lung cancer is totally preventable."
The agency said the increase among blacks could be related to the failed attempt in 1990 to market a cigarette, called Uptown, with advertising aimed specifically at blacks. A national outcry by black organizations that condemned the Uptown cigarette campaign was credited with helping to reduce the level of smoking among blacks to 26.2 percent that year.
The following year, some blacks who tried to quit during the Uptown uproar may have begun smoking again, Dr. Eriksen said. The agency is pursuing a separate study on the effects of the Uptown campaign.
The agency also found that smoking was most prevalent among people ages 25 to 44, Indians and Alaskan natives, those who live below the poverty line and people with less than a high school education.

HEADLINE: Wistfully, Fernandez Urges Budget

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
In his final budget request to Mayor David N. Dinkins, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday asked for an extra $584 million for the school system, and said he wished he could be around next year to help spend it.
"Things are starting to turn around in terms of the budget," Mr. Fernandez said at a briefing for reporters that, in contrast to past years, was marked by optimism about the budget. "Quite honestly, I wish I were here next year." 
 Mr. Fernandez was denied a new contract by a divided Board of Education in February after he endured three years of fiscal austerity in which he was forced to devote much of his energy to cutting spending, rather than rebuilding the school system as he was hired to do.
 
Hope for Help
 But now, as he prepares to depart at the end of June while talking wistfully about his "legacy," he said the school system was poised to receive an infusion of extra money from both the city and the state, and perhaps from Washington as well.
School officials say they now hope to receive a substantial share of an extra $250 million in state education aid under negotiation in Albany, as well as extra money from the city, especially since Mayor Dinkins has promised to make education a top priority.
In the past, negotiations involving the Mayor, the City Council and the Board of Education over the school system's budget have been marked by bitter public spats, and it is not clear how Mr. Fernandez's lame-duck status will affect this year's talks.
 
M.A.C. and Its Money
 Last year, for instance, it was mid-summer, a month or so after the city budget was adopted, that Mr. Fernandez and city budget officials reached agreement on $250 million in spending that averted threatened cuts in the number of teachers.
One source of money that Mr. Fernandez is seeking to tap this year -- surpluses from the Municipal Assistance Corporation -- may simply be unavailable once he leaves office on June 30. Mr. Fernandez is seeking $70 million from the corporation.
Felix G. Rohatyn, the M.A.C. chairman, said the surpluses, which are to come from bond refinancings, would not be available to the schools unless the Mayor and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo agree on a plan to reorganize the Board of Education.
"I am convinced that it is impossible to run the system with this type of board," Mr. Rohatyn said.
 
Rise in Enrollment
 While spending on schools is politically popular, basic education spending often is shorted because it is so expensive. It is all but impossible to reduce average class size, for instance, without talking about hundred of millions of dollars of increases in the city's $7.6 billion Board of Education budget.
The spending increase proposed by Mr. Fernandez includes $345 million listed as mandatory increases to continue required programs amid a surge in enrollment and $169 million for new programs for school safety and repairs.
At least $63 million of the mandated increase was attributed to a projected enrollment increase of 20,000 that would push next fall's total above one million for the first time in 15 years.
Many of the new programs proposed by Mr. Fernandez are ones with which he has become closely identified, from a plan to spend $17.6 million to pay the start-up costs for 40 small high schools, to a system of limited school governance he introduced, and new math and science curriculum initiatives.
In recent speeches and statements, Mr. Fernandez has appeared to lay out his legacy as he sees it in the New York City school system. In a cover letter included with his budget requests, Mr. Fernandez discussed his accomplishments, and said "these reforms must continue."
 
Disputes Over Figures
 Asked about the Chancellor's proposals, Philip R. Michael, the City Budget Director, said, "I'm sure they are worthy, and we will give them as much money as we possibly can," but he made no commitments.
And Mr. Michael disputed Mr. Fernandez's contention that he was forced to cut $750 million in the school budget since 1990. Mr. Michael said the cuts were made against hypothetical spending targets, that in each of the last four years school spending had actually increased and that in all but one year spending had increased more than the enrollment had.
City budget officials have predicted that in the current school year spending will rise by 3.6 percent to $7.6 billion, while enrollment increases by 2.1 percent. But figures provided by the State Education Department showed that spending had declined slightly, without making any allowance for inflation.

HEADLINE: Long-Term Bond Rates Jump to 6.96%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates jumped to 6.96 percent yesterday and could move to 7 percent or higher if today's report on March employment is surprisingly strong and two key inflation reports due next week are disappointing.
In light trading yesterday, the price of the 30-year bond fell 16/32 point as the yield rose from 6.93 percent Wednesday. The long bond's yield of 6.96 percent was the highest since the post-election bond market rally pushed it to a 16-year low of 6.72 percent March 8. 
 There were several possible reasons for the decline yesterday, which also spread to 10-year notes, for which the price fell 9/32 and the yield jumped to 6.05 percent from 6.02 percent. Shorter-term Treasury notes were down only a little.
 
 
Weaker Dollar
 Among the explanations were the weaker American dollar, which prompted foreign selling, and reports of sales by a big holder of long-term bonds.
In addition, there were worries about inflation, despite the fact that yesterday's report on initial jobless claims and the survey of the National Association of Purchasing Managers indicated slower economic growth. [Page D3.]
But traders were primarily concerned about what the March employment report will say about the economy and what they can expect from the Government's report on producer prices next Thursday and the report on consumer prices due on Good Friday, when the bond market will be closed.
"We are going into a very big number," one trader at a primary dealer in bonds said. "And a lot of things are going on that are confusing people."
The key statistic for traders today will be the change in nonfarm payroll workers. In February, there was a surprisingly large increase of 365,000 that knocked out some of the support for the bond rally.
Nonfarm payrolls are exceedingly difficult to forecast, although economists and analysts all around Wall Street dutifully try do so. But there seems to be even more doubt about the March figure than usual because of the wide range of forecasts. They run from a decline of 73,000 to an increase of 235,000.
What many analysts would like is a number that seems to resolve the debate over the pace of economic growth and, in turn, makes it easier to decide whether the unexpectedly high increases in inflation in January and February are something to worry about. If they are, analysts seem to conclude that the decline in interest rates will be over for now.
There are two outcomes that could end the debate:
*Nonfarm payrolls could decline. That could lead to a conclusion that the economy is growing moderately but slowly, perhaps at an annual pace of 3 percent or less, far slower than the 5 percent rate at the end of last year. As such, the price increases from the beginning of the year might not be sustained, possibly leading to inflation no higher than last year's 3 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index.
*Nonfarm payrolls could jump by more than 200,000. That might mean that the economy is moving ahead at a relatively brisk annual pace of more than 3 percent. As such, the inflation rate would probably rise this year. In this case, bond prices would fall and the yield would move above 7 percent, traders said.
But there could be no clear answer. Nonfarm payrolls could rise by 80,000 to 120,000. That would mean the pace of job growth would be almost double the rate of the last three months of 1992. But it would not mean that the economy is really picking up a lot of speed. In fact, the economy would probably be growing at a slower pace than at the end of last year.
 
 
'Doesn't Settle Anything'
 That would not be enough of a slowdown to make inflation less worrisome, analysts said yesterday. "It doesn't settle anything and it raises the ante for next week's inflation data," said Alan Levenson, money market economist at UBS Securities. He said economists and investors would still not know if "the pace of job growth and economic growth is enough to start us heading toward 4 percent inflation in 1994."
So the focus will shift to the end of next week. The Producer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in February, and another such jump would be disturbing. The Consumer Price Index, without food and energy, jumped five-tenths of 1 percent in the first two months of the year, and a similar rise would make it very hard for the inflation rate to come in at 3 percent this year.
Also in the bond market yesterday, the scheduled auction of $14.25 billion of one-year bills was canceled because Congress had not approved an increase in the Government's debt ceiling. Congressional leaders have said they intend to approve a higher debt limit before going on a two-week recess today or this weekend. When that happens, the Treasury will reschedule the auction. The Treasury has said it will run out of cash to pay bills and reach the debt ceiling borrowing limit Wednesday.

HEADLINE: More Evidence of Slowing Growth

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
A strong rebound in manufacturing lost some of its momentum in March, a survey of corporate purchasing executives shows.
The survey, conducted by the National Association of Purchasing Managers and released yesterday, is one of many pieces of evidence that economic growth in the first quarter was significantly less robust than last fall's 5 percent pace. 
 "Growth is still healthy," said Robert Bretz, who supervises the survey and is a purchasing executive at Pitney Bowes in Stamford, Conn. "But we're coming off an unsustainable high in January."
 
 
Other Signs
 There were other signs that the economy's pace was slowing. Construction, which has not shown many signs of life recently, slipped a little further in February, the Commerce Department said yesterday. After adjusting for inflation, total outlays edged down three-tenths of 1 percent after declining seven-tenths of 1 percent in January.
What is more, a spurt in jobless claims in late March to their highest level since November suggests that job growth may have been fairly lackluster. The increase, however, appears to have been partly a result of storms that kept people from filing in earlier weeks. Still, new jobless claims surged to 380,000 in the week ending March 27, the Labor Department reported yesterday. The Government's monthly report on job growth and the unemployment rate is due out today.
"Job growth in the first quarter was fast enough to knock the unemployment rate down," said Roger Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, "but we can't expect gains like we saw in February." He was referring to the Labor Department's initial estimate that 365,000 new jobs were created in February.
Forecasters and investors closely track the purchasing managers' index -- compiled from a dozen or so survey questions -- because it offers the first real glimpse of economic activity in any given month. In March, the index fell to 53.4, from 55.8 in February and 58.0 in January. Any reading over 50 signals that the nation's factories are expanding. A number over 45 suggests that the economy as a whole is growing.
 
 
January's Five-Year High
 "In January, our production index was at a five-year high and the new orders index was at its highest level in nine years," Mr. Bretz said. "Relative to that, anything looks a bit puny."
The rate of growth for production fell sharply last month, the executives reported, and accounted for most of the drop in the index. For production, the problem was not the fierce winter storms that kept consumers out of stores. "The growth rate of of new orders had dropped significantly in February," Mr. Bretz said. "You could almost have predicted that March production would have been lower."
The growth of orders slowed some more in March. Nonetheless, order backlogs got fatter -- especially in plastics and rubber, oil and food -- for the third month in a row. Bigger backlogs suggest more production down the road. Last year, by contrast, order backlogs were flat or falling for much of the year.
The most worrisome note in the report was a sharp drop in export orders to the lowest level since the purchasing managers' survey included a question on such orders. One month does not make a trend, but this could be the first indication that recessions in Europe and Japan are finally taking their toll on exports, a source of strength for the economy over the last couple of years and about a quarter of the market for American factory goods.
 
 
Weakened Employment
 Inventories shrank a bit, though far less than in February, and manufacturing employment also weakened some, no surprise given the drop in production.
But there are indications, namely a lengthening workweek and record overtime, that factories may do some hiring in coming months.
"With backlogs building, hours building and overtime building, at some point manufacturers are going to say 'we've had enough of these overtime costs, let's hire more people,' " Mr. Bretz said. "We're getting close to that point."
At least one large manufacturer has already passed that point. The Whirlpool Corporation in Benton Harbor, Mich., said yesterday that it had added 900 temporary jobs and 800 permanent jobs since January, mostly to keep up with strong demand for its refrigerators.
