HEADLINE: One Last Round as 'Cheers' Finale Is Taped

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, April 1

 BODY:
For all intents and purposes, that agreeable television mix of wry wit and barroom banter, set in a Boston tavern known as Cheers, ended on Wednesday night on a sound stage here.
With considerable emotion and fond remembrances of 11 years, the cast of NBC's "Cheers" shot the 274th and final episode of what has become a Thursday-night ritual in homes across America. It was the ultimate last call for the longest-running comedy on television. 
 Just how the writers plan to contrive a satisfying conclusion is a tightly held secret that was not revealed even to the specially selected audience that jammed Paramount Studios' Stage 25 on Wednesday night. A final scene is to be taped in secret later, and the 90-minute episode is to be shown on May 20.
About the only thing the producers have disclosed is that the bar will not be closed. They also say that President Clinton has expressed interest in making a cameo appearance on the final episode if it fits into his schedule, but that any such appearance would not be a deus ex machina to solve the problem of winding things up.
 
Special Guest Stars
 It can be said for certain that the final episode concerns a return appearance of a former "Cheers" star, Shelley Long, who played Diane Chambers, the brainy former barmaid and sometime lover to the bar owner, Sam Malone, played by Ted Danson. The character left the show in 1987, ostensibly to write a novel, when Ms. Long left to pursue a movie career. She was replaced by Kirstie Alley as Rebecca Howe, who managed the bar for a time.
When the show is broadcast, close observers, especially if they are Hollywood insiders, might notice a few special touches. The stiff, suited extras around the square wooden bar include Grant Tinker, the former chairman of NBC; John Pike, the president of Paramount Network Television; Warren Littlefield, the president of NBC Entertainment, and Kerry McCluggage, the chairman of the Paramount Television Group.
For the regular cast and crew, the reality that it was all nearly over had not yet sunk in. "I'm basically in denial," Kelsey Grammer, who has spent nine years as Frasier Crane, the psychotherapist, said during a break. "I'm going to go away for a while to put this in perspective." He plans to move to a "Cheers" television spinoff, where Dr. Crane will dispense therapy on the radio in Seattle.
"This is never going to happen again," said Rick Reden, a camera coordinator and director, who is also a nine-year "Cheers" veteran. "The show was like a bar. We would come in during our days off."
 
More Work Now, Emotion Later
 In fact, this finale was not the cast and crew's finale. The penultimate episode remains to be shot, out of order, as is not uncommon on television. So the finale was not, for the cast and crew, a real finale, but nonetheless a momentous event for a show that had its premiere in September 1982 when Ronald Reagan was President, Ed Koch the mayor of New York and the Dow Jones Industrial average stood at a mere 900.
James Burrows, who helped create the show and has directed most of its episodes, was behind the cameras for the final show. The script was written by the show's two other creators, Glen Charles and Les Charles; it was the first episode two brothers had written since 1987. All three are executive producers of the show.
"This is my family, our family; it's like a loss in the family," Mr. Burrows said in an interview today, adding that there would be more time for emotion after the penultimate episode is shot next week. He added that last night's shoot was unique in television annals. "No live sitcom has ever shot an hour and a half in one night," he said.
And the taping went smoothly, considering that it was triple the length of a normal episode and that it was difficult to keep the audience in its seats in a shoot that began at 7:20 P.M. and did not wrap until 2:15 this morning. Reporters present were sworn to secrecy, but suffice it to say that the lives of the major characters and their problems are resolved more or less happily before it ends.
 
The Gang's All There
 All the regulars were there: Cliff the mailman (John Ratzenberger); Norm Peterson, the unemployed accountant and barfly (George Wendt); Carla Tortelli, the wise-cracking barmaid (Rhea Perlman); Woody Boyd, the junior bartender (Woody Harrelson), and Rebecca Howe, as well as Sam and Frasier. Mr. Ratzenberger flubbed a line a couple of times, requiring retakes. "I'm just trying to stretch out the season," he blurted out.
NBC has pretty much turned the night of May 20 over to "Cheers." At 9 P.M. it plans to show a 30-minute documentary titled "Last Call: A Celebration of 'Cheers,' " followed by the 90-minute finale, then capped at 11:30 with much of the cast on the "Tonight" show with Jay Leno, who will take his show to the Bull and Finch, the bar in Boston on which "Cheers" was modeled.
But what to do about the set at Paramount, with its red vinyl bar stools, wooden bar with brass rails, old jukebox and posters of Babe Ruth and Ty Cobb? Might the Smithsonian Institution express interest in it as an artifact for some cultural anthropologist of the 21st century, not yet born, to fathom meaning from America of the 1980's?
It already has.

HEADLINE: Stop New York's Shady Borrowing

 BODY:
The proud State of New York has a rotten credit rating, the worst among the 50 states, according to one rating agency. This dubious distinction is rooted in a scheme devised to finance Gov. Nelson Rockefeller's ambitious building projects in the 1960's.
Now Gov. Mario Cuomo and lawmakers, properly embarrassed by the state's sunken standing after 11 years of his stewardship, have endorsed a plan to restore some respect and save some money. It's overdue, by years and billions of dollars. 
 New York's Constitution requires that voters approve state bond issues in a general election, and no more than one issue per year. But even when an issue gets on the ballot, many fail, as 5 of the past 10 have done.
The restrictions and repeated rejections led Governor Rockefeller to the idea of borrowing through public authorities, which could issue bonds without voter approval, albeit at a higher interest rate. The creative thinker behind this scheme was John Mitchell, then a bond lawyer, later Richard Nixon's Attorney General.
The last time voters approved a state bond issue was 1988. Since then, however, state authorities have borrowed more than $6 billion, at an estimated extra interest cost of at least $2 billion, according to Comptroller Edward Regan.
Authority borrowing costs more because it is not fully backed by the state, although in practice the state will make good if the authority comes up short. Costs are also high because authority bond issues are commonly arranged by negotiation with a selected underwriter, rather than by competitive bidding that might get the borrower a better deal.
As originally intended, authorities would borrow for specific capital projects that eventually pay for themselves -- for example, dormitories for the state university. But authority borrowing soon became a convenient device for evading voter approval on all sorts of projects, and for borrowing to cover ordinary budget expenses.
A particularly flagrant example of abuse was the state's sale of the Attica prison to an authority, the Urban Development Corporation, for $200 million in 1990, to plug a budget gap. The U.D.C. sold bonds to get cash for the purchase; the state will eventually repurchase the prison at a cost, in interest and principal, more than double the original one-shot benefit.
With shenanigans like that, it is no wonder that the credit rating agencies rank New York with the lowest of the low. To get out of the cellar, New York must break its addiction to fiscal tricks, completely and convincingly.
The State Senate has approved a proposed constitutional amendment to ease restrictions on voter-approved borrowing -- for example, allowing more than one bond issue per year -- and would create a new, centralized system for authority borrowing, strictly limited to capital projects. Negotiations along these lines are part of the current budget talks between Governor Cuomo and the Legislature's leaders.
Lawmakers have reportedly reached agreement, but their negotiations are shrouded in secrecy. Considering the long-lasting consequences of a constitutional amendment, the Legislature should not race to rubber-stamp whatever agreement the Governor and the leaders have made.
It is important that New York restore the integrity of its debt, but also important to do it right.

HEADLINE: Birth Control 'for All People'

 BODY:
It was a Republican President, Dwight Eisenhower, who made an especially cogent case for the importance of international family planning. "Governments must act and private citizens cooperate urgently through voluntary means to secure this right for all people," he said. "Failure would limit the expectation of future generations to abject poverty and suffering and bring down upon us history's condemnation."
A subsequent Republican President, Ronald Reagan, didn't share Eisenhower's concern and denied funding for International Planned Parenthood and the United Nations Population Fund. The result was to inhibit certain invaluable population control programs for nearly a decade. Now President Clinton's Democratic Administration proposes to restore Eisenhower's compassionate approach to an issue that ought to be above partisan politics. 
 The Reagan Administration, responding to its more extreme right-wing supporters, promulgated the so-called Mexico City policy in 1984, which banned Federal aid to any family planning agencies that so much as mentioned abortion.
When population experts protested that such a ban held poor countries' efforts hostage to America's abortion controversy, Mr. Reagan's advisers had a blithe answer. Population growth, they said, was a "natural phenomenon" that could stimulate economic growth. More people, they argued, meant more ideas, more productivity and more consumers. If the abortion rule constricted population programs, it would do the world a favor.
Try telling that to a woman in, say, Bangladesh, for whom childbearing often begins with puberty and ends with menopause -- assuming that she lives till menopause. At least 500,000 pregnant women, most of them in poor countries, die every year. A quarter of the deaths that occur before term are the results of illegal abortions.
Try telling it to the African women living in those 18 countries in which, because of the Mexico City policy, International Planned Parenthood had to cancel programs.
And try telling it to the Chinese, who are desperately in need of population planning. Yes, there have been reports of coerced abortions, especially in rural areas; and some Americans don't believe China's denials. Still, what better way to discourage abortion than to encourage and facilitate humane family planning? That's what the U.N. Population Fund has been doing in China for a long time, but without American aid since Mexico City.
In the time since Eisenhower spoke of "this right for all people," an extraordinary number of the world's citizens have won that right. Thirty years ago, for instance, fewer than 10 percent of couples in developing countries used some kind of birth control. Now more than half do. And in Africa, where the fertility rate is highest and contraceptive use lowest, births are starting to decline.
Even so, the rate of population expansion remains awesome, threatening to impoverish the planet. We have already seen what drought, poor land use and overpopulation did to Ethiopia. Runaway pregnancy rates are no route to progress.
In asking Congress to renew financing for International Planned Parenthood and the U.N. Population Fund, Mr. Clinton is calling on the United States to pick up the standard it dropped in Mexico City. Once more, America has a chance to make a profound impact on the future of international family planning -- and on history's judgment.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Troubles For Timber

BYLINE: By Jim Weaver; Jim Weaver was a Democratic Representative from Oregon from 1975 to 1987. 

DATELINE: EUGENE, Ore.

 BODY:
The object of today's "timber summit" in Portland, Ore. is to resolve the standoff between environmental groups, who are using the National Forest Management Act of 1976 to block the sale of old growth timber from the Northwest's national forests, and the timber companies and loggers, who want to harvest those trees. Politicians are crying that the environmentalists should be less intransigent, more willing to compromise. I say to those courageous souls: stand fast.
As chairman of the House Forests Subcommittee from 1977 to 1982, I spent countless hours flying over America's forests. The desolation was stark. I saw vast barren deserts in southern Oregon that once were the magnificent timber holdings of the most prominent names in the wood industry; bleached yellow earth that stretched for miles along the coastal mountains of northern California where giant redwoods once stood; contoured road-scars and checkerboard squares of clear-cuts in the national forests. 
 Are we replanting the trees? Surely. But it may take hundreds of years to re-establish the forests. On a 1982 trip with the California regional forester to the Trinity Mountains, we landed on site after site of replantings only to see withered seedlings. Embarrassed for the forester, I began looking for better plantings. "There," I said, pointing to a patch of bright green among the older, darker trees.
"That's a burn," he said wearily.
I called his attention to another lush green splotch.
"That's a burn, too."
The so-called "timber crisis" in the Northwest stems not from environmental intransigence over the spotted owl but from the fact that timberlands owned by the giant corporations have been mowed down. These companies must now resort to Federal timber in the name of jobs and the regional economy.
The primary purpose for conservationists going to court is to spare the few remaining stands in the national forests. People are beginning to understand this. If only the politicians would, too. And if only they'd come to realize that it's possible to stand up to a vocal minority and survive.
As a freshman Congressman from a rural industrial district -- the largest timber producing region in the nation -- I helped write the forest management act. It sounds foolhardy for a politician to bring down on himself the hatred of the main industry in his district. And they hated me! Mill owners would call out their workers before an election and tell them they would lose their jobs if I was re-elected. At a wilderness hearing here in Eugene, 600 log trucks wound about the town, their horns blaring, while workers paraded angrily outside the courthouse. In spite of that, I was elected six times with ever-increasing margins.
So, how do we solve the timber crisis? The Government must raise the price of timber by keeping the harvest from the national forests low. Higher prices will make trees more valuable. The more valuable the trees, the more care will go into in their growing, cutting and manufacture.
Couple this with capital gains tax treatment that benefits the long-term growing of trees -- and not the short-term cutting and exporting of them -- and we will lay the foundation for a sustained timber economy.
But that's not the way many politicians think about the use of natural resources. No doubt the dominant refrain at the timber summit will be criticism of high lumber prices and advocacy of logging of our forests.
This would be wrong. The reduction of the wood work force in the Northwest has had far more to do with the depletion of private timber than with the preservation of trees. When company's cut out their timber, they close their mills.
People will be put to work, as Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt has suggested, cleaning up eco-systems and seeing to it that timber is harvested carefully. High lumber prices will force builders to build more carefully, using less wood.
The public will pay higher prices (including the Japanese who buy an average of 3 billion board feet of logs a year from us), and it should. When I was a builder in the 1960's, the cost of lumber was about 15 percent of the finished house. It is no more than that now. There is lots of room for higher prices, especially for commodities that soon will be gone if we keep up our wasteful exploitation.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Clinton's Bank Account

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Presidents have a kind of political bank account in American minds. When a President takes an important step, or ducks one, each of us makes a mental deposit or withdrawal according to our political tastes.
The accounts never get down to zero except in the minds of ideologues or out-party careerists. But most of us do not let a President get so rich that he can afford to forget we are keeping accounts. 
 In my bank, President Clinton has made a deposit that fattens his balance against some early withdrawals.
By executive order, the President canceled the Reagan-Bush ban on U.S. aid to any birth control group at home or abroad that gives a word of supportive advice or information about abortion.
Aside from violating freedom of speech and medical counsel for Americans, this order was an economic and political blow to countries that can afford it least: nations whose population growth is so explosive that it wipes out hope that there can ever be food for every mouth, or a decent place to rest every body.
I am not a demographer but I do have a qualification to write and shout about the importance of birth control and American help for it. I lived in India for four years.
On my desk is a book I bought in New Delhi long ago -- Murray's Handbook. It tells me the population when I first saw India in 1954 -- about 360 million. All over the world people knew then that India was being choked by its people.
I returned often, drawn by affection for a country that has never surrendered either to despair or despotism. During a visit last month I asked for the projected figure for 1993. It is 844 million.
Can I even grasp this? Just in the years of my own interest in India, it has grown by twice the present population of the United States. My God.
Between Bombay's airport and the city, the bouncy commercial capital of India, I drove along a carpet miles long -- collections of burlap rags in which hundreds of thousands of human beings live. Not fit for dogs.
In their villages there are too many people to feed, no chance of work. On the pavements they can at least hope that somewhere in the huge city there will be something for them, some food, some labor.
Perhaps we can grasp India now. But can our minds encompass a vision of the streets of Bombay, or of scores of exploding cities around the world, in another few decades? I do not think we can; nobody has ever seen such dreadful things as those streets will be.
With decent birth control, India could still be a reachable dream of economic and political dignity. Without it, all the sweat and talent will not fulfill that hope.
There is an almost unspeakable sorrow in that thought -- the knowledge that all the drive and effort that Indians and Mexicans and Nigerians and Egyptians, and so many others, have put into strengthening their countries may add up to nothing but unending misery.
In India, as in other countries that have failed at birth control, the fault is not America's. Their own leaders bear the responsibility for not doing enough in education, health care and the spread of birth control devices and techniques.
And American aid to many population control groups continued during the Reagan-Bush anti-abortion ban. But the order did more than wipe out aid directly or through the U.N. to groups that would not obey Washington's order to shut their mouths and brains about choice. It destroyed American intellectual and moral leadership in the international population-control movement.
For those Americans cynical about the value of American leadership, a couple of reminders. American political democracy brought strength to hundreds of millions during the ice age of Communism. And American push helped bring the agricultural revolution that around the world makes brown fields green.
But by saying thou shalt and shalt not to people and nations working to spread birth control, America separated itself from them, even from many who felt forced to submit. The U.S. surrendered its full moral and leadership powers.
Now America is back, Mr. Clinton's account is greater, and the accumulating interest will be shared by many people in many choking nations.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: In Air, as at Bank, Deregulation Ends in Bailout

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Clinton Considers Measures to Help Troubled Airlines" (front-page, March 22) reports that the American taxpayer will be called upon to bail out the airline industry, in the same way as this long-suffering beast of burden has been called upon to bail out the savings and loan industry.
It is important to note that in both instances the initial damage was done by deregulating an industry that is structurally not suited to unregulated competition. 
 In the case of the savings and loan crisis, the greed of the managers and owners, like Charles H. Keating Jr. of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, was released from controls to the detriment of the depositors.
In the case of the airlines, the preponderance of fixed assets in the provision of services made it absolutely certain that individual carriers would engage in cut-throat competition and monopolistic practices that would seriously weaken the viability of the industry.
Do airline customers now pay retroactively as taxpayers for cheaper tickets in recent years? And will we, again as taxpayers, have to pay for past cost-cutting measures that also cut corners in airplane maintenance and gave us deteriorated service and jammed-together seats?
Further, will passengers now be called upon to make up for past losses by future ticket prices that are higher than they would have been if we had kept regulation? Where, then, have the much-touted benefits of misapplied market ideology gone?
It may turn out in the end that, as both passengers and taxpayers, we will pay more for flying around the country and the world than we would have if we had only let well enough alone.
 
RICHARD HYSE
St. Petersburg, Fla., March 26, 1993
 
The writer retired as a professor of economics at SUNY-Oswego.

HEADLINE: Wipe Draft Off Books In U.S., and the World

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Military conscription is a coercive act of government. It is an infringement of one's personal liberty, the taking away of the right to run one's own life.
The tolerance of military conscription by the people of the United States since the conclusion of World War II is beyond my comprehension. In high-technology modern warfare, there can be no possible need for conscription in the United States. 
 If the United States were to engage in war to protect its national interests, there would be more than enough volunteers, men and women, to fill the personnel needs of the armed services in combat and noncombat units.
President Clinton, who as a youth strongly opposed military conscription and who managed to avoid military service during the Vietnam War by taking advantage of the escape provisions in the Selective Service Act available to college students, is now in a position, as Commander in Chief of the United States armed forces, to lead the United States and the rest of the world away from military conscription.
And by so doing, he can also immeasurably improve the prospects for peace in the world.
I suggest that President Clinton and Congress take action immediately to put an end to the Military Selective Service Act, which was enacted during the Carter Administration, under which young men in the United States upon reaching the age of 18 are required to register for possible military service, even though no one has been drafted since the enactment of that law.
I further suggest that Mr. Clinton, as President, go in person before the United Nations and propose that all nations end military registration and conscription in whatever form and that the nations that end them then deny military, financial and economic assistance to all other nations that have military registration and conscription in any form, without exceptions.
 
CHARLES F. MC LAUGHLIN
Philadelphia, March 27, 1993

HEADLINE: Clinton and Perot Call Off Truce; Both Say, No More Mr. Nice Guy

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANNAPOLIS, Md., April 1

 BODY:
President Clinton and Ross Perot abruptly dropped all pretense of diplomacy today in a fit of cross-country name-calling that noisily shattered their uneasy peace.
In a speech at the United States Naval Academy here, Mr. Clinton said in response to a question that Mr. Perot had engaged in "rumor mongering" by repeating unflattering stories about the Administration's relations with the military. 
 Mr. Perot responded tartly in a telephone interview from Dallas, asserting that Mr. Clinton had "ducked" military service and thus lacked the moral authority to criticize an Army general who recently complained of poor treatment at the hands of a White House aide. "If he wants to climb into the ring," Mr. Perot said ominously, "any time, anywhere."
The flurry of invective between the two men, who have circled each other like prize fighters but largely avoided delivering any direct blows, was apparently unplanned. But the result was to effectively halt the tentative peace that Mr. Clinton and his aides had cultivated assiduously in hopes of attracting Mr. Perot's supporters.
Between the insults, Mr. Perot declared, "There's no bad blood as far as I'm concerned."
But the President was clearly piqued as he responded to a question about Mr. Perot during a question-and-answer session at a luncheon sponsored by the American Society of Newspaper Editors.
 
Perot Spoke Derisively
 "You know, Mr. Perot came to Washington the other day and attacked my chief of staff as not being a real business person, and he had to call him on the phone and personally apologize the next day," Mr. Clinton said. "I mean, people can say anything from the podium."
In an appearance before a Congressional committee early last month, Mr. Perot derided Mr. Clinton's energy-policy strategists as "poets, philosophers and beekeepers," adding, "Not one of them has ever run a business or created a job, far as I know."
Mr. Clinton went on today, "I'd be more interested in why my economic program -- which is 85 percent what Ross Perot recommended in the campaign, except we raised taxes less on the middle class and more on the wealthy and don't have unspecified health care savings -- hasn't been endorsed since it's almost identical to the one he ran on."
 
'His Plan Won't Work'
 Mr. Perot, in his strongest criticism of the economic plan to date, said he had no intention of endorsing Mr. Clinton's proposals.
"His plan won't work," Mr. Perot said. "His plan is going to drastically increase spending. It is not being candidly presented to the American people."
Of the deficit reduction plan in particular, he said: "Most of it is based on really tentative premises and guesses."
The shots across the bow, bitter in tone and apparently the result of frustration in both men, was long in coming. Mr. Clinton has taken some tiny digs at Mr. Perot in recent days.
At a black-tie dinner for radio and television correspondents on March 18, he wrapped his criticism in a joke. When Mr. Perot spoke of the lack of business experience in the Administration, Mr. Clinton took that as a slap at his childhood friend, Thomas F. McLarty Jr., who is the President's chief of staff and ran an energy company until recently.
"He just resents it because Mack's a short guy with real power," Mr. Clinton said.
 
Poll's Findings on Perot
 In the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, conducted Sunday through Wednesday, 42 percent of registered voters said they viewed Mr. Perot favorably, virtually unchanged from the 45 percent who said the same in January. The percentage of those who viewed him unfavorably remained fairly steady as well, at 26 percent in January and 23 percent in the new poll. Each poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Mr. Clinton's thin skin has apparently thinned more in recent days because of articles about his strained relations with the military, among other things..
Mr. Clinton seemed especially annoyed by Mr. Perot's repeating a widely circulated story that a member of the President's staff had refused to speak to a uniformed general on the White House grounds.
"The other story, like all those military stories, was an abject lie," he told the members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, who traveled here from their convention in Baltimore.
Mr. Clinton never served in the armed forces and was forced to defend himself through most of his campaign against accusations that he dodged the Vietnam-era draft.
The President, who has been struggling to establish a relationship with members of the military who oppose his plan to lift its ban against homosexuals, had lunch with 4,000 midshipmen at the Naval Academy today before speaking to the editors.
"I don't think we ought to be out here rumor-mongering myself," he added. "I think it does very little to support the public interest."
The officer, Lieut. Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, told The Washington Post in an article published today that the incident did occur. General McCaffrey went on to say, however, that the incident was overblown and that the resulting debate over the Clinton Adminstration's relationship with the military was a "grossly unfair rap."
In responding to Mr. Clinton's remarks today, Mr. Perot said the President had his facts wrong on the military story and when he asserted that the decision to remove United States Attorneys who were holdovers from the Bush Administration was not politically motivated.
"Nobody likes to be called a liar," Mr. Perot said in the telephone interview. "But to be called a liar by Bill Clinton is really a unique experience."

HEADLINE: Solid Quarter Led by Cyclical Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The first quarter brought smiles to many investors who owned shares listed on the New York Stock Exchange, especially in industries like semiconductors, energy and utilities.
The first three months of the year were less kind to small-capitalization Nasdaq issues, which cooled a bit after a record-breaking advance that had begun in early autumn. 
 And anyone who held medical-related stocks was badly hurt by the uncertainty surrounding the Clinton Administration's plans for reforming the health-care system.
 
A Solid Performance
 Spectacular winners and losers aside, the stock market's first-quarter performance was solid, as most stocks benefitted from a sharp fall in interest rates and signs that the economic recovery might be gathering momentum.
Of the more than 5,000 common stocks tracked by Media General Financial Services, stocks that rose in price during the quarter outnumbered declining issues by a ratio of almost two to one.
Much of the improvement was on the Big Board, where 1,341 stocks rose in price while just 529 fell. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 4.1 percent in the quarter, and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index rose by 3.7 percent.
But the gap between winners and losers on Nasdaq's over-the-counter system was closer, with 1,462 issues posting gains and 1,045 showing losses. The Nasdaq 100 average, a grouping that includes heavyweights like Apple Computer and Microsoft, fell by 1 percent. But the Nasdaq's broader composite index managed to rise by 1.9 percent.
On the American Stock Exchange, 325 stocks rose in the quarter and 193 declined. The exchange actually boasted the quarter's largest percentage gain, with its Wednesday close of 423.43 fully 6 percent higher than its Dec. 31 close of 399.23.
 
Semiconductors Soar
 Among industries, the quarter was a particularly good one for cyclical stocks, including energy, steel, automobiles and gold, that had previously underperformed. And it was an absolutely spectacular time to own shares in semiconductor stocks.
"Investment in labor-saving technology has been soaring for the last six quarters," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corporation. "That is being reflected in the earnings reports of these semiconductor companies."
Of the 88 industry groups represented in the S.&P. 500, semiconductor stocks did best, rising nearly 30 percent during the period. But of the top five, three were energy-related, all with gains of more than 20 percent. And gold stocks rose 20.6 percent.
"Energy stocks had been underowned, they offered high yields and the news on oil prices during the quarter stopped getting worse," said Byron Wein, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley. "Gold prices were unrealistically depressed by heavy liquidation in 1992."
Falling interest rates were a boon to utility and financial stocks. The Big Board's utility average rose 8.9 percent, while its index of financial stocks advanced 8.7 percent.
 
Health Care's Slide

 
 Lists of stocks that lost money during the quarter were littered with names of companies in health care. Five of the six worst-performing groups in the S.& P. 500 were related in one way or another to health care.
The worst were miscellaneous health care companies, like the biotech concern Amgen and the drug manufacturer Alza, whose stocks fell 37 percent during the quarter. Drug stocks crashed 14.9 percent, medical products and suppliers fell 14.1 percent, and hospital management companies slid 13.9 percent.
With interest rates on the rise, analysts were hesitant to predict the second quarter would be as strong as the first. "There is room for stocks to rise further," said A. Marshall Acuff, portfolio strategist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. "But any additional improvement will have to come from better corporate earnings."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 7, 1993, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Friday, with an article about stocks that posted the biggest gains and losses in the first quarter, included an erroneous entry for Humana Inc. supplied by Media General Financial Services. Humana split 2 for 1 in the first quarter when it spun off its hospital management company, Galen Health Care Inc. Thus Humana was not the stock showing the largest percentage decline on the New York Stock Exchange in the quarter.
In addition, the three charts with the article, showing the biggest gainers and losers on the New York and American stock exchanges and the Nasdaq market, mislabeled the quarter covered. It was the first.

HEADLINE: Single-Minded President;
White House Lacks Strength in Congress To Push More Than One Issue at a Time

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
The retreats and delays that are coming to exemplify the Clinton Administration's pursuit of its legislative agenda are rooted in one underlying fact: the White House is only strong enough to fight one battle at a time in Congress.
For the moment, that battle is over President Clinton's economic plan. Everything else -- even promises made dozens of times in the Presidential campaign and afterward -- is tied for second. 
 The main reason is in the arithmetic. The Democratic majorities are not so big that just a few defections do not mean trouble. Sometimes even Democratic unity is not enough, as today's deadlock in the Senate over passage of the President's stimulus package shows. The 43 Republicans are filibustering to prevent a vote on the $16.3 billion spending bill that Mr. Clinton says will spur the economy. [Page 10.]
 
Fear of Abandonment
 The Clinton Administration used the latest unemployment figures released today as ammunition in urging passage of the spending package, even though many analysts said they were reassured that the economic recovery was intact. The Labor Department reported that the number of payroll jobs fell slightly in March and that the nation's unemployment rate remained at 7 percent. [Page 7.]
After being starved for power for 12 Republican years, groups that supported Mr. Clinton distrust his single-mindedness on the economic front. They are besieging the Administration to put their fights first.
When they have to wait, they fear their concerns are being abandoned. This week environmentalists were outraged when the Administration retreated on its plan to change land-use practices by raising grazing rights fees and imposing mining royalties.
Those who want an overhaul of campaign-finance law see the indefinite delay on that issue as a wasted opportunity. Even advocates of anti-crime legislation or the North American Free Trade Agreement or homosexuals in the military wonder if the Administration's decision to delay action on their causes will hurt their chances.
The risk is that where the Administration sees strategic maneuvers others will see political cowardice.
Advocates of abortion rights, for example, watch the Administration sidestep other fights and wonder just how hard it will battle to repeal the ban on Federal financing of abortions for poor women. At the very least, such unease leads to more and more demands for quick action on favored issues.
And opponents of the Administration on various issues may become braver. "We were all concerned about his ability to say, 'No,' " Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the deputy Republican leader, said today at a breakfast with reporters.
But to the Administration, those risks are nothing compared with the risk of failing to obtain the economic package. As Leon E. Panetta, Director of the Office of Management and Budget, said, "Our No. 1 agenda here is keeping the focus on the economic plan."
That concentration echoes on Capitol Hill. "The primary purpose of this Congress is to address the economy, and the other issue is health care," said Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the House Democratic whip. "We're not going to get sidetracked by other issues."
 
Clinton's Role Defined
 And Mr. Clinton's influence is crucial. Without his pressure, said Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, "We're not to be trusted in terms of staying focused."
So if higher grazing fees or mining royalties threaten its passage, out they go. If the trade pact with Mexico and Canada looks like a distraction, it can be shoved back on the schedule, as the irritating issue of campaign financing has already been.
When Mr. Clinton was elected in November, and his party maintained control of both houses of Congress, the Democrats saw long-awaited opportunities on issues Republican Administration had kept off the table. But 57 Democrats in the Senate are not enough to break a filibuster without Republican help.
Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama usually votes with Republicans, so that leaves 56. And when several Western Democrats threatened to desert over mining and grazing charges, the Administration abandoned the fight for now.
The House, with 255 Democrats, provides only a slightly bigger margin of safety.
 
Lesson From History
 History plays a part. Mr. Panetta and others in the Administration acknowledge that they have learned a lesson from the Carter Administration, which began with 292 Democrats in the House and 61 in the Senate but which was judged a failure because of its scattered demands on Congress.
"The shadow of Carter haunts everyone," the budget director said. "There were so many different issues that they were working on and they took so many missteps at the start that they never were able to get their act together."
More recent history matters, too. The Clinton campaign succeeded when it concentrated, and especially when it concentrated on the economy. "They get very nervous about getting off that focus," said Representative Sam Gejdenson, Democrat of Connecticut, who is in charge of campaign-finance bills in the House.
Representative Miller, who heads the Natural Resources Committee and is a critic of the decision on mining and grazing, agreed. He said he knew that the Administration was working behind the scenes to prepare bills on other difficult issues, but that the message it wanted understood by the public was "do only one thing at a time."
 
A Matter of Scale
 Mr. Miller said that while he disagreed, he understood the White House's thinking on putting the success of the budget package ahead of quick change in grazing and mineral charges. "On their radar screen, one was an aircraft carrier and the other was a rowboat."
Now the focus is the economy. Later this year it will be health care, although perhaps only in extended hearings, not floor action.
There will be time to deal with other tough issues, from the ban on homosexuals in the armed forces to abortion to campaign finance to mining laws. But supporters behind all of these measures may find themselves competing for attention and a prime place on the calendar.

HEADLINE: $9.6 Billion Package for M.T.A. Is Crucial to Its Rebuilding Plans

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
The budget agreement in Albany that gives the Metropolitan Transportation Authority virtually all of the $9.6 billion it requested for a rebuilding program over the next five years promises a smoother trip for mass-transit riders in the New York metropolitan region.
One in every five New York City subway stations will be renovated, an automated fare-card system will be paid for and 88 miles of subway track -- 13 percent of the system -- will be replaced, among other measures in the plan. It also calls for 144 new train cars and 40 new locomotives for the Long Island Rail Road and 200 miles of new track for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.
 
Safer and More Reliable
 M.T.A. executives say the plan, which follows two previous five-year plans, each for about $8 billion, is critical to making the New York regional transportation system safer and more reliable. 
 The city's subway and bus systems, which together carry more than 3.5 million riders daily, suffered badly in the 1970's as the city's fiscal crisis and other financial problems prevented even routine maintenance.
Advocates of mass transportation feared that a cycle of neglect would begin again because of the recent recession and a sense that a great deal of money had already been invested on upgrading buses, subways and the two commuter lines.
"A year ago, people thought that we faced a period of disinvestment," said Gene Russianoff, senior attorney for the Straphanger's Campaign, an advocacy group for subway riders. "I'm glad to see that it's not happening."
The agreement in Albany, part of a massive transportation financing package reached on Thursday as part of a budget accord between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders, also pledges to save the $1.25 subway and bus fare for the next two years.
A fare increase is now planned for 1995, and M.T.A. officials hope that by then, after automatic fare cards for subways and buses are in use, riders will be more willing to accept the increase. Although details of the agreement were still being discussed yesterday, legislators and transit officials said that they expected the accord to hold.
They also said that public pressure for spending on transit, together with a slight improvement in state revenue projections, helped make an accord possible between the Republican-led Senate and the Democratic-led Assembly, which often splits on upstate vs. downstate concerns.
The agreement, a complex patchwork of financing that involves dozens of sources of money, much of it borrowed, is also a personal victory for Peter E. Stangl, the chairman of the M.T.A. He lobbied hard to prevent the Governor and the Legislature from scaling back the rebuilding program, or putting it off altogether.
"My concern was that some people might think it was already done," Mr. Stangl said yesterday. "But this is great. It's a recognition of how important transit is to how we live our lives, and how important transit is to keeping our region competitive."
In the M.T.A.'s two previous capital plans, shiny new subway cars brought a visible improvement to the underground network. The new cars break down far less often than the old ones, are air-conditioned and are generally free of graffiti.
In contrast, many of the items in the new plan will be invisible to ordinary riders. For example, $564 million will replace subway tracks and switches, $455 million will buy new signal lights and $518 million will rebuild bus depots.
 
Budget Discussions Continue
 In Albany yesterday, budget discussions continued as lawmakers worked out details of the $32 billion budget deal so that the Legislature could begin to vote on the package. Negotiators said they hoped to finish voting before Monday, when Passover begins.
But lawmakers also said that a Court of Appeals decision declaring that an important part of the way that New York State puts together its budgets is unconstitutional might cause some delays because lawmakers would have to rewrite much of their budget language.
While the rebuilding program also covers buses and commuter rails, $7.4 billion of the $9.6 billion plan will go for subways, the costliest and oldest arm of the city's transit system.
Mr. Stangl warned that details of the plan's financing are not yet final. For example, the plan's $9.6 billion anticipates a $500 million contribution from New York City that the Dinkins administration says it cannot afford.
The plan also relies on money from a $700 million transportation fund, misnamed a "locked box" fund because it was originally intended for transportation purposes only.
As part of this year's budget agreement, Governor Cuomo is taking $516 of the $700 million fund and using it to help cover the state's budget deficit. Much of the remainder of the fund will be used to pay debt service on the hundreds of millions of dollars worth of bonds that will finance the rebuilding plan. But enough money remains for the rebuilding program, transportation officials say.
 
'Division of Funds'
 "I was very disappointed about the diversion of funds," said Assemblyman Michael J. Bragman, chairman of the Assembly's Transportation Committee. "But in the end, this is a package that is more than we believed could happen."
The M.T.A. did not get everything it wanted, Mr. Stangl said. For example, the Legislature refused to grant the M.T.A. the financial flexibility to transfer surplus money from its profitable commuter rails to help finance the subway system.
But the plan will enable the Transit Authority to begin more than a dozen projects as soon as the coming weeks and months. One of those projects is a $15.5 million plan to install a system of signal lights that limit the speed of subway trains as they approach certain stations, including the 14th Street-Union Square station, where a subway accident killed five passengers and injured more than 200 in August 1991.
"Replacing signals doesn't sound so important," Mr. Russianoff said. "But when you have an accident because they are faulty, that's when you understand why this plan is so critical."

HEADLINE: PHILIP MORRIS CUTS CIGARETTE PRICES, STUNNING MARKET

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
The Philip Morris Companies yesterday cut the price of its Marlboro cigarettes, the world's best-selling brand, in an acknowledgment that its flagship product was threatened by competition from discount brands and the changing habits of smokers.
The reduction of some 40 cents a pack will lower the price to a national retail average of $1.80, including excise taxes. The move startled investors, who knocked $14.75 off the price of Philip Morris shares, to $49.375. 
 The collapse of other tobacco stocks and a bond market rout contributed to a broader selloff in the stock market, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 68.63 points. [Page 43.]
Lesser price cuts will extend to other Philip Morris brands. In explaining the reductions, company executives cited gains by discount and generic labels costing as little as 89 cents a pack and an economy that remains weaker than they had expected.
 
Change in Buying Patterns
 The executives also conceded that many consumers had changed their buying patterns, balking at huge premiums for prominent brands and dropping their allegiance once they sniffed better value elsewhere. Marlboro's national market share has fallen to 22.2 percent, from 24.3 percent last year.
The tobacco industry is also under siege from the Clinton Administration, which is considering an increase of as much as $2 a pack in the 24-cent Federal tobacco tax to discourage smoking and pay for changes in the health care system. And some states plan sharp increases in their cigarette taxes; Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has proposed a 21-cent increase, to 60 cents.
Analysts predicted much greater competition in the tobacco industry, which has long been able to raise prices far above the rate of inflation. They said sharp price cuts were all but certain.
"It is a price war," said Leigh Ferst of Prudential Securities. "Some people think it's just a battle, but it's really a war."
The Marlboro cigarette is the world's best-selling consumer product. Annual sales of six billion packs in the United States nearly match the sales of the next five brands combined. Philip Morris said its operating profits from United States tobacco sales would fall this year by as much as 40 percent, or $2 billion, as a result of the price cuts and greater competition.
Smaller savings, on average, will extend to other Philip Morris brands, including Merit, Parliament, Benson & Hedges and Virginia Slims. The savings will show up during the next few weeks through a variety of special offers as well as some direct price reductions.
Company officials spoke carefully of their moves as special promotions rather than permanent reductions, but specified no time limits. They said they would issue discount coupons, send special offers through the mail and cut wholesale prices in some instances, giving smokers an average savings of about 40 cents a pack. These actions will allow the company to formally maintain its current wholesale prices.
Executives at Philip Morris's main competitor, the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, which makes Camel, Winston, Salem and other brands, said they had not worked out details of their response but would defend their brands.
James W. Johnston, the chairman and chief executive of Reynolds, a unit of RJR Nabisco Inc., promised shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday that the company would take "appropriate steps to maintain its competitive positions in every segment of the market."
 
 
Assailed by Health Advocates
 Health groups attacked the Marlboro price cuts as an effort to lure more young smokers before new taxes take effect.
"Virtually all new users of Marlboro start as teen-agers or younger," said Matthew Myers, speaking for an antismoking coalition of the American Cancer, Heart and Lung associations. "It's that market that they're trying to expand and addict before the Federal Government increases the tax."
Philip Morris executives, who have denied aiming their products at young smokers, said they were responding entirely to business rivalry in a slack economy.
"Our strategy today is designed to deal with a competitive marketplace," said William I. Campbell, chief executive of Philip Morris USA. "It has no relation to the Federal excise tax."
In a recent test of the 40-cent price cut in Portland, Ore., the company gained four percentage points in market share, he said. With a lower price, he said, the brand can still gain customers at a substantial premium over discount labels, which have an average price of about $1.20.
"It is certainly not our intention to start a price war," Mr. Campbell said. "Quite the opposite."
Philip Morris, Reynolds and most other makers of high-priced cigarettes also sell discount brands, either under retailers' labels or as generic brands. From 1 percent of sales in 1982, these products have grown to about 36 percent, slowing the nation's overall decline in smoking.
Mr. Campbell blamed RJR Nabisco especially for pitching the industry into intense price competition, telling industry analysts that Reynolds was selling discount cigarettes for 99 cents at 71 percent of the stores Philip Morris checked.
Tobacco companies maintain that their premium cigarettes have premium ingredients: a higher proportion of American tobacco, Mr. Campbell said. But most of the higher price of premium brands represents marketing costs as well as substantial profits, which analysts estimate at about 56 cents a pack for Marlboros, before taxes, overhead and interest. The 40-cent price cut will probably not reduce the company's profit margin to 16 cents, they say, because sales volume is expected to increase.
Philip Morris, based in New York City, last year sold about $59 billion worth of Cheez Whiz, Miller beer, Maxwell House coffee, Kraft foods and dozens of other immediately recognized products -- a volume far greater than any competing maker of consumer goods.
The company calls Marlboro "the world's most valuable trademark," a boast that only the Coca-Cola Company might dispute. The brand is still personified by the rough-hewn cowboys featured in billions of dollars' worth of advertising. In much of the world, the red and white packs are virtually legal tender.

HEADLINE: Clinton Under Crossfire At Logging Conference

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., April 2

 BODY:
President Clinton and nearly a third of his Cabinet huddled around a wooden table here today to hear about old trees, diminishing salmon and a logger named Buzz.
The President's one-day forest conference, intended to solve an extraordinary regional conflict that has drawn the highest levels of government into its fray, left an impression that the public forests of the Pacific Northwest will not be reopened to large-scale logging. The forest have been off-limits to logging under court injunctions on behalf of rare fish and wildlife species, threatening the jobs of thousands of timber workers. 
 At the end of the day, Mr. Clinton said he would ask his Cabinet to bring him, within 60 days, a proposal to end the stalemate. He said the Cabinet's solution would have to insure the long-term health of the forests and the economic stability of communities that rely on timber.
And while he suggested that the Government would quickly try to get some timber to small mills suffering from shortages of logs, he said much of what is causing the turmoil was a result of historical forces affecting other parts of the nation's economy: increased productivity with fewer workers.
 
'Laws of Change'
 "I cannot repeal the laws of change," Mr. Clinton said, hinting that the age of big timber in the Northwest may be drawing to an end.
As loggers marched outside with signs asking Mr. Clinton to help their families, the President heard impassioned pleas to save marbled murrelets, coho salmon, spotted owls and other creatures that are dependent on some of the nation's last stands of old-growth forests.
With today's conference, which fulfills a campaign promise, Mr. Clinton has put the full power of the Presidency into what has seemed to be an intractable dispute. He has also exposed the cracks and tension within the Democratic Party between labor and environmental interests.
On Thursday night, 60,000 people gathered in the rain to demonstrate support of the ancient forests.
Today, thousands of loggers, who were given the day off from their mills, gathered here to appeal to Mr. Clinton to remove some of the environmental restrictions that have hurt their livelihoods.
Seated with Vice President Al Gore, four Cabinet members and two-dozen guests for a series of discussions, the President heard a mix of obscure forestry talk and heart-breaking family tales. A historian said that Northwesterners were "a people possessed by nature," and that the feud over what to do with much of that nature was tearing the region apart.
The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Seattle, Thomas J. Murphy, brought religion to an issue usually dominated by talk of board feet and spotted owl habits. "There are moral values in preserving forests," he said. "The timber crisis is a moral issue."
The President heard about Zane Grey, the early 20th-century outdoor writer, who used to catch big fish in Deer Creek, a stream north of Seattle now denuded by erosion from logging. And he heard loggers compared to the trailblazers who came here 150 years ago in the first year of the Oregon Trail.
"I cut trees for a living, just like my father and my grandfather did before me," said Buzz Eades, a logger from Redding, Calif. "I like to think that some of the trees that started life when my grandfather was cutting are old growth today. Mr. President, you are going to be old growth some day, too." His last remark brought laughter from the President.
 
Competing Industries
 Mr. Eades said some of his friends, "modern Paul Bunyans," as he called them, are on food stamps.
But much of that same logging is killing what was once a great salmon fishing industry, said Nat Bingham, a commercial fisherman.
"If we don't do something now to protect salmon habitat we will be listing species under the Endangered Species Act that will make the owl restrictions pale by comparison," he said.
Some of the nation's environmental leaders, angry over Mr. Clinton's decision earlier this week to delay changes in how Western lands are used, told the President that they would not retreat on the forest issue.
"In the last two months, I have spent more time inside the White House than I have in the last 12 years," Jay Hair, President of the National Wildlife Federation told reporters before the conference. "But what started out as a love affair is now looking like it may turn out to be more like date rape."
 
Labor Looks for a Favor
 But labor leaders, who supported Mr. Clinton here, also hinted that the President owed them a favor.
"Mr. President, Mr. Vice President, you campaigned on the pledge to put people first," said Mike Draper of the Western Council of Industrial Workers, which represents mill workers.
White House officials say the results of this conference will set the stage for future clashes in the country.
"This is critical to the political future of the West," said Representative Peter A. DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon. "Democrats are more at risk than anybody else. We have a tradition of standing up for the environment and for working people."
White House aides say Mr. Clinton is not likely to propose changes in the Endangered Species Act or the National Forest Management Act, which environmentalists have used to halt timber harvesting.
There was also a brief exchange of regional pride. Mr. Clinton said Arkansas had the fastest-growing trees. After lunch, a panelist said, "With all due respect, Mr. President, we grow the fastest trees here."

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
The Spotlight, Again, Falls on Yeltsin

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 2

 BODY:
In principle, it is President Clinton who should be under scrutiny at this summit meeting, the newcomer making his first appearance in the Big Game. In fact, the world will probably once again be trying to figure out his partner, the big, puffy-eyed Russian just in from another brawl.
From the time he first clambered into the Kremlin over the rubble of the Soviet state that he helped to destroy, Boris N. Yeltsin always seems to be dashing from one barricade to another, usually portrayed by his lieutenants as the only viable obstacle to the return of the Bolsheviks. 
 Already before arriving in Vancouver, Mr. Clinton appears to have accepted that for now, at least, Mr. Yeltsin probably represents Russia's best hope. But his personal assessment, once he meets Mr. Yeltsin face to face, might well shape the future of American involvement in Russia's tortuous transition.
If previous impressions of Mr. Yeltsin are any guide, Mr. Clinton is not likely to emerge with a clear image. To many in the West, as in Russia, the large maverick who evolved from the Communist boss of Sverdlovsk into the executioner of the Communist empire remains something of an enigma.
He is the only leader ever elected by all Russia. He is the man who defied the Bolsheviks from atop a tank during the hard-line Communist coup in 1991, who was bold enough to break the state control on prices and to let radical, pro-Western intellectuals begin an economic revolution. He is the politician who has singlehandedly blocked reactionary deputies from power, who has firmly declared that Russia must enter into the league of democratic powers.
But this is the same man who rides roughshod over his legislature and the Constitution in the name of democracy, who nearly declared emergency rule, who came within a few votes of being thrown out of office, who is said to drink too much, who is openly disdained by his Vice President and many former allies.
In the end, Mr. Clinton will probably end up backing Mr. Yeltsin for the same reason that thousands of Russians, many of them veteran "democrats" who had begun to despair of Mr. Yeltsin, hit the streets again last week to chant his name and cheer his political survival.
Whatever most of them thought of Mr. Yeltsin personally, or of his record, or of his policies, the Congress of People's Deputies underscored that for now, at least, the choice is between a legislature packed with neo-Bolsheviks, nationalists and old apparatchiks and a President who has vowed to wrench Russia from their hands.
 
Attacks Boost His Standing
 The more dramatic the contrast, it seemed, the greater Mr. Yeltsin's support. As the delegate from Voronezh noted with some surprise, every time the Congress convened and attacked Mr. Yeltsin for his "anti-people reforms," his ratings increased. The greater the attack, the higher his ratings.
Thus his narrow escape from ouster last week may paradoxically prove to be Mr. Yeltsin's greatest strength in the referendum to which the Congress agreed for April 25. In technical terms, Mr. Yeltsin stands no chance of winning, since the deputies so stacked the rules that unless he takes virtually all the votes cast in the question of confidence in him, he will formally lose.
But in moral terms, Mr. Yeltsin has come out where he is at his best: in opposition. By assailing him so directly and unconditionally, the Congress has enabled him once again to rouse his legions with images of Communist plots and coups.
Whatever the outcome on April 25, it is certain that his lieutenants will lustily proclaim victory and try to push through another round of economic reforms before the Congress regroups and resumes its offensive. In the end, the feud is likely to end only when the Congress finally agrees to new elections.
Until then, the Congress is not likely to rest in its efforts to wrest Mr. Yeltsin's powers from him, and those who see in the Congress the face of reaction have to stay loyal to his banner.
That is not to say that Russians still feel the same passionate loyalty that Mr. Yeltsin inspired when he first raised the banner against the Communists. Many of the "democrats" who put him in power 22 months ago now openly criticize him, and almost all of the lieutenants he originally brought with him into the Kremlin are now gone -- some as sacrifices to his political adversaries. Of those remaining, most have turned against him, like Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi and Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, the Speaker of Parliament.
Though Mr. Yeltsin is hailed for the courage he showed in freeing prices on Jan. 1, 1992, he is criticized by more radical economists like Grigory A. Yavlinsky for the inconsistency of reforms since. Privatization, monetary reform and military conversion have moved at a snail's pace.
Much of the problem, of course, has come from the resistance of the bureaucracy and the Congress, and from the very novelty of the process. But Mr. Yeltsin is also accused of failing to work out a broad strategy for his reform.
Mr. Yeltsin has also been accused of wavering on the political front. Only in the last month, he declared "special rule" and then drew it back, demanded a referendum and then told the Congress he was willing to bargain it away. Meeting with President Francois Mitterrand of France, he said foreign aid was critical, then at the Congress he said it had been an error to put "excessive hope in foreign aid."
His behavior has given rise to charges that he allows himself to be manipulated by whoever is currently near him.
Certainly he remains a far less defined politician than Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union. Mr. Gorbachev was a natural favorite for the West -- decisive, quick, charming, proud, an obvious leader.
 
A Mass of Contradictions
 Mr. Yeltsin, despite a detailed autobiography and regular public appearances, is still something of an enigma. He is clearly more comfortable than Mr. Gorbachev among common people, but he reveals little of himself and has cultivated a presidential aloofness in his formal appearances.
He has a reputation for keen political instinct. But in recent months he has also been accused more than once of snatching defeat from the jaws of victory, of letting personal feelings drive him to confrontation when a compromise was in his interest. A sudden, emotional appearance before the Congress last week was a case in point -- his hair out of place, a hint of inebriation, a sudden and dramatic shift of course, a populist appeal to dispense with all the politics and closet all the leaders for a week or until they came up with a compromise.
The result was a hurried overnight deal that only reopened the question of his ouster. Mr. Yeltsin later said he had not slept three days out of grief over his mother. His spokesman said he had played tennis that day. Opposition deputies hammered at his purported drinking.
But in that clumsy incident also lay the key to Mr. Yeltsin's abiding public support. To many Russians, he remains a personification precisely of the ambivalence and confusion in which they all live, and of an abiding faith that somewhere beyond lies a happier world.
And however harshly his record is criticized, the real question is whether anybody else could have done more. It has been Mr. Yeltsin's lot, after all, to preside over an extraordinary transition, for which no one had a blueprint. That Russia has not turned into a huge Switzerland overnight is no surprise; what is extraordinary is that despite all the chaos and hardship, Mr. Yeltsin is still by far the most popular man in Russia.

HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT;
19 Western Nations Give Russia An Extra 10 Years to Repay Debt

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 2

 BODY:
In an important boost for President Boris N. Yeltsin just one day before he meets President Clinton, 19 Western creditor nations today gave Russia an extra 10 years to make $15 billion worth of debt payments that are coming due this year.
The so-called Paris Club of creditors, which include the United States, also went out of their way to stress "their continuing support for the Russian reform process launched and guided by President Yeltsin" and held out the possibility of further debt relief in 1994. 
 Although the rescheduling agreement announced today involves only part of Russia's $80 billion foreign debt, financial experts said it should make it easier for Mr. Yeltsin to obtain much-needed new credits from the West to finance his efforts to modernize the Russian economy.
The negotiations had dragged on for over a year, complicated by a financial dispute between Russia and Ukraine over assets of the former Soviet Union, but all parties were apparently eager to reach an accord before Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Clinton discuss Russia's economic crisis at their summit meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia this weekend.
 
$100 Billion Price Tag
 Before leaving Moscow tonight, Mr. Yeltsin said Russia needed more than the $1 billion in direct American aid expected to be offered by Mr. Clinton. "West Germany, in order to cope with the Communist hydra in East Germany, invested $100 billion," he told reporters. "That's the price of it."
The agreement today should also help the Group of Seven industrialized nations to come up with a new aid package for Russia when their Finance and Foreign Ministers meet in Tokyo on April 14 and 15.
A statement issued by the French Economy Ministry said the 19 creditor nations had welcomed Russia's "efforts at economic recovery" and called for acceleration of economic reforms so that Moscow could draw credits already approved by the International Monetary Fund.
The creditors, comprising the United States, Japan, Canada, Australia and 15 Western European nations, also noted that the agreement today should help bring about a similar agreement between Russia and its commercial bank creditors. Russia owes about $40 billion to governments, $20 billion to commercial banks and the rest to international organizations.
 
Russian Acknowledges Debt
 The statement said the Russian delegation, which was headed by Deputy Prime Minister Aleksandr N. Shokhin, had acknowledged the "validity" of this debt and had reaffirmed Russia's responsibility for repayment of the entire foreign debt that it inherited from the former Soviet Union. Russia has accepted the lion's share of the Soviet foreign debt, with other former Soviet republics assuming the remainder.
The details of the accord permitting Moscow to postpone its debt payments have not been released.
Arrears on its debt servicing payments had prompted both the United States and Canada to freeze new grain credits to Russia. It was also unclear whether these credits will be released after the agreement today.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Canada Unveils Aid Package
 VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 2 (Special to The New York Times) -- Anticipating the type of help President Clinton may offer on a larger scale this weekend, Canada announced a $200 million Russia aid package today consisting mainly of food credits and technical assistance to speed the Russian transition to democracy and a market economy.
Among the projects included in the Canadian aid package are a new Canada-Russia Private Sector Partnership for management training and financial services, establishment of Russian Project Finance Bank to provide financing medium-sized loans to support privatization, and a program to help Russia modernize its oil and gas industry and improve the grain distribution systems.
Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said that while the Canadian assistance is relatively small in dollar terms, if replicated by other industrial countries it would have "real impact."
