HEADLINE: TOWARD THE SUMMIT: The High Stakes in Vancouver;
Clinton Believes His Own Program Is Tied to Russian Reform

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., April 2

 BODY:
President Clinton appears to be approaching the summit meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia on Saturday with an odd mix of feelings: a sense of urgency, a sense of opportunity and an unspoken fear that no matter what help he offers Mr. Yeltsin it won't make a difference.
The urgency derives from the President's stated conviction that if the United States does not do what it can to bolster Mr. Yeltsin, and Russian reform falters, Mr. Clinton's ability to slash his own military budget and get his own economic program through Congress will be imperiled. 
 In Mr. Clinton's view, aides say, the core of the Russian-American relationship has been fundamentally altered -- from one focused on reducing the threat of mutual annihilation to one focused on reducing the threat of soaring budget deficits in both countries.
More than any other in history, this summit meeting is going to be about balance sheets, not the balance of power. That is why for the first time the American President will be accompanied to a summit meeting by his Secretary of the Treasury.
 
Long Turmoil Predicted
 The opportunity for Mr. Clinton is to use the Vancouver summit meeting to establish himself finally as a credible statesman and leader of the Western alliance, something he has yet to do given his almost single-minded focus on domestic affairs. At a time when some in the military have questioned Mr. Clinton's credentials as Commander in Chief, his ability to assert leadership of the Western alliance takes on added political importance.
The sense of foreboding around the White House springs from a ream of intelligence reports suggesting that even if Mr. Yeltsin survives the latest power struggle, and the betting in the Administration is that he will, Russia will be in political turmoil for years. That will not only be a foreign affairs problem for Mr. Clinton, but also a domestic one.
Indeed, one cannot understand Mr. Clinton's feeling of urgency about helping Russian reform without understanding that he sees this issue as an adjunct of his domestic agenda. At its crudest, the White House logic goes like this: No Russian reform, no American defense cuts; no defense cuts, no chance for the Clinton Administration to deliver on its pledge to halve the budget deficit in four years; no dealing with the deficit, no re-election.
 
Stable Russia Is Key
 The whole Clinton proposal to slash $122 billion from the Defense Department budget by 1998 is built around the assumption that Russia will continue moving, with the inevitable bumps, toward a more open, democratic and free-market society that will not threaten the United States.
As Mr. Clinton said in his speech in Annapolis on Thursday, "If Russia were to revert to imperialism or were to plunge into chaos, we would need to reassess all our plans for defense savings." And if that happens, said Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, "you're going to throw the whole Clinton economic plan into a tailspin."
The aid package that President Clinton will present to Mr. Yeltsin on Saturday is tailored to help keep Russia on the general path toward reform. It is based on two approaches, which Mr. Clinton outlined to President Yeltsin in phone conversation on Thursday night.
The first involves roughly $1 billion in American aid in the form of grass-roots programs to help key political groups in Russia -- from army officers, to farmers to emerging capitalists -- on the assumption that if enough of them can be given a stake in the free market, Russia will inevitably move in that direction no matter who is in the Kremlin. Mr. Clinton has spurred other major Western allies to announce similar aid packages in the next few days, as Canada did today.
 
Rescheduling of Debt
 The second approach involves an American-led effort to get the Group of Seven major industrialized democracies to reschedule some of Russia's $80 billion in foreign debts, as the Paris Club of creditor nations began doing today. In addition, Mr. Clinton is proposing that the Group of Seven come forward with some sort of currency stabilization program that would be run by the International Monetary Fund. But this depends on Mr. Yeltsin's first getting control of his country's runaway money supply, which he and Mr. Clinton will discuss on Saturday.
In trying to persuade the American people to support some $1 billion in fresh American aid for Russia next year -- at a time when they are being asked to pay higher taxes and give up some domestic programs -- Mr. Clinton has relied heavily on economic arguments.
When asked in an interview with CBS News last week why Americans should aid Russia, the first thing Mr. Clinton said was: "America needs good customers for its products, and Russia -- a free Russia -- with a free economy, would prefer to do business with America over any other country. Every year we have to be looking ahead to find more and more markets for our products, because if we get drawn into the global economy, we've got to sell more to other people to keep our incomes high."
Some analysts argue, though, that Mr. Clinton, in his zeal to persuade the American people to support aid for Russia because it will be good business, or because reversion to a non-democratic Russia will bust America's defense budget, is dangerously exaggerating.
"Clinton and his people are saying deceptive things that are going to come back to haunt them," Stephen M. Meyer, an expert on the Russian military at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said. "The fact is Yeltsin is going to go someday, and probably soon, and when he does it is not going to be a pretty sight, and even if he stays it may not be a pretty sight. And then the right-wing in our country is going to say to Clinton, 'Well, you said it, now we need more defense spending.' "
 
Russian Military No Threat
 The fact is, Mr. Meyer said, that "if Stalin himself were to come back from the grave and return to power tomorrow" he would find that he could not pose any serious military threat to the United States.
The Russian military, he said, is in disarray. The Warsaw Pact military alliance is gone forever, Ukraine made off with the best of the Soviet Union's defense industries, land force equipment and strategic rocket forces, and the Russian Navy has virtually stopped all ship repairs, meaning many vessels are simply rusting and rotting.
True, Mr. Meyer added, Russia still has its nuclear arsenal, but those are purely doomsday weapons, which no Russian leader is likely to deploy. "Clinton should not have to deceive the American people to give Russia aid," Mr. Meyer said.
That is not advice Mr. Clinton is going to take, for part of his eagerness to put an aid package on the table, and demonstrate that he is aggressively supporting Mr. Yeltsin, is also to inoculate himself from any future "Who lost Russia?" finger-pointing. Which is a reminder that this summit meeting is not just about shoring up Mr. Yeltsin, it is also about showcasing Mr. Clinton as a world leader.
Just as President Bush established himself as the leader of the Western alliance at his shipboard summit meeting off Malta with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in December 1989, so Clinton aides hope the same will happen to their boss as a result of Vancouver.
But that will not be so easy. Mr. Bush asserted his leadership of the alliance by making a series of radical proposals at the Malta meeting to cut conventional and strategic arms, almost all of which belonged to the United States and meant saving billions of dollars. Mr. Clinton is hoping to assert himself by using Vancouver to take the lead in persuading the Group of Seven major industrialized democracies to increase their aid to Russia.
But, as Clinton aides concede, that will require spending other people's money. In particular, it will require persuading Germany, which holds 60 percent of the $80 billion Soviet debt, to be more forgiving and for Japan to be more forthcoming.
All the allies were ready to follow Mr. Bush down a road to a safer Europe, more free of weapons. But will they follow Mr. Clinton down a road of more aid to Russia, in which Washington gives a little and some allies are asked to give a lot?

HEADLINE: Big Selloffs in Stock and Bond Markets;
Tobacco Shares Pull Others Down; Dow Loses 68.63

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The stock market fell sharply yesterday, pulled down by plunging tobacco shares and rising interest rates.
Heavy selling in cable television stocks also put pressure on prices. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average posted its second-biggest loss this year, falling 68.63 points, or 2 percent, to 3,370.81. Broader market indexes fell as well.
Leading yesterday's rout was Philip Morris, which plummeted 14 3/4, or 23 percent, to close at 49 3/8. That decline alone clipped more than 30 points off the Dow.
Stocks were shaken further by heavy selling in the bond market, which pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond up to 7.05 percent, as new employment figures raised further fears of inflation.
Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange was very heavy yesterday, at 325.3 million shares. The selloff in tobacco stocks accounted for more than 20 percent of the total.
But analysts were not ready to predict that stocks would continue to fall. "It was a collection of unhappy events, but they did not represent a change in the bull market trend," said Stefan D. Abrams, a managing director of the Trust Company of the West, an investment firm.
Indeed, the Dow is still well above its Dec. 31 closing of 3,301.11. The other bad day this year came on Feb. 16, when the Dow plunged 82.94 points, or 2.5 percent, only to rise slightly the following day.
"Typically, major price movements this year have been one-day events," said David G. Shulman, chief of equity strategy at Salomon Brothers.
The plunge in Philip Morris came after it announced before the market opened that it would cut 40 cents from the price of its flagship Marlboro brand to stave off competition from generic brand cigarettes. The announcement came as a surprise, and the company's stock immediately fell after it opened at 10:30 A.M., an hour late.
Philip Morris was the most heavily traded stock, at 34.3 million shares, and its 14 3/4-point drop knocked $13 billion off its total market value.
Other tobacco companies, including Loews, RJR Nabisco, UST and American Brands, were also big losers. Loews fell 16 3/8, to 94, while RJR dropped 1 1/4, to 6 3/4; UST, 3 1/8, to 26, and American Brands, 3 3/4, to 30.
"This was the day that Philip Morris acknowledged that it had to take drastic steps to counter the inroads of the less expensive generic cigarettes," Mr. Abrams said. "Heretofore, the company had left Wall Street with the impression that it had this problem under control."
Meanwhile, the Government's report on March employment yesterday shook up Wall Street. Traders had expected a rise in the number of new jobs. Instead, jobs disappeared in March. But a revision for January showed that jobs had grown much more than the Labor Department had originally reported.
Some people sold stocks in response to the unexpectedly gloomy March number, which suggested that the economic recovery might not be so strong, analysts said. Others, however, took the January revision as a sign that a higher inflation rate might be ahead; so they sold, too.
 
 
'A No-Win Situation'
 "The job report was pretty much a no-win situation," Matthew Finick, an analyst at Birinyi Associates, said.
Rising commodity prices also fed the concern about inflation, as did yesterday's rise in interest rates. Stock prices have gone up fairly steadily over the last two years, partly because people switched money into stocks from Treasury securities and corporate bonds. With interest rates falling for Treasuries and bonds, investors had sought better earnings in the stock market.
Yesterday, however, new signs of inflation and the rise in interest rates made stocks seem less appealing, analysts said.
 
Cable Television Issues Fall
 Cable television stocks came under severe pressure after the Federal Communications Commission ordered sweeping cuts in consumers' cable rates. Time Warner, for example, was down 2 1/4, to 30. In Nasdaq trading, Tele-Communications fell 2 3/8, to 18 1/8, and Comcast Communications lost 2 5/8, to 16 3/8. The drop in Tele-Communications and Comcast helped to bring down the Nasdaq composite index by 16.79 points, or 2.45 percent, to 669.85.
There were other casualties. Rising silver prices hurt Eastman Kodak, which uses silver in manufacturing film. Its stock fell by 2, to 52 1/2.
President Clinton's visit to Oregon lumber country made investors nervous about forest product companies, and several lost ground. Weyerhaeuser took the biggest hit, falling 2 1/4, to 39 1/8.
Some computer industry stocks also dropped, in part because Conner Peripherals, a disk drive manufacturer, reported that its first-quarter earnings would be poor.
And program trading added to the decline. Three sell programs involving futures contracts, offset by only one buy program, resulted in a 19-point loss in the Dow, Birinyi Associates reported.
The market's retreat was broad-based. Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 8.91 points, to 441.39. The number of declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange overpowered the number that rose, with 1,614 down and 397 up. On the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 5.25, to 417.52.

HEADLINE: At Impasse on Jobs Bill, Senate Quarrels Instead

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Frozen in filibuster just 42 days into its legislative year, the Senate dropped all pretense of debating President Clinton's jobs bill today and instead fell to squabbling over whose foot is dragging most.
Democrats and Republicans alike have jumped into the fray with such gusto that it seemed questionable whether they would quit any time soon, even though their two-week vacation was supposed to begin this evening. 
 In a day clogged with news conferences, Democrats accused Republicans of blocking a vote on Mr. Clinton's $16.3 billion package by proposing an endless chain of amendments to the bill, each requiring seemingly endless debate.
Republicans complained that Democrats were really the ones responsible for the bottleneck, wielding the Senate's maze of procedural rules to keep their amendments from being offered, much less debated. And they noted that since the Senate took the bill up eight days ago, Democrats have talked more than twice as much as they have.
This afternoon, the Democrats tried to cut the argument off and force a reasonably quick vote on the jobs bill. But the attempt foundered by a largely partisan vote of 55 to 43, well short of the 60 votes it needed.
 
Try, Try Again
 The Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, said he would try again on Saturday and Monday. In the meantime, he said, he would listen to proposals by Republican leaders for a slimmed-down jobs package that could win their support.
But Senator Mitchell and Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, who is Mr. Clinton's point man on the bill, suggested that the President wants his bill passed in full, or not at all.
That prompted Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, to note: "Sometimes when you play for all or nothing you get all. And sometimes you get nothing."
Mr. Clinton -- who was in Portland, Ore., leading a conference on Western forests -- suggested, in phrases copied from President Ronald Reagan's political handbook, that his opponents want to destroy his dreams for America's economy for political gain.
"It'll be a real shame if a minority of the Senate is successful in keeping hundreds of thousands of more Americans out of work," he said.
The President's argument that the economy needs the jobs bill got some help today when the Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate was stuck at 7 percent last month. The bill would add $16.3 billion to the Federal deficit to create the statistical equivalent of about 200,000 jobs -- mostly summer jobs for teachers and teen-agers, but also more lasting work in construction and manufacturing and in Federal agencies.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, suggested that Republicans would accept a package limited to highway construction, summer jobs, unemployment benefits and immunizations for poor children, totaling about $8 billion. He added that he would offer an amendment to that effect if only the Democrats would let him.
The Democrats, knowing Mr. Dole's amendment would lose on a party-line vote, said that would be fine. But first, they said, Mr. Dole must agree to a firm date for voting on the entire bill, a vote the Republicans would surely lose.
The Republicans declined that offer. The Democrats show no desire to negotiate a compromise.
House Democrats had their share of problems today, too.
After pledging to give Mr. Clinton legislation granting him a diluted form of a line-item veto, the House leadership found itself opposed by an odd alliance: Republicans who called the bill too weak to help Mr. Clinton weed pork out of the budget, and Democratic members of the House Appropriations Committee and the Congressional Black Caucus who called it too strong. Together, they forced the leadership to pull the bill from consideration until after the House's spring break.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Setting Record Lows Against Yen

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar hit a record low against the yen for a third straight session yesterday as news of tepid growth in employment in the United States accelerated the dollar's two-month decline.
Gold prices rose $2.20 on the Commodity Exchange in New York, where bullion for current delivery settled at $340.90 an ounce. The Republic National Bank put gold at $340.15 an ounce, up $1.90 from Thursday. 
 "It's a sluggish recovery in the U.S. still, and that's going to hang heavy on the dollar over the next couple of weeks," said David Brown, chief economist at Tokai Bank in London.
Nonfarm employment in March showed an unexpected drop, of 22,000 jobs, the Labor Department said. The report touched off large-scale selling of the dollar against the yen.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to another record low, closing at 114.00 yen, down 0.54 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London the dollar rose to 114.15 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at a record low of 113.75 yen, down from late Thursday's 114.04.
The Bank of Japan made a half-hearted attempt to support the dollar by making small dollar purchases. But the lack of concerted action by other central banks convinced dealers that the Group of Seven industrialized nations wants a stronger yen, which should make exports cheaper in Japan and thus trim Tokyo's huge trade surplus.
"If they had really wanted to push up the dollar, the amount would have to be much larger or the operation would have been a joint intervention," a bank dealer in the United States said of the Bank of Japan's efforts.
The dollar ended higher against the German mark after touching 1.5860 marks, its lowest level since January. In European trading, the dollar ended at 1.6055 German marks, up from 1.5998. Later in New York, the dollar rose to 1.5975 marks, from 1.5915 late Thursday.
Other late dollar quotes in New York, compared with late Thursday: 1.4780 Swiss francs, up from 1.4755; 5.4400 French francs, up from 5.4020; 1,584.00 Italian lire, down from 1,586.00, and 1.2641 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2598.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Conner Says First-Quarter Profit Will Be Weak

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 2

 BODY:
Conner Peripherals Inc. said today that poor demand and price declines for disk drives, as well as weak orders from its European distributor, would cause first-quarter earnings to fall substantially below current analysts' expectations.
Conner shares fell $1.125, to $13.50 in New York Stock Exchange trading today, and some analysts were surprised they did not fall further. 
 Price wars, the weak economies in Europe and Japan, and a transition to higher-capacity disk drives are likely to squeeze the earnings of all disk drive makers, analysts said. The Western Digital Corporation, another major disk drive maker, said two weeks ago that its earnings would fall below Wall Street expectations, blaming price cutting by competitors.
"The drive industry has had a debacle of a quarter, and I don't see what's on the horizon to make things change for the better," said Todd D. Bakar, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. "Within that framework, companies do better or worse depending on their product and customer makeup. Conner's vulnerability is above average given its product makeup, which tends to be in lower-capacity drives."
Conner said that it was evaluating possible moves to reduce costs and that any such actions could result in additional charges that would further reduce earnings for the quarter. Actual operating results will depend on expense levels or other charges incurred in the quarter, Conner said.
Before today, analysts' estimates for Conner's earnings in the quarter had been as high as 48 cents a share; today, some lowered their estimates to as little as 15 cents. In last year's first quarter, Connner earned $24.7 million, or 42 cents a share, on revenues of $441 million.
"The market for our disk drive products is currently being affected by a variety of factors," Finis Conner, Conner's chief executive, said. "Ongoing price competition and excess capacity in the industry has caused customers to defer purchases and reduce lead times for purchase orders."
Demand is increasingly shifting to disk drives with the capacity to store greater amounts of data, Mr. Conner said, significantly cutting into sales of lower-capacity products.
 
A Problem in Europe
 Conner was particularly affected by a deferral of orders by its major European distributor at the end of the quarter.
"We are currently in discussions with this distributor and are evaluating a restructuring of our relationship in order to improve our control and leadership in this channel," Mr. Conner said. The company will sell more disk drives directly to retailers in Europe, it told analysts in a conference call this morning.
The weakness at Conner "is part of a normal rubber band effect in the disk drive busines between capacity and demand," said James Porter, president of Disk Trend, a disk drive industry market research firm based in Mountain View, Calif.
He noted that disk drive makers themselves do not control demand cycles, but instead respond to demand created by new microprocessors and software in the personal computer industry. "I'm not looking for a decline in unit shipments for PC's," he added, "but growth of zero seems plausible."

HEADLINE: U.S. Jobless Rate Steady, but Payrolls Fell in March

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
In a report subject to widely differing interpretations, the Labor Department said today that the number of payroll jobs fell slightly in March and that the nation's unemployment rate remained at 7 percent.
The decline of 22,000 in payroll jobs was greeted initially with disappointment, since a six-digit rise had been expected. But after closer scrutiny of the figures, which provided the first broad view of the economy's March performance, many analysts were reassured that the economic recovery was still intact. 
 Some of their fears were allayed by upward revisions in the data for January and February, and the realization that the midmonth East Coast blizzard had distorted the March numbers.
 
A Positive View
 "We're still getting some gains in the labor market," said James E. Annable, chief economist for the First National Bank in Chicago. "It sure as heck ain't a recession."
But the Clinton Administration used the report to argue for passage of its $16.3 billion jobs bill, threatened in the Senate with a Republican filibuster.
The news "reinforces the need for the President's stimulus package," declared Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, in a statement issued while he attended a forest conference with President Clinton in Portland, Ore.
Mr. Clinton himself leaked word of the unchanged jobless rate in an early morning television appearance before public release of the data at 8:30, Eastern standard time.
Republicans countered that the stimulus plan was a grab-bag of measures that would probably harm employment by slowing the economy.
While the March job figures paled in comparison with the robust February report, which included a surge of 365,000 in payroll jobs, analysts noted that the labor market managed to at least hold its ground when allowance was made for the severe weather that occurred toward the end of the survey week. The storm led to some job losses but had its biggest impact in shortening the workweek.
The private-sector workweek was 6 minutes shorter, with people in factories working 18 minutes less and factory overtime down by 24 minutes from levels that had been quite high.
The report also revised upward the previously reported job gain for January, to 113,000 from 44,000, and even added another 2,000 to the big February gain.
Moreover, various private economists noted, there was a tendency for full-time jobs to replace part-time work. A month ago, the report for February showed a jump of 348,000 in people working fewer hours than they wanted, and the Clinton camp cited this in support of its stimulation efforts. In March, however, the ranks of the so-called involuntary part-timers fell 267,000.
 
Discouraged Workers
 Nor has there been any significant rise of late in discouraged workers, who are people who have given up looking for jobs because they do not think they will find one. This figure, tabulated quarterly, rose 1.1 percent for the first quarter, the same as in the final three months of 1992.
"It's really fairly good," said H. Erich Heinemann, economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, viewing today's report over all.
Some analysts did, however, express concern about a 5 cent rise, to $10.80, in average hourly earnings, a possible sign of revived inflation. That figure may have contributed to a slump in the bond market today.
Of the 11 major states for which figures were reported today, only Massachusetts had a jobless-rate change of clear statistical significance -- a decline of 1.3 points, to 6.4 percent. New York and Texas posted declines of seven-tenths of a point, to 7.3 percent and 6.8 percent, respectively. New Jersey's jobless rate was calculated at 8.3 percent, up from 7.8.
The payroll survey showed a drop of 59,000 in construction jobs, which had climbed sharply in February. That was largely offset by an advance of 37,000 in business service jobs and a rise of 9,000, albeit smaller than usual, in health services. Factory jobs eased 9,000, after rising 30,000 in January and 20,000 in February.
Still other payroll data showed that the index of aggregate weekly hours of production workers eased six-tenths of a point, to 121.9, while the percentage of industries adding workers slumped to 48.6, from 61.1 in February.
 
Fewer Are Without Jobs
 The survey of households showed a job gain of 114,000, which, when combined with an expansion of 102,000 in the labor force, reduced the ranks of the unemployed by 12,000, to 8,864,000.
The jobless rate for adult women fell to 5.7 percent, from 6 percent, while the rate for adult men rose two-tenths of a point, to 6.7 percent.
"While we have seen slow but steady declines in unemployment between June and February," observed William G. Barron Jr., the Acting Commissioner of Labor Statistics, "joblessness remains well above prerecession levels, when the rate fluctuated between 5 and 5.4 percent. Moreover, the number of persons unemployed for six months or more in March was 1.8 million, triple prerecession levels."
Last month was the second anniversary of the official end of the ninth postwar recession, which began in July 1990 and lasted until March 1991. In the regaining of jobs, the latest recovery stands "a distant eighth," Mr. Barron told the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.

HEADLINE: Science or Art Form? The Top Managers Talk About Their Tactics

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
Most investors in stock mutual funds choose diversified funds, asking the manager to decide which areas of the market are most promising at a particular time. So while single-industry funds offer the possibility of better -- and far worse -- performance in any given period, perhaps the most pertinent information for most people is the performance of general stock funds. Here are three funds that did best over the last quarter, year and five years.

Vista Growth and Income
Best Over 5 Years
Manager: Mark A. Tincher 
 "I think the economy may be a little stronger than people expect, so exposure to cyclical stocks will be better bets than defensive plays," said Mark A. Tincher, who manages the $325 million Vista Growth and Income Fund (800 348-4782) in New York, the best-performing equity fund over the last five years with an average annual return of 31.8 percent.
Mr. Tincher began at Citibank, where he handled the convertible securities part of the bank's institutional money management business. When that was sold to USF&G in 1985, he joined Chase Manhattan, sponsor of the Vista funds, where he managed money for the bank before taking over management of the fund in 1991.
Vista Growth and Income had an inauspicious beginning, starting its investing on Oct. 19, 1987, the day the Dow Jones industrial average dropped a dizzying 501 points, or 22 percent. Despite that, the fund has consistently led the pack of diversified equity funds.
Mr. Tincher attended the University of Toledo on a golf scholarship, earning undergraduate and graduate degrees in business "after I realized that I couldn't put food on the table playing golf," he said. But he indulges his passion every weekend at the Stanwich Country Club, not far from his Greenwich, Conn., home. His handicap: 4.
While Mr. Tincher, now 37 years old, is willing to call his investment style "value- and momentum-based," he says he picks stocks using Chase's valuation model, evaluating characteristics like price-to-book value, cash flow and earnings momentum. Using the model, the fund's five largest holding now are Allied Signal, A.T.& T., Capital Holding, Dayton-Hudson and W.R. Grace.
The fund also owns a sprinkling of small- to mid-capitalization companies, which represent about a quarter of its portfolio. One of Mr. Tincher's favorites is Harnischfeger, which makes mining construction equipment and machinery used to produce paper. The company is a fairly cheap cyclical play on a rebound of the economy, he said, and an offer by a Dutch company to buy 10 percent of Harnischfeger's shares was just announced. Another favorite is Analog Devices Inc., which manufactures computer chips primarily for the telecommunications industry.
 
Oakmark Fund
Best Over Last 12 Months
Manager: Robert J. Sanborn
The Oakmark Fund (800 476-9625), which last year was second to the Fidelity Select Savings and Loan Fund among all equity funds, has kept up its momentum, and ended as the top general equity fund for the 12 months ended this quarter, with a return of 42.5 percent.
Behind Oakmark's success is the patience of Robert J. Sanborn, who runs the $620 million fund with what he calls an "eclectic long-term value philosophy." The 35-year-old manager joined Harris Associates of Chicago, Oakmark's sponsor, after working with the State Teachers Retirement System of Ohio from 1983 to 1987 and started Oakmark in August 1991.
"If things go well, it could be the last job I'll ever hold," he said
Mr. Sanborn says he likes to think of his investments not as stock-picking but as "buying a piece of the business" for five years or more.
The fund's turnover was a miserly 34 percent last year, roughly one-third the annual turnover of all stock funds. Mr. Sanborn says he is trying hard to get that down to 20 to 25 percent.
The excess buy-and-sell activity in 1992 was the result of too many stocks reaching their sell targets, he said. The defining characteristic of the fund is its value approach. Oakmark tries to buy companies that sell for 60 percent or less of what Mr. Sanborn estimates is their true value, then sell them when they reach 85 percent of value.
Trading decisions are based on his view of what a company is worth, revised each quarter, not changes in its stock price.
Infrequent trading helps him meet another goal: minimizing capital gains, commissions and other costs.
Mr. Sanborn says he also looks for companies whose management holds most of its personal wealth in company shares. (Yes, he keeps the bulk of his own net worth in Oakmark.)
Diversification is not a goal because more holdings increase the odds of producing an average performance, he said. Right now 20 stocks account for 70 percent of Oakmark's value, with the balance split among 30 more issues. The fund's largest holdings are mostly contrarian plays.
Its biggest, Philip Morris, took a pounding on Wall Street yesterday plunging $14.25, or 22 percent, to $49.875, after it cut the price of Marlboro cigarettes, endangering its profits. All the tobacco companies are also under pressure because of the increased anti-smoking pressure emanating from the White House.
The rest of his top five are Eli Lilly, the pharmaceutical company; Martin Marietta, a military contractor that may benefit from industry consolidation; Total, a French oil company, and De Beers, the South African diamond company.
Mr. Sanborn earned a bachelor's degree from Dartmouth and an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago. He and his wife, Louise, live in Evanston, Ill.
 
American Heritage Fund
Heiko H. Thieme
Best in Last Quarter
Manager: Heiko H. Thieme
Despite record levels in the market, the party isn't over yet, says Heiko H. Thieme, who runs the American Heritage Fund in New York (800 828-5050), the best-performing general equity fund in the first quarter of 1993, with a return of 18.6 percent.
American Heritage was a $1 million fund that was the worst in the industry, based on its five-year record, when Mr. Thieme took over on Feb. 1, 1990. Under his stewardship, it has become a $32 million champion, although it is still small by fund standards.
What strategy has he used? None, Mr. Thieme (pronounced TEEM-uh) insists. "My conclusion is to use common sense," he said.
Plus hard work. "I use 18 hours a day for work, and I sleep only four hours a night," he said.
After considering a career as a magician, Mr. Thieme earned a law degree from the University of Hamburg and then pursued postgraduate studies at the University of California at Berkeley.
His next stop was at Wood & McKenzie, a brokerage firm in Edinburgh and London. After a stint with White, Weld & Company, an investment bank, he joined the Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation in New York as strategist and then as manager of United States equities.
Mr. Thieme, 49, calls his approach "stock selection plus management of cash." The latter now makes up 15 percent of his portfolio.
He holds what he calls "Dow wallflowers," like I.B.M., Boeing and Philip Morris, and loaded up heavily on the latter yesterday morning as its share price plunged. But the fund's strong performance in the first quarter reflected investments in Evergreen International, a Canadian software company whose customers include the Internal Revenue Service; Triton Energy, a Dallas company that recently announced a major oil find in Colombia; British Petroleum, and International Fast Food, an American company that holds the franchise in Poland for Burger King.
He gives stocks that are in disfavor one to three years to turn around but will take profits when a stock shoots up. That partly explains the fund's recent high turnover of 600 percent, compared with 90 percent for the industry.
About 12 percent of his fund is invested in Senetek, a British biotechnology company, which is traded over the counter in the form of American depository receipts. While Senetek is now trading at less than $3, Mr. Thieme says he thinks it could reach $20 because of two forthcoming products: a formula that the company says shrinks wrinkles and another that it says treats male impotence. He also likes the Fairfield Bank and Trust Company, a small bank in Fairfield, Conn., where he has lived for the last 13 years. He says it is a cheap stock -- trading now at under $1 -- that is poised to profit on a turnaround in residential real estate.
Mr. Theime and his wife of 16 years, Corinne, have three children.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By Robert Hurtado

 BODY:

Switching From Bonds
Q. My wife and I are retired. Two years ago we bought three-month Treasury bills when they were paying 6 percent. Currently they are paying 3 percent or less, and as they start to come due for reinvestment in the next two months we are considering switching to no-load fixed-income mutual funds that pay monthly dividends that average 6 percent. What are the risks?
 BEN NEELAND, Bergenfield, N.J. 
 A. A reasonable move with a different element of risk. "If interest rates rise, the value of the mutual fund shares fall," said John Markese, president of the American Association of Individual Investors in Chicago. "And you can't simply hold it to maturity and get your principal back. My opinion would be to look at an intermediate-term U.S. Government mutual fund, which will produce higher returns with only a small amount of increased risk. An alternative is to simply go into U.S. Government notes, perhaps three- and four-year maturities."
 
 
 
Global Bond Funds
Q. What is the current outlook on global bond mutual funds, especially short-term?
 PAUL SCHWARTZ, Manhattan
A. The outlook is bullish, said Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company. He's been looking at these international bonds funds and is very bullish short-term for particularly Germany, France and Denmark, in part because he foresees a series of interest rate cuts in Europe. "However, I am less bullish on Japan and the U.S. In the U.S., it would appear that the bulk of the move in bond valuation has already been accomplished, while Japan has already cut its discount rate 2 1/2 percentage points and is preparing to spend more than $100 billion to stimulate its economy. With all that, the country surprisingly continues to run a big surplus, suggesting that interest rates in Japan will not move much lower either."
 
 
 
Schedule B, Not D
Q. Does the I.R.S. require that every check written on a money-market mutual fund be listed on Form 1040, Schedule D, for 1992?
 MICHAEL M. MEYERS, Upper Montclair, N.J.
A. No, says Robert F. Lee, vice president for corporate taxes at Advest Inc., a securities dealer. "The fund is revalued daily; consequently redemptions are on a cost-basis price. It is not considered a sale as with other mutual funds. The interest you receive is considered a dividend and as a result is entered on Schedule B under dividend income."

HEADLINE: Unemployment Dips Below 10% in New York City

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Mainly as a result of fewer people seeking jobs, the unemployment rate for New York City fell to 9.6 percent in March from 11.3 percent in February, according to Government data released yesterday. It was the first month since last April that the rate has been below 10 percent.
For New York State, a brightening employment picture -- mainly outside New York City -- helped the rate fall to 7.3 percent, from 8 percent in February. It was the lowest rate since October 1991. 
 New Jersey's rate crept up to 8.3 percent, from 7.8 percent the previous month, showing that a sustained job recovery has yet to take hold. Connecticut's March jobs data have yet to be released.
 
Problems Persist
 "In New York City, employment recovery is still more of a future hope than a current reality," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. "Job recovery is still hostage to a very extensive restructuring and downsizing that is coursing through the New York City economy."
The bureau adjusts the employment data for New York State and New Jersey to smooth out the statistical impact of seasonal factors like fluctuations in hiring and layoffs in industries like retailing and construction.
While the bureau does not seasonally adjust the city's data, economists in the office of City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman do, and they said the adjusted rate had fallen to 9.5 percent in March, the lowest since October 1991.
The number of employed city residents rose in March by a scant 5,000 from February, to 2,987,000, according to the Federal estimates. The number of unemployed residents seeking or available for work fell by 60,000, to 319,000.
Discussing New York State's job market, Mr. Ehrenhalt said, "After many months of idling, the state's economic engine shows some signs of coming to life."
He said employment had improved, particularly in service industries, which have added some 50,000 jobs since last summer. "You're also seeing a bit of strength in the wholesale and retail trades and the finance sector," he said.
There were 7,985,000 employed New York State residents in March, an increase of 127,000 since December and up 39,000 from February. The number of unemployed fell to 629,000, from 688,000 in February.
In New Jersey, the number of employed residents fell to 3,597,000, down 12,000 from February. The number of unemployed rose 19,000, to 325,000. "The problem is not that things are getting worse in New Jersey, it's that they are not getting better," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
Connecticut's job market "is still in the process of bottoming out," Mr. Ehrenhalt said. The unemployment rate fell in February to 6.7 percent from 7.5 percent in January. But job cuts by military contractors and aerospace companies seem to be offsetting gains in other sectors in Connecticut.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
For a Real Challenge, Try Picking Newsletters

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla

 BODY:
THE last time Mark Hulbert looked, 45 investment newsletters devoted themselves exclusively to mutual funds. More are sure to join the fray, which is good news for Mr. Hulbert, who publishes The Hulbert Financial Digest out of Alexandria, Va., and is in the business of evaluating how well investors would do if they followed the advice of the people who sell newsletters.
In 1984, only 3 of the 41 letters he tracked -- 7 percent -- were exclusively giving advice about buying and selling funds. Today, 45 of the 140 investment newsletters monitored by Hulbert specialize in mutual funds -- 32 percent of the total. 
 Notably, it does not seem to matter whether the investment newsletter writer is recommending stocks, bonds, funds or pork-belly futures. Regardless of what investment angle they are recommending, few advisers manage to beat the market.
Mr. Hulbert reviewed the performance of 17 mutual fund newsletters that have been in existence since January 1987 to see how well these veterans have done. By examining a period that began before the stock market crash (and ended Feb. 28), Mr. Hulbert was able to see which fund letters could do better than the overall stock market in bad times as well as in good.
Of the 17, 3 managed to do better than the Standard & Poor's 500, a widely watched index of the overall stock market that was up 124.2 percent in the period covered by the review. That means 14 did worse than the stock market.
But as any newsletter editor will tell you, there is more to investment advice than beating the averages. (You wanted to make money, too? Didn't anyone tell you the 1980's are over?) And mutual fund newsletters today are offering something for everyone.
Investors might not beat the stock market averages by following the No Load Mutual Fund Selections & Timing Newsletter, whose investment recommendations gained 32.5 percent since Mr. Hulbert began to follow it in January 1990. But they might get a little religion from the editor, Stephen L. McKee, who quotes from the Bible below each table of contents.
Indeed, other fund-letter editors are also appealing to investors' devout sides. Sound Mind Investing bills itself as "the financial journal for today's Christian family"; its citations range from Ecclesiastes to Abraham Lincoln to Karl Marx. There's no track record to report, however, because Mr. Hulbert began to follow Sound Mind only two months ago.
Another letter combining profits and prophets is Funding Your Future, whose editor, Martin Kennedy, signs off each issue with a "God bless you, Martin."
Perhaps some other letters could use a little help from the Lord. The Sector Funds Newsletter, 17th of the 17 letters in the review, gained 28.2 percent in the six-year period, not even a quarter of the gain in the S.& P. 500.
Growth Fund Guide, ranked 16th, gained 32.3 percent in the period studied. Neither managed to beat even the 44.6 percent ultra-safe return of Treasury bills.
If fund letters are all over the map in performance, they are equally eclectic when it comes to their opinions about what will shape the market. Every nut case (the other guy) and reasonable investor (you, of course) can find an adviser whose opinions reflect their own.
On the matter of President Clinton's economic program, for example, Fidelity Insight said in March that "Wall Street may be overreacting to President Clinton's economic program."
Don't agree with that point of view? Try the Closed End Fund Digest, whose March headline read: "Say It Ain't So, Bill."
Mr. Hulbert noted that fund followers, more than stock, bond or commodity advisers, feel compelled to do a little editorial padding because there isn't all that much to tell readers after an initial call to buy fund A or sell fund B.
"A lot of these letters like funds for all the right reasons, but then they discover that funds don't have all the excitement they'd like," he explained.
But investors want a little entertainment along with the dull-but-useful advice, so editors provide political commentary, question-and-answer columns, summaries of what other newsletter writers are saying and bashing of newspaper and magazine writers.
They also use a little ink to tell you where they think the overall stock market and economy are going, and the conclusions from the best letters, right now, may not be what investors were hoping to hear.
The Mutual Fund Strategist, which ranked second in the Hulbert study, warned in its most recent issue, "It is very possible that the U.S. could be on the edge of a financial and economic collapse that is directly related to the Federal debt."
Fundline, another newsletter that outpaced the stock market over the last six years, said recent stock market rallies were the result of "uninformed buying usually done at market highs."
Advice from these top-performing publications costs from $96 a year (Fidelity Monitor) to $149 (The Mutual Fund Strategist). Among the newsletters that did not keep pace with the averages, prices run from $89 a year to $187. It does not always hold that you get what you pay for -- if making money is the reason you are subscribing in the first place.

HEADLINE: GOLD;
After a Dismal Year, A Strong First Quarter

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
GOLDBUGS, rejoice! Lexington Strategic Investments, a gold fund, topped the charts among all mutual funds in the first quarter of 1993, rising an eye-popping 72.7 percent. But envious investors should remember that Lexington was the worst performer of the 3,000-plus mutual funds in 1992: the value of its shares plummeted 61 percent.
All gold funds -- there are 32 others that invest in a mix of gold mining stocks and bullion -- are famous for their roller-coaster rides. Share prices swing violently up and down, but mostly down; gold funds are notable as the only stock fund category to lose value in the last decade. 
 Historically viewed as a refuge in international turmoil, gold has lately failed miserably in that role. The funds lost value during the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq in 1990, the Persian Gulf war in 1991 and the unsuccessful Russian coup in the summer of 1991.
Gold has also been viewed as a hedge. Because it does not move in tandem with stocks or, especially, bonds, gold can dampen the volatility of an investment portfolio. "If you have a lot of money tied up in bond funds with maturities of more than five years, you need a hedge," said Gerald W. Perritt, who edits The Mutual Fund Letter in Chicago, perhaps 5 to 10 percent of a bond portfolio.
The Benham Group, a mutual fund company in Mountain View, Calif., that specializes in bond funds, added a gold fund to its mix in 1988 "to provide ballast for the portfolios," said James M. Benham, the chairman. The Benham Gold Equity Index Fund has assets of more than $200 million, the only gold fund to gain assets steadily in the last five years.
While most analysts are disgusted with gold, contrarians have emerged.
One raging gold bull is Michael Metz, chief investment strategist for Oppenheimer & Company in New York. Not a true goldbug -- he doesn't hoard canned foods to await the end of the world -- Mr. Metz says, "The end of disinflation plus declining opportunity costs translate into a huge bull market for gold."
He said the highest short-term interest rates in history worldwide had finally started to tumble, reducing the penalty for holding gold -- an asset that does not produce income -- for individuals and central banks. The long deflationary period worldwide is over, given the long-term strength of the American dollar, the recession in Europe and the slowest Japanese economy in decades. Rising inflation would lift gold prices.
Investors who want to own gold, either as a hedge or for potential appreciation, have a lot of homework to do. The usual way to select a fund, evaluating its long-term performance and risk, is irrelevant.
"Because the gold market has been in a slump for most of these funds' existences, the ones that boast the best track records are generally the group's most conservative entrants," said Eileen M. Sanders, an analyst for Morningstar Inc., a mutual fund researcher in Chicago. So the long-term top performers probably will lag if gold takes off. "It's more important that investors determine what role they want a gold fund to play in their portfolio than it is for them to look at past performance," she said.
For a pure play on gold prices, the best bet is Lexington Strategic, Ms. Sanders said. The no-load fund specializes in South African gold shares. Its share price is extraordinarily volatile, so prepare for a rough ride.
Two more conservative bets on gold are Fidelity Select Precious Metals and Minerals and United Services World Gold, which balance their volatile investments in South African gold with shares in companies in North America and other gold-producing areas, she added.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
A Musical Asks: What Price a Pair of Sneakers?

BYLINE: By JON PARELES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, March 31

 BODY:
It's hard to imagine a more well-intentioned project than "Bobos," the latest production by the American Music Theater Festival. The "jazz, pop, rap musical," which opened Wednesday night and runs through April 11 at the Plays and Players Theater here, is about the brutal choices facing inner-city teen-agers, and it updates theater music with the riffs and beats of hip-hop. The combination of relevance and contemporary rhythm seems intended to draw a younger audience than most musicals do, while reminding the regular theatergoing crowd that there are people struggling just a neighborhood or two away.
"Bobos" aims to cut back on escapism while providing the satisfactions of an old-fashioned musical, from love songs to celebratory dance sequences. The program says "Time: The Present" and "Place: The City," and with props including knives, guns and a crack pipe, "Bobos" flaunts a certain grittiness. "This is the real deal," the opening number insists. 
 The show's composer, James McBride,is a former journalist, and "Bobos" grew out of a story he wrote about sneakers as ghetto status symbols. In "Bobos," Alfred (David Hughes) gets a pair of Brand X sneakers, derided as "bobos," for his 13th birthday. "You can't be down if you're dressed up like a clown," the other kids jeer, so to make the money for a spiffy pair of Nikes, Alfred gets involved with a violent, drug-dealing gang. He commits petty crime, get shaken down by corrupt cops, even lights up a crack pipe. Can his community -- including an adoring female cousin, a derelict with an unlikely secret, a Caribbean chicken chef and a benign quartet of rappers and break-dancers called the Autobots -- save him from evil ways? Since "Bobos" is a musical, the answer is obvious.
The show's creators, including the director, Bertin Rowser; its choreographer, Monica Johnson, and its costume designer, Felix Cochran, have kept an eye on the moves and fashions of current hip-hop: the aerobic routines and hunching swaggers, the bright baggy clothes and backward baseball caps. Broadway musicals like "The Wiz" and "Dreamgirls" have often capitalized on current black pop for a jolt of vitality, and "Bobos" uses rapping and break-dancing to punctuate a score that also includes more conventional show tunes. The gang members spout a little of the misogyny of current gangster rap, though the production steers clear of four-letter words. As at hip-hop concerts, the raps don't always make it clearly through the sound system, the fault of a combination of technical lapses and imperfect enunciation.
Mr. McBride and the librettist, Ed Shockley, dabble in pop-soul ballads, gospel, calypso, jazz and elaborate ensembles that interlace rapping and crooning. Some of the unexpected musical combinations work out well. But there are odd shifts of tone, and at times songs sound as if they had parachuted in from another show. Love duets between Alfred and his vibrant cousin Doris (Mesha Millington), with titles like "Until You Believe," not only proffer Broadway platitudes, but also sound peculiar when sung by 13-year-olds.
Often, secondary characters get the best songs, particularly Gerald (Armsted Christian), the derelict, who has a show-stopping gospel-blues tune in Act I and in Act II both a jazzy number akin to "Moody's Mood for Love" and a tender, dynamic ballad. James Wise as Brick, the head of the Autobots, can rap with playful rhythm and precise articulation, then pull off fancy (if somewhat dated) break-dancing spins and leaps.
The show's other musical center is Skooley (Robert Christophe), the gang leader who lures Alfred with the promise of easy money. Skooley, perhaps named after the pioneering Philadelphia gangster rapper Schooly D, recalls Sportin' Life in "Porgy and Bess"; he has better clothes, more authority and more fun than the virtuous characters. While gang members wear the gold chains and knit caps of characters from "New Jack City," their music comes straight out of "West Side Story": finger-snapping, insinuating tunes in which Skooley is suavely implacable. He holds all the cards; his decisions, more than Alfred's, govern the plot.
When the bad guy takes over a supposedly uplifting story, it's a sign of trouble, and "Bobos" eventually founders on its disparate ambitions. It starts out as a relatively realistic tale of an inner-city teen-ager, drawn by materialism into crime and drugs, not realizing he's gotten in too deep. But the traditional musical depends on a story line with conflicts that can be resolved by one big tuneful number, like the one in "Bobos" that advises, "Stick to the right/even when there's no light." Poverty, unemployment, crack addiction and crime aren't so easy to change -- that's why hip-hop has evolved such fragmentary, relentless structures -- and by allowing such bleak realities into the foreground, "Bobos" raises the stakes beyond what it can deliver.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A scene from the American Music Theater Festival's production of "Bobos," at the Plays and Players Theater in Philadelphia. From left are E. O. Nolasco, James Wise, Nakia Dillard and Tony Vinto. (Mark Garvin/"Bobos")

HEADLINE: Aid -- and Trade -- for Russia

 BODY:
President Clinton, in a speech this week to newspaper editors, laid out sound reasons for America to aid Russia. Aid, especially if targeted to benefit ordinary Russians, could help move reform forward. And an economically prosperous and democratic Russia would open an era of international cooperation, generate trade opportunities and, by paving the way for steep defense cuts, free billions for civilian investment. Think of aid, Mr. Clinton urged, not as charity but as an investment in peace and economic growth.
He will carry this message to Boris Yeltsin today when they begin a two-day summit meeting in Vancouver. He will pledge about $1 billion in U.S. aid next year, and the prospect of a much larger package -- perhaps $30 billion -- from the Western allies after they meet later this month in Tokyo. 
 The historical record -- from Germany and Japan after World War II to Mexico in the 1980's -- shows that foreign aid can help reform succeed. It can do the same in Russia.
Russia needs Western money so it can stop printing mountains of rubles that it uses to finance huge deficits and to extend credit to bankrupt state enterprises -- a policy that has brought the country to the brink of hyperinflation. The West can help the Yeltsin Government summon the courage to cut back these subsidies by setting up a safety net for laid-off workers, promoting private enterprise and creating a fund to stabilize the ruble. A stable ruble is a necessary step toward encouraging trade and foreign investment.
But there's another way the West can help Russia that won't cost taxpayers a dime: Buy Russian exports. Trade is a key to prosperity.
Russia boasts rich natural resources and a highly educated work force. It can produce valuable products at low cost. But Russia can't sell if the West won't buy -- and so far, Western Europe and the U.S. have thrown up one obstacle after another.
Russia wants to export space satellites and launch vehicles. But an official of the U.S. Commerce Department recently called on Russia to raise its prices. The West, she said, wouldn't be interested in buying satellites that are priced "below market" to disadvantage U.S. companies.
But exactly whose market did the official have in mind? It is hard to imagine Russian companies selling below cost because their costs, especially wages, have collapsed along with the economy to appallingly low levels.
The European Community restricts imports of Russian fish. The U.S. and the European Community slap duties on Russian uranium and aluminum. Germany and Finland unilaterally shut out Russian textiles.
Yes, the West will want to protect itself against sudden, traumatic surges in cheap Russian exports. But the barriers so far erected are too tall -- costing Russia perhaps $3 billion in lost sales. That's a whopping amount for a decimated economy. The West should err on the side of leniency -- negotiating rules so that Russia can trade itself toward prosperity.
It's hypocritical, if not masochistic, for Mr. Clinton and other Western leaders to ask taxpayers to fork over billions of dollars in Russian aid while at the same time standing in the way of Russians willing to work their way out of poverty. Trade is no substitute for aid -- at least now. But it's necessary if Russia is to turn into the peaceful, prosperous nation Mr. Clinton envisions.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: How New York's Insurance Law Benefits Small Businesses

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As an insurance broker serving small corporate clients, I understand Jeffrey Heath's alarm in "Small Businesses Need More Time for New Insurance Law" (letter, March 24) at having his health insurance canceled and his concern over spiraling costs.
However, the New York State Health Reform Act, effective April 1, is neither the culprit nor the cause of high insurance rates. 
 Many insurance companies have opposed this law and spent a lot of money mailing scare literature to policyholders, threatening exorbitant rates. The law requires insurance companies who write health insurance in this state to stop discriminating against small business. Mr. Heath's carrier chose not to play by the new rules. Although 10 insurers pulled out, more than a dozen remain, serving the New York City area.
Mr. Heath complains that his insurance rates have increased to $11,500 for a family. I have good news for him. Because of the new law, his company is free to change insurance carriers any time, no questions asked. He can find a variety of insurance plans on the market as of April 1, ranging from $5,000 to $7,000 for a family, with lower rates for single parents and childless couples. Single rates are $2,000 to $3,000 a year.
Had he seen his rates increase to $12,000 a year because of a serious medical condition on staff, he would previously have been a captive of his insurance carrier, unable to move the plan. Under the old rules, a serious illness on staff had the effect of locking in the entire company and throwing away the key. No longer can insurance companies refuse to pay bills on pre-existing conditions when employees change insurance plans.
My office has 80 group plans in force. About 20 percent of our clients will have their rates reduced April 1. Another 25 percent are getting rates that represent an increase of less than 10 percent over 1992 renewal rates. Most of the rest will move to carriers offering affordable rates, not prevented by medical histories or pre-existing condition exclusions.
Had the new insurance law allowed us to comply as all policies became due for renewal, beginning April 1, Albany could have avoided wholesale panic.
 
KAREN OLSON
President, Benefits Design Group
New York, March 26, 1993

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Digital Is Leaving Headquarters Building

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAYNARD, Mass., April 2

 BODY:
In a move that even its chief executive termed surprising, the Digital Equipment Corporation announced today that it was abandoning the 146-year-old Mill building that has been its headquarters since the day it was founded here on Sept. 4, 1957.
Robert B. Palmer, Digital's president and chief executive, said that the decision to leave the 1.1-million-square-foot building, which Digital owns, was part of a continuing effort to cut costs at the beleaguered computer company. Digital, which has not turned a profit in two years, lost $2.8 billion in the 1992 fiscal year and reported a $74 million loss for its fiscal second quarter ended last December. 
 Mr. Palmer said the recommendation to move the 2,100 Digital employees out of the building had been made by a company task force overseeing huge facilities reductions. The 200 employees who make up the corporate headquarters staff will be relocated to another Digital facility in Maynard this summer. The remainder will be transferred over the next 18 months to two years to other facilities, primarily in eastern Massachusetts.
 
'I Would Have Preferred to Stay'
 "It was quite a surprise to me, frankly, that they recommended moving," Mr. Palmer said. "Personally, I would have preferred to stay. But when you look at the numbers, we are attempting to maintain maximum employment, and you just have to make a business decision. It does sadden me."
Digital estimates it will save up to $15 million annually by moving operations out of the brick and beam Mill building, which sits astride the Assabet River in this tiny suburb 20 miles west of Boston. The former woolen mill, built in 1847, supplied wool cloth and blankets to the Union Army during the Civil War.
Mr. Palmer said Digital would work with the town of Maynard and state officials, along with private developers and the Federal Government, to find a use for the building that "will generate the maximum economic and social value."
Kenneth H. Olsen and Harlan Anderson, former M.I.T. research engineers and Digital's co-founders, moved into 8,680 square feet of rented space in the mill in 1957 to start the computer company. What attracted them to Maynard was the rent of 25 cents a square foot, which included heat, parking and a watchman's service.
Digital eventually grew so large that it took over the entire building, which it eventually bought in 1974. The building's confusing layout, twisting staircases and hallmark clock tower came to symbolize Digital to thousands of employees, customers and area residents.
Mr. Palmer insisted the decision to leave the Mill did not represent an attempt to cut ties with the past. Since he took over after Mr. Olsen was forced out by the board of directors last July, Mr. Palmer has initiated dramatic changes throughout the corporation and many longtime Digital executives have left.
Digital continues to trim its work force and facilities. The company has cut 8.7 million square feet of space since 1989, resulting in annual savings of $219 million. Digital also laid off approximately 3,200 employees in the fiscal third quarter, which ended March 31, bringing its total number of employees to under 100,000.

HEADLINE: Haiti's New and Old Rich

BYLINE: By Herbert Gold; Herbert Gold is author, most recently, of "Bohemia: Where Art, Angst, Love, and Strong Coffee Meet."

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
A few Sundays ago, I sat over a long lunch in a hillside mansion above Port-au-Prince, looking over the endless mountains and the wide blue bay. Drinks were served by silent black maids and waiters under trellises in a garden; then we moved indoors for seafood salad, fresh vegetables, fine French wines, sweets. My host and the other guests were light-skinned Haitians, army officers, business people, professionals of the sort who traditionally have gotten rich in Haiti and recently have gotten even richer.
One did a comic imitation of an arriviste trying to drink from a cup with a saucer and thinking the saucer was used to transfer coffee from the cup to the mouth. The black servants appeared not to notice the laughter; they remain invisible to the elite. In the 50's, when I lived in Haiti, a Government minister told me that, with a servant nearby, he could make love and find it no more embarrassing than having a dog or a cat in the room. This class is unhurt by the United States' embargo. It earns money off smuggling. It buys what it needs. Embargos do not apply to the profitable business of transporting drugs. 
 The conversation turned to politics, as it usually does in Haiti, where the Government offers theater of the absurd for the few and oppression for the many. Over coffee back in the garden (saucers properly used) a kindly old gentleman with a fine-boned face listened silently. Suddenly, he turned and whispered, "I very much want President Aristide to come back."
The remark surprised me.
"So the very first day," he continued in his precise and cultured voice, "I can kill him, kill him."
The previous afternoon, I had driven to the village of Petit-Goave, where builders were hammering away at the flotilla being constructed on the beach. One jobless man said, "If God doesn't come back tomorrow, I sail to Miami."
He believed police informants were listening and his life was at risk if he pronounced the dangerous name. By God he meant the exiled President, Jean-Bertrand Aristide. He had gathered money for his passage. The boat-builders make money. The captains of these death vessels make money. The bribe-receivers among local officials make money. And if the boat people are stopped and returned, the police who confiscate the few dollars given them by the Red Cross or generous Americans make money.
Amid the chaos, money is pouring through Haiti in surprising quantities. Hundreds of millionaires live in Petionville, the cool and flowered suburb above Port-au-Prince. Many are the traditional mulatto elite; many are newly enriched.
Since I first arrived in Haiti 40 years ago, it has been a case of the same old same old -- only worse for ordinary people.
The tribe of profiteers grew under the Docs -- Papa and Baby; it is expanding under the military-thug regime fronted by Marc Bazin, the suave former World Bank official. The onetime Mr. Clean has surrendered to the dream of power, like so many. While his army backers trample human rights and the economy, the boat-builders, drug-runners, smugglers and military extortionists are joining the old millionaires.
The roads have gone from atrocious to nearly impassible, so the fashion has shifted from Jaguars and Mercedes to powerful Japanese four-wheel drives. The embargo means soap comes from the Dominican Republic or France rather than the U.S. So what? The French make good soap. Anyway, near St. Valentine's Day a store near the National Palace was filled with red heart-shaped boxes of American chocolates, French truffles, gift baskets of wine, cheese, goodies. What embargo?
Before I left, the first contingent of United Nations and Organization of American States human rights observers arrived. They were unarmed, of course, young people with a mission to . . . observe. "The voyeurs are here," said a cheerful friend. The millionaires, content with the regime, welcome these visitors. "Is it true they are being paid six or seven thousand dollars a month? I love it! They will eat, they will drink, they will spend. Wonderful for the economy!"
The economy of the wealthy who crowd the Petionville restaurants is no worse than it was under the Duvalier kleptocracy. Owning land, exploiting labor, stealing from the treasury or providing airstrips for drugs -- it's all just money. History seems to be on their side just because it always has been.
The philosophy of government can be expressed as: Don't fix the roads (we have four-wheel drives); don't worry about security or an honest police force (we have private guards). Poking holes in the embargo offers another road to profit.
What do the U.N., O.A.S. and the new Administration in Washington want? They say they want democracy and the return of President Aristide. Everyone without a gun wants him back; everyone with a gun wants to shoot him. While the standoff continues, those with guns grow richer and those without guns look to the boats on the beach at Petit-Goave.
At the party that Sunday, a man in an embroidered caftan -- observant, sophisticated, smiling -- said: "Do not worry so much, my friend. We are confident injustice will prevail."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Nicotine Fit Brings Down The Bull Market

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
EVERYONE knew that the Marlboro Man was lethal to many of his customers. But who thought he could kill a bull market?
Whatever else Philip Morris's decision to cut prices may signify, it marks an end to the era in which big consumer product companies were viewed as growth stocks on Wall Street. The belief was that such branded companies could push up prices forever, thus raising profits even if consumption was growing slowly or, in the case of tobacco, shrinking. 
 But things have changed. Now, as Philip Morris put it, companies must fight for market share in "a highly price-sensitive market environment."
The collapse in Philip Morris shares -- the price fell 23 percent on Friday -- came on the same day the Government's latest employment report provided solid evidence that the economic recovery is for real. But with competitive pressures depressing profit margins, even a good recovery may not bring the big profit gains that Wall Street is expecting.
That is a scary idea for stock owners in large part because expectations of a lot of good news, and very little bad news, have gone into prices. At the peak last month, the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index had a dividend yield of 2.73 percent. (Now, after Friday's plunge, it is 2.83 percent.) Arnold Kaufman, the editor of S.& P.'s Outlook newsletter, points out that only seven previous times in the index's 66-year history has the yield gone under 2.9 percent, the most recent one being in 1987. In every case, a sharp fall in stock prices has followed.
Many believe this time is different. Low interest rates, they say, mean that low dividends are to be expected and that the history of dividend yields is not important. The public, which has been buying stock mutual funds at a record pace, has nowhere else to invest. And as the economy grows, dividends will rise. Abby Joseph Cohen and Steve Einhorn, the Goldman Sachs strategists, talk of a "silly putty" recovery stretching out for years.
It is perhaps comforting that Friday's fears were a bit confused -- rising gold prices and employment threaten inflation, while the Philip Morris announcement implies the opposite -- and calmer reflection may make things look less bleak. Perhaps the bond market, which fell Friday on the employment report, will bounce back, and traders will feel better.
Or maybe they won't. Philip Morris was the stock most owned by institutions, a core part of every portfolio. A lot of money managers got off to a horrid start in the second quarter and seem destined to underperform the market averages.
Neat explanations of market tops are seldom available until after the fact. If a top has passed, there will be talk of the Clinton Administration's anti-business hostility to drug and tobacco companies, or perhaps of a turn in interest rates.
But the real lesson may be simpler. When stocks are expensive -- as the low dividend yield shows they are now -- it is risky to bet on them staying that way for a sustained period.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
A Capital Quarter for Real Estate

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
CALL it Wall Street's nod of approval for the new occupants of the White House: a 3.3 percent rally for equity funds in the first quarter. At that pace, there would be double-digit returns for the year as a whole.
The only losers were health-and-biotechnology funds, which fell 14.1 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J. The other 22 stock fund categories showed gains ranging from a low of eight-tenths of 1 percent for environmental funds to a high of 21.7 percent for gold, which gained on dwindling supply after being last's year worst performer. 
 But aside from a small group of funds investing in Japan (up 17.2 percent because of local factors) the quarter's next biggest winner was the real estate category, up 15.1 percent in a showing that well reflects investors' improving sentiments about the economy in a Clinton era.
Several factors are at work. A number of successful initial public offerings by real estate investment trusts have helped the sector regain Wall Street's interest. A tightening supply of housing -- because of a slowdown in construction after the overbuilding of the 1980's -- has pushed up rents. In addition, many pension managers who had been badly burned by real estate investments in the 1980's are moving back in, bidding up prices. Most real estate fund managers expect returns of 15 percent to more than 20 percent in the next few years.
"The real estate industry and real estate stocks in '93 are where the United States stock market was in '81 -- we've had a bad period and now there's good times ahead," said Barry A. Greenfield, who manages the Fidelity Real Estate Investment Portfolio. Proof of growing confidence: his fund's assets have soared from $150 million on Jan. 1 to $450 million.
Sam Lieber, manager of the $10 million Evergreen Global Real Estate Fund, sounds a note of caution, however. Those buying for yield only, he said, are focusing solely on dividend rates and ignoring the value of the underlying real estate. They could scamper off, to the detriment of the market, he said, "if interest rates pick up over the next year, particularly on the short end."
Mr. Greenfield of Fidelity, a confirmed bear from 1986 through last September, says he has shifted since then from health-care real estate investment trusts and cash into more aggressive commercial and industrial real estate. And while REIT yields have tumbled this year as prices rose, they still average 5.5 percent -- a nice premium over the 2.5 percent paid by money markets.
Mr. Greenfield cautions that while he expects this to be the start of a three- to seven-year upturn, in the short run real estate stocks are now somewhat pricey and a temporary slowdown may be in order. He advises buying on the pullbacks.
His fund's three largest holdings are REIT's: Weingarten Realty, a dominant developer in Houston; Federal Realty, which owns properties in Maryland and Virginia, and Carr Realty, a new company that owns office buildings in Washington.
In February, Allen A. Parker, who runs the $25.4 million U. S. Real Estate Fund, added a chunk of California thrift institutions, which now account for 8.7 percent of the fund, and national mortgage bankers, 15.5 percent, to his homebuilders and REIT's portfolio. Mr. Parker believes the California recovery will be gradual, and prices of savings and loans should be first to jump as home-buying interest revives. Two favorites: Great Western Financial and Golden West Financial.
And mortgage bankers, he said, should gain market share at the expense of failed savings and loans, especially given the wave of homeowner refinancings expected this spring. He also invested 2.5 percent of the fund in Ethan Allen, a furniture store that first offered shares in mid-March, because a lot of the cash freed by lower mortgage rates is being invested in furnishings.
While the $45 million Templeton Real Estate Trust can invest worldwide, half of its holdings are in the United States, partly because REIT's still offer much better yields than short-term securities. Adding projected growth, returns could reach an annual 16 percent over the next couple of years, said Jeff Everett, who runs the fund from Nassau.
Mr. Everett, who took over in December, likes American Health Properties, which operates psychiatric facilities in the Northeast and yields 8 percent, and Nationwide Health Properties (6.4 percent), which operates nursing homes across the United States.
Unlike most of his colleagues, Mr. Lieber manages his Evergreen Global fund solely for capital growth, not yield. Slightly less than one-third of the fund is invested in the United States, 26 percent in Europe and 39 percent in Asia. His biggest holding is Alexander's, which he says is using its valuable properties to transform itself into a real estate company.
PRA Real Estate Fund, $95 million in assets, and Cohen & Steers Realty, $99 million, the two funds with the highest returns in the latest quarter, cater mainly to institutional investors with $100,000 minimums. As of last week, however, Cohen & Steers is also offered through Charles Schwab & Company with a $2,000 minimum (to rise on May 28 to $10,000). PRA expects a similar link soon.
