HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Eve Michel and Alfred Milanese

 BODY:
Eve Musette Michel, the director of design for the New York City Economic Development Corporation, was married yesterday to Alfred Charles Louis Milanese, who heads the New York retail and distribution operation for Martin's Handmade Pennsylvania Dutch Pretzels. The Rev. Michael Donahue performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Francis Xavier Church in New York.
Ms. Michel, 37, is an architect. She is keeping her name. She graduated from Washington University and received a master's degree in international management from the School for International Training. She is a daughter of Mary Elizabeth and Henry Michel of New York. Her father is the chairman of Parsons Brinckerhoff Inc., an engineering consulting company in New York. Her mother, who is retired, was a social worker at New York Hospital. 
 Mr. Milanese, 42, also is an author in New York. He graduated magna cum laude from Tufts University. He is a son of Marianna and John Milanese of Rockville, Md. The bridegroom's mother, who is retired, taught mathematics at Sligo Junior High School in Silver Spring, Md. His father, also retired, was a supervisor of management information systems for the Economic Development Administration in Washington.
(Erica Berger)

HEADLINE: A Summit to Discuss Mere Money

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia

 BODY:
In the years that superpowers reigned supreme, summit meetings were awesome spectacles. Nations great and small would watch spellbound as two men with the power to pulverize the planet met to impose limits on their rivalry and delineate their empires. Their every utterance, their every handshake, their every signature had instant and fateful impact on millions of lives, and set billions of dollars in motion.
The summit of Presidents Clinton and Boris Yeltsin is clearly of a different order. Sure, the hype is still there -- the "Bill and Boris" T-shirts, the entwined American and Russian flags, the miles of television cable strewn through some cavernous convention center. But giving American money to Russia, no matter how ardently the need is argued, just doesn't have the mind-focusing quality of a nuclear holocaust. 
 Alas, that does not make the job any easier for the two Presidents at their meeting in Vancouver this weekend. On the contrary, they are meeting precisely because managing a world stripped of the discipline of the cold war is proving at least as difficult as managing the cold war.
The point was dramatically underscored by Eduard A. Shevardnadze not long ago. Being the Foreign Minister of the Soviet Union was far easier, he said, than trying to lead his war-ravaged homeland of Georgia. As a Soviet leader, he had only to make a decision for the potent apparatus of the Kremlin to set it in motion. In Georgia, he could barely keep tabs on the wars breaking out all over the place, much less manage them.
Tell me about it, Mr. Yeltsin might be tempted to say. Only last week he narrowly escaped ouster at the hands of a Russian Congress that has persistently worked to undermine his reforms and his rule. His decrees are increasingly ignored in the provinces. "In principle," as the Russians say, he still carries around a nuclear button and commands the biggest army in the world, but whether he really controls any of this is anybody's guess.
That political shakiness is the main reason Mr. Clinton is seeing Mr. Yeltsin this weekend. The American President has argued that if reactionary forces do take charge in Russia, the price of a revived confrontation will be far higher than the cost of trying to prop up Mr. Yeltsin.
That may be so. But Washington is also learning that power is not what it used to be. When Communism succumbed, there was a naive sense that everything would organically settle into a "new world order," in which the soothing forces of the market and political freedom would triumph under the paternalistic tutelage of the sole superpower. But the survival of Saddam Hussein in Iraq, the savagery in Bosnia, the brush fires in Central Asia and the Caucasus, Ukraine's new taste for nuclear power -- these are only some of the nasty manifestations set loose by the erosion of superpower dominance.
In many ways, Russia's wavering over its course has been the most difficult new problem. At first, the post-Communist Russians seemed uniformly enthusiastic to join a new world order, replete with a market economy and a democratic government. In retrospect it should have been obvious that a nation largely ignorant of the free market, unschooled in democratic fair play and accustomed
 
 
to global influence would not so easily settle into the role of obedient apprentice.
The problem, still unresolved, is that so much depends on what direction Russia chooses. Right now, this includes the problems of Bosnia and Iraq, both of which a militant Russia could inflame. Beyond those lie the shape and cost of Western defenses, the security of Europe and Asia, the very stability of any new world order. Until Russia resolves its power struggles, everything stays in flux.
In addition, Washington has had to accept that its ability to influence events in Russia is limited. The cold war conditioned Americans to ascribe great moral power to their teachings. A few years ago, Russians seemed desperate to hear the message of freedom, and their Government equally desperate to block it. This persuaded many Americans that once heard, their voice would play a major role in putting Russia on the right track.
So it came as a surprise that American views were not universally embraced, that many Russians were convinced that their country was not suitable for American prescriptions, that there were even Russians who resented and resisted American pop culture and American conceptions of free enterprise and private property.
 
More Promised Than Delivered
 The question was not only money, though the fact that the West promised far more than it delivered did not help. The very notion of aid proved intolerable for a people accustomed to being treated as co-arbiter of the world's affairs. And the perception that the West was trying to block Russia from its traditional markets, especially for selling arms, only added to the resentment.
These themes were clear at the Congress last week. Reactionary deputies assailed Mr. Yeltsin for "selling out" to the West. Mr. Yeltsin himself acknowledged the error of putting too much faith in Western aid. And legislators who are normally warm to the West argued against trying to tailor aid to Mr. Yeltsin's political problems. "To give tactless support to one man is counterproductive," said Yevgeny Ambartsumov, chairman of the parliamentary committee on foreign affairs. "It is only seen as interference in the internal affairs of a great nation that finds itself in a sad state." These are the sort of things that neither Eisenhower nor Khrushchev had to worry about when they held the first postwar summit meeting at Camp David in September 1959. And that is what makes the meeting of Messrs. Clinton and Yeltsin in Vancouver qualitatively different.
At Camp David, the leaders of the United States and the Soviet Union had only to issue a few carefully measured signals to achieve their ends. In the heightened atmosphere of the cold war, a few small agreements -- scientific and cultural exchanges, new disarmament talks -- were enough to foster "the spirit of Camp David" and to change the entire course of relations.
The great summits of those years were ends in themselves, carefully choreographed symbols whose power was in the spectacle of two leaders meeting, rather than in the content of their talks. Most agreements they signed were concluded long in advance.
There is some of that Vancouver, to be sure. The very fact of the meeting is an indisputable part of the message for Mr. Yeltsin's supporters and detractors. But the ritual dance of summitry is not the whole point; these are not chiefs meeting only to raise a peace pipe, but wary partners trying to help each other get a grip on a confusing world. What happens in Vancouver is not the culmination of a process, but the process itself. That may reduce the glamor, but certainly not the substance.

HEADLINE: Clinton the Conservationist Thinks Twice

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For reasons that nobody in the White House can fully explain, President Clinton has trouble with trees. When Mr. Clinton was a young governor in Arkansas in the late 1970's, his proposal to end clear-cutting in the state's forests attracted such disdain it contributed to his only defeat for re-election.
Last week, on the way to a forest conference to help decide the fate of the last great stands of timber in the Pacific Northwest, Mr. Clinton stumbled again. Days before arriving for the meeting in Portland, Ore., the White House announced that the President had cut a deal with Western Democratic senators. The compromise with the senators, who had threatened to oppose Mr. Clinton's budget, derailed a bid to roll back destructive land-use practices in the West that had been subsidized for a century by the Government. 
 The announcement was seen by environmentalists as a betrayal. Some House members felt upstaged because they had already voted on the land-use package and hadn't been consulted about changes. The most vocal protest came from Representative George Miller, Democrat of California and chairman of the House Natural Resources Committee, who is the national environmental movement's most influential ally on Capitol Hill. "It shows exceptionally poor political judgment," said Mr. Miller. "It was the imperative of deficit reduction and shared sacrifice that would have allowed the necessary changes to be made. They have given away the advantage they had to get the policy changes enacted."
But as the week ended, it became clear that the issue was far from dead. While the White House clearly had suffered a setback, it landed upright in a position in which it has found itself with increasing regularity: compromise. Faced with the reality that everyone's an environmentalist until change comes to the backyard, Mr. Clinton blinked but persisted, though on a less ambitious course.
He gained commitments from the Western Democrats to support administrative and legislative proposals that would improve the management of Western lands. Though the steps would not be nearly as drastic as those proposed by Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, they would begin to halt Government-subsidized grazing, mining, and logging that leaves scars on the land. And he used the forest conference that he had organized in Portland to shore up his credentials as a conservationist and to tell timber interests, in effect, that they would have to change with the times.
But there was no question that the criticism had stung. The White House worked hard to make nice to bruised Congressional egos and to convince the press that it had not sold out. "The environmentalists and their friends in Congress say you can't win unless somebody else loses big time," said a White House aide. "And there are some in business who still think environmental protection is nonsense. That is not the way environmental policy is being shaped by Bill Clinton. After years of arguing this issue from the poles on the right and the left, and getting nowhere, we're trying to move the debate closer to the center."
It is a message that even Mr. Clinton's two closest advisers on environmental policy -- Vice President Al Gore Jr. and Interior Secretary Babbitt -- may have had trouble grasping. Although both Mr. Gore and Mr. Babbitt have talked about marrying economic and environmental goals, their first actions as members of the new Administration suggested a strict conservationist agenda. In December, even before he took office, Mr. Gore promised to block the opening of a hazardous waste incinerator in Ohio. But three weeks ago, the White House overruled him and cleared the $160 million plant for commercial operation this month.
 
United in Portland
 For his part, Mr. Babbitt, the former chairman of one of the country's most influential environmental groups, had been riding the Western range for weeks touting a plan to protect public lands by requiring miners, loggers and ranchers to pay much more for Government-owned resources. After being warned by Senator Max Baucus, a Democrat from Montana, that regional loyalties supplanted party politics on such issues, Mr. Clinton easily compromised.
Mr. Clinton's decisions on the incinerator and land-use policy embarrassed Mr. Gore and Mr. Babbitt. But if there was any lingering discord, it was not visible in Portland on Friday. Flanked by the Vice President, the Interior Secretary and several other Cabinet members, President Clinton listened intently for hours to loggers and environmentalists and suggested that the age of big timber was ending.
Though nothing was decided in Portland, the week had tested Mr. Clinton's campaign promise to make economic and environmental concerns compatible, and had produced some lessons. Mr. Clinton signaled to business executives that it is he, not Mr. Babbitt or Mr. Gore, who commands the environmental agenda. And he signaled to environmentalists that their concerns were important enough to put near the top of his domestic priorities. Finally, said White House aides, Mr. Clinton, following the pattern he had established with daylong sessions on the economy and health care, was trying to broker a new approach to environmental policy-making through consensus.
Mr. Babbitt, who had been shot out of the saddle, rallied to his boss's defense. "Bill Clinton promised change and there will be change," he said last week.
The question is how much change and whether it will make any difference. As with Mr. Clinton's other daring early proposals, such as ending restrictions on Haitian immigration or opening the military to homosexuals, the President had promised much more on the environment than he was capable of quickly delivering.
In February, Mr. Clinton announced a proposal championed by Mr. Babbitt to radically change a century of practices that promoted development of the West at Government expense. Mr. Clinton billed the plan as an effort to raise revenue and reduce the deficit, though the extra revenue would amount to less than $1 billion over five years. The real importance of the plan, tucked into the Clinton budget package, was to manage millions of acres of Government land more carefully.
The Administration proposed to more than triple the grazing fees, now $1.86 a month for a cow and her calf, on 280 million acres. Interior Department officials said the intention, in addition to providing revenue, was to dissuade ranchers from abusing the land. The White House wanted to raise the price of timber from national forests and end the practice of offering it below the market price. And Mr. Clinton proposed royalties on gold, silver and other minerals that had been mined on Federal land under a law that had remained virtually unchanged since 1872.
The plan was hailed by environmentalists as a breakthrough in ending a century of Government-sanctioned destruction. But across the West, well-organized, influential groups of landowners, ranchers, loggers and miners raised a fuss and found supporters in senators from Mr. Clinton's own party.
The most powerful of those lawmakers is Senator Baucus, who is the new chairman of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee. Like two Democrats before him, Georgia's Senator Sam Nunn, who opposed homosexuals in the military, and Louisiana's Senator John Breaux, who had questions about Mr. Clinton's budget, Mr. Baucus found an opportunity to both solidify his support at home and to alert the White House that he was a player to be reckoned with .
With Mr. Babbitt, a former governor of Arizona, just getting his feet under him at the Interior Department, and without a single specialist in Western resource issues in the White House, the Administration was unprepared for Mr. Baucus's attack. After all, Mr. Baucus enjoyed the dependable if unenthusiastic support of national environmental groups in Washington. The Montana lawmaker had battled to prevent development of oil wells in Alaska and protect endangered species.
But Mr. Baucus also has deep roots in a way of life dependent on the land -- and an abiding interest in being re-elected. His family owns one of Montana's largest ranches. Last year Mr. Baucus sponsored legislation to cut a million acres of Federal forest in his home state, and he has consistently opposed increases in grazing fees and protected mining companies.
 
Western Heft
 Thus, Mr. Clinton's environmental intent became tempered by regional politics. Led by Mr. Baucus, a group of Western Democrats trooped down to the White House in late March after the House had voted on the plan, and negotiated a new deal with the President and Thomas F. McLarty, the chief of staff. According to White House aides who were close to the negotiations, Mr. Baucus made it plain that he had enough support in the Senate to scuttle Mr. Clinton's entire budget package, the centerpiece of his young Presidency.
Mr. Baucus demanded that the White House drop the fee increases from the budget plan. He also asked for an adjustment to the energy tax that Mr. Clinton had proposed to reduce its effect on farmers and industries in the West. According to a White House aide, Mr. Baucus then promised to support the Administration's effort to change some of the exploitive land-use practices in the West by seeking smaller fee increases through legislation and administrative efforts.
On Monday , the White House agreed to the demands. But before Mr. McLarty and other White House officials could explain the changes to members of the House or the press, Mr. Baucus sent a press release to Montana newspapers.
Trying to make the best of diminished possibilities, Mr. Babbitt said he would hold public hearings after which the Department of the Interior would establish grazing fees without legislation and would encourage better grazing practices by tying the fee levels to the quality of range management. Fees would be highest for ranchers who caused the most damage. And Mr. Babbitt said the President would support legislation sponsored by Mr. Clinton's friend from Arkansas, Senator Dale Bumpers, to amend the mining law to require royalties and to establish measures for cleaning up mining wastes.
"The politics of this was not handled in the best of fashion," said Representative Mike Synar, a Democrat from Oklahoma and chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on environment, energy and natural resources. "But we're going to get to the same place, just in a different manner. The fees on grazing, timber and mining are going up."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Gridlock In the Peace Business

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: BONN

 BODY:
With President Clinton, President Boris N. Yeltsin and practically every European leader in between tied up in knots over domestic problems, the United Nations, the NATO alliance and other international bodies have been hovering close to uselessness.
Last week, the most frustrating spectacle continued to be the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina. There, Serb commanders repeatedly blocked United Nations forces trying to deliver relief to starving Muslims in the east, but backed by neither the international will nor the power to insure peace. The parliament of Bosnia's Serbian nationalists rejected even a conditional acceptance of a peace plan already approved by the country's other two warring factions. One of the authors of the peace plan, former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance, ended his months of effort with little success, handing over his United Nations mediating role to Thorvald Stoltenberg, Norway's Foreign Minister. 
 In Brussels, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization agreed to enforce a United Nations-ordered air-exclusion zone over Bosnia, NATO's first operation in a war zone since its creation in 1949. Yet the Serbs have besieged Muslims mainly from the ground, with artillery and other forces, and hardly from the air at all. NATO remains unable to agree on the makeup of a ground force that could back up a peace accord if it is ever reached.
The international near-paralysis underlying such events results largely from the way both the world's crises and the domestic preoccupations of nations are intertwined. It is nothing new that chaos, or for that matter peace, often reigns through a complex interaction of national motivations; what is new is that the complexity is no longer obscured by the simplicity of bipolar confrontation and proxy wars.
It is certainly clear that solving conflicts is not necessarily any easier now that the United States and Russia are usually pulling on the same end of the rope instead of being at odds. The recent political turmoil in Russia demonstrated that.
Many diplomats believe that consistent pressure on the Serbs by the Russians, their cultural and diplomatic allies before communism, is needed for any settlement in the Balkans. But that pressure has dropped noticeably, diplomats say, since President Yeltsin's conservative adversaries in the Congress of People's Deputies started gaining ground while criticizing him for being too pro-Western.
No country is an island, to take John Donne one step further. Europe and the United States are willing to do what they can to help Russia bring about economic and political change, because if Russia disintegrates, so could world order, and with it most hope of using the cold war bonus to rebuild the West's suffering economies. Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher said the stakes were "enormous" at the meeting between Presidents Clinton and Yeltsin in Vancouver this weekend.
 
Leadership Void
 But the real tests for leadership are in places like Kuwait and Bosnia, and in the Balkans the West so far is getting a failing grade. Frustration over Bosnia helped prompt the American intervention in Somalia late last year.
With leadership lacking in Europe, Europeans have still not fully grasped the implications of the United States' decision, confirmed last week, to reduce its troop strength to 100,000 by the mid-1990's. Germans still ask Americans what Mr. Clinton would do if the Russians menaced Lithuania, or if Hungary and Romania started fighting, not realizing that the answer is: very little. From now on, American administrations will expect Europeans to first try to solve their problems by themselves.
But the war in the Balkans has pointed up the inadequacy of the European Community as an instrument of solving such conflicts. The resulting demoralization has domestic consequences, as well. Some commentators suggested that it was one reason for the Socialist defeat in France's elections last month. The past, meanwhile, weighs heavily on the strongest European power, Germany, which seems hopelessly divided over whether its soldiers can participate in peacekeeping missions.
The Germans sent cargo planes to drop supplies to Bosnian Muslims last week, for example, but bucked to a constitutional court the question of whether it was legal to leave German crew members on NATO surveillance planes after the Security Council voted to enforce the flight ban over Bosnia.
In Europe and the former Soviet Union, what has happened is a dangerous resurgence of 19th-century nationalism, with conflicts breaking out all over just where many of them left off in the 1930's when the first, Wilsonian attempt at a new world order failed.
What the effect of continued impotence will be on other world crises, from the Middle East to east Asia, is not hard to see. North Korea last month showed its contempt for international control over nuclear development by renouncing the non-proliferation treaty. Iraq has long shown similar disdain, and South Africa recently announced that it had secretly developed a nuclear arsenal and then dismantled it, all without any effective outside controls.
Muslim fundamentalism is a mounting concern in many countries, also with a connection to Western impotence in Bosnia. The Arab world has long believed that the West has a double standard for Israelis and Palestinians. If Muslims come to believe that the West wrote off Bosnia's Muslims, allies like Turkey could turn away from the West, with negative strategic consequences.
Sooner or later, unresolved resentments come home to roost. Muslim terrorists bombed the World Trade Center in New York City to protest what they saw as American complicity in humiliations in the Middle East. Everything is connected, and sooner or later Europe and the West may have to pay a price for their impotence in the Balkans.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Seattle Has a Plan: Urban Renewal for Fun

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
It is the Fourth of July in the year 2000, and another half-million people have moved to Seattle. Every gas station has an espresso machine subsidized by the city and Boeing machinists can work out of their homes.
In a summer mist, civic leaders cut the ribbon to Seattle's contribution to the dawning century: a grand new park in the center of the city, lined by apartments, town houses and open-air restaurants. A salmon stream runs down the middle of the manicured greenway and all the people who live in its vicinity have cellular phones. 
 Welcome to Seattle's dream du decade. A mix of indigenous goofiness and back-to-the-future practicality, the Seattle Commons is the centerpiece for this city's plan to build a series of "urban villages" over the next 20 years.
The urban village term comes from Mayor Norm Rice, who has broken with the city's no-growth tradition and proposed that Seattle should welcome newcomers rather than make fun of them. The Commons concept, which sprouted from the musings of a local newspaper columnist, has been embraced by the city's leaders as a jump-start out of a civic midlife crisis.
Most American cities are in a reactive posture, trying to hold onto the basics of public safety, fire protection or keeping the bridges from falling. Seattle, a city that spent its first 140 years tearing down its hills, filling in its tidelands, building the West Coast's largest office towers and recycling anything that wasn't bolted down, has never given up the self-improvement kick. The Space Needle, perhaps the city's most lasting icon, started as a doodle on a cocktail napkin in the infant Space Age.
As the metropolitan area has gone through unrelenting growth, with the suburbs pushing to the edge of the Cascade Mountains, Seattle's reaction has been to bemoan urban sprawl while carefully guarding its unique single-family neighborhoods. Under Mr. Rice, the city is openly welcoming growth, so long as it is channeled into one of the Mayor's half-dozen or so urban villages.
 
Suburban Flight
 The areas targeted for hyper-growth are underused or rundown semi-industrial areas stalled by commercial indecision. The Mayor's plan would bring parks, transportation hubs and other amenities in the village area while encouraging new high-density housing through zoning changes. Traffic is just bad enough to make political leaders bet that many people, especially families, are ready to pick in-city living over the suburbs.
In fact, families are willing to move back to most American cities if enough of the trimmings of suburban life -- safety, a good park, retail outlets -- are nearby, say urban experts. "The problem is when you're starting something new, on such a grand scale as Seattle is trying, you have to create really nice neighborhoods very soon," said Allen Altshuler, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.
Mr. Altshuler, who has studied Mayor Rice's urban village concept, said the plan has tremendous risks because of its scope. "But I think it can be done," he said. "Seattle is probably one of the few places that could make it happen because it has a tradition of in-city living and very little tradition of racial polarity."
The biggest of these urban villages would be the Commons, 470 acres of residences, small businesses, a school, a marina and a big park running down the middle. It would connect Lake Union to the downtown retail core and to the Seattle Center, where the major theater, ballet and opera companies are based.
Mayor Rice describes the Commons, and urban village concept in general, as "A community where people can shop, play and go to school, all within walking distance of where they work." The description may fit Manhattan -- and when you add the park, which is being billed here as a small version of Central Park, the comparison is even closer. But what the urban village visionaries are really trying to do is create a suburban feel inside the city.
But many critics of the park -- most notably the Seattle Times, the largest private land owner in the Commons -- have said the city could end with up little more than a very expensive new high-crime area.
Enter the cellular phone option. Many of the prominent early backers of the Commons are young, wealthy entrepreneurs who made their billions in high-tech. Paul Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft, has given the project a $20 million line of credit to buy land for the park. Another backer, Craig McCaw, head of McCaw Communications, the cellular phone giant, donated $1 million. He said he would like to see the Commons as a wireless community, where residents and workers would carry a phone at all times. Wireless phone service would cost about the same as normal phone lines if it was installed at one time, Mr. McCaw has said.
Mr. McCaw said his donation was not contingent on cellular phones being a part of the project. But it added a new dimension to the crime debate; backers said Commons residents would be only a press of 9-1-1 away from police help during evening strolls in the new park.
Mr. McCaw also has his corporate headquarters in the Commons neighborhood. He took a poll of his employees and found that most of them would like to walk or ride their bikes to work.
An aversion to the automobile is one of the major precepts of the urban village design. "Work, live, play -- all without a car, that's the driving vision behind the entire project," said Joel Horn, the director of the Commons project.
In presenting the Commons plan to the city, the backers wrote: "People are beginning to see the costs of abandoning the city -- traffic, long commutes, sprawl, the loss of rural open space and the loss of a sense of community. They are starting to return to the cities, not just to do business, but to live. The Commons is a response to the growing appetite for city living."
Several big obstacles are ahead of the Commons backers, who say they would like to open the park on July 4, 2000. One problem is cost. Now in the hands of its private founders, the Commons would become a city project next year if the Seattle City Council votes, as expected, to make it part of the mayor's urban village master plan.
It could cost up to $400 million to acquire all the land and build the park and its amenities. The money is supposed to come from short-term bonds and tax money from an anticipated rise in adjacent property values.
In theory, private developers will build the housing once the area is rezoned. But a variety of market conditions, not the least of which is the Boeing Company's plan to lay off 28,000 workers in the Seattle area over the next two years, could keep developers on the sidelines. Without the housing, the urban villages are nearly worthless, say critics.
But optimism around this project flows like the rain water that is supposed to drain the city's hills and recirculate into the salmon stream in the new park. Seattle, forever remodeling itself, seems incapable of unpacking its boxes and settling in.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Voting on The Budget: The Easy Part's Over

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
So far, the votes in Congress on President Clinton's economic program have been little more than tests of party loyalty. Democrat ranks held last week, and the House and Senate approved the outline of the President's five-year budget plan without the vote of a single Republican.
Now comes the hard part. 
 When Congress reconvenes the middle of this month after a break for Passover and Easter, the lawmakers will immediately begin dealing with what Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, calls "areas of quicksand" -- politically sensitive topics like Social Security and Medicare, military spending and energy taxes.
The Clinton Administration is under no illusions that its honeymoon can continue indefinitely. "I know it's going to be a lot tougher when you get to the details," said Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, one of the President's chief political and legislative strategists.
Mr. Clinton has already shown his willingness to back down to keep Democratic votes in line. To retain the support of several Western senators, he agreed last week to remove from the budget his proposal to raise fees for grazing and mining on Federal land. For farm-state lawmakers, he proposed that ethanol, the fuel made from grain, be exempt from energy taxes. For New Englanders, he agreed that the tax on home heating oil would be no higher than the tax on natural gas. He also scrapped his proposal to limit the cost-of-living increases in the pensions of civilians retired from Federal jobs.
But other matters are so central to the President's goal of simultaneously lowering the deficit and generating more public and private investment that they cannot easily be set aside. These are some of the ones likely to cause the most political fireworks:
Taxes on Social Security benefits Single retirees with annual incomes above $25,000 and couples with incomes above $32,000 now pay income taxes on up to half of their Social Security benefits. Mr. Clinton would tax up to 85 percent of their benefits, a proposal that would raise nearly $25 billion over the next five years.
Mr. Clinton argues that everyone must pay a price for deficit reduction and that only the richest 20 percent of retirees have enough money to be affected at all.
But Republicans and many Democrats maintain, with some justification, that the proposal makes a mockery of Mr. Clinton's campaign pledge not to raise the income taxes of anyone but the wealthy. A pair of retired schoolteachers with pensions totaling $30,000, dividends and interest of $5,000 and Social Security benefits of $15,000 could hardly be considered wealthy, but their taxes would rise by more than $550 a year.
Energy Tax To raise nearly $50 billion over five years, Mr. Clinton would place a new tax on nearly all fuels. When fully in force, it would raise the price of a gallon of gasoline by 7.5 cents and increase the typical homeowner's electricity bill by $2.25 a month. Treasury officials say that the average energy bill of a family of four making $25,000 a year, now $2,242, would rise by $105. But the cost of almost all consumer products would also rise, so the total cost to families of modest incomes would be considerably greater.
Mr. Clinton has said that this is the fairest tax that would raise enough revenue. Mr. Rostenkowski said he thought the members of his committee, who have the first crack at tax legislation, would "swallow hard" and accept the tax. But many important Democratic senators from oil-producing states, including J. Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, chairman of the Energy Committee, have vowed to try to defeat it.
Investment Tax Credit Mr. Clinton's proposal to give businesses a tax break on the investments they make in machinery and equipment would cost more than $20 billion over five years and would be offset by an increase in the corporate tax rate to 36 percent from 34 percent. The tax credit has little support in Congress, and executives in most businesses say they would rather keep the lower tax rate.
Mr. Rostenkowski and his counterpart in the Senate, Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, chairman of the Finance Committee, are at best unenthusiastic.
But Mr. Bentsen said the tax credit was an integral part of the President's program that would not be abandoned. "What the President is looking for," he said, "is the biggest bang for the buck, the best leverage for stimulating the economy, and you get that with the investment tax credit."
Military SpendingMr. Clinton wants to cut the military budget to $246 billion in the 1997 fiscal year from $273 billion now. Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the most important Democratic lawmaker on military matters, questions the wisdom of such a deep cut. But the main question here is not so much how the military budget will be received by Congress but exactly how the President and the Pentagon plan to bring it about.
The military budget for the next fiscal year, which was released last weekend, was called a "holding budget" by Defense Secretary Les Aspin. Details of just what cutbacks Mr. Clinton will seek in arms programs and troop strength await an assessment of the nation's military needs to be completed this summer.
Health Ultimately, Mr. Clinton's success or failure in domestic and economic policy will turn on his ability to develop and win enactment of a health-care system providing universal insurance coverage on the one hand and cost containment on the other.
Last week, Administration officials acknowledged that the original May 3 deadline for sending Congress the legislation would be missed and that the measure stood no chance of enactment before next year.
Mr. Rostenkowski, whose committee has jurisdiction over not just taxes but also health, said he thought it just as well that this year would be devoted to tax and spending measures and next year to the health system. The last time they talked about the health plan, he said he told the President, "This is going to take all your strength, all your attention, all your commitment."

HEADLINE: Conversations/Elizabeth A. Taylor;
Tourism's Latest Tough Sell: 'Waco, a Wonderful Place to Visit!'

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK

DATELINE: WACO, Tex.

 BODY:
"You could say a hidden advantage to all this is that everybody now knows where Waco, Tex., is," says Elizabeth A. Taylor, the city official in charge of marketing Waco as a tourism and convention destination. "All this," of course, refers to the bizarre standoff between an armed doomsday cult and hundreds of Federal agents that has played out on the central Texas prairie near here for over a month.
Ms. Taylor arrived to take over as director of the Waco Convention and Visitors Bureau on Feb. 27 -- exactly one day before a shootout at the cult's compound left at least six people dead and, however unfairly to this city of 100,000 people, left the name "Waco" synonymous with guns, violence and religious fervor run amok. She was unpacking boxes when the news came on the radio. Some might see her timing as a monumental case of bad luck, but Ms. Taylor, 32, has exuberantly assumed her new duties as the challenge of a professional lifetime. 
 "There's no doubt about it," says Ms. Taylor, who has shown up at daily F.B.I. news briefings loaded with brochures, maps and helpful advice about everything from where to eat to where reporters and agents could buy, ahem, clean underwear as the siege stretched on. "I think that once it's over we have a real opportunity to turn some lemons into lemonade and really tell people about Waco's story."
Waco does have a pleasant story to tell. "First of all, we're conveniently located," she says. "We have beautiful parks and the Brazos River and 14 museums." She proceeds to name nearly all 14, ticking them off on her fingers with a flourish. "We're the home of Dr Pepper. You can take your kids to the Dr Pepper Museum and see where it all got started. You can have a Dr Pepper float at the soda fountain there.
"And then there's the Texas Ranger Museum, which is the all-time favorite here," she continues. "It just truly is the all-time favorite."
But Ms. Taylor is the first to concede that for now, Waco will have to contend with being the butt of Jay Leno's jokes. This brings up an observation on her part: the city's name is pronounced WAY-Co, not WACK-O. She has even been ribbed by colleagues in the tourism-promotion industry about having the toughest job in America, but she hardly seems fazed.
"I guess I've developed a pretty thick skin, mainly because of my name," says Ms. Taylor. Her parents always loved "Elizabeth" and, she says, never thought through the complications of giving their daughter the name of a famous movie star.
 
Liz and Dick, Sort Of
 "Usually when I meet people they go, 'Right. Sure. You're Elizabeth Taylor.' " But she just laughs along and can even offer one of those amazing-but-true stories to complete the punch line. When she was an undergraduate at North Texas State University in Denton, she worked for a while as a news announcer on a local radio where the disk jockey was a fellow named Rich Burton. "It was a real scream," she says -- an all-night jazz and news show with Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor. "The calls would come in, people were on drugs or they were drunk and they thought they were just hearing things."
Some people in Waco are outraged that the city is getting all the attention when the standoff is actually just outside the city limits, in an unincorporated part of McLennan County. But Ms. Taylor has urged them to be calm about that particular injustice.
Yet even as she and other city officials are fretting over the long-term damage to Waco's viability as a vacation or convention site, the short-term effect is just the opposite. The siege has kept hotels and restaurants jammed for weeks with reporters and law enforcement agents and may yet amount to the greatest economic-development initiative the city has seen. "I don't think anyone is reveling in the reason that you-all are here," says Ms. Taylor. "But the plain fact is that you-all are spending money in Waco."
Her most immediate headaches actually stem from the fact that too many people want to come here. Just last weekend, she barely managed to avert a major confrontation when hundreds of Shriners showed up for a golf tournament, only to find Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agents sleeping in their beds. "So you've got some very persistent people here saying, 'Hey, we've got these reservations,' " Ms. Taylor recalls. Perhaps because city officials would prefer return business from the Shriners rather than from the camouflage-clad gun-toting agents, they let the Shriners prevail. "We very carefully relocated 40 rooms of Federal agents into other hotels," Ms. Taylor said.
But sooner or later, the standoff will end, the agents and the media will leave and Waco will need to address an image problem that Ms. Taylor's $220,000 advertising budget may not be able to overcome. Even now, her tourism representatives are having to field questions about whether it is safe to come to Waco, never mind desirable. The facts are that the standoff is miles from downtown and the F.B.I.'s biggest security problem lately has been religious fanatics trying to sneak into the compound. Still, people are worried.
 
Nervous Detours
 "We've had some inquiries from individuals who say, 'I've got to drive down to Austin or San Antonio for such-and-such, now if I stay on the interstate will I be safe?' " she says. "Because people don't realize we are not under siege, we do not have military blockades in the street."
Ms. Taylor grew up on a peanut farm in DeLeon (west Texas) and has managed tourist and convention bureaus in Georgetown (central Texas), Big Spring (west Texas) and Denton (north Texas). She majored in journalism but opted for tourism. "It's more fun helping people have a good time," she explains.
Ms. Taylor is not so worried about losing convention business because, she says, the people who plan them tend to be more concerned with hotel rates, the frequency of daily flights to Waco and other bottom-line questions.
"It's a standard set of questions, really," she says. "We're competing with Lubbock, we're competing with Midland-Odessa, we're competing with Abilene and Amarillo. We're competing with anybody who has a similar-sized facility."
There have been nervous jokes shared among city officials about running bus tours out to the compound when all this is over, turning the site into sort of a Ford's Theater of what will surely go down as one of the strangest episodes in the country's law-enforcement history. But Ms. Taylor doubts that such a strategy will ever be adopted.
"I don't know that there's any point to trying that," she says. "I think we're really trying to say, 'Okay, Waco's bigger than this. Waco can come out ahead of this.' "
And for Ms. Taylor, the $39,000-a-year-job in Waco has already evolved into more than just another line on her resume. "I guess it comes from me being a pretty adventurous spirit," she says. "My thinking is: Wow, this is going to be fun, kind of with a little dread but also with a little excitement. Boy, am I going to have another great chapter to add to my book -- that type of thing."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN VANCOUVER;
CLINTON PRESENTS BILLION TO YELTSIN IN U.S. AID PACKAGE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 3

 BODY:
As President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia began their first summit meeting today, Mr. Clinton presented the Russian leader with some $1 billion in American aid programs intended to support Russian democrats and spur the Western allies to make Russian reform their top foreign policy priority.
Among the new or expanded programs in the package were loan guarantees to build apartments for demobilized Russian soldiers; loans for Russian entrepreneurs; medical supplies, food and grain assistance; funds to help the Russian Government sell state-owned industries, and technical advisers to help repair pipelines and oil wells and begin exporting again. 
 Mr. Clinton said the package was intended to help promote free-market skills on a grass-roots level in both Moscow and the Russian countryside, so the movement toward democratic reform would continue no matter who governs in the Kremlin.
 
Cold-War Laws Cited
 But while aides said the two men had hit if off personally, the leaders also voiced complaints on several issues. Mr. Yeltsin complained bitterly to Mr. Clinton about laws from the cold war era still on the books in the United States, like those that tie Russia's trading privileges with the United States to Moscow's relaxation of emigration restrictions, and laws that restrict American investment in Russian high-tech industries that have potential military uses, like communications technology.
Mr. Yeltsin argued that Russia's behavior has changed so fundamentally that these laws should be repealed. The Russian leader also complained about the collision of an American submarine with a Russian submarine in the Barents Sea two weeks ago, for which Mr. Clinton expressed his regret.
 
Russian Military Send-Off
 Mr. Clinton voiced his concern about the behavior of Russian Army troops based in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, where they have been accused of siding with a separatist movement, and about the pace of Russian withdrawal from the Baltic republics, which was suspended this week.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin arrived in Vancouver this morning. Mr. Clinton flew in from Portland, Ore., where he moderated a conference between the timber industry and environmentalists, and Mr. Yeltsin came from Moscow, where he was seen off by the country's military leadership in a signal that they would insure that no one would try to topple the Russian leader while he was gone for the two-day summit meeting.
Mr. Yeltsin, who just narrowly survived a vote to remove him from office by the Russian Congress last weekend, said he would be running the country "by telephone" and that the "nuclear button" was in safe hands.
The Vancouver Province newspaper greeted the two leaders with various irreverent headlines, including "Bold Boris Comes Cap In Hand" and "For a Look At Bubba and the Bear Try These Sites."
Security around the meeting sites was provided by 2,000 Mounties, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. They guarded all access roads; all manhole covers were sealed and all mailboxes and newsstands were removed.
 
Anthems in the Rain
 Mr. Yeltsin stepped off his Aeroflot jetliner into a pouring rain and brushed aside an attempt by aides to protect him with an umbrella. He stood ramrod straight in the downpour as the Canadian and Russian national anthems were played.
Shortly after their arrival, the two Presidents drove through the gray mist to the campus of the University of British Columbia, on a wooded promontory overlooking the Pacific. They were joined for lunch there by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada at the sprawling Mediterranean-style home of the university's president. Mr. Mulroney, speaking of Mr. Yeltsin, told reporters after the lunch, "He and the President seem to be getting along like a house afire."
After bidding farewell to Mr. Mulroney, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin took a brief walk through a wood of shaggy evergreens to the university's Museum of Anthropology and then sat down to their first one-on-one session, with only note-takers and interpreters present.
What was most striking about this get-together was the degree to which both men appeared to be looking over their shoulders at their domestic fronts, as much as across the table at each other.
Mr. Clinton, apparently worried about polls showing many Americans opposed to increasing foreign aid for Russia at a time when they are being asked to cut domestic programs, promised that the United States would not try to solve Russia's problems alone.
"I want America to act, but America cannot and should not act alone." Mr. Clinton said in his regular Saturday radio program, broadcast as he arrived in Vancouver. "Just as we mobilized the world on behalf of war in the gulf, we must now mobilize the world on behalf of peace and reform in Russia."
 
Dangers of Too Much Aid
 Mr. Yeltsin, who has been under attack by Communists and nationalists in the Russian Congress who say he has sold out to the West, said on arrival that while his country needed Western help, too much of it would not be good because his opponents would only use it to paint him as a lackey of Washington.
Asked by reporters if $1 billion in new American aid was enough, Mr. Yeltsin said: "Too little is not good because it is not enough to enable you to solve problems, whereas too much also could be bad because it can be used by the Communists to target us. The opposition will say we are enshackled by the West. What we need is an optimal figure that will enable us to keep the reform afloat and not let the Communists come to power."
Mr. Yeltsin was not shy about letting Mr. Clinton know that without him the prospects of Russian reform would be greatly diminished, and therefore the West could not allow him to go home empty-handed.
"As long as there is President Yeltsin in power in Russia," Mr. Yeltsin told reporters on his arrival, "then definitely the reforms will continue."
 
A Long-Term Mission
 But while Mr. Yeltsin was obviously preoccupied with his own political future, Mr. Clinton repeatedly stressed in his arrival remarks that aiding Russia must be viewed as a long-term enterprise that cannot be judged in the short run, or according to the fate of any one person.
Aides said Mr. Clinton is trying to lead the American public to think differently about Russia, so the public will not want to withdraw aid in the midst of what are expected to be many false starts, back steps, and bumps along the way.
"I believe that what you will see building up over the next few weeks is a very significant effort to support a long term process in Russia," Mr. Clinton said. "It is important that the efforts be targeted to lasting and tangible benefits to people in Russia. I look at this as a long-term effort."
 
First Session on Economics
 American officials said the first one-on-one session was devoted entirely to economics, and began with Mr. Clinton sketching the broad outlines of what his Administration was ready to do now to support the Russian democratic movement. The President, aides said, outlined a three-pronged American approach.
While the White House held a briefing on the meetings, the Russians canceled the one they had planned.
Mr. Clinton said the package should be viewed as the American contribution to a much broader effort by the major Western democracies "to support a long-term process of developing Russia," which his Administration is orchestrating and which will become fully apparent in coming weeks as more countries announce aid. Already in the last two days, Britain and Canada have announced increases in aid to Russia, and after Mr. Clinton spoke by telephone with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan on Friday night, American officials expressed optimism that Japan would give more, too.
The first element in the American package outlined by Mr. Clinton involved roughly $1 billion in aid, drawn from funds already appropriated by Congress for fiscal 1993, either specifically to support Russian reform or from the international aid budgets of various government departments that will now be redirected for this effort.
This package included the following:
*Housing loan guarantees for the construction of several thousand housing units for Russian military officers stationed in the Baltic states, who have been reluctant to leave because they have no housing in Russia.
*An initiative that will provide the Russian Government with funds over three years to help sell off state-owned factories to the private sector. American business and accounting advisers and farmers will also be sent over to help these new private businesses in capitalist practices.
*An enterprise fund that will provide seed loans to Russian entrepreneurs.
*New agricultural grain credits to help the Russians obtain American wheat, despite being in default for failure to pay back $625 million in grain credits from 1991-92.
*Food, medicine and other nonmilitary assistance from surplus American military stocks, directed particularly at areas outside of Moscow.
*A technical assistance program to help repair and improve Russia's dilapidated natural gas and oil industry, so it can earn more foreign currency.
 
A List of Priorities
 The second element of the package consists of programs that the United States believes could also be helpful to Russian reform, but for which the money has not yet been appropriated by Congress for fiscal 1994.
While Mr. Clinton's fiscal 1994 budget calls for spending only about $700 million on aid programs for Russia and other former Soviet republics, he told Mr. Yeltsin that he was ready to go to the Congress and seek even more money because of the urgency he attaches to the success of Russian democracy.
The third element of the package included the President's thoughts on the types of multilateral assistance that could be provided to Russia -- including debt relief and currency stabilization funds -- through the Group of Seven major industrialized democracies and institutions like the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.
Mr. Clinton said Washington had discussed with its allies a package that could amount to as much as $30 billion in the form of aid to Russians who would be unemployed by the sell-off of state-owned industries, money to underwrite the importing of new machinery and spare parts and a $6 billion fund to help stabilize the inflation-ravaged Russian ruble.
Mr. Clinton, aides said, discussed with Mr. Yeltsin how far the Russian was ready to go in getting control of his country's runaway money supply, which would be crucial to how much outside financial institutions would be prepared to do. The President said he would convey Mr. Yeltsin's views to the Group of Seven, whose finance and foreign ministers will meet in Tokyo on April 14 and 15 to discuss Russian aid.
According to Russian officials, Mr. Yeltsin asked that Mr. Clinton convene a meeting of the Group of Seven heads of state no later than May to undertake this multilateral aid package, because to wait any longer could be dangerous for Mr. Yeltsin politically.
Asked if he was satisfied with the outcome of the summit meeting so far, Mr. Yeltsin said tonight that he was "very pleased."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN VANCOUVER;
One Year Later, Russians Doubt West's Aid Total

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 3

 BODY:
From the day the first parcels of relief aid were unloaded from American military aircraft at Moscow's international airport more than a year ago, Russians have been puzzled by what they see as the West's fumbling attempts to help their beleaguered country.
First, amid a blaze of publicity, came shipments of food, ranging from baby food to American military rations left over from the Persian Gulf war. Then the Group of Seven major industrialized nations patched together a complex $24 billion financial aid package intended to help Russia build a vibrant economy. 
 Now, after a year of watching a stream of Western consultants troop through Moscow, Russians are asking what happened to the $24 billion that was promised them last year. Some question whether it ever came at all.
 
Aid Missed Mark, Russians Say
 The answer, as Western economists have tried to explain at great length, is "no" and "yes, but. . . ." From the West's point of view, Russia's failure to meet payments on its loans has in effect been hidden assistance.
The problem was that the $24 billion package never focused adequately on meeting the country's needs, some in Russia argue. Instead it consisted of a hodgepodge of old loans, a few give-away programs and new credits contingent on conditions that proved impossible to meet.
Only a little more than half of the $24 billion was actually delivered, although some Western Governments and institutions say the figure is closer to two-thirds. The difference between what was promised and what was given arose mostly because loans and a $6 billion ruble stabilization fund planned by the International Monetary Fund were contingent on harsh austerity measures that were not adopted. These measures included bringing monetary and budget policies under control.
Of the aid that has been disbursed, only a small portion has been in the form of outright give-aways. Last year, Russia received 476,000 tons of food, valued at $700 million, and $200 million worth of medicine donated by public and private sources.
 
Aid or Business Deals?
 The core of the aid package was an $11 billion commitment for credits issued by several Western countries, of which about $8 billion was actually distributed in 1992.
To many Russians, these credits were not so much aid as business arrangements that helped the lending nations find markets for their goods more than it helped Russia pay for them. Most of these credits were granted to the old Soviet Union. They are not distributed in cash, but in the form of food, industrial equipment or other items purchased by Russia from the lending countries on normal commercial terms.
Because of its debt problems, Russia has not been in a position to obtain commercial bank loans to buy these commodities. In that sense, the credits offered by the West are a boon. But not surprisingly, many Russians are less than grateful for what they see simply as an opportunity to buy things from their benefactors.
"Most of these credits are a prepackaging of old programs, circulated by the lending countries for their own domestic purposes," said Denis Kiselyov, chief of the analysis unit at the World Bank offices in Moscow. "It is very difficult to qualify them as aid."
 
Biggest Chunk Goes for Feed
 For instance, $3.5 billion -- the single biggest loan in the package -- is a credit from the United States to buy American grain, to be used mostly for livestock feed, as part of a program that has been around for decades.
Other foreign credits have been used to purchase machinery, equipment and spare parts. How the money has actually been spent is difficult to track. For the most part, the credits were allocated to Russian industries, just as they were in the days of Gosplan, the monster state planning agency of the old Soviet state.
This summer, in an effort to introduce market economics into the system, the Russian Government required factories receiving the parts or equipment to pay back the foreign credits themselves, with interest.
Mr. Kiselyov said this approach has been resisted by some crucial industries which, through powerful lobbies, are able to plead for special treatment.
Over the last few years, Russia has been the beneficiary of numerous special aid programs, not all of them included in the $24 billion package. Since 1989, Germany has provided about $48 billion in cash and credit guarantees -- much of it to buy Moscow's acquiesence to the unification of Germany. Most of the aid has been used to build housing for returning Soviet military officers. The United States is also providing $800 million to help the Russian Army dismantle and dispose of its nuclear arsenal.
In the meantime, private programs have been established, of which the most spectacular is the international Science Foundation, founded by the American financier George Soros, which in the next two months plans to distribute $10 million to 20,000 scientists in Russia and the other former Soviet republics.
When the Group of Seven industrialized nations first came up with the $24 billion figure for Russia, they also proposed to deliver another $20 billion to the other states of the former Soviet Union. But so far the other states -- with the exception of the three Baltic nations -- have received no money because they continue to use the Russian ruble as their currency and therefore are not in control of their monetary policy.
One of the main reasons for the failure of the International Monetary Fund to distribute its loans is that there has been a running feud between the Government and the Central Bank, which is answerable to a legislature dominated by opponents of Mr. Yeltsin's economic reforms.
For example, the Central Bank has resisted pressure to curb loans and subsidies that have fueled Russia's 25 percent monthly inflation, and only recently was it persuaded to release critical information about its operations, a prerequisite for the next round of negotiations with the monetary fund.
Western creditors say that a major part of their aid to Russia has been a set of marathon negotiations to reschedule the payments due on $80 billion in past debts, and on Friday the Western governments reached an agreement to let Russia postpone $15 billion worth of payments falling due in the next year.
To the West, granting Russia a more relaxed repayment schedule amounts to a huge break. But for average Russian citizens, debt reschedulings, loans, credits and stand-by agreements are abstract notions.
 
Russian Resentment
 What Russians see, instead, are Western food products -- cooking oil, butter, dried milk -- that have trickled into their stores, and Western medicines dispensed mostly through hospitals and clinics.
Some items have stirred feelings of resentment and embarrassment among Russians. Some Russians are convinced that most aid has either been stolen, or diverted by the "mafia" for private gain.
Recently, Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi charged that 60 percent of the aid had been siphoned off by "commercial structures," which he said pocketed $59 million in profit.
Countering the criticism, Aleksandr A. Zhitnikov, first deputy chairman of the Government commission that distributes the aid, vigorously defends his program. Early on, the Government chose to sell the donated goods to commercial outlets, with the proceeds going to special social welfare funds. Russia's federal social welfare fund, for example, got $20 million from the sale of American butter and Taiwanese rice.
"The majority of the population regards aid with understanding," said Mr. Zhitnikov.
 
Trust Us, Administrator Pleads
 Mr. Zhitnikov and his commission have objected to some conditions placed on the aid -- such as the initial requirement that it be targeted for Moscow and St. Petersburg, even though these cities contain only 10 percent of Russia's population. "The West needs to trust us and our assessment of where the needs are," he said.
Taking advantage of the West's reawakened interest in Russia's problems, the Russian Government has stepped up a campaign to force an opening on Western markets for Russian goods and commodities which, it says, is more important in the long run than more short-term loans.
"The Americans are talking about expanding aid to Russia," said Sergei Y. Glazyev, Russia's Foreign Trade Minister. "What we demand is a free access of Russian goods to the markets of developed countries, including that of the United States, and an end to discrimination against Russia in foreign markets."

HEADLINE: Florida Blazes Trail to a New Health-Care System

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., April 3

 BODY:
The Florida Legislature approved a sweeping overhaul of the state's overburdened health-care system early today, making Florida the first state in the nation to combine free market competition and government regulation in a way similar to the Clinton Administration's plans for controlling soaring medical costs.
Overcoming obstacles posed by lobbyists who sought to gut the proposal with hundreds of amendments, Gov. Lawton Chiles, the author of the plan, won bipartisan support for his package after three days of marathon deliberations in the State Capitol and threats to call lawmakers back for a special session if the plan was voted down. The difficulties the Governor faced provide a glimpse into the resistance that President Clinton is likely to confront in his efforts to revamp the system. 
 Mr. Chiles said he hoped that Florida's embrace of a system of managed competition, in which large numbers of people and businesses buy health care from organized networks of doctors and hospitals, would be a model for other states as well as Washington. "We would like to be able to chart the way for the Federal Government," he said.
 
Biggest State Experiment
 Other states have taken steps toward broad changes in their health-care systems, including Hawaii, Oregon, Vermont and Minnesota. But Florida's plan, which will tryto cover most people eventually and at the same time to control health costs, is taking place on a larger scale than anything seen elsewhere.
In part, Florida's lawmakers were pushed to act by the soaring health-care spending, which rose to $38 billion last year from $9.4 billion in 1980. Another factor was the size and composition of the state's population. Florida's 13.5 million residents include the highest proportion of elderly people in the nation, as well as large numbers of immigrants and rural and urban poor. In addition, businesses with 50 or fewer employees, the companies most affected by rising health-care costs, account for 95 percent of all jobs in the state.
As a phalanx of lobbyists representing hospitals, insurance companies, doctors, drug manufacturers, pharmacists, malpractice lawyers, laboratories and other interests watched, both houses of the state legislature authorized the creation of 11 Community Health Purchasing Alliances. As envisioned by Mr. Chiles, these new state-chartered regional cooperatives will help employers obtain the best care at the cheapest price and decide what kind of care plans can be offered on the market.
As a result, 2.5 million uninsured residents in the nation's fourth-most populous state should be able to obtain what Mr. Chiles has described as "full access to quality, affordable health care." People already enrolled in health-care plans will be able to remain with those programs, although some premiums are expected to rise initially. Eventually many insurers and employers are expected to participate in the purchasing alliances.
The plans will also be open to self-employed, unemployed and low-income people. Depending on their incomes, they may qualify for state or Federal subsidies.
"I don't think there will be immediate savings," Mr. Chiles, a Democrat, said shortly after the State Senate passed the package at 1 A.M. today. "But I do think there will be people getting health care who never had a chance to get it before, and there will be small businesses that will be able to cover their people that they were not able to cover before."
Mr. Chiles said that although health care costs would not immediately drop, "I don't think we will see the 15 to 20 percent increase in premiums that we have seen every year for the last five years." He added, "We have got to stop the spiraling increases, and then we'll talk about savings."
 
Questions Still Not Answered
 Many practical questions remain unanswered. Because Florida's approach is untested, no one knows how much the system will cost or save. Nor is it clear what the minimum benefits will include and what sort of treatment guidelines will be applied to doctors who choose to take part in the system.
"This is an experiment," said Doug Cook, director of the state's Agency for Health Care Administration and Mr. Chiles's chief adviser on health issues. "We're going to have to see how it works as we go along. This is the first shot across the bow, and there aren't any guarantees."
Mr. Cook acknowledged that the initial phase of the program would require additional investment by both the state and Federal governments to provide coverage to people not now insured. He said he anticipated that both Federal and state authorities would be willing to increase aid.
But the bill's backers here, who included both conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats, argue that as more and more people gain access to health care, costs will ultimately be reduced. Through the large volume they are expected to generate, the 11 local health-care alliances would be able to obtain the best price for consumers, while insuring a steady flow of business to participating doctors.
Mr. Chiles's package nearly foundered as a result of arguments over how much authority the purchasing alliances should be granted. On Thursday night, the Florida Senate voted down a plan that would have allowed the cooperatives to decide what type of health-care plans would be offered to employers, establishing that a minimum of three types of plans be made available.
Opponents of Mr. Chiles's plan objected both to granting broad power to the alliances and the Governor's insistence that he be allowed to appoint the majority of the 17 members of the boards supervising each cooperative. With so much government participation, "you are in fact creating a system that leads to socialized medicine," Alberto Gutman, a Miami Republican who is chairman of the Senate Health Committee, said in an interview. "You are setting up a one-payer system that is like a utility, and I have never seen the price of a utility go down."
Doctors and their allies favored a much weaker organization, in which the purchasing alliances would serve primarily as information clearing houses for individual businesses looking for the coverage best suited to their needs. In the words of Dr. Mathis L. Becker, chairman of the Florida Medical Association's Council on Legislation, the cooperative should be "a place to come in and get a bunch of brochures."
But through old-fashioned negotiation and repeated reminders that the Federal Government might impose a solution that did not take Florida's needs into account, Mr. Chiles was able to win over most of those who had opposed his plan. Of the 10 state senators who voted against the plan, several were liberal Democrats who said they concerned the overhaul did not go far enough.
Mr. Chiles was willing to compromise, for instance, on the thorny issue of whether Medicaid recipients and state employees should automatically be enrolled in the purchasing alliances. State employees will be allowed to choose whether they want to join. And recipients of Medicaid, the joint state and Federal program for the poor and disabled, will be put into a separate pool so that, as Mr. Gutman put it, "the costs to non-Medicaid people do not increase."

HEADLINE: Truly Modern Filibuster: Choreographed Gridlock

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
On what was supposed to be an off day, the Senate came to work this morning just long enough to certify that it cannot agree to vote on President Clinton's jobs bill, to register a few political accusations and to plot its next battle.
Then it quit until Monday, when most lawmakers who were collared by reporters outside the chamber seemed to think that they would do pretty much the same thing all over again. 
 "I am assuming I can cancel my trip to Bosnia and Russia," said Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat who had intended to fly today.
This is the modern Senate filibuster. It is nothing like the popular image, enshrined in Jimmy Stewart movies and old newsreels, of obstinant lawmakers delivering all-night stemwinders and reading from phone books.
 
Religion, Sunset and Games
 To the contrary, this exercise in gridlock is not only completely choreographed, but also contrived to give everybody as much time on television and as little inconvenience as possible.
Sensitive to religious concerns (and, some might suggest, to the opening of the baseball season on Monday in nearby Baltimore), the lawmakers are taking off Palm Sunday and planning to meet only briefly Monday morning. They will also interrupt their deliberations in deference to Passover, which begins at sundown Monday, a few hours before the national collegiate basketball championship game.
So relaxed is this struggle over the nation's economic health that only 89 of the 100 senators showed up today, nine fewer than on Friday.
In truth, the Republicans, who are staging the filibuster to block the President's proposal, do not need to be here at all. The Democrats need 60 votes to end debate and force a vote on the bill, a $16.3 billion amalgam of public works projects and spending increases for Federal agencies. But there are only 57 in the entire Democratic membership, so unless some Republicans defect, the majority senators are powerless.
In the only action today, the Democrats got 52 votes, all from their own party. The 37 Republicans in attendance voted to keep talking.
 
Looking Toward Wednesday
 Some predicted the two sides would begin to reason together by Wednesday, when Passover has ended, Mr. Clinton has returned from meeting President Boris Yeltsin of Russia, and lawmakers have wearied of argument.
To call this debate leisurely is not to mock its seriousness. Mr. Clinton, and many Senate Democrats, argue that the legislation will create 200,000 jobs. They also believe it wrong for the Republicans to toss obstacles before a new President's economic program, particularly when his election victory rested largely on unhappiness with his predecessor's fiscal stewardship.
"Grass-roots Americans want to end the gridlock and get the economy moving," Mr. Clinton said in his Saturday radio address. "Unfortunately, some people in Washington, D.C., haven't gotten the message that the people want fundamental change."
Speaking of the Republicans, Senator Donald Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said today: "This is Presidential politics, plain and simple. They're prepared to wound this President, to wound his chances to help this country."
The Republicans have coalesced against the jobs bill in part because the Democratic majority tried to ram it through in a way that denied them any chance to offer amendments. They also argue that the bill would increase the deficit, create few permanent jobs and is ridden with pork.
Not long ago, they might have held the floor for days and nights on end to block it, but these days, all-night speeches are more for show than effect. Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, staged one last year to dramatize his support for a threatened Long Island factory, and former Senator William Proxmire, a Wisconsin Democrat, orated nocturnally every so often about the public debt.
True filibusters began to die in the mid-1960's, when the Senate managed to break a Southern roadblock against the 1964 Civil Rights Act.
The last filibuster worthy of the name, Senate officials say, was back in 1988, when Republicans successfully blocked a Democratic overhaul of campaign-spending laws. The Capitol Hill police arrested Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon, and carried him into the Senate so Democrats could have enough members on hand to conduct business.
"The Republicans have their blood up, and well they might," Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said today. "And I think they kind of enjoy it."
