HEADLINE: CLINTON IS CAUGHT BY BOSNIA DILEMMA

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG with MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3

 BODY:
The Bosnian Serbs' rejection of a plan for peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina brings President Clinton face-to-face with the question he raised during the Presidential campaign and has avoided ever since: Should the United States use force to stop the fighting in Bosnia?
Now, the Serbs have called the Administration's bluff -- betting, in essence, that Washington will not respond with force and that they can weather sanctions while they continue grabbing land in Bosnia. Even today, fighting was reported in Sarajevo and the eastern enclave of Srebrenica, in violation of a cease-fire.
 
'Argument Still Goes On'
 Administration officials said that they plan to support tighter sanctions against the former Yugoslavia in meetings at the United Nations next week, and then to look into exempting Bosnia from the arms embargo. Already today, the Security Council called for more peacekeepers in eastern Bosnia, but did not respond to a request that the peacekeepers take over Srebrenica to save the besieged residents. 
 While there is an Administration consensus on sanctions, there is no agreement about what, if any, military action to take if those efforts fail. "Where the rubber hits the road is the use of force," said one senior Administration official. "The argument still goes on."
Since Mr. Clinton took office, he has relied on diplomacy and economic sanctions as his weapons. He has said he was willing to send ground troops, something he once opposed, but only in the role of peacekeepers to enforce an agreement honored by all sides.
On Friday, the Bosnian Serbs brought the Clinton White House full circle. During the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton ruled out ground troops but called for air strikes against the Serbs and said the West must be tough in discouraging the ethnic aggression unleashed by the fall of Communism.
After taking office, President Clinton shelved the most muscular military options and sought instead to improve a peace pact that recognizes some of the Serbs' victories, but denies them their aim of annexing parts of Bosnia.
Critics inside and outside Government argue that Mr. Clinton's initial decision against arming the Bosnians or using force amounted to a failure of will that emboldened the Serbs. Mr. Clinton's aides insist they are doing far more than their predecessors, and argue that Mr. Clinton's shift in position is part of the education of a President who is still at the mercy of shifting international realities and who needs to keep his domestic agenda of economic renewal in the forefront.
 
Toughest Foreign Policy Issue
 A reconstruction of the Clinton Administration's decision-making on Bosnia, based on interviews with officials, has brought to light new details about what officials call their toughest foreign policy dilemma.
Limits were set at the outset on the extent of Washington's involvement. The Clinton Administration concluded shortly after taking office that Bosnia's travail, though tragic, did not amount to a "never again" scenario that morally compels America to intervene. Rolling back all the Serbs' territorial gains, about 70 percent of Bosnia, was not a realistic goal, officials decided.
The value of using force has prompted conflicting advice from the Pentagon. Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has persuaded some top policy makers that air strikes would not silence the artillery around Sarajevo or deter Serbian aggression. But Defense Secretary Les Aspin has argued in meetings that air raids could deter Serbian attacks.
Although the Administration has placed great hopes on the effect of tighter sanctions, the Central Intelligence Agency recently concluded a study that says they will have little immediate effect on the fighting in Bosnia. The Serbs' weapons are so abundant, the agency said, that they are exporting arms to raise cash.
They also discussed the effect on President Boris N. Yeltsin, who told the Administration that tough action against the Serbs could further jeopardize his position with the Russian Parliament. Serbs and Russians have historically been allies.
In July, Mr. Clinton issued a statement that said: "If the Serbs persist in violating the terms of the current cease-fire agreement, the United States should take the lead in seeking United Nations Security Council authorization for air strikes against those who are attacking the relief effort." Later, he said Washington should be prepared to use force to free the prisoners held in Serbian detention camps.
 
Response to Bush Challenge
 The remarks served a political purpose. At the time, President George Bush was asking whether his opponent had the steel to be Commander in Chief, attacking Mr. Clinton's inexperience in foreign affairs, his avoidance of the draft and his lukewarm support for the Persian Gulf war. In taking an assertive stance on Bosnia, Mr. Clinton fought back and used the Bush Administration's inaction on the issue as evidence that Mr. Bush lacked the vision to lead the post-cold-war world.
The Clinton team began the Presidential transition eager to reverse the Bush policy. Bosnia was the subject of Presidential Review Directive 1, the first issue on the White House's foreign policy agenda. The issue was considered so important, it was sent directly to "the principals," a committee made up of Secretary of State Warren Christopher; Mr. Aspin; the Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey; Vice President Al Gore; General Powell, and Madeleine K. Albright, the United Nations delegate.
The Administration instructed the State Department and Pentagon to draw up the broadest possible list of options, but many were discarded.
With the President elected on a platform of domestic change, "clearly he was not going to entertain the option of 'going in' in a major way," an official recalled. Each proposed cure, they said, seemed to have side effects that were as bad as the disease -- or worse.
At the Administration's orders, the Pentagon drew up a list of possible bombing targets, including the artillery around Sarajevo, bridges between Bosnia and Serbia, and targets deep in Serbia. General Powell repeated his argument that bombing would not seriously hamper the Serbs' ability to wage war, persuading some senior officials, but not Mr. Aspin.
 
Escort Troops Ruled Out
 Another possibility, adding American troops to the United Nations contingent delivering aid to Bosnia, was ruled out. "If you send in forces to escort humanitarian aid, and the situation gets worse, you're in a quagmire," one official said.
Arming the Bosnians was more complicated. Mr. Clinton and most of his aides favored this step, while others argued that no peace settlement would endure until the Muslims reclaimed a reasonable amount of the land and were able to protect themselves against Serbian efforts to drive them from their homes.
Britain and France, fearing Serbian retaliation, said they would pull their troops out of the United Nations operation in Bosnia if the arms embargo were lifted. Though Bosnian officials told the Pentagon months earlier that they would rather have guns than food, senior Administration officials felt they could not risk the starvation of thousands of people.
Russia was another factor. Administration officials worried that Moscow might veto any move by the Security Council to lift the embargo.
Miss Albright, the United Nations delegate, was especially gloomy. "Every time this topic comes up," one senior official said, "Madeleine rolls her eyes and says: 'You may get the Security Council to approve a no-fly zone, but you will not get this.' "
The same factors were seen as likely to block Security Council approval of air strikes against the Serbs.
Europe's objections to arming the Bosnians or air strikes were reinforced by Lord Owen, the European Community peace envoy, and Cyrus R. Vance of the United Nations. As Mr. Clinton began his policy review, Mr. Vance and Mr. Owen said the factions were close to agreement. They mobilized European officials against the options Clinton presented in the campaign.
 
Qualms About Peace Plan
 On Feb. 5, at their third meeting on Bosnia, senior Administration officials had serious qualms about the Vance-Owen plan, which they criticized because it partitioned Bosnia on ethnic grounds and ratified the gains the Serbs had achieved through violence.
Nonetheless, the consensus was to give diplomacy a chance. Officials understood that if the United States wanted a direct role in the talks, it would have to ante up troops for the peacekeeping force.
The aides agreed on a package of options: Push the United Nations to enforce a no-flight zone over Bosnia; strengthen economic sanctions, send an American envoy to the peace talks, and signal willingness to help enforce an accord.
An hour and half after the meeting began, Mr. Clinton sat down at the table. The President said he was inclined to agree with his aides' recommendations, but wanted the weekend to think the decision over.
On Feb. 8, after one last phone call to General Powell, Mr. Clinton signed a presidential directive ordering the steps. Two days later, Mr. Christopher announced the policy, using strong words to propose restrained actions.
 
Campaign Promises Abandoned
 The Secretary of State was well aware that his announcement represented an abandonment of the campaign promises. "Our options are less good than they were at the time the President spoke when he identified in August the need to take aggressive action on this subject," he said.
Former Bush Administration officials call these rationalizations, and say that most of the obstacles to forceful military action cited existed in August. "They need to explain better than they have how the options that looked so good during the campaign look so bad now," said Arnold Kanter, Undersecretary of State for Political Affairs in the Bush Administration.
Differences among Administration officials widened after Mr. Christopher announced the policy, particularly over the circumstances under which Americans would join a peacekeeping force. Both Mr. Aspin and General Powell want to wait weeks to make sure the warring factions are making a good-faith effort to implement a treaty before stepping in to police it. The State Department, the C.I.A. and NATO agree that any pact will unravel without swift, large troop deployments. That dispute is likely to reemerge if the Serbs change their mind and sign the peace pact.
Meanwhile, Administration officials believe there is only a small constituency for tougher steps on Bosnia. One official cited a poll that found only 10 percent of respondents want to go beyond sending peacekeepers.
The political pressures also are clear. On Capitol Hill, there is little support for military adventures in the Balkans. Few legislators have joined Representative Frank McCloskey, the Indiana Democrat, who recently sent Mr. Clinton a letter in which he said: "Western defeatism in the face of genocide stands exposed. Your Administration is saying that the U.S. will tolerate land grabs at the end of the 20th century: we will not come to Bosnia's defense with the awesome airpower at our disposal."
 
 
BALKAN UPDATE
 Bosnian Serbs meeting in Bileca reaffirmed their contempt yesterday for the Bosnia peace plan drawn up by mediators, declaring they were determined to pursue their goal of dividing Bosnia into three parts, despite international sentiment. In a second vote on the plan, they rejected it 68-0, with one abstention.
The Muslim-led Government of Bosnia threatened to resume full-scale war against the Bosnian Serbs unless the West persuaded Serbian nationalists to sign the peace accord soon.
But Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today in Vancouver that he believed the Bosnian Serbs might still accept the plan and suggested it was possible that the proposal could be adjusted to accommodate some of their concerns.
Conditions deteriorated in Srebrenica in eastern Bosnia, where approximately 60,000 Muslim civilians are trapped, when Bosnian Serbs blocked further United Nations aid convoys but said they would allow empty trucks to enter to evacuate the Muslims.
 At the United Nations, the Security Council approved a statement condemning the Bosnian Serbs for blocking the relief effort and asked for more peacekeeping troops in Eastern Bosnia, but it did not act on a recommendation to send troops to Srebrenica. It expects to meet on Monday to discuss further sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro, the two remaining republics in Yugoslavia.
Increasing violations of the fragile, week-old cease-fire were reported in both Srebrenica and in Sarajevo, the capital, United Nations observers said.

HEADLINE: With Europe in Flux, No More Politics as Usual

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 1

 BODY:
With public opinion polls showing voters all over Europe fed up with the political leaders and parties that have dominated politics for decades, at first glance the French elections held last weekend seemed to reaffirm the strength of mainstream democratic politics.
On a continent where far-right parties have been making hay out of rising popular frustration over the social and economic problems caused by foreign immigration and turmoil in formerly Communist countries, this was no small comfort. 
 But three years after the epochal changes that followed the collapse of Communism in Europe, signs of crisis in the political systems that insured the success of its free societies during the cold war remain evident from Britain to Germany in the north and from Spain to Greece in the south.
"My children are aged between 17 and 20, and when they get together with their friends, they don't talk about politics," said Jean-Manuel Bourgois, a French publisher. "They talk about whether any of them or their friends will have jobs after they finish their studies."
 
The Future Is the Issue
 Worry about mounting unemployment and the sagging economy is the underlying issue everywhere, but there is also confusion about the purpose and strategic future of Western European societies now that "Western Europe" is no longer forced to lead a separate existence.
The French, with more than 3 million people out of work -- 10.6 percent of the labor force -- did what voters in the United States did in November after they concluded that the government was incapable of solving the problem. They threw the governing party out and brought in the opposition.
And, just as nearly a fifth of American voters registered their frustration by voting for Ross Perot, nearly 20 percent of the French electorate supported environmental movements and parties like the far-right National Front of Jean-Marie Le Pen.
But the new conservative Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, now has two years to show that he can do better trying to solve economic problems and to define the new Europe than Francois Mitterrand and the Socialists.
 
Out of Ideas
 It is in addressing the future of Europe that the real problems begin, because the European economies are closely linked, and in Germany and Italy as well as in France, leaders and parties that have been in power for years have run out of fresh ideas.
There is also a sense that conventional politics is increasingly corrupt, and its practitioners are being discredited. In Italy, an entire generation of leaders stands accused of having been in the pocket of organized crime.
Here, Mr. Mitterrand's party was weakened by scandals over alleged financial corruption and the health service's mishandling of blood supplies tainted by the human immunodeficiency virus, which causes AIDS.
In Spain, the Government of Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, in office since 1982, has been steadily losing popularity because of corruption scandals and soaring unemployment. Jose Maria Aznar, leader of the opposition People's Party, contends that the French election presaged a similar outcome in Spain later this year.
"The French have put an end to an administration that, just as in Spain, offered a sad balance of unemployment and generalized corruption," he said.
 
Scandals in Germany
 In Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl faces general elections in the fall of 1994. Since unification, his conservative-liberal coalition Government has been paralyzed by one petty scandal after another, as well as by a broader indecision about the economic and strategic problems.
The most recent scandal involves the Transport Minister, a man from eastern Germany named Gunther Krause, who insisted on getting a sizable Government subsidy for his cleaning woman. Since she found the job through the state labor office, the subsidy was perfectly legal; but politically it was a big mistake at a time when Germans are being called upon to make sacrifices to pay the unification bills.
"If you pay taxes, you're helping to clean the Krauses' house," one radio commentator put it the other day.
Mr. Kohl's Social Democratic opponent, Bjorn Engholm, is in no better shape after disclosures that a key party ally had been making payments to a member of Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats, who had tipped off Mr. Engholm about plans to discredit him five years ago by spreading false rumors.
 
Discord Over Immigrants
 The German parties fought with each other for years about how to cope with the rising tide of foreign asylum-seekers and illegal immigrants.
Strong showings in regional elections by right-wing German parties like the Republicans, and a wave of far-right attacks against foreigners last year that killed 17 people, raised fears that Germans were sliding back into evil old ways.
But in France, the National Front party of Mr. Le Pen, who appeared at campaign rallies with a private police force that bore stronger resemblance than anything in Germany today to the Nazi SA paramilitaries, drew a strong protest vote in the first round of the two-stage French elections.
"I voted Le Pen in the first round because no other party came out and said what's really rotten in France today," said Francois Barbey, an unemployed real-estate salesman in Fontenay-sous-Bois. "France is losing its cultural and national identity under a tide of foreign immigrants. The whole hill in back of my house is full of welfare housing projects, and foreigners have most of the apartments."
 
No Seats at the Edges
 Mr. Le Pen's party won no seats in the French Legislature in the second runoff round on March 28, and neither did the coalition of environmental parties that represented the other side of the spectrum of what many had hoped or feared would turn out to be a new politics to replace the old.
Brice Lalonde, a former environment minister who lost his seat in the elections, explained the defeat as a rejection of socialist policies. "A lot of French people don't know what it means to be French anymore," he said.
Mr. Bourgois was worried that many voters would still feel disenfranchised. "Farmers and fishermen have already taken to the streets, and there could be a lot of violence ahead if things don't go well," he said.
The farmers and fishermen have been protesting against European Community policies they blame for costing them their livelihoods.
[A wave of strikes and demonstrations on Friday from Britain to Italy brought a million people into the streets, with many protesting the community's inability to do anything about the rise in unemployment.]
But the community itself has been largely paralyzed for more than a year by the difficulty of ratifying the treaty on monetary and political union on which its leaders agreed in Maastricht, the Netherlands, in late 1991.
 
More Votes on Treaty
 Danish voters rejected it last June but will vote again on May 18. Depending on what happens, Britain's Parliament will vote on the treaty in the fall. Rejection by any one of the 12 member countries would leave it dead.
In both France and Germany, a revival of French-German cooperation is seen as the best way of reinjecting vigor into the European Community, and almost the first thing Mr. Balladur did after being named was to announce plans to see Mr. Kohl.
The new French Government is expected to press the Germans harder than Mr. Mitterrand did to get the independent Bundesbank to lower short-term German interest rates and to allow the French to bring theirs down and stimulate their flagging economy.
"The Germans are used to living quite happily for the past 12 years with a weak France," said Pierre Lellouche, foreign policy adviser to Jacques Chirac, leader of France's conservative neo-Gaullist party.
But like many German politicians and bankers, Mr. Lellouche said he thought the common European currency foreseen by the Maastricht treaty would never come to pass.
"The treaty is a dead letter," Mr. Lellouche said.
Marie-France Garaud, an opponent of the treaty who is president of the International Institute of Geopolitics in Paris, disagreed. "There is already a de facto common currency," she said, "the Deutsche mark."

HEADLINE: Casino Panel's New Mission: Save Atlantic City

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 3

 BODY:
New Jersey's powerful Casino Control Commission is changing its mission from micro-regulation of the casino industry to the restoration of aging Atlantic City to its former prominence as a resort.
It is a race against time, says Chairman Steven P. Perskie, to insure that the gaming industry, confronted with mounting competition from explosive growth in all forms of gambling across the country, does not fall victim to stagnation as the once-grand city did. 
 "I look at the opening of the new convention center as a new beginning," said Mr. Perskie, referring to the $260 million downtown convention site that is scheduled to open in 1996 as the centerpiece of the city's long-promised renaissance.
 
Aiding a Battered Industry
 "Nineteen ninety-three, '94, '95 will unquestionably be the most critical period of all," said Mr. Perskie, who in his two years at the helm of the commission has transformed it from the gambling industry's adversary to its watchful ally. "The question is, is it too late? I don't believe it is, but if it doesn't happen by 1996, it will be too late."
In theory, the primary role of the five-member Casino Control Commission remains the regulation of legal gambling in Atlantic City -- chiefly keeping it free of mob influence.
But in fact, Mr. Perskie's appointment to its chairmanship in September 1990 was part of an intensive effort by the city, the state and the regulators themselves to shore up an industry battered by the junk-bond financing binge of the 1980's and legal gambling's failure to keep its promise to reverse Atlantic City's decay.
Besides the convention center, the state has bought and is committed to expanding Atlantic City International Airport. State and local officials also plan to build new housing, raze decrepit downtown properties and replace them with a new corridor of hotels and restaurants to be anchored by the convention center, and to promote the development of non-gambling attractions along the boardwalk.
The commission -- which is now purged of dissenting voices -- is also, as Mr. Perskie puts it, "literally rewriting the entire system of regulation."
"All the infrastructure investment and the regulatory change has been done to create an attractive environment for new investment," he said. The goal is to revive Atlantic City as a resort and convention destination, not just a magnet for gamblers.
 
Slacking Off on Regulation?
 Legal gambling was adopted in 1976 in an effort to save the city. By the time the first casino went up in 1978, all the elegant old resort hotels had been torn down, the boardwalk was all but deserted and the population was declining rapidly and becoming increasingly poor.
The casinos have flourished, employing more than 40,000 people and winning $8 million a day. But the city continued to spiral downward, and today its population is about 36,000, half of what it was at its height in the first half of the century. It is also a one-industry town, depending on gambling for 90 percent of its revenues, compared with Las Vegas which derives half of its income from non-gambling attractions and tourism.
Mr. Perskie is at pains to deny that the commission is slacking off on its regulatory mission at the expense of revitalizing the city, but others are not so sure.
One is W. David Waters Jr., a tough regulator who resigned from the commission 18 months ago, after it became clear that he would not be reappointed to a second five-year term.
"I think the industry has done a masterful job of whining and crying over their supposed inability to make money," he said. "The industry has convinced the present commission to go easy on them. The attitude, beginning with Perskie, has been to have more sympathy with things the industry presents as problems that stand in the way of their making money."
Mr. Waters resigned after losing in a series of votes that he said sharply departed from regulatory guidelines.
 
Support for Trump
 Among them was a decision finding Donald J. Trump "financially stable" despite being more than $3 billion in debt -- $1.3 billion of it due to his three casinos, the Trump Castle, the Taj Mahal and the Trump Plaza, which represent about one-third of the $3 billion-a-year Atlantic City gaming industry.
Another was a relatively minor fine of $65,000 levied against the Trump Castle in 1990 after Mr. Trump's father, Fred Trump, made an illegal loan to his son to allow him to make his soaring bond payments. By buying $3.5 million worth of chips at the Trump Castle but not making a single wager, Fred Trump allowed Donald Trump to use the money for his payment.
Mr. Waters called it an "outrage" that the commission would "fail to carry out what it understands to be its responsibility" to heavily fine or suspend specific individuals for violations, rather than levying what he saw as a token fine against a faceless corporation.
Asked if there was any substance to suggestions that the commission is no longer as tough as it once was -- it once denied licenses to the hotelier Barron Hilton, who was subsequently licensed by the current commission -- Mr. Perskie said, "There is a superficial reality to that, but only a superficial one."
"It was an express policy of the Governor that we yield not a micrometer on the high standards of licensing" and other oversight responsibilities, said Mr. Perskie, the former chief of staff for Gov. Jim Florio.
"When I got here, there was a regulatory culture in this agency and the Division of Gaming Enforcement, and it was clearly understood by the industry, and that was that the regulatory environment was adversarial to the industry," he said. "I said to the staff the first day I got here that we're neither the adversary of, nor the advocate of, the casino industry. Regulating can be done without an adversarial atmosphere."
Commissioner Frank J. Dodd was one of those who voted in favor of finding Mr. Trump financially stable, a requirement if he was to to keep his three casino licenses. Mr. Dodd, whose five-year term expires this year and who is hoping for re-appointment, said he voted for Mr. Trump to avoid chaos in the industry.
"One banker told me confidentially that it would be like foreclosing on Uruguay -- you bring the whole country down," Mr. Dodd said in a recent interview.
 
A Host of Competitors
 Mr. Dodd, Mr. Perskie and the other three commissioners now agree that the worst of the junk-bond financing crisis, which left some casinos with debts they could not meet, is largely over. The new danger, they say, is the seemingly endless competition from a rapidly proliferating gambling industry.
The decade and a half when Atlantic City stood alone, as the only place between Monte Carlo and Las Vegas where casino gambling was legal, is gone amid a swirl of gambling fever across the country:
*A veritable fleet of reincarnated riverboat casinos is already plying the Mississippi, with more planned.
*The Foxwood Casino, opened in Connecticut last year by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians, is already earning tens of millions of dollars and has become a model for similar ventures across the country.
*New Orleans is planning a casino hotel to dwarf Mr. Trump's billion-dollar Taj Mahal, Chicago would like to host a major casino and the list of new and potential alternative gambling ventures like lotteries and electronic card games continues to grow.
*Gov. Mario M. Cuomo just last month reached agreement with the Oneida Indians to allow New York State's first high-stakes casino in the center of the state, and negotiations are under way with the Mohawks for another. More than 50 tribes in 17 states now operate casinos or big bingo parlors.
 
Call for a Time-Out
 Nelson Rose, a professor at Whittier College of Law in California who analyzes the growth of gambling, predicts that within a decade, every major population center in the United States will be within a two-hour drive of a casino resort.
Such growth has generated mounting concern in New Jersey, a deluge of proposals for new and expanded gambling ventures, and a call from Governor Florio for a time-out to take stock. In January, the Governor overruled the State Lottery Commission, which had approved a plan to allow high-speed keno lottery machines in bars and restaurants.
The machines proposal, adamantly opposed by the casino industry, would have allowed a player to play every five minutes, 16 hours a day, and came on the heels of the expansion of gaming hours in Atlantic City to 24 hours a day, the introduction of horse-racing simulcasts in casinos, and overtures to legalize sports betting and to allow video poker terminals outside Atlantic City.
"There is a need to evaluate the complete gambling picture in New Jersey," the Governor said, as he halted further expansion of the industry to take a hard look at the state's increasing reliance on gambling as a major revenue source.
Commissioner James R. Hurley, who was a member of the Legislature 17 years ago when casino gambling was approved, acknowledged that the state had gone back on its promise at that time not to allow nonstop gambling 24 hours a day, but said, "The marketplace has changed."
Commissioner Dodd, who also played a role in pushing the legal gaming legislation through as Senate president in the 70's, said, "The hue and cry at the time was, 'We don't want to be Las Vegas!' But if you have ever been in Atlantic City, you would die to be Las Vegas."
"I and other legislators envisioned that casino gambling in Atlantic City would be men in tuxedos and women in evening gowns sipping champagne," he said. "That was 15 years ago. Now we are happy to get beer drinkers."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James R. Hurley, a member of the Casino Control Commission, on the boardwalk in Atlantic City. (Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times) (pg. 42)

HEADLINE: YELTSIN TIPTOEING ON SENSITIVE ISSUE

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 3

 BODY:
No Russian or Soviet President has ever traveled abroad watching his back quite as anxiously as President Boris N. Yeltsin must in Vancouver.
In his very first comments on arrival here for his summit meeting with President Clinton, Mr. Yeltsin gave a measure of the danger he faced when he acknowledged that even overly generous Western aid could be a weapon against him in the vicious political struggle back home. 
 "You see, too much is not very good either," the Russian leader said when asked how much aid he was seeking. "Too little is not very good. Too much also could be bad, because it can be used by Communists to target us. The opposition will say we are shackled by the West."
 
Hostile Comment From Speaker
 The comment followed a stinging attack on his visit by Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, the Speaker of the hostile legislature and Mr. Yeltsin's bitterest opponent. Meeting with Western diplomats in Moscow, Mr. Khasbulatov complained that their capitals were "rushing too fast to support the ill-conceived steps of one political side in Russia."
If Mr. Yeltsin's actions result in bloodshed, Mr. Khasbulatov warned, "then a share of the responsibility will rest on Western countries."
The very notion of criticizing a leader, much less discussing the possibility of civil war, while he is on an international mission would have been unthinkable before in a nation that has always put great importance on maintaining a bold and unified face abroad. Mr. Yeltsin himself was dismissed from the Communist leadership in 1987 in part because he publicly criticized Mikhail S. Gorbachev on the eve of a United States-Soviet summit meeting.
This time, even Mr. Yeltsin's Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, undermined his President's mission a bit by publicly declaring that he found foreign aid degrading.
"What they tried to do, this humanitarian stuff, it's humiliating, though it's not meant that way," he said in a television interview. "We have to thank them for it. But I, for one, feel humiliated in that sense."
 
Top Ministers See Him Off
 Other symptoms of Mr. Yeltsin's plight were less public, but no less telling. All three "power ministers" -- those of Defense, Security and the Interior -- showed up at the Moscow airport on Friday to see Mr. Yeltsin off, along with Vice President Aleksandr V. Rutskoi, in what was evidently a demonstration of support.
Russian officials privately acknowledged that Mr. Yeltsin had decided to leave Defense Minister Pavel S. Grachev in Moscow, leading President Clinton to leave Defense Secretary Les Aspin behind.
Mr. Yeltsin also felt compelled to reassure his countrymen on departure. "I have a telephone, and I will run the country myself," he told reporters before boarding his plane. "Be assured the nuclear button is in safe hands. I am not abandoning the controls."
Officials also privately reported that Mr. Yeltsin would impart his most personal thoughts to Mr. Clinton on a walk outdoors, to preclude the leaking of a transcript to his opposition, as happened after his meeting with President Bush in January.
Mr. Yeltsin's requests to Mr. Clinton reportedly include a greater emphasis on economic cooperation rather than direct aid, a more substantial aid package, an accent on assistance to the private sector and an emergency meeting of the Group of Seven major industrialized nations as early as May.
Mr. Yeltsin was also expected to raise the crises in other former Soviet republics, most notably in Georgia, the Nagorno-Karabakh enclave in Azerbaijan and Tajikistan, where civil wars are proving increasingly intractable.
 
Delegation Reflects Situation
 The Russian President's delegation in Vancouver also reflected Russia's financial crunch and the political turmoil at home.
Only a handful of Russian reporters were in evidence, and the Tass team complained bitterly that they had been denied electronic communications gear. For the most part, this reflected the shortage of hard currency.
But the absence of Pravda, which as the Communist Party daily used to be a major presence at all United States-Soviet summit conferences, was interpreted as an ideological boycott. Even its Washington correspondent failed to make the trip, and the paper wrote today: "One has to admit, although it is painful, that the summit is a stillborn diplomatic child."
Mr. Yeltsin's security detail, by contrast, was undiminished.
His immediate team included Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev; Aleksandr N. Shokhin, the Deputy Prime Minister charged with social policy, who has been conducting economic negotiations in Paris, and Boris G. Fyodorov, the Deputy Prime Minister responsible for economic policy.
The man most closely advising Mr. Yeltsin at this meeting is Dmitri Ryurikov, his adviser on foreign affairs, who is said to be slated for a senior Government position.
Mr. Yeltsin's interpreter in Vancouver is Sergei Berezhkov, whose father, Valentin Berezhkov, was Stalin's interpreter at the Yalta conference 1945.

HEADLINE: A Brooklyn Precinct: Crime Figures Send a Complex Message

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
His body tense, his hand hovering over his holster, Officer Dennis Gallagher cautiously pushed open the door to a dank apartment house in Fort Greene, Brooklyn. He searched the lobby for the addicts who usually scurry away when he enters, leaving behind crack vials and fearful tenants. But he found none.
"When community policing started, a lot of people were skeptical," said Officer Gallagher, who now speaks proudly of his alliance with the building's superintendent and others in the neighborhood who have helped him rid the block of drugs. 
 Officer Gallagher, 34 years old, has no doubt why recent statistics show that reported serious crime dropped 6.8 percent last year in the 88th Precinct in Fort Greene and 7.8 percent in New York City overall: growing ties between New Yorkers and a police force that is moving from its patrol cars onto the streets.
 
Mixed Reviews
 Not everyone in Fort Greene agrees. Interviews with residents, merchants and police officers paint a more mottled picture about the reasons for the decrease and which residents have benefited in the 88th, a racially diverse swath of north-central Brooklyn with a population of about 60,000.
To be sure, no one -- including the Police Department -- knows exactly why crime has declined in New York City since 1991 after steady increases that began in the mid-1980's, when crack-related violence ripped through many neighborhoods.
But a look at the 88th Precinct -- which ranks about average in crime and includes sturdy middle-class areas as well as pockets of grinding poverty -- may provide some hints about the evolving nature of public safety and law enforcement throughout the city.
Since 1991, reported serious crime has dropped 21.3 percent in the 88th Precinct. Beneath the sure simplicity of that figure, though, lies a knot of influences.
Crime seems to be down in some parts of the 88th because residents have embraced their patrol officers, inviting them to block association meetings and feeding them steady streams of information. On foot-patrol beat No. 5, merchants call Officer Gallagher by his first name. (Local criminals call him "Red" or "Blondie" because of his hair.)
Changes in the drug trade, particularly the waning allure of crack, also appear to be a factor. Another important influence is the economic growth of the area. The 88th Precinct, which includes Fort Greene, Clinton Hill and a small slice of Bedford-Stuyvesant, once had a reputation as one of the city's poorest. But since the early 1970's, many people have bought and renovated the stately 19th-century brownstones that have long defined this part of Brooklyn.
These homeowners seem particularly interested in working with their beat officers, perhaps because they want to protect property values. "They take a more active role in their community," said Evelyn Williams, manager of Community Board No. 2, which includes the 88th Precinct. "They demand more services."
In poorer sections, though, people seem more reluctant to get involved and far more skeptical that the police can make a difference in their lives. Many even refuse to discuss crime because they fear retribution from the drug dealers and muggers who they feel outnumber the police.
Edward A. Carter was strolling the other day through the Walt Whitman housing project at the northern end of the 88th Precinct, pointing out the dangerous courtyards and chatting with women around the scraggly benches that rise from the cracked pavement. The talk was of drugs and guns and an unrelenting onslaught.
"We don't have a lot of stores around here where kids can get some work, some salary," Mr. Carter, 59, a long-time tenants' leader at the project, said to shouts of agreement. "They have to cut their eye teeth on some kind of crime."
Mr. Carter and many residents of these areas scoff at the recent statistics. In fact, even as crime has dropped in the precinct as a whole, it has remained constant at the two largest housing projects in Fort Greene, the Walt Whitman and Ingersoll Houses, where more than 11,000 people live.
 
Settling Disputes With Guns
 The project's residents say the crack trade may have ebbed since the frenzied late 1980's, but they point out that more and more teen-agers are using guns to settle disputes.
Relations with beat officers, the cornerstone of community policing, seem frayed in the poorer neighborhoods, as if residents, who are mostly black, still view the mostly white officers as an occupying force. Nearly 60 percent of the officers in the 88th Precinct are white.
"I don't really think that they want to get involved," said Jeanette Turk, 35, who lives on Fulton Street, one of the most crime-ridden areas of the precinct. "They want to do their eight hours and get home safe."
The police are further hindered by the lack of stores in these sections, as Officer Manuel Da Silva pointed out the other night while he roamed past abandoned tenements and empty lots near Ms. Turk's block.
"When you walk into a store, you have customers inside and you can interact," said Officer Da Silva, 23, who patrols beat No. 9. "Stores are very helpful, because they know what's going on when the cops are not there."
But in other parts of the precinct, residents and merchants seem pleased by the new officers hired under Mayor David N. Dinkins's Safe Streets, Safe Cities plan. The 88th expects to increase the number of foot-patrol officers to 40 by 1994, up from 29 now and fewer than 10 in the late 1980's.
 
'Out There on the Street'
 "Things have drastically changed over the past few years," said Morissa D. Geller, a children's book illustrator who is president of the Cambridge Place block association. "I attribute it to the community patrols. The officers are out there on the street. There is real problem-solving taking place.
"Before, the police were a foreign force. They were something to be feared -- an unknown entity."
Mel Corbett remembers when customers shunned his store, Myrtle Variety Hardware at 341 Myrtle Avenue, because addicts and dealers lingered on the sidewalks outside, drawn to the block by a grocery that did a brisk trade in crack and heroin. That was in the late 1980's, before the Police Department adopted community policing as its guiding strategy.
"It was like a drug supermarket," he said.
Mr. Corbett, 40, a community leader who lives nearby, said the store owners on his street helped close the grocery by funneling information about drug sales to Officer Gallagher and narcotics investigators.
"When you see cops on the street, you are not going to see the random crime that you would see if the cop wasn't on the street, or the cop was in the car," Mr. Corbett said.
Kent Davis, owner of Diamond Kuts, a barber shop at 218 DeKalb Avenue, can also recall a time when he felt besieged. He sought help from Officer Gallagher several times last year about the rowdy teen-agers who smoked and sold marijuana on his block. "Recently, it's so peaceful," Mr. Davis, 32, said. "Words can't even explain it."
 
Making the Police Smile
 That kind of talk makes Capt. John J. White smile.
When Captain White took command of the 88th in January 1992, he installed a large map of the precinct on a wall in the lobby of the station house, a rickety 19th-century brick building at 298 Classon Avenue that is known as the "Castle on Classon" because of its turret.
Using the map, residents can identify which of the 11 foot-patrol beats they live in and who their patrol officers are.
"We cannot do it alone," said Captain White, 51, who joined the force 30 years ago as a beat officer in Harlem. "It has to be a partnership."
Both Captain White and Lieut. Joseph Moscatt, who heads the precinct's community policing effort, acknowledge that the sharp decline in reported serious crime in the 88th is rooted to some extent in a decrease in drug-related violence.
"Obviously, there are natural fluctuations," said Lieutenant Moscatt, who joined the precinct in 1989. "With the crack epidemic, we have come off a major high in crime over the last few years."
Residents like Mr. Corbett and some officers believe that drug use has dropped because today's teen-agers have learned from the devastation wrought by crack in the 1980's. And they point out that a decade after crack flooded the streets, some of the most violent dealers are in jail.
 
Old Crimes, New Hideouts
 Others insist that dealing has just moved from the streets into buildings because of the stepped-up foot patrols. The traffickers know that the police face greater obstacles in going after crack houses, which they cannot enter without search warrants.
"These people are not stupid," Officer Da Silva said on patrol the other night, pointing to a fortress-like tenement at 1000 Fulton Street, which is apparently the center of the neighborhood's drug trade. "They know what we can and cannot do."
He and other officers have waged a lengthy war against 1000 Fulton. But it has reopened several times. The precinct is now trying to close it for good under the city's new public nuisance laws.
That would please Freddie Hamilton, 49, an executive at a child welfare agency who lives on nearby Waverly Avenue. Just like others in her neighborhood, she is encouraged by the growing numbers of foot-patrol officers, but still believes that crime has not declined.
"The optimism is very guarded," she said. "The only thing that I can say is that the people who have decided to stay, the people who know that they are going to be here, understand that if we don't come together and do something, we won't survive."

HEADLINE: West That Is No More Turns Back Land-Use Fees

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, April 3

 BODY:
Except at rodeos and in country music bars, the cowboy hat has become a rare sight in the American West. The typical Westerner today is an urbanite, usually no more likely to know the difference between an Angus and a Hereford than the average New Yorker.
In the economy of the New West, which is tied more closely to computers than to cattle, the number of ranchers who work public lands in 11 Western states has dropped to about 30,000. Even in the West, far more people belong to the Sierra Club than to the Cattlemen's Association. 
 But President Clinton's retreat on grazing-fee increases, as well as on royalties on the minerals mined from public lands, illustrates that the political might of the Old West has not faded into the sunset just yet. And it vividly demonstrates how the Senate, with two members for each state, gives less-populous states disproportionate influence. The support of Western Democrats is essential for passage of Mr. Clinton's economic program in the Senate.
Environmentalists complained bitterly that Mr. Clinton's move signaled a lack of resolve in confronting entrenched economic interests, especially in light of the relatively small number of ranchers and miners on public land. All of the public-land ranchers in Colorado, for example, would not have enough votes to elect a City Council representative in Denver.
 
A Cowboy's Symbolic Power
 But the philosophical battle over public land, like the storied heritage of the cowboys, cannot easily be reduced to pure economics or numbers.
"It's remarkable that such a small minority could wield such influence," said Patricia Limerick, a historian at the University of Colorado. "But to understand what's at work here, you have to enter the fuzzy world of the imagined West, the tangled collection of cultural values, the symbolic power of the cowboy and the miner, and what we think we owe to our founders."
To be sure, it was not symbolism but economic pain that the Western senators emphasized when they objected to Mr. Clinton's proposal to raise grazing fees by 56 percent over five years on the 280 million acres of public range and establish a 12.5 percent royalty on minerals. They say the increases would not only eliminate jobs in mining and ranching, but would also harm the small towns that depend on ranchers and miners for their trade.
But if it were a matter of rural economics alone, say a small-town widget factory that was seeking protection, it is unlikely that so many Westerners, far removed from the old ways of the region, would care as deeply. But to Americans, cowboys are not just widget-makers.
"It isn't the normal way that people get ahold of politicians, through campaign contributions or big voter turnout," said Richard Lamm, the former Governor of Colorado, who lives in Denver. "You'll get a call from a family that has been on the land for 100 years. They pioneered it. They remember their grandfather telling stories of how they got through the blizzard of 1888. And then they tell you that if a new law goes through, they're going to go under. Well, I don't care how hardened you are, it's difficult not to be moved by that."
 
'Trust-Fund Babies'
 The debate has also been colored by perceptions of class. Most Westerners see ranchers and miners as blue-collar people working hard to survive. And they tend to view the environmentalists who call for restricting use of public land as privileged people with little understanding of the labor involved.
"The environmentalists have not been very good at getting their message across," Ms. Limerick said. "If there is anything more smug than white, middle-class environmentalists, then I don't know what it is."
Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado has emerged as a champion of miners and ranchers, depicting many of the environmentalists as "trust-fund babies who come out to hike in thousand-dollar equipment," and who look condescendingly on the "blue-collar people on Federal lands trying to make $25,000 a year."
While the miners and ranchers on public lands cast themselves as the legacy of the rugged West, environmentalists depict these industries as remnants of an old, inequitable power structure that uses politicians tied to the status quo to get their way.
 
Far From Status Quo
 In this battle of image and public relations, ranchers and miners could scarcely have cast a more appealing leader than Senator Campbell, an American Indian who wears a pony tail and a bolo tie, a former Olympic judo champion and a jewelry maker who rides a Harley Davidson motorcycle.
"I'm not exactly the status quo," he said with a deep chuckle.
Neither could Mr. Campbell be considered much of a conservative, with his record in support of minorities, unions and abortion rights.
On behalf of Western senators, Mr. Campbell wrote to President Clinton in February and warned of hardship in rural areas that the public lands proposal would cause. Mr. Clinton met twice with the senators and arranged for his chief of staff, Thomas F. McLarty 3d, to meet with them on two other occasions. Finally the President granted their request to delete the public lands provisions from his budget proposals.
 
Next Move on Fees
 Mr. Clinton has vowed to press ahead with fee increases. His spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, has described the President's retreat as a "change in process, not policy." The issue will now go to Congress on its own, not as part of the budget package.
Environmentalists have pressed for ranchers to pay a higher fee that reflects fair market value. Ranchers now pay $1.86 a month for the equivalent of one cow and her calf, which is as much as 90 percent cheaper than leasing private land.
The mining industry pays no royalty for the minerals it takes, which critics say amounts to a giveaway of Federal bounty. But mining industry officials say the searching for gold, silver and copper is so expensive that royalties would cause mass layoffs.
In an interview, Senator Campbell conceded that some increase in grazing and mining fees was inevitable. "We're all going to have to share the burden in reducing the Federal deficit," he said. "But the initial proposal would have been devastating."
An alternative proposal on Federal lands, which the President had requested, is now being drafted by the Westerners, at Mr. Clinton's request, but it would be far less reaching the President's proposal.
Ms. Limerick, the historian whose work has debunked much of the mythology of the Old West, said American still yearned to celebrate the vanishing life of Western ranching.
"In economic terms, it probably doesn't make much sense to help save these ranchers," she said. "It would be more efficient to raise all the cattle in feed lots.
"But as a nation, we may come to the conclusion this this is a cultural resource, a way of life that we want to preserve, like Yellowstone, as dramatic and glorious as any scenic attraction."

(Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Still a Dream 25 Years After King's Assassination

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, April 3

 BODY:
Twenty-five years after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis, more than half of black and white Americans rate the nation's race relations as poor, and blacks and whites remain deeply divided on economic issues like preferential hiring and promotion of minorities.
The findings in a New York Times/ CBS News poll conducted March 28-31, as well as the prevailing sour racial mood, in which the name King today more often summons up Rodney G. King than the slain civil rights leader, provide a gloomy counterpoint to nationwide observances in memory of Dr. King's death on April 4, 1968. 
 Still, the current mood accurately reflects the frustrations of Dr. King's final years when he became increasingly aware that addressing the economic and social problems of the black poor across the nation was going to be far more complicated and elusive than mounting the moral crusade that desegregated the South. In recent years a more troubled economy has made these issues even more difficult to address and contributed to both increased competition for scarce jobs between blacks and whites and the plagues of drugs and crime in black communities.
 
Unforeseen Developments
 "His whole focus at the end was on the economic issues, but no one could have foreseen the levels of cultural decay in American life and the kind of economic slowdown we would face," said Cornel West, chairman of the African-American studies program at Princeton University. "No one could have expected the level of violence, physical and psychic, we see today. It would bring tears to his eyes."
According to the nationwide New York Times/CBS News telephone poll, only 37 percent of Americans rated the nation's race relations as good. That included 38 percent of white respondents and 27 percent of blacks. Fifty-five percent of whites and 66 percent of blacks said race relations were bad. A slim majority of Americans, 52 percent, including 54 percent of whites and 45 percent of blacks, said race relations were better now than 25 years ago.
The poll of 1,368 people, of whom 1,056 were white and 229 black, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points for whites and six percentage points for blacks. The responses from 83 others, who indicated they were of some other race, were too few to be statistically reliable.
On some issues, blacks and whites had sharply differing perceptions. For example, almost half the white respondents who were asked how much real improvement there has been in the position of black people in the last 25 years said blacks had made a lot of progress. Only 29 percent of blacks agreed that there had been a lot of progress but more than half said there had been some.
 
Gap on Job Preferences
 The gap between blacks and whites was widest on issues that touched on jobs. When asked if blacks should be given preference in hiring and promotion where there had been job discrimination in the past, 33 percent of all Americans said yes. But while only 28 percent of whites said a preference should be given, 66 percent of blacks said there should be a preference.
Many respondents, in follow-up interviews, said economic pressures and competition between whites and blacks for jobs were imperiling the gains they had seen in their lifetimes.
"When there's economic tension, when there are a lot of people out of work, when people are competing against each other for few jobs and the jobs that do exist don't seem to pay enough to make ends meet, then the old prejudices and hatreds resurface," said Dennis Souza, a 42-year-old white social worker from Somerset, Mass. "That has a lot to do with what we've seen in the last year or so."
 
Lack of Progress Seen
 Many blacks said the legal gains of Dr. King's era had not translated into lasting social or economic ones.
"I was one of the original marchers on Washington, and what I've found is, as far as race relations go now, it's just a facade," said Samuel Butler, 47 years old, of Columbia, Md., who recently left his job of 13 years and sued his employer, saying he was a victim of discrimination. "There are a number of people I've met and talked to here, over the last few years especially, who've become victimized by racism."
And if many whites see significant racial progress, some clearly feel threatened by the changes they have seen in their lives, particularly in urban areas where blacks control political power.
"In Birmingham, I mean, if you're not black, then you're nobody," said Sheila Watson, a 44-year-old white homemaker from Moyer, Ala., about 25 miles from Birmingham. "Things have changed for the worse for white people."
 
Place in History
 Twenty-five years after his death, Dr. King remains a towering figure in American history, but one whose image is in transition, scholars and former associates agree.
David Garrow, a historian who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1987 for his biography of Dr. King, "Bearing the Cross" (Morrow, 1986), said the increased interest in Malcolm X, and the oversimplified comparisons between Malcolm X and Dr. King, had to some extent reduced Dr. King's influence today.
But he and others say the trend largely reflects the degree to which Dr. King is remembered as a soft-focus, nonviolent dreamer rather than the tough-minded, increasingly frustrated tactician he was.
"We've put Martin on this rotunda of irrelevant adulation and removed him from the struggle for economic justice," said the Rev. Joseph Lowery, who now heads the Southern Christian Leadership Conference, which Dr. King founded. "Somewhere along the line we managed to resurrect the messenger and bury the message."
Dr. King's son, Martin Luther King 3d, said an organized, nonviolent campaign to put pressure on corporate America to provide more opportunities for blacks was the kind of activity his father would support today.
"I don't think the broader society has really focused on the issues that affect black people," said Mr. King, a 35-year-old Fulton County Commissioner here. "Now we're at a point where we don't have a choice."
Despite the increasing interest in Malcolm X, the poll results showed little retreat nationally from the goal of integration. Only 6 percent of whites and 7 percent of blacks saw separation of the races as a worthy goal.
 
Falling Short of Dream
 Shelby Steele, an author who is often at odds with the civil rights leadership, said the racial divide today reflected how both whites and blacks have failed to live up to Dr. King's vision.
"I think people see integration as a form of idealism, and I think Dr. King saw it as a form of pragmatism," he said. "I think what he meant by integration was very difficult for whites and blacks. It requires a commonality; it requires achievement on the part of blacks; it requires an enormous amount of tolerance on the part of whites; it requires government expenditures -- all sorts of things. I think rather than go for that we've retreated into a kind of ethnic politics."
Mr. King and other black officials felt a new sense of optimism because the Clinton Administration is viewed as more receptive to black concerns than the Republican Administrations of the last 12 years.
"I think we're at a turning point," said Representative John Lewis, Democrat of Georgia, a former civil rights leader. "I think Bill Clinton's election has given people hope, and hope is a very important thing."
 
No Successor to King
 Still, few think that in a nation where racial issues are wrapped up in economic ones and compounded by an increasingly multiethnic and multiracial society, the solution to America's racial ills will come from a commanding figure who will be able to shape this era as Dr. King dominated his own.
"We've been fooled into thinking that we need some magic hero," Mr. Lowery said. "That there's some eight-foot tall black dude riding a big black horse wearing black shining armor waving a black magic wand, making everything healthy, wealthy and wise."
With a weary shake of his head, he said: "He ain't coming. He ain't coming."

HEADLINE: Irish Ex-Premier Hopeful for Ulster Accord

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBLIN, April 1

 BODY:
Life is not as exciting now for Garret FitzGerald as when he was Prime Minister of Ireland and persuaded Margaret Thatcher to give Dublin an official toehold in Northern Ireland for the first time since Ireland won independence from London in 1922.
Nor is it as vexing as when, as Prime Minister, he had what he described as an "exasperating" meeting in New York with John Cardinal O'Connor at which he failed to persuade the Cardinal to publicly condemn the violence of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. 
 Nor is it as discouraging as when the Irish Ambassador in Washington reported that President Reagan had told him that East European Communists were fomenting much of the trouble in Northern Ireland. But Mr. Reagan did help with Mrs. Thatcher.
Mr. FitzGerald, an economist who was last Prime Minister from 1982 to 1987 and was head of the Fine Gael party, retired from Parliament in January and is now, at 67, enjoying the life of a senior statesman -- writing a weekly column in The Irish Times, lecturing abroad, joining his wife, Joan, in admiring the daffodils in front of their Victorian home in the fashionable Rathmines section.
Interrupting a speech-writing session recently, he described Ireland's current problems: the weak economy and the civil strife in the north and how the current Government, headed by Prime Minister Albert Reynolds, might have an unusually good chance to end the conflict, in which more than 3,000 people have died since 1969.
On the anomalous economy, he noted that while Ireland has relatively low inflation, moderate Government borrowing and an enviable international payments surplus of more than $1 billion, it is still in deep trouble, with unemployment running at about 20 percent, the highest rate in the European Community.
The root of the problem, he said, is demographic: "It's not that we produce less. We've more people to feed, too many dependents per worker. For every one person working, there are two dependents. In Europe the ratio is 1-to-1."
He said that until the last few years, Ireland, an overwhelmingly Roman Catholic country where the church preaches forcefully against contraception, had the highest fertility rate in Europe. This produced tens of thousands of new jobseekers each year in an economy that could produce only a few thousand new jobs. But between 1986 and 1990, an average of 30,000 Irish a year emigrated, keeping unemployment relatively low.
"The recession of the early 90's," he said, "has hit Britain very badly and America also, the two places emigrants go to, so that on top of having this huge number of people seeking jobs, we've now got people coming back rather than going out."
 
Baby Boom Wanes
 But he said the fertility rate is dropping fast, and by 2000, the baby boom will be over and the unemployment rate should drop.
On Northern Ireland and the relationship between Ireland, Britain and the United States, Mr. Fitzgerald moved back and forth between the current efforts to make peace in the north and the Anglo-Irish Agreement, which he and Mrs. Thatcher signed in 1985, giving Ireland a consultative role in the north and establishing an Irish Government office in Belfast.
"American support can be helpful" in the north, he said, "but you have to get the right balance." He declined to say whether President Clinton should appoint, as he has suggested he might, a special envoy to Northern Ireland, a proposal that worries the Governments here and in London.
Mr. FitzGerald said the new Irish Government had a reasonable chance of making progress toward a settlement because it has a large parliamentary majority with a coalition of Prime Minister Reynolds's party, Fianna Fail, traditionally hard-line anti-British, and the more flexible Labor Party.
With Labor leading the way toward a new agreement, Mr. FitzGerald said, Fianna Fail, which seems better trusted not to betray the country's interests, could persuade people to support a new plan for the north.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 647 words

HEADLINE: Justice Cuomo?

 BODY:
There is this much to be said for the idea of putting Mario Cuomo on the Supreme Court. By leaving Albany for Washington, he might improve both places.
After a dozen years of dominating New York's political scene, Governor Cuomo's departure would allow a new generation of leadership to develop. Certainly New York politicians of both parties are rooting for a new Cuomo career. Democrats stir at the possibility of movement at the top of the party. Republicans have already begun to see their party's 1994 nomination as a prize worth seeking. 
 For most of his three terms, Governor Cuomo has seemed poised for a lunge at national office -- or a run at a state judgeship. His tortured deliberations have led some to suggest that the last thing he needs is a job requiring clear decisions. But Mr. Cuomo, a man of words whose talent lies more in what he says than in what he does, seems to think he has the right temperament for the bench. A former court clerk, a lawyer and occasional law teacher, he has even expressed envy of those he has appointed to New York's Court of Appeals.
Of course, Mr. Clinton may be playing a cruel little political game: first woo and flatter Mr. Cuomo by mentioning him when he needed him during the campaign, then turn to another nominee who offers something that Mr. Clinton needs in 1996 -- say, a swing state that is less predictably Democratic than New York.
But let's assume that Mr. Clinton is at least half serious. The President has talked about the qualities he's looking for, but he's cited only the Governor by name.
Mr. Cuomo has moved Democratic conventions with oratory about heart. Last summer, he lamented the economic distress of "millions of Americans who took for granted the basic right to make a living with one's own hands and mind and heart . . ." Is that the "big heart" of which the President spoke in seeking a justice with "a fine mind, good judgment, wide experience in the law and in the problems of real people, and someone with a big heart"? Governor Cuomo has been stingy with executive clemency, even at Christmas. But that deficiency of heart might not hurt him with the former Arkansas Governor who refused to stop four executions. Mr. Cuomo is infamous for carrying bitter grudges, never forgetting or forgiving. That may not disqualify him with Mr. Clinton either.
Mr. Cuomo has intellectual energy and broad public law experience. Whether he can do the work of the Supreme Court, including the quiet slogging over many cases that are anything but cosmic, is a question he himself has raised. Earl Warren comes to mind as a Justice who was rusty on the law but skillful in ways that public service develops. But Mr. Warren, another former Governor, went as Chief Justice, not the junior member who gets up to answer the door at secret conferences.
The President seems to see Mr. Cuomo as a potential peacemaker on the splintered Court. But Mr. Clinton also relishes the spectacle of a Justice Cuomo in verbal bash-ups with another loquacious lawyer from Queens, the right wing's Justice Antonin Scalia. In any case, a little electricity can't hurt.
Retiring Justice Byron White, who will leave at the term's end, has given Mr. Clinton much more time to think about this vacancy than most Presidents are granted. He might well dwell on the qualities of various public figures and how they might mesh with a Court that needs intellectual firepower and more sanity and compassion about issues such as abortion. Mr. Cuomo has firmly endorsed a woman's right to choose, incurring the wrath of the Archbishop of New York and other high-ranking members of Mr. Cuomo's own faith.
To discuss Mario Cuomo at this point is neither to endorse him for the Court nor to wish for his departure from Albany. Yet the notion of a Justice Cuomo stimulates thought, mischievous and solemn, about change.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28; Column 1; Magazine Desk
