HEADLINE: FOUR FUTURES FOR RUSSIA

BYLINE: By David K. Shipler; David K' Shipler is a former Moscow bureau chief for The New York Times and the author of "Russia: Broken Idols, Solemn Dreams

 BODY:
Russia is at a painful turning point, facing momentous alternatives but appearing powerless to make a deliberate choice. Its people stand at the junction of their authoritarian traditions and their novel experiment with political freedom; they hover between a state economy and a free market; they are simultaneously bound together and driven apart by their history and their current striving for a new identity.
Hardly any nation's future is more crucial to global well-being than Russia's and hardly any nation's future is more uncertain. After decades of gray, predictable Soviet inertia, the land that sprawls some 6,000 miles from Europe to the Pacific rim churns with volatility. Even tomorrow is a question.
As President Boris Yeltsin and President Clinton were preparing for their summit meeting, scheduled for this weekend, the rising confrontation between Yeltsin and his legislature reached a crescendo. In the absence of a firm constitutional structure, any outcome seemed possible. 
 Clinton, who gave Yeltsin a rousing endorsement, last month proposed increasing American aid to improve Russia's economy and support democracy. But Western assistance cannot be decisive, as helpful as it would be psychologically and materially. Even without Yeltsin, the Russians might continue to lurch toward a democratic, free-market system. And even with him, they might fail. They are destined to find their direction in their own culture and politics, but even these lack definition.
Russia is groping in an ideological wilderness, devoid of the Marxism-Leninism that once served to decode history and chart the future. Gone is the evangelical patriotism that fueled a mighty empire. Vanished is a pride in the past, except among those few who cling to the myths of Communist achievements and czarist glories. The sense of mission has disappeared, and nothing has replaced it.
Religion has not yet overcome its traditional subservience to the state to arise as a comprehensive system of belief. And democracy, an alien idea, is still regarded as little more than a political position, not the deeply rooted set of moral convictions that it must become to flourish.
Into this void swirl the impatient winds of yearning. They batter the fragile structures of free debate, open politics and private enterprise. They pick and nag at every untidy, unfinished part of a work in progress for which no blueprints exist. Russia is suspended among its fears, waiting, it seems, to be propelled along one course or another by forces undefined, uncontrolled.
Hardly any nation's future is more crucial to global well-being than Russia's, and hardly any nation's future is more uncertain. After decades of gray, predictable Soviet inertia, the land that sprawls some 6,000 miles from the edge of Europe to the rim of the Pacific is a cauldron of volatility. No one with a shred of wisdom would claim to foresee what lies ahead. Even tomorrow is a question, for Russia always seems at a turning point these days. [I'll insert here reference to recent developments, such as the outcome of the confrontation between Yeltsin and the Congress of People's Deputies.]
Despite the unknowns, visions can be sketched, parameters drawn, variables calculated as an exercise in thinking through the possibilities. Without making predictions, four plausible scenarios for the future of Russia are presented here.
Simple regression to a Communist state seems unlikely. Although many Russians look back wistfully at the economic security they felt then, the dogma of the Party is discredited, and the old doctrine cannot satisfy the search for a guiding truth. Those who hunger for order, discipline, an encompassing ideology and a firm hand at the top must search elsewhere. That is where we begin, by examining the prospect of dictatorship in another form.
 
I. THE AUTHORITARIAN STATE
The comfortable country dacha is nestled in deep snow that turns blue in the late winter dawn. Boris Yeltsin, still groggy from too much drink the previous night, peers through the frosty panes at the black bones of the birches against the drifts, then he starts. He grips the windowsill.
Poking out from behind a mound of plowed snow at the end of the drive is an oblique angle of blackness--not a truck, not an automobile--some part of an armored personnel carrier? And silhouettes of men in uniform, pacing, stamping against the cold, looking frequently his way.
Yeltsin rushes to the spacious desk in his study, which holds five telephones. He picks up one after another. All dead. It has finally happened. It could be next year, or next week, or tomorrow.
Perhaps the coup has taken place suddenly, like the unsuccessful one in August 1991, with the army moving swiftly at the command of such conservative civilians as Aleksandr Rutskoi, the Vice President, and Ruslan Khasbulatov, Speaker of the Parliament. Since 1992, Rutskoi has given expression to a reviving Russian nationalism, part of that thirst for national meaning. Khasbulatov, who craves power, has tried to use the legislative branch not to check and balance the executive but to take over its functions.
It may be that military leaders, weary of the chaos of the country, have seized the reins of authority themselves. The armed services, once respected on a global scale, have been vilified in the press and disrupted by shortages of funds, internal ethnic tensions and pullbacks from the periphery of the crumbling empire. A breakdown of discipline has inflicted civilian society as well, with the police in retreat and organized crime on the offensive in smuggling, fraud and protection rackets.
Or, perhaps it has been the "creeping coup" of which Moscow politicians have been speaking worriedly: a gradual consolidation of reactionary control over the legislature, or the election of a new Parliament, which in the current mood might be quite nationalistic and conservative. After all, there is a clear answer to the question: Are you better off under Yeltsin than you were under Brezhnev? If a referendum is held, voters may choose a parliamentary over a presidential form of government, allowing a rightist legislature to drain away the power of the President or elect one of their own as national leader.
Those who know Russian history recognize the country's authoritarian tradition as a central factor in the future. Melor Sturua, a veteran columnist for Izvestia and a visiting professor at the University of Minnesota, sees the strong possibility of an ultranationalistic, ultraconservative Russian state supported by the Russian Orthodox Church. In the absence of ideology, Sturua believes, the church is emerging as the only moral authority in the country. And people in the church want a czar in the Kremlin, he says, as a way of regaining their prerevolutionary power. They might support a reactionary Parliament that heads in that direction.
In other words, if Yeltsin, the first popularly elected leader of Russia, proves too large a figure to be removed from office, the office could be removed from him, in effect, by being rendered impotent. He may never have to confront soldiers outside his dacha. Or Yeltsin himself, who has shown autocratic tendencies, could try to dissolve the legislature and impose "emergency rule," which he has intimated he might do.
There are many paths to authoritarianism, all leading through a hard landscape of economic turmoil, ideological emptiness and political disorder; they come out of a traditional Russian affinity for strong leadership and a search for a single idea to unite the nation. Now that Marxism-Leninism is dead, the idea can be a mystical sense of Russian greatness, in which Russian Orthodoxy is the interpreter of Russian history and Russian pride.
If banners and slogans reappear across the broad boulevards leading to the red brick walls of the Kremlin, they are not the red and white calls of Communism but blue and white letters exhorting a mighty Russia to regain its purity: "Russia For Russians!" "God Save Sacred Russia!" "We Shall Never Sell Mother Russia to the Jackals of the West!"
Pamyat, the extreme Russian nationalist organization that surfaced under Gorbachev, gains adherents who preach anti-Semitic and anti-Western conspiracy theories. Scattered assaults are made against Jews. Swastikas appear on apartment doors, and right-wing newspapers print articles blaming Jewish entrepreneurs--as well as Armenians, Georgians, and Asians--for driving up prices and enriching themselves off struggling working people. Cartoons are published with anti-Semitic caricatures of sly businessmen gouging the elderly. Rumors are spread that Yeltsin and his top advisers who advocate liberal economic reform are Jewish and are taking orders from Jewish bankers abroad.
But the most insidious nationalism has worked its way more subtly into the ranks of the colonels, bureaucrats and civilian politicians who strive to control Russia within, reassert its dominance over adjacent lands and recapture its global role as a superpower. The sense grows that Russia is unnaturally truncated and that, as Yeltsin said in early March, Russia ought to police and quell the conflicts in the surrounding former Soviet republics. Here, the ethnocentrism and xenophobia are turned into policy.
The conservatives articulate the moral revulsion toward capitalism felt by many ordinary Russians, the visceral sense that it is simply wrong to amass private property, to employ workers who do not share in profits, to buy goods at one price and sell them for more. Reacting to the hyperinflation that has wracked the country, the state strives to retard the move toward a private economy. Land, the dearest symbol of nationhood, is returned to unyielding state jurisdiction, and private leasing is ended. Small-time entrepreneurs are labeled "speculators" and are rounded up for trial. Rigid customs and monetary restrictions are enforced to curtail the flight of capital and the flow of smuggled goods.
At the same time, however, the government declares its desire to proceed with Western investment, even amid suspicions that the West is trying to buy Russia cheaply, to strip the Motherland of valuable resources. This is an argument that has been made frequently through the years by conservative Communists and then by conservative anti-Communists. Paradoxically, Moscow continues to lobby for Western aid, even as it stakes out a more independent economic and foreign policy. A limited private economic sector is deemed desirable, and many Russians speak admiringly of the Pinochet model in Chile, as they began to do in 1991. As before in Russian history, the goal is to modernize without Westernizing.
The boisterous press that has grown up under Gorbachev and Yeltsin is gradually brought to heel, first by the manipulation of state supplies of newsprint and printing facilities, which squeeze the unfavorable publications and reward those that extol the virtues of the government. State television is drastically revised; hard-hitting documentaries disappear, and the nightly news show--whose old name, "Vremya" (Time), is revived for its nostalgic appeal--mutes its critical reporting and gives increasing voice to a new tone of Russian patriotism.
Such patriotism is really a retreat into elemental ethnic identity. It instills in film and theater a reverence for unblemished Russian village life before the country was tainted by the un-Russian, Western ideas of Marxism and then democracy. It exacerbates the prejudices against non-Russians in the Russians' midst. It animates a popular conviction that the Russian army should defend and rescue Russians who are facing discrimination in Moldova, Lithuania, Tadzhikistan and other former Soviet republics where Communism has been replaced by the governing ideology of ethnocentrism. It encourages a reanimation of the historical Russian drive to expand contiguously, to recapture lands that were lost when the Soviet Union collapsed.
The attachment to what is "Russian" also colors foreign policy, feeding the sullen resentment over Yeltsin's slavish deference to Washington in the Middle East, the former Yugoslavia and elsewhere. Russia resumes extensive arms sales to Syria, breaks with the United States on Iraq, and refuses to back Security Council resolutions that authorize military action against Serbia. Further negotiations on reducing strategic nuclear weapons become difficult.
Outside Yeltsin's dacha, the snows gradually melt away. The guard is thinned out, for Yeltsin comes to understand that he is not going anywhere, that his fate is not to be like that of Gorbachev, who was able to travel and speak and run a think tank after his fall from power. Yeltsin is to be held as Khrushchev was -- in comfortable silence.
 
II. DISINTEGRATION AND CIVIL WAR
Five or ten years from now, when historians try to trace it all back to a single incident, they find the spark in a sad, grimy bar in Ulan-Ude, the poor, industrial city south of Lake Baikal. Ulan-Ude is the capital of Buryatia, a part of the Russian Federation that borders on Mongolia, and whose population is mostly ethnic Mongolian.
Late on a Friday night, the floor of the crowded bar is slippery with mud, tracked in from the spring rains. As usual, the men inside--there are no women there--are a mixed group: Mongols, Russians, Ukrainians, and others. They have come directly after their work in the steel-girder factory nearby; their dinner has been vodka and cognac.
A grizzled Russian in stained overalls lifts his glass in a loud toast. "To Mother Russia!" The Russians drink, but the Mongols look away. Some grumble. "To Mother Russia!" the Russian repeats, raising his glass and catching the eye of a burly Mongol, challenging him to join in the salute. "I said, to Russia!" Now the bar has fallen silent.
Finally the Mongol stands and lifts his glass slowly until it is high above his head. "To our motherland, Buryatia!" he declares, and throws the liquor back in one gulp.
"You chuchmek," the Russian growls. It is the slur applied to Central Asians, but rarely uttered in their presence. It gets immediate results. The Mongol lands a solid punch, and the brawl begins.
Outside, two policemen sit in a patrol car, the engine idling, part of the force that is routinely stationed near bars on weekends. Their windows are rolled up against the chilly evening, and they do not hear the fight until it spills into the street. By then, a few Russians are badly outnumbered by many Mongols, who are pummeling them with fists, kicking them as they sink to the ground. An officer thinks he sees the glint of a knife, and he fires, and then his partner fires, and several Mongols fall dying to the sidewalk.
In a vacuum, the episode would have had little consequence. But this is no vacuum. Throughout the vast Russian Federation, the same centrifugal forces that tore the Soviet Union apart in 1991 are now pulling at Russia itself. Every one of more than twenty ethnic or regional groups, it seems, has carved out a zone of independence. Every one chafes at the chains of control in which Moscow has held them in bondage, from the czarist era through Soviet Communism.
Under Communism, strict economic controls from Moscow's central planners were a source of constant, albeit quiet, complaint. Farms in the distant steppes could grow only the crops they were told by Moscow bureaucrats to grow, regardless of local needs. Polluting factories were erected anywhere, at Moscow's whim. The Siberian city of Yakutsk, where temperatures fall to 40 or 50 below, could not install specially insulated windows and doors in new buildings without permission from Moscow, six time zones away.
The erosion of central authority under Gorbachev, and the acceleration of the decline under Yeltsin, have speeded the fragmentation of Russia into regional fiefdoms. What begins with a struggle for economic autonomy, then, translates quickly into an attachment to language, history, culture, religion, race, ethnicity. And so the episode in the bar spreads rapidly as Buryat Mongols hunt down Russians in the streets, in schools, in apartments. The Russian army mobilizes and confronts the local militia. But the army, too, is fragmented along racial lines, and soldiers are soon fighting against each other. The conflagration spreads to scores of hot spots throughout Russia, and the army cannot contain the breakup of the country. "Ethnic cleansing" takes place, mostly against Russians, but also by Russians in some areas against Central Asians, Armenians and others.
In the year or two after the collapse of the Soviet Union, the vestiges of the Soviet army fought in the brushfire ethnic wars of Georgia, Moldova, Tadzhikistan and elsewhere. So it seems a natural development that reactionary leaders, amid calls to protect the 25 million Russians living outside Russia's borders, send troops against local authorities in Tadzhikistan, Moldova, even Ukraine. And the warfare spreads, threatening to escalate into a devastating confrontation between Russia and Ukraine, which retain their nuclear arsenals.
The fragmentation of Russia could also be relatively peaceful, owing to the simple collapse of central state institutions that began under Gorbachev and continued under Yeltsin. Local warlords, many of them former Communists, raise their own militias, collect their own taxes (which they refuse to send to Moscow), arrange their own economic systems (which maintain intricate trade with Russia) and align themselves with various foreign powers, whether Japan or Iran or China or Western Europe.
The sequence of events is variable. Perhaps the disintegration has been provoked by the imposition of authoritarian, military rule in Moscow. Or, the threat of such fragmentation could deter the rise of dictatorship, as Harley Balzer of Georgetown University believes. Would-be autocrats in Moscow realize that as soon as they tried to establish a dictatorship, he says, defiant regions would immediately break away into dozens of independent countries.
Whether or not the army could prevent this is a matter of debate among experts. Stephen F. Cohen of Princeton sees the military as more capable than Balzer and others believe. Its loyalty is to the idea of Russia, Cohen says, and it still defers to Moscow, unlike other institutions. The army remains encamped in many of the former Soviet republics, he notes, most of whose forces would be no match for Russia's.
However long a breakup might last, it need not be only along ethnic lines, according to Paul Goble, a former State Department specialist now at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington. The dynamics are different from the Soviet Union's demise, he observes; that was decolonization, whereas Russia is witnessing the death of a state.
Goble predicts that within a year or two, 20 to 30 percent of Russia's territory will no longer be under Moscow's control. The North Caucasian Confederation led by its president, Dzhokhar Dudayev, has already seceded, Goble notes, and he expects the six million Kazan Tatars in the middle Volga region to break away to realize their goal of creating an Idel-Ural Federation. Such a federation would cut European Russia's transportation and communication links with the Russian Far East, which is primarily ethnic Russian and rich in natural resources. The Far East would then spin into independence. But by the end of the century, he foresees a nationalist Russia expanding again to recapture the lost territories, in what could be ugly warfare.
In the meantime, virtually all Russians have fled Buryatia, piling into Russian cities as refugees, ill-housed and jobless. They fuel a rising indignation and a lust for revenge.
The bar in Ulan-Ude has only Mongolian patrons now, and the blue, white and red Russian flag has been taken off the wall. But not forever.
 
III. DEMOCRACY AND A MARKET ECONOMY
In twenty or twenty-five years, when Muscovites enter the small, curtained voting booths, they do so with a sense of confidence that their voices will be heard. It is now their fifth or sixth presidential election, and they are beginning to believe in the stability of a democratic system that has provided repeatedly for the peaceful transition of political power from one leader to another.
To sketch this rosy scenario is to describe the enormous distance that Russia must travel. Every element in the optimistic picture is roughly the opposite of what exists today.
In this hopeful future, a number of parties have emerged, including the Communists on the left, European-style Social Democrats, conservative business-oriented groups and right-wing ultranationalists. After years of undisciplined speechifying and uncoordinated politicking, a certain coherence has come to the parties, and they are acting roughly as units, representing an array of constituencies.
Lobbyists, so vilified in the West but so essential as middlemen between interest groups and government, have finally evolved to fill what had been a yawning gap. Environmentalists have their action committees, as do entrepreneurs, factory owners, farmers, transportation interests, tenants' organizations, and others who have business with the Parliament. They can now be heard by the legislators as never before.
The legislators themselves have staff, as they did not previously. As a result of visits to Congress by Russian lawmakers during the Gorbachev and Yeltsin years, a Russian version of the Congressional Research Service, modeled after that agency in Washington, has been established with American aid so that members of Parliament can rapidly acquire budget, tax, and legal information to help them make informed decisions. The executive branch accepts its obligation to provide accurate data.
The tone of debate has improved. It is still raucous at times, but less malicious and more prone to compromise; no longer does a politician try to destroy everyone who disagrees with him. Legislators are more prepared to form coalitions to get measures enacted than in earlier years, when every individual seemed to have his own agenda. A healthy dynamic of check and balance has grown up between the legislature and the President, without either trying to usurp the powers of the other.
At the local level, a civic society is developing, with growing involvement by ordinary citizens in their town and neighborhood governments, where the impact of their activities is most immediately felt. They plan land usage, clean up polluting industries and relegate manufacturing to non-residential districts. They channel private housing into well-organized living areas and improve public transportation. Voluntary and charitable organizations multiply. The visible changes that people can make to their immediate environment encourage others to participate, and a true political culture gradually emerges.
Because young people who were teenagers during Gorbachev's liberalization came to intellectual maturity in an atmosphere of free inquiry and discussion, they have become a generation resistant to oppression. They have grown up accustomed to speaking candidly, a habit reinforced by more open schooling and the robust press. The longer the freedom lasts, the broader the constituency for free speech will be, the more animated the forum of competing ideas will become, the more difficult the task for any aspiring dictator.
Along with a new respect for the concept of checks and balances and separation of powers, an independent judiciary arises. Professional judges are now immune to the old system of "telephone justice," in which a Communist Party secretary simply picked up the phone to get his desired verdict. Although some of the judges are holdovers from the Soviet system, they relish the right to exercise their own minds, and they grow to fill their new roles.
Protections of defendants' rights finally take hold. At long last, the police and the courts are observing the law, passed under Gorbachev, that provides access to a defense attorney immediately after arrest, rather than after interrogation and investigation. This requires serious police work and an end to the earlier reliance on forced confessions. Police morale is damaged for a while and crime soars, but after some years police professionalism improves, and citizens begin to have faith in the impartiality of the criminal justice system.
The Constitutional Court, created under Yeltsin, is strengthened as the first body in Russian history with the power to decide on the constitutionality of legislative or executive actions. Modeled on the United States Supreme Court, it brings an aura of legality to a society that has never embraced the rule of law.
In the economic sphere, Russia moves increasingly toward private markets. After long debates and political battles, laws are finally passed permitting land to be owned, bought and sold by private individuals or institutions, without restrictions. The ruble is made fully convertible, repatriation of profits by foreign businesses is allowed, government red tape is stripped away, and investment pours in from manufacturers in the United States, Western Europe, Japan and the Middle East. Consumer protection laws are enacted and enforced.
With its wealth of natural resources, cheap labor and scientific talent, Russia becomes a prosperous complement to Western economies and enjoys a slow but steady rise in the standard of living, especially in the cities.
Moscow's foreign policy remains closely aligned with Washington's as Russia becomes a durable ally of the United States in defusing trouble spots abroad and, ultimately, providing aid to developing countries.
And in the voting booths, Russians still use paper ballots, continuing the old practice of crossing out the names of the candidates they oppose.
 
IV. MUDDLING THROUGH
Nothing has changed in the Siberian village of Nizhneangarsk. Woodburning stoves still heat the log cabins, fighting the frost on the insides of the walls. The shelves of the town's only store are usually barren of red meat and green vegetables. Villagers survive on potatoes, spaghetti, bread, canned tomato sauce, half-rotten cabbages and, on occasion, fatty pork rind and canned fish. The schools are poor, and people still try to find their way to the cities, where crime is rampant but goods are more plentiful. A decade from now, life in such remote villages is still considered fitting punishment for criminals, who continue to be exiled there.
Except for a new class of wealthy entrepreneurs, Russians face hardships that have not eased appreciably after years of hesitant reform. The economy remains a mixture of state ownership and private enterprise as authorities try to blend the efficiency of the market with the social protections of the welfare state. Transportation, mining, the weapons industry and most other heavy manufacturing remain in the hands of government, although officials and former officials enrich themselves by funneling goods into the private marketplace. Entrepreneurs have begun producing some consumer items--clothing, furniture, toys, books, music tapes and the like--but private businessmen are involved mostly in stealing state-made goods and selling them.
Agriculture remains largely under the jurisdiction of collective farms or state farms, for very few individual farmers have been willing to risk going out on their own. Inconsistent government policies have undermined confidence; farmers permitted to lease land one year have been thwarted by local officials the next. Only half steps have been taken toward private land ownership--acreage must be held at least a decade before being sold, for example--and farmers have no network of financial institutions from which they can get loans.
Western investment has been fitful and uneven, partly because of Russian ambivalence toward foreign businesses, partly because of Western reluctance to provide enough aid to guarantee loans and stabilize the ruble. Yeltsin and his successors recoiled from the "shock therapy"--the rapid privatization of the economy--demanded by the International Monetary Fund as a condition of assistance.
Politically, Russia is neither a dictatorship nor a full-fledged democracy. It stumbles from crisis to crisis, along what seems to many Russians the brink of anarchy. No new Russian constitution has been written because the atmosphere has been too contentious; the old, Soviet document has merely been amended into a patchwork of provisions. The legislative and executive branches continue to vie for dominance, but in their maneuvers have brought about a crude balance of power. The economic tribulations and the specter of political disorder promote an illiberal mood in the public, but the spirit of open debate remains pervasive. The press remains irreverent.
For years, Russia's enormous problems have looked like volatile chemicals that must eventually transform themselves by decaying or exploding. The notion that they can continue indefinitely, without resolution, has seemed improbable. But Stephen F. Cohen, the Princeton historian, takes a long perspective, cautioning that Russia moves very slowly, usually in gray areas where dichotomies and clear-cut categories do not exist. The issues and choices can remain undecided for a long time, he believes, and Russia's course can consist of zig-zags of advance and retreat; even if democracy and the private economic sector grow, the country will find its own particular formulas and not adopt those of the United States.
Russia is caught in competing impulses that coexist with each other: an opening to the West and a xenophobia, an embrace of political pluralism and a deep desire for order and authority, an infatuation with the free market and a revulsion over its methods and results. These uneasy contradictions may describe the most likely scenario of all.
And the hard winters still come to the village of Nizhneangarsk.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 25; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 728 words

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
13 Millionaires, 90 Losers

BYLINE: By Allen Barra; Allen Barra writes about sports for The Village Voice and The New York Observer.

 BODY:

THE WORST TEAM MONEY COULD BUY
The Collapse
of the New York Mets.
By Bob Klapisch
and John Harper.
304 pp. New York:
Random House. $21. 
 THE Mets championship teams of 1969 and 1986 seem to have spawned a shelf of books each, but "The Worst Team Money Could Buy" very likely will be the only clothbound yearbook for the franchise's 1992 season. And mercifully so: the '92 Mets, with a team payroll of $44.5 million, won just 72 of 162 games -- surely fewer victories per dollar than any team in baseball history, even allowing for inflation. A team with 13 millionaires on its roster finished 10th in the National League in earned-run average, 10th in scoring, 11th in home runs and 9th in fielding.
Living through the season was like enduring six months of water torture divided into 162 nasty drops. And that was just the regular season. Two New York sportswriters who covered the Mets last year -- Bob Klapisch for The Daily News and John Harper for The New York Post -- take the reader from the preseason trades of disgruntled star players through accusations of gang rape to enough petty feuds and squabbles to fuel a soap opera. All you want to know about the Mets' 1992 season is in "The Worst Team Money Could Buy," as well as a few things you may not want to know and quite a few things you would never have thought to ask.
In one sense Mr. Klapisch and Mr. Harper have done their job. They detail the arrogance, egomania and ineptitude that helped create the 1992 fiasco, like the misguided paternalism of the front office that dismantled a championship team and the staggering immaturity of semiskilled millionaires like Gregg Jefferies and Vince Coleman.
On the other hand, "The Worst Team Money Could Buy" at times is more excruciating to read than the season was to live through. Despite occasional nods to the players' humanity -- it is refreshing to read something nice about Gary Carter, and Darryl Strawberry tells how he is praying for his father's recovery from a heart attack -- the book seems driven by dislike and envy of its subjects. Page after page bombards the reader with phrases like "money-inflated egos," "overpaid prima donnas," "spoiled ballplayers," "pampered, irresponsible millionaire ballplayers," "excuse-making ballplayers," "over indulged millionaire ballplayer" -- well, you get the idea. And if you don't, you certainly will after Mr. Klapisch reports that he "gawked" at the paycheck a laughing Dwight Gooden waved in front of his face.
"The Worst Team Money Could Buy" never comes to grips with the fact that the enormous sums baseball players now earn have changed the role of the newspaper beat writer. To their credit, the authors acknowledge that beat writers no longer just report the news but are having an increasingly greater influence on the shaping of it. (In one bizarre vignette, the Mets' then manager, Davey Johnson, calls a peace meeting between Mr. Klapisch, his colleague Mike Lupica and the Mets' first baseman, Keith Fernandez, whom Mr. Lupica had called "the Prince of Darkness.") Newspapers are no longer the primary source for descriptions of games, as they were in, say, Ring Lardner's day, when players and writers traveled, ate and played cards together, and when players' off-field exploits were taboo subjects for news columns. Today it seems that beat writers more and more cover teams to explore the players' private lives and to offer judgments about players' character (or lack of it). Friction between press and players, especially in New York, seems inevitable. One wonders if it isn't beginning to grate on readers.
Certainly the preoccupation with ballplayers' money and morals in "The Worst Team Money Could Buy" can grate on the reader. As Florida prosecutors neared a decision on whether to prosecute the Mets pitcher David Cone on rape charges, the authors write, "scandal-frenzied journalists spent the game hanging around the press box, bored by the mundane matters of baseball." Unfortunately, this description is appropriate far too often for Mr. Klapisch and Mr. Harper. They frequently seem to regard any baseball issue that does not concern sex or money as uninteresting. "As a whole," they write, without apparent irony, "journalists tend to get self-righteous in these kinds of matters." Correct -- as a whole, and sometimes in pairs.

HEADLINE: 'I Want' Now Gets

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla

 BODY:
POWER to the people. The little people, that is.
Marketers and some decidedly grown-up interest groups have discovered that the shortest distance between two points is a straight line: straight from advertisers to children who will use a product. 
 It's a pragmatic strategy based on a simple truth: Now that mom is away from home nearly as often as dad is, there isn't much point in fashioning media messages that follow the traditional route from advertiser to parent to child. Why bother explaining to mom the proportions of water to Kool-Aid mix when it's junior who's mixing the stuff in the first place?
"Kids are making more and more purchasing decisions," said Arthur I. Pober, director of the Children's Advertising Review Unit of the Council of Better Business Bureaus. "Because of that, they're being marketed to directly, and that gives them consumer power."
It doesn't mean that parents aren't buying for their children; they are, and at a furious pace. But where Ozzie and Harriet once decided what size blue jeans to pick up for Ricky, today mom and dad are seeking their children's opinions -- or letting the children make purchasing decisions on their own.
"The family unit has changed dramatically, with parents vying for the approval of their kids," Mr. Pober said. "It puts kids in a very powerful role."
Even when parents are doing the spending, the discretionary money tends to flow into children's items, not into adult goods. James U. McNeal, professor of marketing at Texas A & M University, who has overseen 30 years of spending surveys on the 4-to-12-year-old set, says parents and children are on a spending spree. In a telephone survey of 120 parents last Christmas, he said, most parents told him they were holding back on spending "except for the kids."
Children themselves have more money to spend, even as their parents' disposable income declines -- a function of both guilt and a quest by parents to make children more independent.
Marketers are taking note as this increasingly powerful consumer group takes shape, said Jim Williams of the Williams Inference Service in Longmeadow, Mass., which has been counseling clients on the emerging "child power" theme and how to exploit it. "You've got a two-member earning situation or a broken home," Mr. Williams said, "which means that the adults are just plain not there much. Children, as clever as they are, can take advantage of the situation."
So can adults with a product or a message to sell. Eleven cruise lines were pitching family vacations at last count, Mr. Williams said, while restaurants are wooing young customers with everything from crayons at the table to full-screen cartoons.
It was just a matter of time before someone invented a word to describe the marketing hullabaloo over children. "Filiarchy," Professor McNeal calls it. Lou Pinkowitz, vice president of market development at Kid Care, a child's toiletry maker, points to "the G factor" -- runaway guilt. "There are more and more working mothers, and one of the things we know that generates is guilt," Mr. Pinkowitz said.
Enhancing the G factor is the phenomenon of women postponing childbearing to allow their careers to develop. "It doesn't take an economist to tell you that if you postpone satisfaction, it's more important to you when it finally comes," Professor McNeal said.
Children are also spending more money on themselves. "Kids are in day care much younger, which gives them greater independence," Mr. Pinkowitz said. And because many working parents leave their older children for long stretches, a number of parents are beefing up allowances so that youngsters can shop for their own clothes or snacks, Professor McNeal said.
Lest there be any doubt that we are talking about real dollars, Professor McNeal's most recent survey of 1,440 families, in 1991, found that the 34 million children in the 4-to-12 age group had a combined income of $14.4 billion, of which they spent $9 billion. On a weekly basis, that is an average income of $8.13 a child, of which the youngster spends $4.90, Professor McNeal said.
The fastest-growing spending categories were shoes and clothing, which accounted for 13 percent of children's 1991 spending, up from a level so minuscule in the 1988 survey that it was lumped in a "miscellaneous" category. Parents are spending an additional $146 billion on everything from vacations to videos at their children's behest.
And the ranks of the young and spendthrift are growing. A Rand Youth Poll released last September found that teen-agers spent $58.9 billion in 1992 -- a key year, since it marked a reversal in the declining number of teen-agers in America. "They're making $40 and $50 buying decisions for video cartridges," said Michael Lyden, senior vice president for marketing at Tyco Toys in Mount Laurel, N.J. "Kids above 8 are buying with their 'own money' that came from mom and dad. And in the standard toy business," he said, including items such as dolls and toy trains, "we're losing kids earlier."
In many respects, child consumers have become more sophisticated, but the marketing pros who study children's buying habits say that the sophistication tends to be very shallow.
Rita Underberg, clinical professor of psychiatry and psychology at the University of Rochester Medical Center, says parents can make the most of the family financial arrangement by insuring that not all gifts are in the form of money or material objects. Give things "that cannot be measured and that cost no money," she advises, such as reading an extra story at bedtime.
Parents should also consider limiting how much children can spend and what they can spend it on. Ms. Underberg suggests that parents make it clear that there are negotiable and non-negotiable issues when it comes to purchases. "I never think a kid should have more than five bucks sitting around in the house," she said, "so the non-negotiable part is that more than five bucks goes into the bank." The negotiable issue could be that the children can choose between two toys.
Older children should have more leeway, Ms. Underberg believes, though she urges parents never to permit "things in their home that make them feel uncomfortable," including pornographic magazines.
This does not mean that adults should strip their children of all their purchasing power and influence, psychologists say; many parents agree. "My mother-in-law used to say to my wife, 'Why are you asking the kids what they want for lunch?' " Mr. Pinkowitz recalled. "My wife said, 'If they can't make decisions about what they want for lunch, they can't make decisions about what class to take or what job to have.' Little decisions make it easier for them to make bigger decisions."

HEADLINE: Disrespect Rules

BYLINE: By Felicia R. Lee

 BODY:
WHEN Richard Wallman walks the halls of John Marshall High School in Rochester, he never knows what he might see or hear. There are students who look right through him when he talks. There are students who use obscenities when they tell him to get lost. There are students who threaten each other with weapons while he is in within earshot.
Mr. Wallman, a soft-spoken man, says he expects a little more; after all, he is the principal. Yet last year he watched in disbelief as one student shot another at the school, evidently over a cassette player. 
 "There seems to be a lack of respect from a good number of students," he said. "Kids come into the high schools not as prepared as they should be, and they get turned off very easily. I think a lot of it is frustration. Then the summer before last we had more fatal shootings than ever before in the city, and what happens in the school just mirrors what happens in the city."
What is happening in Rochester is also happening in San Francisco, Chicago and almost every city in the nation. Students, educators, parents and people with a finger on the pulse of social trends say there has been a severe erosion of respect among many young people for schools, teachers and each other. While those students may well be in the minority, experts say, there are enough of them to sour everyone's school experience.
The disrespect includes rampant violence in inner-city schools, but also occurs in suburban schools where teachers bemoan the students' emphasis on grades instead of knowledge -- sometimes expressed as a belief that teachers owe them the good grades needed to enter competitive colleges.
In all types of schools, teachers and principals complain about students who openly talk back to them using vulgar language or only slightly veiled sarcasm.
It is, however, the violence that has everyone most concerned. Every day, 100,000 children take guns to school. Every day, 6,250 teachers are threatened and 260 are attacked. Every day, 14,000 young people are attacked on school property. Every day, 160,000 children miss school because of the fear of violence.
These statistics, from the United States Department of Justice and the National Association of School Psychologists, provide a sketch of the pain, fear and anger pervading schools. And they go far in explaining why teachers talk about changing professions and students talk openly about carrying weapons for protection.
"This is part of the culture," said Carol Nagy Jacklin, a psychologist and dean of social science and communications at the University of Southern California, in Los Angeles. "Aggression and violence are plentiful and there is a general problem of not respecting elders. I'm not sure we ever did. Moreover, in general the culture doesn't respect teachers. We pay more to parking-lot attendants.
"The problem is even more exaggerated for children raised in the drug culture and inner-city areas," Ms. Jacklin said. "They're often raising each other and themselves. They're not getting all the mores they've always gotten about respect, punctuality, the value of life."
Linda Floyd, on leave after teaching for 24 years at Marshall High in Rochester, said she reached the end of her rope when, several months after suspending a 19-year-old ninth grader for slamming a door on her, she read in the newspaper that the former student was part of a gang of 15 people arrested for beating a boy to death; they apparently wanted his jacket.
"It's gotten to the point where they're defiant, disruptive and dangerous," Mrs. Floyd said, adding that she had become emotionally drained by the demands of teaching. "I was bitten by a girl when I tried to break up a fight," she said. "I've been stepped on and pushed around. The verbal abuse and the emotional abuse are the things that have bothered me most of all."
Frank Mickens, the principal of Boys and Girls High School in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, said it was the relative absence of violence at his inner-city school, where students have gone on to Ivy League colleges, that had won Boys and Girls a national reputation for working against the odds.
The success has had a price. Mr. Mickens has banned decorative gold tooth caps and expensive jewelry and coats from the school to cut down on theft. In the mornings and afternoons at dismissal he patrols the school's perimeter to prevent drug dealers and other outsiders from approaching students. Each semester he expels scores of students who refuse to obey rules by fighting or cutting classes. On the other hand, the school spends a great deal of time honoring students who do well.
"We service seven or eight of the toughest housing projects in the city," Mr. Mickens said. "I have a simple proposition: This is my house. I'm 46 years old. A 15-year-old is not going to dictate to me how this school is run."
Ladeeta Smith, a college-bound senior at the school, said it was naive to expect students who do not respect their parents to respect teachers. She said many parents were so overwhelmed by their own problems that they were ineffective as guardians and role models.
This disrespect toward all adults, she said, means never publicly deferring to authority lest one lose respect among peers. "I think a lot of time they have to put up a show," Ms. Smith said. "Deep down, they would really like respect from teachers and to respect them in turn."
In places like Westhill High School in Stamford, Conn., where the student body ranges from low-income children of the housing projects to the upper middle class, disrespect is more nuanced. While a shooting would be a shocking occurrence at West hill, a fairly sedate school, negative student feelings about teachers are expressed in other ways, like sarcasm and pressure for good grades.
"If the kid who believes he is an A student gets a B, watch out," said Frank Donatucci, a guidance counselor. "They know what it takes to get into those colleges."
Michael Miller, a senior at Westhill, says that while he sees less respect for adults, students are often only acting in their best interests in a competitive academic and economic climate. He says that parents also push their children and the teachers for good grades.
The situation at Marshall High in Rochester deteriorated to the point that the district brought in David Hursh, a professor of education at the University of Rochester, to help teachers and student teachers deal with the conflicts. Professor Hursh says he found that students were suffering as much as teachers.
Most of Marshall's student population is black or Puerto Rican from low-income households. Half the student body drops out before graduating. Professor Hursh found from his interviews that many students felt that the teachers often did not respect them because of race or economic background and that their schools expected little from them. "When kids see that their school is dirty, there are not enough desks or materials, what kind of message are you giving?" he said.
"In the 50's," Professor Hursh observed, "middle-class kids like me sat through classes and jumped through the hoops because they knew at the end there were jobs. These kids don't believe there are jobs at the end."
Erin Thompson, a junior at Marshall, agreed that some black students felt that white teachers looked down on them because of race. "I think a lot of students come to school angry and they're venting their frustration," Mr. Thompson said. "School is just where they are five days a week."

HEADLINE: EX MACHINA;
Computer-to-Go Generation

BYLINE: By Peter H. Lewis

 BODY:
EVER SINCE the start of the microcomputer revolution, educators and parents have entertained a fantasy ideal of a computer on every child's desk. But as schools become more technologically savvy, that idea is slowly evolving into a more practical notion of classrooms using a mixture of a few powerful desktop systems and many portable machines.
Some schools, especially at the college level, recommend and in some cases require that students carry portable machines, like laptop or notebook computers. The Harvard Business School, recognizing that graduates will be increasingly on the go, is among many standardizing on portables.
 
Supplemental Tools
 But even at the elementary-school level, notebook and laptop computers are getting new attention, not necessarily as replacements for desktop systems but as supplemental, mobile tools. 
 "Schools are nibbling at Powerbooks and laptops," said Sal Capozzi, product manager for elementary and secondary schools at the research firm Market Data Retrieval in Shelton, Conn., which recently concluded a survey of technology purchasing plans at hundreds of school districts nationwide.
Even a year ago, notebook computers were viewed by many educators as impractical. They lacked color displays, and color is important for most elementary and secondary school educational software. But the need for color on the portable is less if there is a color desktop system nearby, and some of the newer notebooks can be attached to an external color monitor. Also, in the last year, virtually every maker of notebook computers has added a color-screen option.
A larger concern was that portables were expensive, with consumers paying a premium for portability. A Zenith Data Systems Corporation Z-Note 325Lp color notebook computer costs $2,224 when purchased by schools, for example. It has an 85-megabyte hard-disk drive and a 386SL microprocessor. A comparable desktop machine can be had for half that price.
On the other hand, the Z-Note price is remarkable considering that color notebooks cost at least $4,000 just a year ago, before the microcomputer price war began; that's less than the price of last year's desktop models, though still costly for financially pressed districts.
The best-selling computer in the world today, Apple Computer Inc.'s Powerbook, is even costlier, ranging in price from about $2,000 to $5,000 and up.
"It's still at a point where the cost is prohibitive for widespread use," said Susan Harman, chief author of "Educational Technology, a Catalyst for Change," a research report by the investment firm Robertson, Stephens & Company of San Francisco. "They really have to get to the point -- I'd say $1,000 -- to start widespread adoption."
Price alone is an incomplete benchmark, says Marilyn Feltenberger, who directs educational sales for Zenith Data, of Buffalo Grove, Ill. "When the lights are turned off at the school, the desktop computers are not being used," Mrs. Feltenberger said. "That's not necessarily a wise use of the taxpayer's dollars. Although the initial outlay for a desktop might be lower, on a pennies-per-hour-of-use basis, the portable is more economical."
"But it shouldn't only be a dollar issue," Mrs. Feltenberger said. "The goal of computers is to enhance the learning of the individual or teacher, and it's not enhancing their learning a bit when they don't have it at home doing the homework at night or on weekends. The portables offer mobility and usage 24 hours a day."
 
Security a Concern
 But the idea of sending a $2,000 portable home with a student, or even leaving one sitting around a classroom, scares the most stalwart administrators. Many notebooks have built-in security locks, and in schools where notebooks are used, it is common to lock them in the school safe at night.
But David Dwyer, project manager for Apple's Learning Technologies Group, says, "One thing I've learned is that if the kids are given the opportunity to be responsible, it's amazing how responsible they are."
Mr. Dwyer said that in schools where security is of primary importance, where computers are bolted to table tops and chained, the highest incidence of vandalism occurs. "The message is, 'We don't trust you with this device and it's the property of the school,' " he said. "The message in the other world is, 'Here, kids, here's a grown-up, professional tool that's going to enable you to do something that you can't do in any other way. Take care of it.' At schools where students are given responsibility, vandalism is virtually zero."
In her report, Ms. Harman of Robertson, Stephens speculated on the school of the year 2000. Notebook computers were key: "Using portable computer notebooks connected to the central work station with video disks, CD-ROM's, network access and digital libraries, students are exploring their community and the world to
present detail about their project. By simply creating and selecting video, sound, text and graphic images that appear on the screen, students construct an exciting presentation."
The report concludes: "Sound like science fiction? In reality, the technologies are here today. Their implementation will accelerate as society addresses the need to restructure schools and to use technology as a catalyst for change."
Obviously, implementing these technologies will also go faster as computer prices decline so that schools can better afford them. "The only certain speculation is that prices in the computer industry continue to go down," Ms. Harman said.
Indeed, at Ward Chapel Primary, an elementary school in Middlesboro, Ky., Betty Helton's first-, second- and third-grade students are preparing to use Powerbook computers provided by Apple as a grant for a project on transportation. Working in teams, they will also use video camcorders to create a report on local fire trucks, ambulances, police cars and other vehicles. The portables allow them to go where the learning takes place.
Apple provided her class with five Powerbooks and a desktop Macintosh as part of a broader experiment in finding successful classroom arrangements of computers. "I can't believe all the opportunities the Powerbooks provide us," Mrs. Helton said. "It has enhanced the educational experience."

HEADLINE: College Majors Often Prove Minor

BYLINE: By Margo Kaufman

 BODY:
IN THESE judgmental times, when you are what you eat, wear and drive, it's comforting to think back on those simple days in college, when all you were was your major. On campus, a field of emphasis was a trusty Rorschach test: A declaration of electrical engineering meant a nerd with a pocket protector; business, a loud fraternity brother with a sweatshirt and loafers without socks; philosophy, a head-in-the-clouds intellectual who was disconnected from life.
But while the common stereotypes often ring true -- sociology majors do tend to be liberals, premeds serious and music majors dressed in black -- conversations with graduates from all walks of life reveal that a degree is not destiny.
 
Manzi? Classics?
 For instance, Jim Manzi, president and chief executive officer of Lotus Development, the second-largest software company in the world, studied classics at Colgate. Roger Corman, the Louis B. Mayer of B Movies, earned his degree in engineering at Stanford, and Jonathan Winters, the comedian, and Patrick Ewing, the center for the Knicks, both majored in art -- at Kenyon and Georgetown, respectively. 
 "To be honest, I majored in golf," said Jon Winokur, who insists he was more often found playing the course at Temple University than working at courses in his ostensible major, political science. The author and compiler of numerous books, including "The Portable Curmudgeon Redux," Mr. Winokur says his time on the links was not in vain. "It taught me that golf is ruinously expensive even if you don't gamble."
Greta Martin took a bachelor's degree in mathematics at Spelman College, but no calculator swings from her garter belt in her current job as a Hot Box Girl in the Broadway musical "Guys and Dolls." "People always love to tease dancers about not being able to count to eight, but I can count eight and a lot more," said Ms. Martin, adding that her analytical background helped her learn dance routines more quickly.
In the same way, Julie Sahni, a chef and author of "Classic Indian Cooking," credits her study of architecture and urban planning at Columbia with giving her an analytical approach to food. "There's a belief that food is all approximation and feeling," Ms. Sahni said, "but when you want to translate that into a language so that you can teach other people, it helps to be able to codify."
 
A Media Game
 Sam Perkins, the forward who is now with the Seattle SuperSonics, says his University of North Carolina degree in communications (an area of expertise often in evidence under the backboard) made it easier to deal with the media.
And Bob Garfield, a commentator for National Public Radio, said his English major at Penn State insured that he would never have to wear a three-piece suit and tasseled loafers. "The day I graduated I was utterly untrained and untrainable, and thoroughly ill prepared for any kind of adult pursuit," he said. "Which of course forced me into journalism, which requires no skills."
Perhaps there are two types of people: those who spring from the womb knowing what they want to do with their lives, and the rest of us. The focused include New Jersey Senator Bill Bradley, who majored in American history at Princeton, knowledge that may not have been useful in his previous job with the Knicks trying to hit from the outside; George Lucas, who majored in film at the University of Southern California; the actress Frances Sternhagen, who studied theater at Vassar -- but only because she was getting C's in history and a professor steered her away from a fact-dependent department, and Dr. Joyce Brothers, whose Cornell degree is in psychology.
Actually, she took a dual major with home economics. "One of my final exams was making a Napoleon, for which we had to roll out 18 or 20 layers of dough," Dr. Brothers recalled recently. "I sweated that."
Wafflers who didn't declare a major until senior year -- most likely under threat that they could not graduate if they didn't make a decision -- can take solace in the fact that students who are very decisive often cannot tolerate ambiguity, so they make up their minds prematurely. "They don't like to deviate from what they perceive is the correct way," said Gary Emery, a psychologist and the director of the Los Angeles Center for Cognitive Therapy. The goal-oriented, he said, may set a course as early as grade school, though some people seem to have assembled resumes in kindergarten.
"Actually it was prenatal, second trimester," said Stuart Brotman, a former communications major who advises executives in the communications industry. By high school, Mr. Brotman says, he was so certain of his calling that he chose Northwestern University because it had a program that would enable him to work in his field before graduation.
People like this can be really intimidating to people like the rest of us who end up making excuses for having stumbled into our current professions much as we luck into a great pair of shoes on sale. In our defense, while we may not have a map, we do have a sense of direction. Ellen Gould, a sociology major at Brandeis turned actress, recently starred in "Bubbe Meises, Bubbe Stories," a one-woman play she wrote about the lives and stories of her grandmothers, which, she said, is "essentially the sociology of a generation."
Lori Cole, who designs computer games, drew from her degree in elementary education (tempered with art courses) at Arizona State to create her "Quest for Glory" fantasy adventure series, in which an apprentice hero learns to fulfill increasingly difficult tasks, like saving a small kingdom.
 
Perfecting Deception
 The magician Harry Blackstone Jr. says his theater arts/ communications major at the University of Southern California suited him well for his current work -- making elephants disappear. "Magic is the great theatrical art of what if," he said. "And since I minored in journalism and spent some time in politics I had the perfect background for the art of deception."
Blanche Roberts, the national pug breeder of the year, majored in drama at Syracuse with a minor in education. It's proved very useful now that she's judging, she said, because the ring is like a little classroom. "You tell people where to go and what to do, and they obey," she said. "And it's helped me speak clearly: 'Go to the end of the line,' and, 'The winning bitch is . . .' "
Of course, some people are stuck with majors that were dictated not by preference or by default but the times. "I majored in revolutionary anarchy," said Deborah Levin, an artist's representative and Goddard College alumna. While Ms. Levin concedes that her courses showed her how to be a free thinker and take risks, her studies had a lingering drawback. "It makes it impossible to lie about my age," she said.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
Bungee Jumping

BYLINE: By William Safire

 BODY:
'One scene from the last Judson Welliver Society meeting stayed with me," writes Mary Kate Cary, recollecting the assemblage of former White House speech writers, of which she is one. When that ghostly gathering learned that President Clinton had reviewed a speech on the prompter for the first time only minutes before air time, she notes, Anthony Snow, with whom she served on the Bush staff, exclaimed, "That's bungee jumping!"
As the group chuckled, Arthur Schlesinger Jr. -- a Kennedy adviser and writer, and the coiner of such phrases as "the Imperial Presidency," "the vital center" and "permanent government" -- turned to Tony Dolan, the author of Ronald Reagan's "evil empire" phrase, to ask, "What's bungee jumping?" 
 "Tony explained something about people tying a rope around themselves and jumping off a cliff," Ms. Cary recalls. "Schlesinger peered through his glasses at Tony for a time, and made a 'harrumph' noise."
The sound, I think, was not a disapproving har rumph; it was more of a hmpf of wonderment from a lover of vivid metaphors.
A few days later, the phrase was back in the news. Dick Thornburgh, the former Attorney General who spent a year decompressing as United Nations Under Secretary for Administration and Management, issued a farewell report that described the financing of peacekeeping operations as "much like a financial 'bun gee jump,' often undertaken in blind faith that timely appropriations will be forthcoming." A New York Times editorial on this subject was titled "Bungee Jumping at the U.N.," which The International Herald Tribune improved with "Enough Bungee Jumping."
Bungee, which is sometimes spelled bungie, is defined in the Oxford English Dictionary Supplement as British slang for "india rubber." A 1934 citation says, "The piece of india-rubber for erasing purposes was referred to as 'india-bungie' or 'bungie.' "
However, Punch Coomaraswamy, a former Singapore Ambassador to the United States, who grew up in a Malaysian rubber-growing area, challenged this assumption and sent me an entry from Hobson-Jobson, a glossary of colloquial Anglo-Indian words that defined bangy, rooted in the Sanskrit vihangama, as "a shoulder-yoke for carrying loads, the yoke or bangy resting on the shoulder, while the load is apportioned at either end in two equal weights, and generally hung by cords."
Other Lexicographic Irregulars have noted the word used for elastic ties for parachutes -- "we always snapped those bun gies to make sure they still had their elasticity" -- and in a 1946 book, Theodore H. White described a model airplane driven by a propeller worked by a rubber band as "her wretched bun gee airplane."
Whatever the correct etymology, the ideas of elasticity and load-bearing cords are present. We are now ready for a bungee jump.
You are hoisted high aloft by a crane or attain some altitude in your hot-air balloon. Attached to your ankle is a bungee cord, a thick elastic that is also tied to your jumping-off point. You then leap, screaming, into the blue; well before you hit the ground, the elastic cord begins restraining your fall, until you are bouncing up and down. After a while, you are just hanging there, gently bobbing, and your friend at the jumping-off point hauls you back in.
"Modern bungee jumping," The New York Times reported in 1991, "using the wrist-thick bundles of rubber strands wrapped in woven nylon, was born on April Fool's Day, 1979, when members of the Oxford Dangerous Sports Club attached bungee cords to themselves and dived from the 245-foot Clifton Bridge in Bristol, England." At the time, The Sunday Telegraph quoted one member as saying, "Quite pleasurable, really."
Its current political and financial meaning, Professor Schlesinger: Any unnecessarily risky undertaking, especially a stunt that gives the participant a feeling of living dangerously and onlookers a thrill of trepidation.
 
 
SATAN'S HOMETOWN
 WHAT'S GOT INTO Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan -- doesn't he know how to spell? Doesn't Oxford University Press have a proofreader?
"Pandaemonium" is the title of his 16th book; this one, about the ethicity of ethnicity, argues that self-determination is undermining the harmony of mixed cultures. Pandemonium -- the word, not the Moynihan title -- is a word that takes tumult and uproar to their outer limits, a condition of all hell breaking loose. It should be spelled, of course, pandemonium, without the a before the e.
But wait: the very thought of the breaking-loose of hell gives us a clue to the author's intention. Pandaemonium is a place. Pan- is a Greek combining form meaning "all"; demon ium is a gathering of demons. John Milton, in his 1667 masterpiece, "Paradise Lost," coined the word, writing of "the walls of Pan daemonium, Citie and proud seate of Lucifer." The Devil called for "A solemn Councel forthwith to be held/At Pandaemonium, the high Capital/Of Satan and his Peers."
The ae lasted until Thomas Carlyle, in his 1831 "Sartor Resartus," wrote of those who "in this hag-ridden dream, mistake God's fair living world for a pallid, vacant Hades and extinct Pandemonium."
The senior Senator from New York is harking back to Milton's meaning -- the capital of Hell -- in his study of ethnicity in global politics, and can thus get away with the archaic spelling. The rest of us, in using the word to denote "wild disorder, noisy confusion, bedlam," should stick with the capitalization, just as we capitalize Hell when referring to the place. (I'll feel like hell when Hell freezes over.) But we should adopt the modern spelling because Carlyle was a respectable writer and ae is hard to figure out how to pronounce. Pat should remember that when he writes his encyclopaedia.
 
MEANWHILE, BACK AT REVANCHE
 "I BELIEVE THE Western world and Western countries did not understand the reality of revan chism," said Boris Yeltsin, standing at the side of the French President, Francois Mitterrand. He defined the term in the next sentence: "a serious attempt to restore the Communist regime of the Soviets."
Mitterrand could have told him that revanche is the French word for "revenge," usually meaning the retaking of lost territory or return to old regimes. For generations, Soviet leaders complained of West German revanchist aims toward East Germany; now the term, evidently a Russian favorite, will be popping up at summits, directed at the Communist apparatchiks seeking to make a comeback in Moscow.
The word is always used pejoratively; if you are for economic revanchism, you eschew that word and say instead you favor retaliatory democracy or you're a reciprocitist. Revanche, in diplomacy, is never admitted to be sweet.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Georgetown

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
THE Wilsons are typical of many young adults who grew up in well-to-do Fairfield County. Thomas Wilson is from Westport, his wife, Susan, from Weston. Like many of their peers, they are rearing their first child, and cannot afford to live in either town.
After spending two months looking at 40 houses -- "whatever we could afford in Westport or Weston was in terrible disrepair," said Mr. Wilson -- they decided to look farther north where prices were more reasonable. 
 Last November they bought a well maintained three-bedroom, two-bath house for $188,000 on almost an acre in Georgetown. "We like the area because of the small-community feeling," Mr. Wilson said, "and there are lots of other couples in their early 30's with young children."
A major attraction was the array of services and highly regarded school systems available to residents, wherever their homes may be in the four-town area. For Georgetown is not a town itself but a neighborhood of homes with a one-block business district at the confluence of Redding, Ridgefield, Wilton and Weston.
Many Georgetown children attend Redding Elementary School, Reed Middle School and Barlow High School in Redding. Enrichment programs are an important part of the curriculum, beginning in third grade with 6 to 10 weeks of study on the violin, flute, clarinet or guitar.
The Miller-Driscoll K-3 school in Wilton has a computer program in which pairs of children view an event on screen, then use the computer to draft, write, edit and produce in book form an essay on what they saw.
"We can see the day when laptops will travel to and from school with each child instead of notebooks," said Dr. Donald Holt, curriculum administrator.
More than 90 percent of graduates from the four public high schools go on to higher education.
Resident permits are issued by each town for its swimming facilities, tennis courts, hiking trails and other recreational services. The Dhly Ridge Municipal Golf Course in Ridgefield charges $400 a year plus $3 a day to play, and $250 for each additional family member. Several free tennis courts are available.
Redding's Topstone Park offers a beach and swimming pond, horseback riding, canoeing, hiking and basketball on 280 acres at $80 for families, $35 for individuals. Weston runs five-week summer day camps for children. Half-days for 4- and 5-year-olds cost $375 and a full-day sports camp for older children is $500.
On Georgetown's Main Street, which is parallel to Route 107 and has no sidewalks, the Georgetown Saloon offers dinner for $12. Dress is casual and the dance floor is jammed on Saturday nights. The Sagebrush Cafe next door charges $18 for a southwestern dinner. A TV repair shop, barber shop, two liquor stores and a vacant shop or two fill the rest of the street.
Millicent Good, owner of Driscoll Country Real Estate on Route 107, notes that "housing is not available in quantity at any time in Georgetown, " adding that "people tend to settle in for the long haul." Prices occasionally fall below $175,000 and rarely go above $250,000 for a large Victorian. "Close to Main Street houses and lots are small," she said, "under half an acre, but as you fan out, homes are larger and lots go up to an acre."
"I've watched Georgetown evolve for 22 years," said Marilyn Sloper of the local Shaker Realty. "I'm getting more calls for Georgetown specifically from young people who have the energy to fix up a house themselves."
From 1813 until five years ago Georgetown was a blue-collar enclave dominated by the Gilbert & Bennett wire mill, which employed 90 percent of the community's work force. The paternalistic company, with 44 buildings and a large pond on 50 acres along Route 107, provided not only employment but also housing and a public school for its workers.
TWELVE years ago the schoolhouse was taken over by the Landmark Academy, a private school named for the building's National Register of Historic Places status. The youngest of its 160 pupils are 18 months old and its classes range through the 8th grade.
"We believe in early learning," said Linda Keefer, the director. "French and physical education begin at age 3 and reading at age 4. We teach Judeo-Christian values and enroll children of all faiths." Fees range from $462 a year for part-time infants to $6,000.
In 1988, Gilbert & Bennett moved its manufacturing operations to Georgia, keeping only a skeleton staff on site while it made plans to convert the complex into a mixed-use development.
Several brick buildings are on the National Register of Historic Places and will be renovated and new housing will be built around the pond. Groundbreaking is more than a year away and completion could take 10 years, but eventually it will have 295 rental and condominium units of one to three bedrooms, 145,000 square feet of retail and 21,000 square feet of office space. The housing will be offered at market rates.
Several of the dozen or so two-family houses on Portland Avenue built by Gilbert & Bennett at the turn of the century have been bought and updated by owner-occupants or investors. A unit can sometimes be rented for $700 to $900 a month.
Before redevelopment begins at Gilbert & Bennett a state-mandated sewer treatment plant must be built to eliminate septic leaching on Main Street. The plant will be financed jointly by the company and Ridgemoor at Redding, a $100 million life-care facility to be built just north of the wire mill on Route 107.
Plans include 299 condominium apartments and detached homes for people 62 and older, ranging in price from $350,000 to $1 million. Common charges have not been established but will cover use of a 60-bed skilled nursing home on the 144-acre site. A clubhouse, restaurants, spa, greenhouse, indoor and outdoor pools and other amenities will be available to residents.
Paula Ream's Branchville SoHo Gallery, next to the Metro-North Danbury line's tracks, is one of the region's prestigious exhibition spaces. It has exhibited the work of established artists for more than 13 years. On the upper floor, simplex and duplex apartments rent for $650 to $850.
Built in 1853, the gallery, now on the National Register, has undergone many metamorphoses. Originally a communal storage barn, it became a stagecoach stop and inn, an antiques shop and, at its nadir, a plumbing supply store with toilets displayed in the windows.
Another noteworthy establishment next to the tracks is the Branchville Railroad Station Whistle Stop Muffin Company, which occupies the former station house. Commuters cannot buy a ticket there, but they can and do get breakfast before getting on the train.
A scone weighing half a pound costs $1.50, as do nine varieties of enormous muffins, 20 varieties of cookies, buns, rolls, brownies and cake slices, freshly made on the premises. Customers can settle down in the antique 8- by 10-foot waiting room with their carbohydrate, coffee and newspaper, or order a variety of cakes and pies to take home for $13 to $36.
In 1991, Georgetown's despondency over the closing of the wire mill was dispelled while the cavernous old buildings became the setting for the film "Other People's Money," with Gregory Peck and Danny DeVito. "Some of the actors stayed in private homes and townspeople were hired as extras," said Richard Gibbons, attorney and spokesman for Gilbert & Bennett.
The short-lived boost to the economy was welcome, but cannot compare with the 850 temporary and 725 permanent jobs to be created by the $120 million Gilbert & Bennett project, or a projected $40 million in construction earnings and $20 million annually in retail sales.

Lost Landmark: During the Revolutionary War, the basement of what was later called Tory House in a divided Georgetown was used to hide Loyalists, who would spy on rebels plotting above and pass the information on to the British. Last year, to the dismay of the Redding Historical Society and many area residents, the unlandmarked house on Route 107 about 200 feet from Route 7 was torn down without warning and replaced with the new owner's house. "We have lost a piece of history forever," said Ebba Anderson, a society member.
