HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Avenue of the Americas;
From Corporate Corridor to Boulevard of Barristers

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
FOR years, Avenue of the Americas was called the Corporate Corridor. And for good reason: Street after street of look-alike buildings, headquarters to Exxon, J.C. Penney, W.R. Grace and other corporate stalwarts, stretched from the 40's to Central Park, spelled only by an occasional hotel.
But now many of those companies have packed up and moved South. Others, like McGraw-Hill, have retrenched, creating a space vacuum along Avenue of the Americas/Sixth Avenue that, increasingly, law firms have rushed to fill. A result is that the Corporate Corridor is rapidly becoming Barrister Boulevard.. 
 "No other avenue is so identified with law firms that once coveted a Park Avenue address," noted James B. Frederick, a principal at the real estate brokerage Abrams Benisch Riker/Colliers.
The numbers are striking. According to Cushman & Wakefield, in 1990 law firms leasing more than 10,000 feet sopped up more than 1.18 million square feet of Manhattan space, 7.4 percent of the 15.89 million total feet of space leased. Seventeen percent of the law firm deals were on Sixth Avenue.
A year later, big law firm space deals accounted for 6 percent, or 801,880 square feet, of the 13.42 million feet rented; 35 percent of the law firm deals were on Sixth. Last year was more of the same: Law firms renting more than 10,000 feet took nearly 1.18 million feet of space, or 7 percent of the 16.75 million feet of total space that was leased; 36.3 percent of the law firm leases were for Avenue of the Americas space.
Architecturally, the Sixth Avenue buildings are well suited to a law firm's needs. Many have large, rectangular floorplates that provide for enough windowed offices to appease as many senior partners as necessary and most are skyscrapers, offering spectacular views. And the combined shrinkage and flight of corporate tenants opened up floor upon floor of contiguous space.
"Sixth Avenue is the only place left with large blocks of economical space," said David W. Levinson, an executive managing director at Edward S. Gordon.
But the availability of space would have counted for naught if an Avenue of the Americas address did not project the "right" image. And until recently, for lawyers it did not.
West Side rents have always been well below East Side rents. Where Park Avenue has stayed in the low-to-high $40's, Avenue of the Americas rarely makes it beyond the high $30's. Moreover, brokers report that Sixth Avenue landlords offer particularly rich workletters and free-rent packages.
For publicly held corporations, whose shareholders reward frugality, that was a plus. Law firms, however, assumed that clients associated plush offices and fancy addresses with affluence and success, and thus with competence. And that meant east of Fifth Avenue.
The recession changed that. As the free-spending 80's became the cost-conscious 90's, clients who once seemed impressed with ostentation started to look askance at lawyer's overheads that, they feared, were being passed on in legal fees.
Thus began the migration of law firms to the West Side. Cravath, Swaine & Moore has settled into Worldwide Plaza, on Eighth Avenue and 50th Street. Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn has gone to 1585 Broadway, at 48th Street. Last year Mendes & Mount left 3 Park Avenue, at 35th Street, for 750 Seventh Avenue, at 49th Street.
Indeed, law firms that move to Avenue of the Americas aren't mavericks anymore.
"Where Sixth Avenue used to be the westernmost boundary of midtown, it now is centrally located," said Mitchell Barnett, a director of Cushman & Wakefield who represented LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae last summer when it moved its 1,200 people to more than 200,000 feet at Avenue of the Americas Plaza, at 125 West 55th Street. "Couple that with the cost-consciousness that a Sixth Avenue address projects, and you see lots of firms coming round."
Those considerations certainly tipped the balance for LeBoeuf, Lamb. It had been scattered among floors at 520 Madison, near 53d Street, and at nearby 10 East 53d, and it wanted to consolidate. Avenue of the Americas Plaza, with its 23,000-square-foot floorplates, seemed ideal. The firm could get eight floors plus the concourse level. The building offered ample electrical and telecommunications wiring. And Alan M. Berman, chairman of LeBoeuf, Lamb's real estate group, says the deal's economics were "excellent."
Still, in the high-flying 80's, LeBoeuf, Lamb would have been reluctant to move west, lest clients think it was coming down in the world.
"FIVE, six years ago we would have been a lot less comfortable trading a Madison Avenue address for the West Side," Mr. Berman said. "But today, clients are impressed when lawyers have efficient office space, because they feel we'll pass the savings on to them."
There's a lot about Sixth Avenue that impresses the lawyers themselves.
Peter S. Britell, head of Coudert Brothers' real estate group, waxes positively eloquent about the five high floors his firm just moved into at 1114 Avenue of the Americas, the former W.R. Grace building on 42d Street. Coudert, which moved from 200 Park Avenue, at 45th, also took the fourth floor at 1114 for a "treetop conference center" that overlooks the newly refurbished Bryant Park.
"On a clear day we can see the Statue of Liberty, Kennedy and Newark Airports, and the conference center makes you think of London or Paris," Mr. Britell said.
Mr. Levinson, who represented Coudert in its move, adds this filip: "Maybe smaller firms need to be on Park, but Coudert is beyond needing a street number for image."
Numerous brokers say their law firm clients are having similar reactions.
"These days, lawyers are choosing a transaction, not just an address," said Barry Shaw, a senior director with Sylvan Lawrence who represented Gordon Altman Butowsky Weitzen Shalov & Wein in its move last year from 101 Park Avenue, at 40th Street, to 50,000 square feet at 114 West 47th.
Park Avenue, meanwhile, has lost its luster, says Steven A. Swerdlow, executive vice president of CB Commercial Real Estate, who is helping Morrison & Foerster, a law firm at 1290 Avenue of the Americas, at 52d Street, find expansion space.
"You've got a lot of functionally obsolete buildings on Park Avenue, which just can't accommodate the electrical and telecommunications needs of a modern law firm," Mr. Swerdlow said.
Not surprisingly, Sixth Avenue landlords have actively courted law firms, to replace corporate tenants that have moved away.
As soon as the Exxon Corporation, which had been the major tenant at 1251, at 50th Street, announced its plan to move to Dallas in 1986, Wm. A. White/Grubb & Ellis, then the building's leasing agent, went after Shea & Gould, which was at 330 Madison, at 42d Street, and was looking to expand.
"We knew they wanted high, big floors, and there simply are not that many buildings in New York that could offer this kind of space," said Howard Rosen, an executive vice president with Wm. A. White/Grubb & Ellis. The law firm became part of the first wave of Sixth Avenue converts, moving into about 200,000 feet on four high floors in 1988.
Last year Fish & Neave moved from 875 Third Avenue, at 53d Street, to 109,000 square feet at 1251 for similar reasons.
"They got a building with 41,000-foot floors, window space to spare, a rent that starts in the mid-$30's, a flexible lease and a terrific concession package," said Mr. Frederick, who represented the firm in the deal. "How can you beat that?"
Despite the Avenue of the Americas' new cachet, the flood of law firms moving there will probably slow to a trickle. The avenue, in a sense, is a victim of its own success: The large blocks of contiguous space that attracted the firms are growing scarce.
"This trend will have a natural end," said Mr. Rosen. "The space will just run out."
If that happens the trend may come full circle. Price Waterhouse's move to Americas Tower has opened up more than 300,000 feet at Citicorp Center, on Park Avenue. Chemical Bank's and Ernst & Young's moving out of 277 Park Avenue, at 47th Street, will make 500,000 feet available there. And there's still about 70,000 square feet available atop 450 Lexington Avenue, at 44th Street.
If the deals are right, the old Park Avenue law firms may go back East yet again.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Westchester;
As Condos Fade, Rentals Move Into Gap

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
IF the 80's could be called "the decade of the condo, we're now entering the era of rentals," said Paul J. Feiner, Supervisor of the Town of Greenburgh.
With his strong support, the Town Board recently approved an 87-unit rental project, the first to be built in the town in 33 years. "I hope we're leading the way on this issue for other communities," said Mr. Feiner. "Rentals is the ideal housing for our seniors and many other groups whose needs are not now being met." 
 Similar proposals for rental housing are showing up in other parts of the county as well, including a 330-unit project for the Village of Tuckahoe, 159 units in the Town of Mamaroneck, 26 in the Town of New Castle, 14 in the Town of Harrison and 12 units in the Village of Croton-on-Hudson.
Many of the projects are affordable housing and, as such, receive government subsidies. But market-rate projects are being planned, too.
This is due primarily to falling land prices and the virtual disappearance of the condominium developer from the market.
The Greenburgh project is for a site on Hillside Avenue once occupied by the Old Tarrytown School where 87 one- and two-bedroom units will be built in six buildings.
The complex will also have a tennis court and picnic area, said Samuel Wilkins, president of Hillside Realty and Management Corporation, of White Plains, which is developing the project.
Mr. Wilkins had originally planned to build 88 condominiums, "but the condo market is very slow," he said, "and market studies were showing a large rental market."
Twenty percent of the units will be marketed as affordable, rents from $560 for a one-bedroom to $675 for a two-bedroom.
The remaining apartments will rent at market prices, $775 for a one-bedroom and $870 for a two-bedroom.
Mr. Wilkins has agreed to give Greenburgh residents first priority. He now has 76 people interested in the units. "We should have interest for all 87 in short order and we haven't even begun marketing," he said.
The project is being financed primarily through a long-term $4 million loan from the state's Housing Finance Authority.
It also has a $1 million grant from the county's Housing Implementation Fund and $500,000 in tax credits from the state. Mr. Wilkins said he was now applying for some additional grants.
GREENBURGH has also given preliminary approval for 105 rental units on Taxter Road by Trammell Crow Residential of New Canaan, Conn. The garden-style apartment rents will range from $900 for one-bedroom units to $1,600 for two bedrooms.
Trammel Crow is one of the largest developers of rental housing in the Northeast, where it has built a total of 5,000 units, according to Samuel Fuller, development partner for the company.
"In recent years, we've been building steadily in Long Island, Queens, New Jersey and Connecticut," Mr. Fuller said, "but the door was closed in Westchester. Land prices were extremely high. With condo developers bidding for the land, they created an artificially high price. There was also an onerous approval process."
Now, with land prices at more realistic levels, the developer is exploring additional Westchester projects, including one in Mamaroneck for which details are not yet available. By far the majority of rental projects now under way in the county fall into the affordable housing category.
One of the largest is the Hommocks Park Apartments in Mamaroneck, where 54 one- and-two-bedroom units will be built by the town on the site of now-demolished Larchmont Motel, on the Boston Post Road.
In recent years, the motel housed welfare clients and had turned into "a drug haven," said Town Supervisor Caroline Silverstone. The town bought the 1.7 acre property for $2.2 million.
Twenty percent of the tenants will receive rent subsidies from the Federal Section 8 low-income housing program. The rest of the units will be available to those with incomes of $34,000 to $51,000, depending on the size of the family.
Rents will be 30 percent of a tenant's income in both cases. Priority will be given to municipal employees and volunteers, such as firemen and paramedics.
There are 120 people on the list of prospective tenants; among them is Kevin Leddy, a tree trimmer for the town. Mr. Leddy said he hoped that when the project is completed a year from now, he would still be able to afford it.
Now living with his brother, Mr. Leddy said that in order to afford his own place, he'd have to move to the Bronx.
"I live and work in town," he said. "This is the first project that's come along that would help me stay here. I hope it doesn't get lost in red tape."
The county government has identified a need for 5,000 units of affordable housing by the year 2000, according to Lynn Oliva, County Planning Commissioner. "There's a tremendous need for more affordable housing options, both in home ownership and rental," she said. "In the last year or two a lot more projects seem to include rentals."
Part of the reason rental housing is so scarce in Westchester is that 42,000 units were essentially taken off the market when they were converted to co-ops and condominiums in the 80's.
MOST municipalities discourage condominium and co-op owners from renting out their units by placing them under rent restrictions imposed by the Emergency Tenant Protection Act.
Also, developers have been reluctant to build new rental housing and become long-term landlords. "We'd rather individuals buy their units," said Robert Weinberg, chairman of the Robert Martin Company, of Elmsford, which owns a portion of the Taxter Road property in Greenburgh that's now scheduled for rental development.
Mr. Weinberg is convinced that the market for condominiums will rebound, "in two or three years," he said.
Meanwhile, rentals are a way around the current problems in the market, he said. "It's a psychological reaction. People don't want to make an investment in housing until they see some improvement in the economy."

HEADLINE: A Day With Christine Whitman

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AT 10:30 one recent morning, after a 40-minute drive from her family farm in Hunterdon County, Christine Todd Whitman called a meeting of her campaign staff in the People for Whitman headquarters in a modern office building in Clark.
"This is clearly a wonderful story," Ms. Whitman said, holding up a newspaper article in which a public opinion poll had been interpreted as showing tepid support for the re-election of Gov. Jim Florio. "We can use it to feel good, get excited, and to confirm what we've been hearing out on the street. But we can't let it go to our heads. Things haven't gotten nearly as hot as they're going to get." 
 The campaign workers, a relaxed group of fresh-faced 20-somethings, many in denim jeans and sweaters, nodded their agreement and sipped their Diet Cokes. Ms. Whitman -- formal and aristocratic, wearing a cobalt blue suit -- proceeded to the next item on her agenda.
So began another day in the campaign of the 46-year-old woman who, some political experts say, represents the Republican Party's best hope for unseating Mr. Florio in this November's gubernatorial election. Her first political hurdle, though, is the June 8 primary, which pits her against three fellow Republicans: Patrick Gilligan, a Morris County businessman; James Wallwork, a former state senator, and Cary Edwards, the state's former Attorney General.
In the course of a nine-hour working day, Ms. Whitman spoke to meetings of Republican women, teachers, business people and a newspaper editorial board -- and referred to her Republican rivals hardly at all. Her time was spent attacking the policies and political philosophy of Governor Florio.
In an interview during the day, Ms. Whitman returned to her theme that a November campaign would be hard-fought, particularly since the Democratic State Committee has hired James Carville, President Clinton's chief campaign strategist last year, as a campaign consultant. Mr. Carville and Mr. Florio are "street fighters," she said, "and James Carville's M.O. is to put the opponent on the defensive early on."
After an 11 o'clock session in her private office with State Senator C. Louis Bassano, the Union Republican who is chairman of the Senate Health and Human Services Committee and who briefed her on a variety of health-related issues, Ms. Whitman set out for her first appearance of the day, a luncheon of the Essex County Republican Women in West Orange.
Along the way, seated in her leased 1992 Mercury Sable, Ms. Whitman said that on a typical day she traveled about 200 miles. She recalled her losing 1990 race against United States Senator Bill Bradley, her first statewide campaign.
"We would have to drum up events," she said. "Nobody really cared that we were out there. If I saw two people on the street corner, I would stop to talk." Now, she said, "we are in a position of constantly turning down events."
Though born into a prominent Republican family -- both parents served the party in various state and county positions -- Ms. Whitman herself has held just one elected office, that of a Somerset County freeholder from 1983 to 1988. She then spent two years as president of the State Board of Public Utilities.
It was the campaign against Senator Bradley that catapulted her into her present prominence. Though he was widely considered unbeatable and outspent Ms. Whitman by a ratio of 12 to 1, she received 49 percent of the vote.
Some political experts say that Ms. Whitman's surprising showing was attributable to voter backlash against Governor Florio and Mr. Bradley's refusal to talk about the Governor's unpopular tax increases; nevertheless, it gave her instant name recognition among voters.
"She nearly knocked off New Jersey's premier political icon," said Ross Baker, professor of political science at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. "That clearly gives her a lot of credibility."
At the Manor in West Orange, 150 Republican women were waiting to hear what Ms. Whitman had to say for herself. Before her formal speech, she worked the room.
Her style bore little resemblance to the way most politicians, including Governor Florio, perform that task. Ms. Whitman moved tentatively from one person to another, smiling and gently shaking hands, maintaining a measured distance. There were no shouts of recognition, no hearty laughs, no arms flung over shoulders.
In her speech, Ms. Whitman concentrated on what she would not do as governor: she would not do what Mr. Florio has done.
"I don't like what I've seen happen in the state of New Jersey in the last three years," she said. "It's common sense not to spend more than you take in, and it's common sense to know where you want to go before you try to get there.
"We've given him over $7 billion in new money over the last three years," she continued, referring to revenue raised by taxes Mr. Florio has imposed since taking office in 1990. "The question that has to be answered is, 'What happened to it?' "
 
For a 'Business Friendly' State
 Ms. Whitman also criticized what she called Mr. Florio's reluctance to bring "people into the process" of government. Decisions that adversely affected business -- like the increase in the sales tax and the stiffening of regulatory policies -- had not been discussed with business leaders, she said, adding: "We've got to make this state business friendly. We need jobs, and we can't have jobs without businesses."
But Ms. Whitman offered only a few specific proposals of her own. She did say that she supported a constitutional amendment that would require the Legislature to earmark a revenue source for every new expenditure. And she called for a "two-year budget planning cycle" rather than the one-year cycle that is now used. "It makes sense to know what things are going to cost you, not just this year when the bills come in, but next year as well," she said.
In her formal talk, which she delivered without notes, Ms. Whitman's style was measured and serious with none of the political orator's anecdotes or dramatic gestures. At times, she shifted from one idea to the next without completing her thought.
Ms. Whitman seemed most at ease answering questions from the audience. When asked about abortion, she said was pro-choice. She called for increased sex education in the schools to avoid unwanted pregnancies, and better support for women who become pregnant out of wedlock and choose to bring the pregnancy to term. "The bottom line is that that is a very personal decision that should be made between a woman, her physician and her conscience," she said.
 
A Stop for Lunch
 At about 1:15, after leaving the luncheon without eating, Ms. Whitman and her entourage -- including her 15-year-old daughter, Kate, a student at the Deerfield Academy in Massachusetts -- found their way to a West Orange restaurant, Pals Cabin. There the candidate and her daughter ate at a separate table.
The next stop was a 2:30 meeting in Hackensack with the editorial board of The Record. Just the day before, the newspaper had published the results of a poll it had conducted with The News Tribune in Woodbridge, which indicated that Mr. Florio would defeat both Ms. Whitman and Mr. Edwards if the election were held now. That was the poll that had inspired the article in The Record that had so pleased Ms. Whitman at her headquarters earlier.
Gerald M. Pomper, a professor of political science at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, later explained how one poll could yield two results.
The poll indicated that if the election were held in mid-March, Mr. Florio would get 39 percent of the vote while Ms. Whitman who would get 30 percent. And if he were running against Mr. Edwards, Ms. Whitman's closest rival, Mr. Florio would get 40 percent while Mr. Edwards would get 25 percent.
"I read that poll as not being very comforting to Mr. Florio," Mr. Pomper said. "He's the incumbent, and he didn't even get 50 percent."
After the June primary, Mr. Pomper said, "the race is going to be between Florio and 'not-Florio.' " And if the "not-Florio" is a credible alternative, he said, Mr. Florio will very likely lose the election.
 
Voters' View of Women
 As a result, he said, the Republican candidate's ability to elicit trust among the voters will be the essential key to victory in November. And Ms. Whitman, he said, is likely to appear more trustworthy than Mr. Edwards simply because she is a woman. "Voters feel women are cleaner, more honest, fresher," Mr. Pomper said.
In any event, there is little to distinguish between Ms. Whitman and Mr. Edwards on policy matters. The two hold similar positions on such issues as abortion, taxes and education, and both favor providing incentives to business to stimulate the state's economy.
"You really have to be something of a connoisseur of philosophical shadings to see the difference between the two," said Mr. Baker, the Rutgers professor.
After the editorial board meeting, which was closed to the visiting press, Ms. Whitman was asked how the session had gone. "I think it went fine," she said, adding that she sometimes has trouble giving journalists the kind of answers they seem to want. "I get accused at times of not being substantive enough."
 
Coffee With Teachers
 It was just after 4 o'clock when Ms. Whitman arrived at her next stop, a kaffeeklatsch with a group of local teachers at the home of a former Wood-Ridge mayor, Peter Incardone Jr.
Seated on a straight-backed chair in the living room, Ms. Whitman fielded their questions. Most of them appeared to agree with her endorsement of a program that would give parents the right to send their children to the public schools of their choice, and her approval of the concept of school vouchers, which could be applied to the cost of private as well as public education.
The teachers balked, however, when Ms. Whitman explained her views on tenure. "Everybody would like a job to be forever," Ms. Whitman said, but she said she preferred "five- and seven-year contracts to take a teacher beyond any political cycle."
One teacher in attendance responded: "I'm a teacher advocate. If you did that, if you eliminated tenure, I would be fired."
At 5:40, after leaving the kaffeeklatsch, Ms. Whitman made a brief detour to the Wood-Ridge Public Library, where she was shown a computer system that makes thousands of books throughout the county available for lending. She put the system to the test by asking if the officials could locate a book of poems that she long been hunting for, in vain.
The system came up with the book, and Ms. Whitman delightedly took pen and paper out of her purse, wrote down the information ("A Treasury of the Familiar," edited by Ralph L. Woods and published in 1942) and slipped the paper into her purse.
 
Session With Executives
 Another 15 minutes in her Mercury Sable took Ms. Whitman to Saddle Brook, where a group of 150 business executives in the area had gathered at Manchester, a company that specializes in out-placement services. Molly Shepard, the company's president, is a former classmate of Ms. Whitman's at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass.
The guests were sipping wine and eating snacks when Ms. Whitman arrived and began making her rounds. During a brief lull between handshakes, the candidate paused for a moment and took a deep breath, and her daughter, Kate, came up behind her and touched the small of her back. Ms. Whitman reached around behind her without looking and took Kate's hand, squeezed it and then moved on.
Among the guests was Anthony D. Zajkowski, a Newark banking executive. "I'm dying to find out what she has to say," Mr. Zajkowski said. "I think personally that it's about time that the Republican Party came up with some quality women in leadership roles. I came to see if she's the one."
Eventually, everyone went to the cafeteria in the basement. Ms. Whitman had been asked by her former classmate to give a speech that was "not political." Ms. Whitman said later that she had wondered, "How do you give a speech that's not political when you're running for governor?" But she succeeded in doing so.
 
Question on Gun Control
 In the question-and-answer period after her speech, however, politics intruded. Mr. Zajkowski asked Ms. Whitman about her position on gun control and whether she believed that the National Rifle Association "had a lock on the Legislature" on the issue. He said he had recently "had a gun pointed in my face in Newark."
Ms. Whitman responded that the Legislature's failure to derail Mr. Florio's ban on assault weapons did not indicate "a lock on the Legislature," but she did not discuss in any detail her own feelings about gun control. She owns a shotgun, which she uses for shooting clay pigeons.
Later, when asked about his reaction to the candidate, Mr. Zajkowski said that he liked what she had said "from an overall standpoint," but that he was not satisfied about her stand on gun control. "I think she skirted a little bit around the issue," he said.
 
Assessing a Rival
 By 7 o'clock, the meeting in Saddle Brook was over and Ms. Whitman was in her car heading back to campaign headquarters. She reflected on the differences between herself and Mr. Edwards.
"It really comes down to the way we view government," Ms. Whitman said. "It's the old way of doing things versus the new way of doing things." She cited Mr. Edwards's suggestion that the position of state auditor be created to oversee the budget process.
"That's a typical response for another layer of government," she said. "We don't need that. We have all the tools we need to bring government back under control without adding on another layer."
 
Differences With Florio
 Her differences with Mr. Florio, she said, are more fundamental.
"One is faith in the people," she said. "A recognition that you have to bring people into the process rather than precipitous decision-making where the governor says, 'I know what's right for you and here it is and you're going to like it.' "
It was 7:45 when Ms. Whitman arrived at campaign headquarters in Clark, and soon she and her daughter were on their way back home to have dinner with the rest of the family -- John R. Whitman, a financial consultant, and the Whitmans' son, Taylor, 14.
Earlier in the day, during the meeting in Saddle Brook, Kate had stood watching her mother shake hands and chat with people she had never seen before. "I don't think I'd ever be able to keep smiling that long," Kate said.

HEADLINE: The Children of the Shadows: Shaping Young Lives

 BODY:
They are the children of the shadows: the impoverished youth who live in the tumbledown neighborhoods of the American inner city; the children of often desperate and broken families, where meals are sometimes cereal three times a day; the young people who daily face the lures of drugs, sex, fast money and guns; the unnoticed youths who operate in a maddening universe where things always seem to go wrong.
 Their world, while never especially sunny, has grown far bleaker. After a period of decline, the proportion of children living in poverty has been rising. School performance has steadily fallen. Juvenile crime has exploded and turned more violent. Teen-agers are killing more often, killing younger and being killed with numbing regularity. 
 Numbers and trends, though, tell only so much. Behind them are the young people themselves, their voices, their lives. New York Times reporters spent weeks with 10 inner-city children, learning their stories. In addition, a group of reporters spent hours in round-table discussions with 15 teenagers from the New York region, speaking about their families and their schools, drugs, gangs and sex, their hopes of escape and their fears that they never will.
 
TODAY, their stories begin with Nicholas Whitiker, a Chicago fourth grader growing up too fast. Other profiles are:
TUESDAY, APRIL 6 Ladeeta Smith, a Brooklyn teen-ager who lost a father to alcoholism and a mother to AIDS.
THURSDAY, APRIL 8 Crystal Rossi, Bensonhurst schoolgirl losing focus in class as she is tempted by the streets.
SUNDAY, APRIL 11 Marcus Tramble, a Chicago youth frustrated by his fears and the fears of others.
TUESDAY, APRIL 13 Fernando Morales, a Connecticut drug dealer, full of bravado and fatalism.
THURSDAY, APRIL 15 Jerina Gervais, an Oakland girl trying to expunge a wayward life of teen-age sex.
SUNDAY, APRIL 18 Freddie Cherokee Brown, a Bronx youth haunted by confrontations with the police.
TUESDAY, APRIL 20 Asenhat Gomez, newly arrived from the Dominican Republic, now isolated in Brooklyn.
THURSDAY, APRIL 22 Derrick White, a Memphis teen-ager, groping for a road map out of the projects.
SUNDAY, APRIL 25 Shawn Hunt, a one-time messenger for Brooklyn drug dealers, closing in on success.
 
States were ranked on six factors affecting the lives of the teenagers who live there. The composite score is a way of evaluating where teen-agers face the most obstacles to success.
 
The measures were:
*The percentage of all births that are to single teen-agers.
*The violent crime arrest rate among juveniles.
*The percentage of teen-agers no in school and not in the labor force.
*The violent death rate for teen-agers.
*The percentage of children living below the poverty level.

OTHER VOICES
'I Want to Be the First One to Stay Married'
 
Q. The whole idea of traditional family has changed a little bit since when our parents were growing up. What is a family? How do you define family?
 
DOUG KILCOMMONS, 17, Staten Island (Tottenville High School): Your family is people who love you, people who love you and are going to support you through thick and thin.
 
JUAN RIVERA, 18, Brooklyn (Bushwick High School): It doesn't have to be blood relationship, because I have several families. I would say my friends, when we're all gathered around. I can go to them for any support, love and understanding.
 
Q. Is there an ideal family?
 
WUBNESH HYLTON, 19, Brooklyn (Hunter College): I was just talking with my roommate last night and she was asking me if I wanted kids and I was telling her, 'No,' because whenever I envisioned it, it was always me raising a child by myself, and I never wanted that. I came from a single-parent household. And I was telling her, you know, if I did have a kid I would have to see some commitment coming from the guy. So I guess my vision for, like a family, would be like mother and father but also extended family like grandmothers and uncles and aunts and cousins, supporting that nucleus.
 
JERRY VITALE, 16, Brooklyn ( Lafayette High School): My parents, they brought me up, they gave me a home, shelter, clothes. So when I would have my wife and my kids, let's say, and they getting old, I would take care of my parents. It would be my turn. So, right there that would be my little family.
 
ZAIRE GRAHAM, 17, Bronx (Fashion Industries High School): I do want to be the Huxtables. You know why I want to be the Huxtables? Because they cool.
 
BERNARDO VASQUEZ, 17, Manhattan (A. Philip Randolph High School): What I like about the Huxtables is that that's something positive. If a little kid is sitting in the back and he's thinking, damn, click. That might be the clock that might make him the doctor.
 
ZAIRE Exactly. Not the show itself. It's just the ideal behind it that there can be the black "Brady Bunch," you know, the black family on TV. It gives the kid like me in the projects the ideal that I can have this brownstone in Brooklyn with my husband who's a doctor and me the wife who's the lawyer. Cause if all the shows we have are "Good Times" that means, damn, I'm stuck in the projects for the rest of my life. I ain't going nowhere.
 
Q. In your own families, what things would you like to change?
 
BARBARA FUENTES, 16, Hartford (Hartford Public High School): I would like my parents to have gone to college. My parents didn't go to college and my older sister was a pregnant teen and my other sister is now wed and has another child. I'm setting a goal for myself so that I could go to college and be the first one in may family to get married and have a successful life.
 
ZAIRE In my family, I think I want to be the first one to stay married, because everybody in my family, yeah, we got married, but nobody stayede married. When I get that house and that husband and everything, want to be able to hold on to it.
 
JUAN If I wanted to change something, maybe growing up with a father around.
 
JERMAINE WIGGINS, 20, Bronx: Same here, a strong male in the family. I have an older sister and she's supposed to be, you know, my role model. And my mother looks on me as, you know, "You're the man of the house." Where if my father's living there with us it would be great.
 
Q. What is the most special time that you spend with your family?
 
DONALD CROSBY, 18, Bronx: Each morning I can wake up and just kiss my mother on the cheek and tell her that I love her. That's a special occasion for me, or when I can just see my sister home from college or when my father's home from work and my mother and father are not arguing. That's special. You know, little things like that.
 
JUAN For me I feel it's Thanksgiving when all of my family comes over and, you know, we all eat together and hang out, and speak and thank God for everything, you know, just being together.
 
Q. Who do you look up to the most in your family?
 
DONALD My role model in my family would be my uncle. This man is completely motivated. He's been working all his life. It doesn't matter what he's doing, he can be hustling, this man keeps food on his kid's table and he talks to me a lot, comes takes me out. Being that I'm not so close to my father, he tries to fill in that gap.

HEADLINE: Focus: California;
Can Impact Fees Stunt a Town's Growth?

BYLINE: By JERRY CHESLOW

DATELINE: RIVERSIDE, CALIF.

 BODY:
THERE is no receptionist at the front desk of the Riverside County Planning Department. A revolving sign assures visitors that "someone will be with you in a few moments." Another says the agency is closed every other Friday. Just beyond is a cavernous area filled with empty desks.
One of the fastest growing counties in California -- its rate of growth was 10 percent in 1989 and 6.4 percent in 1992 -- Riverside is a typical example of an area that has grown to depend on real estate impact fees to pay for vital services and develop infrastructure. When times were good, the fees helped municipalities and counties grow by making development pay for its effect on the community, like the need for more or wider roads, sewers, schools, parks, fire protection and other services. 
 But many of those communities have found that in a recession high fees stunt growth and that services paid for by fees have shrunk to dangerously low levels. The county's Buildings Department, for example, which gets 97 percent of its funds from impact fees, went from 197 employees in 1989 to 15 today.
"Because we depend so heavily on impact fees," said Gerald V. Jolliffe, the county's principal planner, "when building slowed, we lost the fees and with them our ability to plan in advance. Applications for building permits now take much longer to get through the approval process and we are unable to prepare for the next development wave."
The county gets a total of $6,675 in fees for each new dwelling unit. Of these, two-thirds are classified as impact fees. They are used to cover not only the effects of new construction on public facilities but also the activities of the Building Department.
Some sections of the county have an additional fee of $1,600 an acre of development to cover the impact on the endangered Stevens kangaroo rat. Those fees are on top of other impact fees charged by municipalities and school districts, which often bring the total impact charges on new construction to more than $30,000 a unit.
Since 1978, when Broward County, Fla., became the first jurisdiction to impose impact fees, they have been challenged in the United States Supreme Court, which decided in 1987 that there must be a "rational nexus" establishing a clear connection between new growth and mandated local improvements.
So far, at least 17 states have passed enabling legislation to let counties and municipalities impose such fees. New Jersey and Connecticut have legislation to allow fees for improvements to roads and sewer, drainage and water systems. Although New York State has no such legislation, municipalities regularly force developers to make infrastructure improvements as a condition for permission to build large projects.
California's impact fees are among the highest in the country, partly to make up for shortfalls in property taxes resulting from Proposition 13. That measure, passed in a referendum in 1978, stipulates that municipalities may not increase property taxes by more than 2 percent a year on properties bought before 1978.
IN May 1992, the Riverside County Planning Department tried to make up for its shortfall by asking the county's Board of Supervisors for a 60 percent increase in fees. The request was rejected after the local Building Industry Association brought representatives of all of the building trades to the meeting to persuade the supervisors that an increase would further hobble the limping construction industry.
"The supervisors understood that raising fees when building activity drops is like beating a dead horse," said Thomas Van Voorst, executive director of the Riverside County Building Industry Association. "What you really need is to lower fees to stimulate the market."
"For every $1,000 in additional fees you lose 7 percent of the market," said Stephen Johnson, a partner in the Meyers Group, an independent firm that studies real estate trends in Southern California. "The more fees you impose, the more middle- and lower-income people are shut out of the market."
The most extreme example of a community suffering from impact fees is Chino Hills, a posh city of 44,000 with rolling hills and bridle paths. It is in San Bernardino County, just west of Chino, and abuts Los Angeles and Orange Counties. It was started by San Bernardino County in 1982 as a bedroom community to serve larger employment centers nearby. All of its infrastructure was to be financed through impact fees, which started at $4,200 per dwelling.
On Jan. 1, 1992, Chino Hills was chartered as a city, with excellent road and park systems financed by fees that now total more than $40,000 per dwelling. These include development fees of $36,000 that are charged when the building permit is issued and school fees of $2.65 per square foot of construction.
"Often the fees total more than the cost of the land," said Ronald N. Short, Director of Community Development at Chino Hills.
One of the first actions taken by the new City Council was to authorize an evaluation of the impact fee structure that had been put in place by the county. The Council found that although large one-family homes were still selling because of the natural beauty and the location of the city, the fees had all but ruled out other development. Its one low- to-moderate-income area, the Los Serranos neighborhood, which has about 170 empty lots, was deteriorating.
There was virtually no commercial development because the county had set commercial fees at an average of 9.2 times those of residential.
"We would try to bring in commercial development," said Mr. Short, "and they would have to pay $160,000 an acre just in fees. That was outrageous and no one would go for it."
In February the City Council passed a resolution cutting impact fees by 25 percent, waiving fees for new housing in Los Serranos over the coming year and allowing commercial property to pay up to one half of its fees from sales taxes it generated for the town.
As a result, Mr. Short said, a developer quickly put up 13 modest one-family houses in Los Serranos and sold them within a week for $137,000 each. The number of building permits for one-family homes went up by about 20 percent and the city was able to negotiate a deal for the construction of what Mr. Short calls a "power center," a large mall of outlet stores and discount shoppers clubs.
The city, which gets 1 percent of all state and county sales taxes collected within its boundaries, expects to reap $700,000 a year in sales taxes alone from the power center, which would more than double the amount of sales tax revenue currently collected. Construction is expected to begin before year's end.
Mr. Short says that the recession made Chino Hills begin to examine its fee schedule because there was considerable competition for the little commercial development taking place in Southern California. However, he said, the current reduction in fees is just the start of a process that he hopes will lead to a complete restructuring of the fee schedule.
"WE are looking at all of our fees and comparing them with what other communities in our area are doing," he said. "We've already found some ridiculous inequities. For instance, we charge $19.05 per square foot in impact fees for restaurant development. In Chino, it's $1.35. So who in his right mind would build a nice restaurant here? For regular retail stores, our fees come to $14.44 a square foot, as opposed to 64 cents in Chino."
Mr. Short hopes the new fee structure, when it is finally worked out, will allow the city to attract several more power centers.
"We realized that the idea of making development pay for itself is good to a degree," he said. "But sometimes that can be an oversimplification. You have to look at the fee structure in terms of the goals of the town, and by reducing our fees, we are actually in a lot better shape on our operating budget."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gerald V. Jolliffe, Riverside County planner, left; Ronald N. Short, director of development at Chino Hills. (Lilian Del Rio for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Impact Fees Re-Examined in California

HEADLINE: Skillful Students Offer Money-Saving Ideas

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: VALHALLA

 BODY:
THE economic turnaround has not yet caught up with many county residents who are still looking for ways to save money rather than spend it. For those willing to sacrifice prompt delivery of services for substantial savings, programs offered by the Board of Cooperative Educational Services at regional Technical and Occupational Education Centers can pay off. The centers offer services ranging from automobile and computer repairs to carpentry, floral design, catering and haircuts, performed by high school students, young adults and displaced workers looking for opportunities to try out new vocational skills.
"Our purpose in providing these services is primarily to give our students an opportunity to practice what it is they have learned here, to apply the skills they have been taught here," said Dr. Joseph S. Schwartzberg, director of occupational education at the Southern Westchester Center for Technical and Occupational Education in Valhalla. 
 "Since these are service occupations, we want to give students the opportunity to interact with the public," Dr. Schwartzberg added. "Our purpose is instructional, so every project becomes an instructional activity or lesson for the class."
 
'Nobody Pays for Labor'
 Dr. Otto Behrens, director of occupational education at the Northern Westchester-Putnam Center for Technical and Occupational Education in Yorktown Heights, added, "What we're trying to do is give them a real-life experience, what they would find out when they are on a real job."
Because students attend classes for only two to two and a half hours each day, potential consumers should be aware that there can be a long waiting list to schedule an appointment. With car and computer repairs, instructors usually want to assess the educational value of the project before assigning it to a class. Repairs and projects are also likely to take longer than if a customer brought a comparable assignment to a local shop. For most services, however, there is only a materials charge -- and consumers are guaranteed close supervision for their project.
"Nobody pays for labor," Dr. Schwartzberg said. "What we charge is what it costs us to do it. The work that gets done here is top quality, because students are supervised by teachers who have spent years in the trade. We never compromise on quality."
Dan Brady, coordinator for transitional services at the Board of Cooperative Educational Services' incarcerated-youth program, has been taking in his cars for the last 15 years. "It's thorough, because the teacher supervises the work," Mr. Brady said. "And I like the idea of the kids' getting a real learning experience. Since they have no vested interest in selling me parts, I believe them when they say I need something for my car."
Except where indicated, all the following services are available at both the Southern Westchester Center for Technical and Occupational Education, 65 Grasslands Road, Valhalla (761-3400), and the Putnam-Northern Westchester Center for Technical and Occupational Education, 200 Boces Drive, Yorktown Heights (245-2700). Consumers are advised to call for an appointment. Telephone extensions are available for the Yorktown Heights center only.
Drivers with dented or damaged cars can obtain an assessment in the auto-body repair program. The instructor will determine the educational benefit for students and give the driver a cost and time estimate. For tuneups and mechanical problems, drivers should apply to the auto-mechanics programs.
A small-engine repair program, at the Yorktown Heights center only (Extension 436), is offering consumers a seasonal special: tuneup and cleaning of lawn mower motors for $10. Students in this program will also tune and repair outboard motors, snow blowers and garden tractors.
The carpentry program offers a combination design and construction service. Whether it is a backyard gazebo, outdoor storage shed or picnic-table set, students in the architectural-design program will create a blueprint that can be followed by carpentry students. Consumers have to provide and arrange for delivery of materials.
A three-day-a-week nursery school, available at the Yorktown Heights center only, is staffed by students in its child-care program. Parents interested in enrolling their children in this program should call Extension 434 to find out if space is available.
 
Cosmetology Clinic Days
 In the computer-repair program (Extension 438 at the Yorktown Heights center) consumers baffled by gremlins in their latest model I.B.M. or Macintosh can take their equipment in for diagnosis and repair.
Students in the cosmetology program ply their skills at shampooing, haircutting, manicuring and coloring on clinic days, when the public is invited to make an appointment. At Valhalla, clinic day is Friday, with classes starting at 8:30 A.M. and noon. Fees range from $2 (for a manicure) to $4 (for a basic haircut). More complicated processes, like a frosting or permanent, cost $15.
At the Yorktown Heights center, fees are $1 for a manicure, $3 for a haircut and $14 for a permanent. Clinic days in Yorktown Heights are Thursdays and Fridays. The number to call for an appointment is 245-4869.
 
Student-Run Restaurants
 With prom season and Mother's Day approaching, the horticulture program's offerings can be especially timely -- and inexpensive. At the Valhalla center, corsages and boutonnieres start at $3, bouquets at $5; floral centerpieces start at $12. At the Yorktown Heights center, boutonnieres are $1.25, corsages $2.25 to $4, table centerpieces $8 to $15.
Both centers offer the public a dining experience in their on-site student-run restaurants. At Valhalla's Taste of Class, reserved sittings are available on Wednesdays from 11 A.M. to 1:30 P.M. A five-course lunch is $10.
In Yorktown Heights, the Educated Palate is open to the public on Thursdays from noon to 1:30 P.M. for a buffet lunch at $9.95. The extension to call for reservations is 236. Students in the Yorktown Heights program will also do off-site and on-site catering for meetings or special events.

HEADLINE: Japan's Recession Felt in the County

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

 BODY:
FOR Kumiko Buller, a real estate agent who works for Ye Village Realty in Dobbs Ferry, a particular three-bedroom Colonial in Irvington had always been an easy rental property to offer to relocated Japanese executives who sought her services. That house's location near the train station and the elementary school made it desirable -- and as soon as one Japanese family returned to Tokyo, Mrs. Buller could count on a waiting list of clients.
But when the last Japanese tenants went back to Japan in July, the house remained vacant until March 1, an ominous sign to Mrs. Buller of the changing Japanese market in the county. "We see people going back, but we're not seeing their replacements," Mrs. Buller said. "Japanese companies are sending fewer people over, or they are closing offices in the metropolitan area. In the past, when the selling market was very weak, the rental market was very strong. Now the rental market is also weak. I can see the change very well." 
 Similar signs are also apparent to at least one restaurateur, Tony Saegusa, owner of Azuma Sushi in Hartsdale, which is a popular spot for Japanese executives. "For the first time in two decades, more people are going back to Japan than are coming over," Mr. Saegusa said. "Among our regular customers, we see that fewer companies are going to have new representatives here."
While the official numbers on Westchester's Japanese population have remained relatively constant for the last two years -- about 10,000, according to the Japanese consulate in Manhattan -- those who work with the Japanese community in the county say that there has been a significant change in the demographics of the Japanese population in the county since 1991.
 
Trading Down Is Now Normal
 Realtors and business owners who cater to this market say that the combination of tighter visa restrictions, which went into effect in 1992, and recessionary economies in Japan and the New York City area, have resulted in fewer Japanese companies sending executives overseas. And those managers who are transferred to the New York area now tend to be younger -- and are expected to take on longer assignments than in the past.
"Because of the recession in Japan, many families are sent back to Japan," said Dan Omori, vice president of Furumoto Realty in Scarsdale, a real estate agency that specializes in the Japanese market. "The moving expense is so great for Japanese companies that companies now like people to stay at least three years or more. And people want less-expensive properties now than they did two or three years ago." For example, while a 50-year-old executive might have wanted a prime piece of Scarsdale real estate, a thirtysomething replacement is willing to take a two-bedroom condominium near a train station.
Added Cynthia Landon, a rental agent with Redac, a Scarsdale-based real estate and relocation firm: "We're absolutely seeing a drop-off. The Japanese companies are cutting back on their overseas staff because of our economy and theirs, and because it's more difficult to obtain visas."
The impact of the county's changing Japanese population goes beyond restaurants and real estate. Younger families that are now being sent over are more interested in nursery-school programs than in school districts, with the ramifications being felt by after-school and weekend Japanese programs and by school districts.
 
School Districts Also Affected
 "The Japanese Weekend School, which teaches Japanese language and academics to school-age children, faces a critical problem in enrollment, especially in the last year," Mr. Saegusa said.
School districts that have long been attractive destinations for Japanese families are beginning to sense the change as well. "When I go to conferences, I have noticed people saying to me, 'Oh, are you losing Japanese students?' " said Rita McGuigan, a teacher of English as a second language at Edgemont High School. "But we haven't noticed a decrease yet, although some of my advanced students think that we will soon."
A spokeswoman for the Scarsdale Board of Education said that the district had observed that fewer Japanese corporations were sending executives to the area, although statistics on the decline had not yet been gathered.
 
Conclusions May Be Premature
 "We're not getting as many students in for a short time, the way we used to," said Barbara Gstalder, a teacher of English as a second language in Chappaqua's middle and high schools. "Our numbers are down. Normally, I would have expected 5 to 10 new Japanese students by this time of year, when the Japanese school year ends, but there is only one new Japanese student so far. There is definitely a slowdown."
Despite such evidence, others say, it is premature to assume that there is any real Japanese flight from the area. "Japan is not abandoning America," said Joseph Brunetto, president of JapanAmerica Communications Corporation, a 10-year-old company in Scarsdale that offers language classes in Japanese and English to Americans and Japanese and activities like yoga classes, aerobics, bridge and arts and crafts. It also publishes Japanese-language magazines and books for the Japanese community here and in Japan.
"The population is changing as companies are bringing in younger people," Mr. Brunetto said. "Very simply, the bubble burst in Japan the same way it did in America. Now they are downsizing and looking at ways to reduce expenses. If they have a 50-year-old office director with a wife and two children about ready to enter college and can replace that family with a 28-year-old person who has a wife and 3-year-old child, they don't need to provide subsidies for education. Companies are bringing fewer top people over here. They are also trying to give more autonomy to the foreign offices by trying to get the American staff to do more and stabilizing their work force in America."

HEADLINE: Enough of the Old-Style Summits

BYLINE: By Michael R. Beschloss; Michael R. Beschloss, a historian, is author of "The Crisis Years: Kennedy and Khrushchev 1960-1963" and (with Strobe Talbott) of "At the Highest Levels: The Inside Story of the End of the Cold War."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After Presidents Clinton and Boris Yeltsin leave Vancouver, it would be a good time to ratchet down the ceremony between American and Russian leaders.
One cannot help but be struck that in atmospherics the Vancouver summit resembles less the low-key sessions Mr. Clinton recently has had with Western leaders than the media events of the cold war: two leaders flying to a third country at a moment of world drama, the throwaway remarks as they vanish behind closed doors, the TV correspondents filling time outside, the instant assessments. 
 There are good reasons for Mr. Clinton to have convened this first summit in the old style. Yet he should think carefully about the next time. Staging future meetings with Mr. Yeltsin or his successors in the customary grandiose manner could hamper his foreign policy -- by increasing the tendency to focus relations on one man, by shortchanging alternative Russian leaders and other states of the former Soviet Union.
Mr. Clinton hoped to provide the Russian President with at least the outward appearance of a meeting between two states of equal might, as in the old superpower days. Nobody's interest would be served if Mr. Yeltsin were to appear the supplicant.
During the Presidential campaign, Mr. Clinton criticized George Bush for his failure to expend sufficient political energy to fulfill U.S. promises of serious aid if Moscow stayed the course of radical reform. Flying to Vancouver allowed Mr. Clinton to demonstrate that he is taking a different approach.
Mr. Clinton is acutely aware that Russia could revert to its authoritarian and expansionist ways. He does not want history to judge him as a President so absorbed by domestic affairs that he missed the chance to prevent retrenchment. He also knows that such a retrenchment could produce hysteria at home, cause the military budget to expand and undermine his economic program.
Furthermore, a decision not to give Mr. Yeltsin the royal treatment would have been seen as evidence that, in Mr. Clinton's mind, Mr. Yeltsin's political ills were incurable. It would also have been offensive on a purely personal level. Mr. Yeltsin is a sensitive man who bitterly remembers his first U.S. visit, in 1989, when he was hustled into a White House side door, without photographers present, in order to avoid offending Mikhail Gorbachev. A full-scale summit is thus a boost not only to Mr. Yeltsin's shaky status at home but to his morale.
The fact remains that the substantive business could have just as easily been transacted during a quiet weekend in Moscow or at Camp David. Mr. Yeltsin will say some things he cannot say in public or safely telegraph through other channels: the exact state of his relations with the Russian military or which domestic political compromises he will or will not make in order to keep his job. He will use his formidable powers of personal persuasion to make the case for large-scale Group of Seven assistance to Russia.
Ritualized summitry adds nothing to these discussions and may even distract the participants. Indeed, both men seem to prefer quieter settings. Mr. Clinton's White House talks with the departing Canadian Prime Minister, Brian Mulroney, suggest that his diplomacy is best when informal. Mr. Yeltsin's own allergy to rigid protocol need hardly be noted.
More fundamentally, for Mr. Clinton to afford Mr. Yeltsin the imperial-summit treatment in the future would personalize American policy toward Russia in exactly the way for which Mr. Clinton lambasted George Bush on the campaign trail. For Richard Nixon to hold a theatrical summit with Leonid Brezhnev, for instance, did not suggest that he was siding with Mr. Brezhnev against his political rivals: for all practical purposes, there weren't any.
But in the turbulence of today's Russian politics, this is no longer true. Recall the Abbott and Costello scenes in Moscow when Mr. Bush met Mr. Gorbachev in July 1991. Mr. Bush tried to include Mr. Yeltsin and other republican leaders, and Mr. Gorbachev tried to include them out. Mr. Yeltsin then announced that he would not be part of a "faceless mass audience." Invited to a private session with Mr. Bush, Mr. Yeltsin pointedly kept him waiting, prompting one Bush aide to complain, "That guy's got to be told we're not going to let him use us in his petty games!"


T hat farce suggests how difficult it is to have a ceremonial summit with a contested Kremlin leader while trying to take due account of his colleagues and rivals. Although Moscow hardly teems with reform politicians of national stature, there is little for Mr. Clinton to gain by fostering the notion that Mr. Yeltsin is the only head of the Russian Government with whom he can work. That would stifle the emergence of other reformers to succeed Mr. Yeltsin when he leaves.
The prime ministers of Japan and Britain and other U.S. allies, received in Washington in the conventional manner, can be excused for wondering why the President would persist in interrupting his White House schedule for days at a time to prepare for and fly off to a media event with a Russian leader.
But future imperial summitry with Russia might easily injure American relations with other former Soviet republics. Even now, the leaders of Ukraine and the Baltic states are not happy to see the U.S. lavish such attention on Mr. Yeltsin when their own foreign policies -- and perhaps their armies -- might collide with those of Moscow.
Ceremonial summits between American Presidents and their Kremlin counterparts were invented for a specific purpose. In 1943, at the dawn of the cold war, Stalin was angry and suspicious about the failure of Roosevelt and Churchill to open a promised second front against Nazi Germany. Always confident of his talent for personal relations, F.D.R. flew halfway around the world in an uncomfortable little plane to Teheran, in Stalin's backyard, in order to renew trust.
Without knowing it, Roosevelt had improvised a mainstay of the half-century struggle that followed. Grand summits brought a regularity and civility to a relationship that was fragile, strained and monumentally dangerous. But now that the perils of the cold war have mainly receded, Mr. Clinton would do well to heed George Bush's first private, handwritten letter to Mikhail Gorbachev, in July 1989: "I would like very much to sit down and talk to you, if you are agreeable to the idea. I want to do it without thousands of assistants hovering over our shoulders, without the ever-present briefing papers and certainly without the press yelling at us every 5 minutes about 'who's winning,' 'what agreements have been reached' or 'has our meeting succeeded or failed.' "
Mr. Bush did not take his own good advice. Mr. Clinton should.

HEADLINE: New York City Readies 37 Specialized Schools

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON

 BODY:
In the most sweeping expansion of New York City's public high school system in decades, school officials are rushing to sign up students and prepare classrooms for the inauguration of 37 small experimental schools this fall.
The dozens of new schools, each with a curriculum centered on a separate theme, represent an extraordinary effort to bring into the mainstream educational approaches that have been tested, until now, only in isolated pockets of the city's system. The initiative, which involves starting up more high schools at one time than have opened altogether in the last half century, gained final school board approval in a series of recent meetings. 
 The new institutions, most of which will occupy space in existing school buildings or on college campuses, focus on topics varying from music to finance to community organizing.
Most of the schools were developed in partnerships between the Board of Education and unions, colleges, neighborhood groups and even some churches in all five boroughs. Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez's support has been crucial, and he and his top aides hope that the initiative will remain as his main legacy, overshadowing the battles over condom distribution, teaching about homosexuality and other controversies that led to his ouster.
"This is the most extensive reform of secondary schools going on anywhere in the nation," said Stanley S. Litow, Mr. Fernandez's deputy chancellor for operations.
 
Change Amid Many Tensions
 Educators elsewhere agree. "I think the folks in New York have good reason to sound breathless," said Michael Kashley, executive director of the Washington-based Council on Great City Schools. "What's unique is that they're opening so many new schools as a way of decentralizing the bureaucracy and offering more personal attention to students. One would think it was an act of genius if it weren't so obvious."
But the change comes as the city's school system is already experiencing tremendous tensions, with a divided central Board seeking a replacement for Mr. Fernandez, ideological wars racking many of the city's 32 community school boards, and many political leaders calling for basic change in the way the system is governed.
As a result, some educators and union officials are murmuring that too many experimental schools are being opened too fast. The scope of the undertaking has raised questions about how the lumbering school bureaucracy will cope.
With many of the students in the city's full-size high schools -- some have nearly 5,000 students -- headed for failure, the new schools aim to make learning more relevant by focusing the basic academic subjects on a practical community project or a professional or vocational specialty. Although some schools are to be vocationally oriented, the overall approach is meant to be much broader.
The schools are organized around a variety of themes, which will be used as springboards to present lessons in different subjects. At El Puente Academy in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, students are to study science by organizing a neighborhood measles vaccination campaign. At the High School for Economics and Finance in Manhattan, classrooms will simulate a corporate office. Students at the School for Social Change in the Bronx, pioneered by Hospital Workers Union Local 1199, are to learn community organizing through service projects like planting neighborhood gardens.
 
Little Effect on Crowding
 Thirty schools will open with ninth-grade classes in the fall. Seven others will open with lower grades and are to add high school classes in coming years. The schools opening in September will add about 4,000 new seats to the city's system, which this year includes 124 high schools. When they reach their average enrollment of 500 to 600 students in 1997, the new schools are expected to enroll more than 25,000 students, school officials said. Even so, they will have little effect on classroom overcrowding because the student population is growing by more than 20,000 a year.
Measuring student-staff ratios or class sizes has not yet begun, because most staffs have not been hired. But school authorities hope the new schools will give students more individual attention.
Since the board voted final approval on March 17, authorities have printed a new high school catalogue and rushed 170,000 copies to hundreds of lower schools so that students can re-evaluate their fall plans. Students were to apply by today, but applications received by April 15 will be accepted, school officials said. Students already accepted at other high schools may apply to the new schools and, if accepted, make their final choice later, the officials said.
 
If Washington Had the D Train
 The selection criteria vary from school to school, but in most cases are intended to avoid "creaming," or selecting only the top students.
The schools are in varying stages of development, but board approval has set off feverish preparations everywhere. The School for the Physical City, a collaboration of the Cooper Union, Outward Bound, and other groups, will build a curriculum around study of New York's bridges, subways and other infrastructure. It has already hired its principal, Mark Weiss. Last week in a temporary office at Cooper Union, Mr. Weiss and aides were planning a history sequence that will include a reconstruction of George Washington's Revolutionary War retreat through Prospect Park and across the East River.
The same day, recruiters from the Boys Choir of Harlem were visiting junior high schools auditioning singers -- boys and girls -- for the ninth-grade class of a new Choir Academy of Harlem High School, which the choir is organizing in collaboration with Community School District 5.
At his offices at 127 West 127th Street, Horace Turnbull, the choir's general manager, said he was searching for a school leader who can adapt to the singular traditions of the choir, which intends to build a classroom schedule around the choir's national and international tours.
Union leaders are watching closely to see how the involvement of community groups in the administration of public schools will work out in practice. Donald Singer, the president of the principals union, said he regarded the founding of smaller schools as a good idea in theory and had been assured by Mr. Fernandez that the new institutions would comply with all union contracts and staff certification requirements. But he said the bewildering number of new schools made him uneasy.
John Soldini, a vice president of the teachers union, voiced similar concerns. He has tried to track the initiative with office graphics, he said.
"But every time you finish a chart, a new school pops up," Mr. Soldini said. "This is a radical transformation of the system, and with the Chancellor in limbo, they want to move ahead as quickly as possible. I'm not saying it's a bad idea -- too many of our students are lost under the traditional structures -- but I've never seen anything like this. It's overwhelming."
Some of the schools have run into 11th-hour difficulties. Last week staff members and parents at Junior High School 293 in downtown Brooklyn, complaining that they had not been consulted, forced cancellation of plans to open one of the new schools, the High School for Global Citizenship, in a wing of J.H.S. 293.
 
'Schemes for Segregation'
 Two schools that are expected to appeal primarily to black and Hispanic students have drawn opposition from the New York Civil Rights Coalition. They are the Middle College High School at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn, and the Leadership Secondary School, slated to open in September on the Lower East Side with sixth- and seventh-grade classes.
"These schools are inherently racist, new schemes for segregation," said Michael Meyers, the Coalition's executive director. Mr. Meyers said he intended to file complaints against the two schools with the Office of Civil Rights of the United States Department of Education.
Despite these storm clouds, however, most educators viewing the process are speaking in superlatives.
"People will say that creating so many small schools is going to be an administrative morass," said Theodore Sizer, a Brown University professor who has collaborated on six of the schools. "But who cares? That's just a management problem. Usually, ease of management has replaced what is right for kids. Now they've reversed that."
Academics long ago began to attribute the high dropout rates and failings of traditional American high schools to their huge scale and industrial atmosphere, with school days punctuated by clanging bells. For nearly two decades, some New York educators have been experimenting with smaller high schools, often in defiance of the bureaucracy.
