HEADLINE: 'Hey Prez!': Computers Offer New Line to Clinton

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
Want a full transcript of President Clinton's latest speech on housing or welfare? Just tap in a command on your home computer.
Want the White House to know instantly what you think of Mr. Clinton's economic plan? Call the "White House comments line" and punch in a response on your touch-tone phone. 
 Have more to say? Just type a note on the computer and punch in the White House electronic-mail address. In seconds, the message will have reached 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.
Mr. Clinton does not have a computer in the Oval Office (he prefers legal pads), but he has surrounded himself with a new generation of aides who are steeped in the latest technology. They are marketing Mr. Clinton (his computer name is Clinton Pz) in ways that a President has never been presented before.
While the grind of speeches and news conferences by the Clinton Administration may be conventional, the President's messages -- critics would say propaganda -- are penetrating households and offices in far less traditional ways.
For the first time, even people with little knowledge of computers can send a message to the White House through electronic mail. One computer jockey recently began a note to Mr. Clinton with the greeting, "Hey Prez!" Another punched in, "To Waffle Willie."
Subscribers to major on-line computer services like America Online, Compuserve, Internet, MCI Mail and Prodigy can get information put out by the White House on their computers within hours after it is processed.
After punching the command "GO WHITEHOUSE," users of Compuserve see this greeting flash on their computer screens: "Welcome to the White House forum!" They can then retrieve speeches from the President, Vice President or First Lady on dozens of subjects.
They can also view photographs of the President striking any number of patriotic poses. In classrooms around the country, students and teachers can retrieve by computer the daily White House news briefings and schedules, and Mr. Clinton's speeches.
That is only the beginning: Administration aides are tinkering with things like digital photography that would allow the President's image to be transmitted almost instantaneously to people around the country, and building the President's own cable television network to show Government at work. There is even talk of a live, on-line "town meeting" with Mr. Clinton.
"The advantage is you're getting information from the horse's mouth," said Randall Davis, a professor of computer science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who has advised the White House on computers. "You are hearing what the original source said. Not only has the message not been filtered before it arrives at your computer, it has not even been repackaged."
Others warn that the White House is simply using technology as another way to go over the head of a probing press corps.
"People are going to be taken in by the glamour of having a hot line of their own to the White House," said Jarol P. Manheim, a professor of political communication at George Washington University. "And the glamour is going to blind them potentially to the level of management of information that inevitably lies behind anything they put out. The danger is that people perceive it as unfiltered when in fact the filter is one step back so that it's being done by those who produce rather than gather the news."
Opening the White House to new ways of communicating, however, does not guarantee a positive response. One computer user named Anthony recently fired off a message to the White House, attacking Mr. Clinton's economic plan and saying he hoped the President would "stop dividing this country by economic class for crass political purposes." (Mr. Clinton probably never saw the message.)
 
Not That Gore
 Hundreds of computer messages, or E-mail, are sent to the White House each day. A man named John Jackson recently sent an electronic message there and got a reply from a man named Alan Gore, who apparently does not work in the Administration.
"You are not THE Al Gore ARE YOU?" he asked.
"No," chimed in a man named Marc Perkel, who was also on line, "he ain't the Veep."
Then Alan Gore replied himself: "The Veep is Albert, and I'm Alan," he wrote. 'Don't feel bad: since the election, I have gotten quite a few phone calls (one obscene) and E-mail messages from people who are confused over the name. I also get lots of mail from Green wacko organizations, thinking I will support them in their mission of Earth-worshipping destruction of civilization."
A boy in Maryland recently sent this electronic letter to Mr. Clinton: "I am 8 years old and I am very concerned about animals and pollution in our country. Please try to make cleaner factories and cars and save our animals from dying. P.S. Do you have a job for me?"
The technology has not reached the point where people can routinely get electronic messages back. Until the White House tools up its computer operation, people who send electronic messages to the President and Vice President will get a written, albeit slower, response via the United States Postal Service (snail mail, computer users call it).
While there is no talk yet of amazing technological feats like beaming holograms of Mr. Clinton to every breakfast table in America, Jeff Eller, who heads the White House media affairs office, said he had been besieged by vendors asking him to try out assorted new gadgets, offers that he happily accepts.
He tosses off phrases like "pretty cool stuff" to describe the possibilities, but Mr. Eller vowed not to get carried away from his objective of getting Mr. Clinton's message out as effectively as possible.
"It's nice to have great toys, and technology is a wonderful thing," Mr. Eller said as he chomped on his familiar unlit cigar and fiddled with a full-color image of the White House on his computer screen. "But you should never use technology for technology's sake."
 
More Mail Than Predecessors
 Mr. Clinton is receiving more regular mail than any of his predecessors, officials of the White House correspondence office said, and messages by computer are coming in at an even faster pace.
"Our goal is to make all this information available to all Americans, regardless of location, and with no attention to station in life," said Jonathan P. Gill, a software developer from Medford, Mass., who is now the White House electronic mail coordinator. "It will lead to a more informed electorate. A lot of what the campaign was about was disaffection and alienation. The President used the term 'to reconnect.' It's wonderfully democratic."
But officials from the correspondence office said most of the computer messages were coming from a rather narrow audience: the best educated and most affluent. In other words, those who can afford computers.
Diane Bradley, a reference librarian at Auburn University who has made use of data from the White House, scoffed at concerns about demographics. "It's a current events source that the public did not have access to in full text before," she said.
With all the talk of high technology, the paradox is that the White House inherited an antiquated, patchwork computer system for internal use that many people simply do not use.
"People never turn their machines on because it's so dysfunctional," said John Podesta, the White House staff secretary, who handles all the paper that crosses Mr. Clinton's desk. "It's not helpful to send someone a computer note if they're not going to work on their computer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "It's nice to have great toys, and technology is a wonderful thing," said Jeff Eller, head of the White House media affairs office, who tries out the new gadgets sent to him. But he vowed not to get carried away from his objective of getting Mr. Clinton's message out as effectively as possible. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. A14)

HEADLINE: Egypt Warned U.S. of Terror, Mubarak Says

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that the United States could have prevented the bombing of the World Trade Center if American officials had heeded his country's warnings about an Islamic fundamentalist network in the United States.
But he suggested that the information provided by Egypt related generally to activities by individuals in the United States, not that Egypt had passed on specific information foreshadowing the bombing. 
 Mr. Mubarak called on the new Administration to take a more active role in stemming international terrorism, particularly activities inspired by Islamic fundamentalist groups. He blamed the current violence in Egypt and elsewhere in the Middle East in part on Iran and in part on veterans who fought with Afghan guerrillas as part of the American-backed war against the Soviet-backed Communist Government in Kabul.
 
New Details About Suspect
 He offered new details about the background of Mahmud Abouhalima, a suspect in the World Trade Center bombing who was captured in Egypt and flown back to the United States two weeks ago. President Mubarak asserted that the suspect said during his interrogation by the Egyptian authorities that he had quarreled with Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, an Egyptian fundamentalist cleric for whom he served as a driver and aide.
In an hourlong interview, a day after his arrival in Washington, Mr. Mubarak also said he would ask President Clinton when they met for the first time on Tuesday to urge Israel to make another gesture to help resolve the problem of the 400 Palestinians deported to Lebanon in December.
But Mr. Mubarak's most surprising remarks concerned the bombing. "It could have been prevented if you listened to our advice," he said. Asked whether the United States had been given clear information about the activities of individuals and specific mosques, he added: "That's right. And this information has been exchanged with American intelligence."
Mr. Mubarak declined to give details of what information had been passed on or how the American authorities could have used it.
But other senior Egyptian officials said that several months ago, they had given the Americans detailed warnings about the activities and inflammatory oratory of Mr. Abdel Rahman and his operation in New Jersey, and about mosques in Brooklyn, through diplomatic and intelligence channels.
The American authorities have not publicly linked Mr. Abdel Rahman with the trade center bombing, nor have they sought to question or detain him.
 
Close Intelligence Ties
 The United States and Egypt have an extremely close intelligence-sharing relationship, and the Embassy in Cairo is used by the Central Intelligence Agency and its sister intelligence agencies as the information-gathering hub for much of the Middle East.
Despite the repeated warnings from Egypt, American law enforcement and intelligence officials have taken a somewhat sanguine view about the threat posed by Mr. Abdel Rahman and his followers. In an interview last month, senior Government analysts said they believed that his role in violent acts was limited to exhortation. The C.I.A. declined comment today on Mr. Mubarak's assertions.
Concerning the Middle East peace talks, Mr. Mubarak said he would "try to do my best with the President" to persuade him to urge the Israelis to speed the return of about 400 Palestinians deported to Lebanon in December.
This issue has frozen the peace talks. Washington has invited all the participants to a new round of talks on April 20, but the Palestinian delegation is demanding additional concessions on the deportee issue before attending.
"The Palestinians now want a small step within the package to take place," Mr. Mubarak said, referring to an accelerated timetable for the return of the deportees that Secretary of State Warren Christopher has presented to Israel and to the Palestinians.
 
'I Think It Would Help'
 "If President Clinton could agree with it and discuss it with Prime Minister Rabin," he said, "I think it would help a lot."
Senior Egyptian officials said one idea would be for Israel to bring back all the deportees by August or September, instead of the current deadline of the end of the year.
Asked about Mr. Mubarak's proposal, a senior Administration official said the Clinton Administration would be unwilling to ask Israel to make another concession on the deportees.
"The ball is very clearly in the Palestinian court as to its decision to come to the next round of talks," the official said. "The time has come for the Palestinians to decide on the basis of the significant package and understandings that got worked out with the Palestinians and the Israelis to come to the table, and that's it."
Mr. Mubarak said he would also urge Mr. Clinton to maintain the current amount of aid for Egypt -- $2.1 billion a year, saying he was heartened by Mr. Clinton's pledge not to cut the aid. Such aid is necessary if Egypt is to continue its economic modernization program and make up for lost tourism revenue caused by terrorist bombings in the last year, Mr. Mubarak said.
But he added, referring to budget debates in Washington: "We realize the situation here. We are not asking for any more. Economic reform will take another two, maximum three, years and then we will look to what will happen with aid."
 
Arrest of Abouhalima
 Mr. Mubarak seemed reluctant to discuss events surrounding the World Trade Center bombing, but he offered new details about Mr. Abouhalima, who was arrested in the Egyptian port of Alexandria and interrogated by the Egyptian authorities before he was sent to the Untied States.
Mr. Abouhalima's lawyer and family members have said that he was tortured by Egyptian authorities and that any statements he made were coerced. United States officials have said he was examined for signs of torture, but the results have not been disclosed.
President Mubarak said that after Mr. Abouhalima left Egypt in 1980 for Germany, he tried unsuccessfully to get political asylum "as a man who is not wanted in Egypt because he a Nasserist," a follower of Gamal Abdel Nasser, the President of Egypt from 1956 to 1970.
Before his return, Mr. Abouhalima went to Jidda, Saudi Arabia, to get an Egyptian visa because he had German documents, Mr. Mubarak said. He suggested that the Egyptian authorities had arrested Mr. Abouhalima on their own initiative rather than at the request of the United States.
During the interrogation, Mr. Mubarak said, the suspect professed his innocence, saying, "I'm ready to go to the United States to prove I am innocent, because there is no evidence against me."
 
Criticism of the Cleric
 Although during his interrogation, Mr. Abouhalima said Mr. Abdel Rahman was his spiritual guide, he accused the sheik of violating Islamic principles, Mr. Mubarak said, because the cleric had raised funds for Afghan guerrillas and put the money into an interest-bearing bank account, in violation of the Islamic ban on interest, and taking the interest for his personal use.
Acquaintances of Mr. Abouhalima say he traveled to Pakistan or Afghanistan for months at a time as part of the effort to help the Muslim rebels.
Mr. Mubarak said he would not request the extradition of Mr. Abdel Rahman, who has called in sermons for his overthrow. "Oh, keep him in your country!" the President said. "We don't need Abdel Rahman. You accepted him in your country, keep him! He is a normal Egyptian. If he wants to go to Egypt, he is welcome. But he is not allowed to violate the law."
Although Mr. Mubarak said Iran was sponsoring terrorism in the Middle East, he also blamed the United States for creating the basis for an Islamic terrorist network by supporting so-called Islamic fighters against the Soviet occupiers in Afghanistan.
"When the Soviets occupied Afghanistan and the war started," he said, "so many criminals, thieves, those who have been sentended to jail for several years, not only in Egypt but everywhere, were being summoned to participate in liberating Afghanistan.
"You in the United States were encouraging these people to go there to work against the Soviets at that time, against Communism. Then after the Soviets withdrew, the United States pulled away its hand."
Mr. Mubarak said that after the war, Iran had begun to use Afghan veterans for its own terrorist goals, and he called on the Clinton Administration to redouble its efforts against terrorism, in particular to help clean out the thousands of veterans who still live in Pakistan along the Afghan border.
The United States should play "a tough role," he said, "because it is a source of problems, and not only for the Middle East."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt yesterday in Washington. (Lisa Berg for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Military Cuts: A Millstone for Ex-Workers

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
David H. Dolson assumed he was on the right track. He was part of a team coordinating the production and delivery of replacement parts for aircraft made by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. While still there, he set about preparing himself for work in a society no longer bracing for war with a Soviet superpower.
Mr. Dolson, who is 27 years old, determined that industry needed managers for foreign plants, so he earned a master's degree in international relations. Laid off in September 1990, he went to Bolivia and learned Spanish. Home again, he said, "I'll go anywhere." So what is he doing now? "Installing kitchens," he said. He earns $7.50 an hour, half his pay at McDonnell Douglas. 
 Mr. Dolson is one of the faces behind what policy makers call conversion, the shift of many military bases and weapons factories to reduced or altered missions. But for most of the people in the weapons industries, conversion is just not working.
The problem is not confined to McDonnell Douglas, the nation's biggest military contractor. If good work is hard to find for these workers, most of them skilled in modern technologies, what does that portend for the economy of the next decades?
Once before military-industry workers faced a large-scale conversion, after World War II, when a resurgent economy took them on. Some workers here say the nation needs Washington or a new Henry Ford to create new industries to do the same.
 
Sharp Cuts in Pay
 "And so far," said Linus J. Portman, a 51-year-old engineer let go by McDonnell Douglas after 26 years, "we don't seem to have anything."
Rather than the shift from one good job to another, as conversion implies, most workers find themselves in the same boat as steel and automobile workers, facing month upon month of unemployment, unstable jobs and sharp cuts in pay.
President Clinton has promised to spend $375 million through this September to retrain the workers, and retraining would consume an undetermined part of the $20 billion that he proposes to spend for conversion over the next five years. But some analysts say the money does not begin to meet the need to develop new jobs and the skills of workers to perform them.
"The long range economic programs being espoused by the Administration will not lead to jobs for the people being let go today," said V. W. Souverall, who monitors conversion as executive director of the National Center for Career Change in Walnut Creek, Calif.
Nationwide, Mr. Souverall said, nearly 400,000 military workers have lost jobs since the industry's contraction began in 1989. With more old Pentagon contracts winding down and fewer new ones coming along, he said, 450,000 more will be out of work by 1996. Other estimates put the total loss by then at more than a million.
 
Hampered by Slow Recovery
 Finding good new jobs has been slow in part because the recovering economy has been slow to produce them. But other influences impede the workers' conversion. Age is one. Many laid-off workers are in their 40's and 50's. Another, the workers say, is that some employers find them too specialized, or ill-equipped or spoiled and overpaid for cost-conscious commercial businesses.
Still another factor is that military contractors and workers conspire against conversion. Like many companies these days, McDonnell Douglas has occasional spurts in business that it absorbs by rehiring laid-off workers. They come in as temporary independent contractors with good pay but often without any of the old benefits. This only postpones the workers' preparations for permanent new jobs.
Independent contracting still appeals to the workers because the Clinton Administration's preferred antidote, training in new skills, pays slim rewards. Industries requiring the new skills are hard to find. Where jobs are available, the workers discover that they have to compete with kids who have learned the same skills. Like the kids, they must start on the bottom rung, at kids' wages.
The dynamics of conversion play out in a one-story, former McDonnell Douglas office building here. Using a Department of Labor grant of $3.4 million, the State of Missouri and St. Louis Community College operate a Worker Re-Entry Program for McDonnell Douglas's castoffs. Job-seekers learn resume writing and interview techniques and consult lists of job openings that counselors cajole from area employers. The workers with appointments for job interviews here arrive at the center in suits. Most days, just one or two suits show up.
Jane A. Boyle, the center coordinator, said that about 3,000 laid-off workers had enrolled over the last two years and that 100 to 200 came in each day, some every day. Most are white, middle-age men who had earned $20,000 to $150,000 a year and now collect Missouri's unemployment benefit of $175 a week, or $9,100 a year.
Job-seekers here say they feel devalued, like the crazed former military worker in the film "Falling Down." "I helped to build America," the character, played by Michael Douglas, says. "You should get rewarded for that."
Donald R. Earney, 51, earned about $30,000 helping run the internal telephone system that connects the company's acres of plants and offices bordering the city's airport. He began at 19.
 
'You Do Feel You Failed'
 He was laid off in September. At the end of March, he found work helping a Prudential Securities stock broker. He works 20 hours a week for less than $10 an hour, without benefits. "In 32 years at McDonnell Douglas," Mr. Earney said, "I never missed a working day. You do feel you failed."
People with all levels of skill and experience come through the center. J. Robert Caldwell, 62, shows up wearing blazers and plaid button-down-collar shirts. He was "director, international business development, McDonnell Douglas Missiles Systems Company," his business card says. He earned more than $100,000 a year.
The ax fell on Mr. Caldwell without warning in November, ending a 37-year career at the company. He said he spent nearly all those years at the cutting edge of missile technology. "I went out to feed the monster," he said. "The monster can't be fed any more."
Mr. Caldwell is one among tens of thousands. Since the middle of 1990, McDonnell Douglas has chopped its entire work force to 80,000 from 132,900 and in St. Louis, its headquarters city, to 26,000 from 42,000.
About 50 percent of those laid off through last fall have found permanent, full-time jobs, said E. Terrence Jones, a professor of political science at the University of Missouri in St. Louis who has surveyed the workers. Some of the rest have retired or remain unemployed. But he said some have also been in and out of temporary jobs, staying connected to the company as independent contractors.
"Contracting is a big thing here," said Ms. Boyle, the coordinator of the job center. "If it means six months of work, they'll take it." McDonnell Douglas owns a business that places independent contractors, most at McDonnell Douglas.
Donald J. Price Jr., who earned $17 an hour, about $34,000 a year, as an aircraft mechanic, said he hoped to be recalled. "I'm not going to throw away 15 years working on aircraft," he said.
 
Problems for Older Workers
 But the practice creates complications. In addition to postponing the workers' search for more secure jobs, it seems to feed a bias among employers against taking on McDonnell Douglas workers. Ms. Boyle says some companies balk at hiring them for fear they will bolt the moment McDonnell Douglas invites them back.
Like unemployed people generally, those having the most difficulty finding work are older workers like Fred Broemmer. Mr. Broemmer, 50, was laid off last July. On a work table, he places a four-inch stack of copies of job applications he has submitted to more than 500 employers, all for naught.
Mr. Broemmer was a $60,000-a-year manager overseeing two supervisors and 15 workers who maintained the offices and plants. He said there was nothing esoteric about the work. Most companies need people with his skills. His rejection letters rarely give reasons.
 
Stereotyping by Employers
 One that he said was typical, came from a health services company and read, "Although you have an impressive background, the qualifications which we are seeking to fill the position of materials manager most closely match another candidate."
Stereotyping of McDonnell Douglas workers may also be thwarting the searches of Mr. Broemmer and others. Such stereotyping holds that workers from a company contracting with the Government might not be cost conscious enough.
Roger B. Pickett, who was laid off in December 1990, earned $41,000 as an industrial engineer. "There's a definite stigma," said Mr. Pickett, 36. "I called one employer who was looking for an industrial engineer. I said I worked for McDonnell Douglas. He said, 'That's five strikes against you.' " Mr. Pickett did not get the job.
Employers will not directly acknowledge stereotyping, but one said there were grounds to the workers' suspicions. "I believe other companies don't understand their industry," said Ronald Uliano, St. Louis-area vice president for TAD Technical Services, which hires engineers, computer programmers and technicians for temporary contracting jobs much as the McDonnell Douglas subsidiary does.
Some people in business say that there are other considerations that inhibit their hiring former McDonnell Douglas workers. The area's leading power utility, the Union Electric Company, receives many applications from the re-entry center. Few get jobs, but the reason is that the utility, too, is cutting staff. Joseph Nesselhauf, the employment manager, said Union Electric had hired some people with needed skills, including three or four people from McDonnell Douglas.
 
Specialization Acknowledged
 Workers admit to one criticism: that some are overly specialized. William J. Drescher, 39, laid off in December, was a packaging engineer. He devised boxes and crates that were nearly bomb proof for shipping missile and fighter plane parts, some of the parts worth more than $1 million. "Not a whole lot of people ship that kind of stuff," he said.
He is taking courses in computer-aided design and computer programming. But there, too, he thinks any new job will mean a big cut in pay. Like many job seekers here, he is willing to relocate, but there are no more jobs for packaging engineers elsewhere than there are here.
Some workers profited from leaving McDonnell Douglas -- eventually. Patrick Fisher, 39, a chemical engineer, was laid off in January 1991. In December he found a permanent job here as a chemical engineer at the Mallinckrodt Specialty Chemicals Company, and he is earning around $60,000, 35 percent more than before.
More typical is the case of Veselina Jovanovic, who was a financial analyst at McDonnell Douglas. After seven months out of work and interviews with only two employers, she started work in March as a financial analyst at Washington University here.
The job is permanent, but the pay, $28,000 a year, is $7,000 less than she earned at McDonnell Douglas.
Job seekers here say the policy makers in Washington have hardly begun to grasp the human toll in paring down the military industry they largely created. "Everybody in this room has dedicated a reasonable portion of their life to supporting the defense of this country," said Jay Lowry, 46, an electro-optics engineer who was earning more than $50,000 when he was let go in December. "All of a sudden they're told, 'Goodbye.' "
Jeannie Broaders, 43, spent 16 years at the company, the last six as a human- resources manager. She takes herself less seriously than some job hunters, one day wearing a plastic parrot on her left ear, a one-inch-diameter orange ball on her right, and on her blouse a button reading, "I'm in a huge cult called the unemployed."
But she sees a monumental challenge facing laid-off military workers. "It's like the Amazon rain forest," she said. "There's no one solution."

HEADLINE: A Forbidden Fruit in Europe: Latin Bananas Face Hurdles

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia

 BODY:
The French Embassy in Ecuador has been pelted with bananas. Workers in Colombia's principal banana-growing region have lost their jobs. In Panama, the President was forced to announce that he could not close the canal to vessels with European flags, much as the people might like that.
Latin America is in revolt against Europe over bananas. The European Community recently adopted a package of quotas and tariffs aimed at cutting by more than half Europe's banana imports from Latin America. 
 Europe wants to help some former banana-growing colonies of European nations in Africa and the Caribbean by waving through their bananas tariff free while imposing steep taxes on the Latin fruit.
Many people here see the move as a sign of growing protectionism in Europe, particularly against Latin America, an area perceived by many Europeans as part of the United States' sphere of economic influence.
 
Like Snow in the Amazon
 For Latin American growers, who made Europe their fastest-growing export market in the 1980's, the decision is as shocking as a snowfall in the Amazon. Banana prices are falling here, land prices for banana plantations are slipping and some fruit is rotting in the fields.
Until recently, growing bananas for northern markets was a multibillion-dollar bright spot for Latin America's struggling economies. About half of the region's banana exports have traditionally gone to Europe, and growers calculate that the new restrictions, announced in February and effective July 1, will cost the region $1 billion and 170,000 jobs by 1995.
"It is one of the greatest acts of injustice in world economic history," declared President Rafael Leonardo Callejas of Honduras, a Central American nation that depends on banana sales for 60 percent of its export earnings.
Juan Manuel Santos, the Colombian Trade Minister, is fuming. "Diabolical, perverse, discriminatory and illegal," he said, and for good reason: his country is the world's third-largest exporter of bananas.
"Banana wars," predicted a headline in Colombia's most widely circulated newspaper, El Tiempo.
Belgium and Germany, a nation that is particularly fond of bananas, are trying to reverse the ruling in the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg.
Bananas are not the only Latin American fruit to run into barriers erected by a newly unified Europe. Apple imports from Chile will be drastically limited under a new European Community measure that mandates a 19 percent drop in European apple imports, to 611,000 tons this year. For Latin America's heads of state, Europe's exhortations about the marvels of free markets are now ringing quite hollow.
 
 
Calls for Trade Reprisals
 "The European Community wants to give us a tremendous blow, one which goes against all the free trade rules and principles which they have been preaching for so long," Panama's President, Guillermo Endara, said at a meeting about the issue in Ecuador in February. The meeting, attended by the Presidents of Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua and Panama, echoed with calls for trade reprisals against Europe.
The biggest beneficiaries of the new restrictions -- besides the former colonies in Africa and the Caribbean -- will be American banana eaters.
"After July 1, you are going to have 40 million boxes of bananas loose on the world market," predicted Francisco Swett, general manager of Exportadora Bananera Noboa S.A., Ecuador's largest exporting company. "There could easily be a 10 percent drop in American supermarket prices."
Costa Rica, the world's second-largest producer, has announced that on July 1 it will offer a discount of 50 cents to $1 on its 40-pound boxes. With prices ranging from $4 to $4.50 a box, the discount could be as high as 25 percent.
"If Ecuador does not cut production quickly and sharply, there will be a price war," John M. McMillin, a food industry analyst for Prudential Securities Inc., predicted in a telephone interview from New York. "Everyone is wondering: what's going to happen to the millions of excess bananas that can't go into Europe on July 1? U.S. companies should lobby in Brussels, should cut production growth and should pray for a hurricane in Ecuador."
In one effort to avoid the European restrictions against Latin American bananas, the Del Monte Fresh Produce Company began in the 1990's to supply bananas to Europe from two former European colonies in Africa -- Cameroon and the Ivory Coast.
"We have had our strategy to keep flexible about what happens in Europe," said Brian Haycox, president of the Mexican-owned company, which is based in Florida. "But after July 1, there will still be more fruit around than we will like to see."
In the last six years, the consumption of bananas from European nations' tropical islands and former colonies leveled off while Europe's consumption of Latin American bananas doubled.
Last year, Europeans ate 2.7 million tons of bananas from Latin America. Under the new system, Europe will import only up to 1.35 million tons of Latin American bananas with a 20 percent duty. Any Latin imports over that level will be hit with a punitive duty of roughly 180 percent.
 
Old Colonial Ties
 Although a World Bank report last year described the plan as "grossly inefficient," Europe's goal is to restrict the number of bananas and pump up prices paid to growers in areas that have the greatest influence in Brussels, the headquarters of the 12-member European Community.
These are the banana growers tending the small hilly plots of Europe's tropical islands, like the Greek island of Crete, the Portuguese archipelago of Madeira and the Canary Islands of Spain, and former Caribbean colonies, like Dominica and St. Lucia, once controlled by Britain, and Martinique and Guadaloupe, French islands in the Caribbean.
Under Lome Convention rules first negotiated in the 1960's, Europe's former colonial powers give trade preference to 66 former 20th-century colonies in Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific.
Latin American growers, with their low labor costs and large expanses of flat tropical land near port cities, grow bananas at half the cost of growers favored by the European Community.
"It's absurd to take measures to protect expensive and inefficient banana producers," said Sergio Hugo Amaya Cordoba, president of Colombia's largest banana exporting company, Uniban. "It makes us angry. We open all our borders to Europe's industrialized products and then our agricultural products are blocked because they are competitive."
 
 
Consumer Backlash
 Growers here hope that the European plan will cause a consumer backlash against high-priced, poor-quality bananas. And there has already been dissent in Europe.
Germany and Belgium are suing to overturn the decision in the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg. And Spaniards, faced with eating stubby, expensive bananas from the Canary Islands, cherish Colombian bananas like a forbidden fruit. In three raids since January, Spanish authorities have confiscated 37 tons of Colombian bananas, and news reports use language usually reserved for confiscations of cocaine.
In one recent banana shipment from Colombia, which was hidden among potato boxes from the Netherlands, the Spanish press described the seized contraband as a having "a street value" of $13,000.
The impact is most traumatic for Ecuador, the world's largest banana exporter, because it relies on banana sales for 25 percent of its foreign exchange earnings. During the 1980's, Europe was Ecuador's fastest-growing market, tripling imports in a decade.
 
 
Land Prices Plunge
 With July 1 looming, prices for plantation land near Ecuador's Pacific coast have dropped nearly 40 percent, to $4,000 an acre, from $6,500 an acre just a year ago.
"A number of small banana growers are selling their properties for the salvage value," said Mr. Swett, the manager of the Ecuadorean exporter, in a telephone interview from Guayaquil, where the best hotel is Oro Verde, or green gold -- the local slang for bananas.
Some growers are letting bananas rot. Others are giving the fruit to hospitals, schools and asylums. Exporters are desperately negotiating contracts with nontraditional buyers like China, Iran, Russia and Tunisia. Government ministers have proposed banana barter deals, trading bananas for 2,000 buses or to pay for a river dredging project.
And realizing that production will have to be cut, plantations are exploring new fruits: mangoes and hearts of palm.
 
 
Unemployment and Violence

Here in Colombia, the banana depression is expected to sharpen chronic violence in the growing areas.
"In Colombia, exports will fall by $100 million a year, 10,000 hectares will have to be eradicated, and 7,000 direct and 14,000 indirect jobs will be lost," according to a study by Augura, the banana producers association of Uraba.
Governed by Medellin, this coastal section of Colombia's Antioquia district is expected to become more violent once unemployment spreads through the banana fields. Last year, Europe bought 55 percent of Uraba's production of 50 million boxes.
"In these circumstances, violence will unavoidably return and will fertilize the landscape, allowing drug traffickers and guerrillas to increase their activity," the Augura report predicted.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN VANCOUVER;
Excerpts From News Session: Cementing a New Superpower Relationship

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, BRITISH COLUMBIA, April 4

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a news conference today at the end of a summit meeting between President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. Mr. Yeltsin spoke through an interpreter.
 
CLINTON'S STATEMENT
 The heroic deeds of Boris Yeltsin and the Russian people launched their reforms toward democracy and market economies and defended them valiantly during the dark days of August of 1991. Now it is the self-interest and the high duty of all the world's democracies to stand by Russia's democratic reforms in their new hour of challenge. 
 The contrast between our promising new partnership and our confrontational past underscores the opportunities that hang in the balance today. For 45 years, we pursued a deadly competition in nuclear arms. Now we can pursue a safe and steady cooperation to reduce the arsenals that have haunted mankind. For 45 years, our nation invested trillions of dollars to contain and deter Soviet Communism. Now the emergence of a peaceful and democratic Russia can enable us to devote more to our own domestic needs. The emergence of a newly productive and prosperous Russia could add untold billions in new growth to the global economy. . . .

 	 	 		. . .	 	Mr. President, our nation will not stand on the sidelines when it comes to democracy and Russia. We know where we stand. We are with Russian democracy, we are with Russian reforms, we are with Russian markets. We support freedom of conscience, of speech and religion. We support respect for ethnic minorities. We actively support reform and reformers and you in Russia.
The ultimate responsibility for the success of Russia's new course of course rests with the people of Russia. It is they who must support economic reforms and make them work. But Americans know that our nation has a part to play, too, and we will do so.
In our discussions, President Yeltsin and I reached several important agreements on the ways in which the United States and the other major industrialized democracies can best support Russian reforms.
First are programs that can begin immediately. I discussed with President Yeltsin the initiatives totaling $1.6 billion intended to bolster political and economic reforms in Russia. These programs already are funded. They can provide immediate and tangible results for the Russian people. We will invest in the growth of Russia's private sector through two funds to accelerate privatization and to lend to new small private businesses.
We will resume grain sales to Russia and extend $700 million in loans for Russia to purchase American grain. We will launch a pilot project to help provide housing and retraining for the Russian military officers as they move into jobs in the civilian economy.
Second, beyond these immediate programs, the President and I agreed that our partnership requires broader perspectives, and broader cooperative initiatives which I will discuss with the Congress . . . .
We also agreed to work in concert to help resolve regional crises, to stem weapons proliferation, to protect the global environment, and to address common challenges to international peace, such as the tragic violence in Bosnia, advancing the promising peace talks we have cosponsored in the Mideast, and continuing our cooperation to end the regional conflicts of the Cold War era.

 	 	 		. . .	 	
 
YELTSIN'S STATEMENT
 I am fully satisfied by the results and by the spirit and atmosphere of my encounter with President Bill Clinton. It was in all senses out of the ordinary. But it was made extraordinary by processes transpiring in the United States and Russia conditioned by very special relationships developing between ourselves and Mr. Bill Clinton. We met for the first time but yesterday, but became partners back at that meeting in Washington.

 	 	 		. . .	 	At previous meetings, the nations' leaders discussed primarily the disassembly of confrontational structures, but here in Vancouver we talked about building the new, laying the foundations of a future economy. This was the first economically oriented meeting of the two great powers. . . .
We decided to eliminate discriminatory limitations on trade with Russia. We in fact said that we were simply hurt America had embarked upon the path of democracy, whereas America was still treating us as though we were a Communist country. In fact, we're struggling against Communism. I stated that quite clearly, and Bill Clinton agreed.
We are prepared to compete, but compete honestly. We decided to alter our approach to trade in Russian uranium, space technology, access to Russian military technology. We decided to do away with the Jackson-Vanik amendment.

 	 	 		. . .	 	We're looking forward to other steps to be undertaken by the United States of America and other major industrial countries to support real reform in Russia.
The linkage between that set of measures and other political measures was avoided. Of course, military and political problems could not be skirted. We discussed what might be done to see to it that all participants in the Bosnian conflict support the U.N. position. Here our positions match as to the main points. We devoted quite a lot of attention to problems of nonproliferation. We decided to extend our agreements on the avoidance of accidents, such as the near-accident involving submarines very recently.

 	 	 		. . .	 	Another very important result is that we, with President Bill Clinton, did establish some pretty close personal contacts. Bill Clinton is a serious partner.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

Q. (In Russian, through interpreter): . . . The elimination of restrictions on trade with Russia, if that does happen, will perhaps be the harbinger of the establishment of those relations of partnership which we've been talking about for so long.
Now, I'd like to ask you gentlemen, what particular priority areas are up for partnership and cooperation? And President Clinton, how do you feel? Are there particular areas which the U.S. might like to stress in building up business cooperation with the Russians?
YELTSIN: (through interpreter): On that first point, I should like to say that we discussed something like 50 issues yesterday and today, and practically all of those issues had to do with partnership. . . .
And in discussing those approximately 50 issues, we didn't sweep anything under the table, we didn't set anything aside. We decided either to pass them on for further investigation and analysis or else we resolved them on the spot.
CLINTON: I'd like to answer the question also and respond to what President Yeltsin said. Among the areas in which the United States sees real opportunity for joint activity are energy, space, the environment, nuclear safety.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The second point I'd like to make in response to the comment by President Yeltsin. We did discuss a phenomenal number of issues. We did not agree on everything.
But we did come to agreement on how we would handle these issues, how we would try to work through our disagreements and what we would do in the future.
Q: . . . Mr. President, on another irritant in the U.S.-Russian relationship . . . the patrolling off the Russian coast by U.S. submarines, what have you agreed to now to prevent these kinds of accidents from recurring down the road? Is this another case of old habits dying hard, that the U.S. still finds a need to keep these kinds of submarines off the Russian coast?
And for President Yeltsin, an irritant in the U.S.-Russian relationship is the slow withdrawal of Russian troops from the Baltic states and from Eastern Europe. Are you committed to withdrawing the Russian soldiers as quickly as possible from those independent nations?
CLINTON: Let me answer first. I don't mind saying to this whole assembly that I told President Yeltsin I very much regretted the submarine incident and that I had ordered a thorough review of the incident as well as the policy of which the incident happened to be an unintended part and that I would -- as soon as that review was completed, I would engage Russia at the appropriate levels to discuss whether the policy should be changed and where we should go from here.
That was a regrettable thing, and I don't want it to ever happen again.
YELTSIN: (through interpreter): . . . In regard to withdrawal of troops from the Baltic states, we are adhering very closely to the schedule on troop withdrawals from Lithuania, and we are completing work on that schedule since Lithuania does not violate human rights and treats the Russian-speaking population fairly. If Latvia and Estonia violate human rights, if their laws are presently so structured that in fact some national minorities continue to be persecuted, and that involves basically Russians, we have on the whole adopted a political decision, a policy decision to withdraw troops from those states. We will be scheduling the actual withdrawal in line with what they decide in the human rights area.
Q. (In Russian, through interpreter): . . . President Yeltsin, you indicated that Bill Clinton's economic package lays the groundwork for partnership between the United States of America and Russia and will provide considerable impetus to the reform process in Russia. In April, we're going to have a referendum in Russia. How here today in Vancouver would you forecast the situation unfolding on the basis of agreements reached here in Canada?
. . . President Clinton, the personal factor is a major element in policy, in politics. Now, what would you indicate by way of your personal contact with President Yeltsin?
YELTSIN: (through interpreter): In regard to the referendum, that's our internal domestic issue. Whether it will be impacted directly or indirectly is another issue, but it's up to us to deal with the referendum issue. It's up to us to work with our people, it's up to us to persuade the citizens of the Russian federation that if they do not vote in favor of confidence on the 25th of April, they will be dealing a major blow not only upon Russia, but also upon the United States of America, upon the other countries of the world. This would be a loss to democracy, a loss to freedom, a rollback to the past, a return to the Communist yoke, something which is entirely inadmissible.
CLINTON: My personal reaction to President Yeltsin based on these two days is, first, that he is very much what he seems to be. He is a person who rose from humble beginnings, who has never forgotten where he came from; and second, that his enduring virtue is that he trusts the Russian people.
The great courage involved in all democracies is that in the end, you have to trust the people, including you have to trust the people if they decide to throw you out.
Boris Yeltsin has put the fate of the government of Russia into the hands of the people of Russia. That is a unique thing in your history. There are few nations in the world that have the spirit, the culture, the richness that the Russian people can claim, and yet for too long, they were never given control over their own destiny.

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN VANCOUVER: Not Just Another East-West Face-Off;
Welcome to the Lifestyle Summit

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 4

 BODY:
Vancouver may well be remembered as the first quality-of-life summit meeting -- a couple of world leaders up to their necks in debt, dwelling more on materialism than on the military, and on standards of living rather than life and death.
The meeting had all the drama of a bankrupt businessman applying for a bridge loan from the president of a failing S. & L. In part, this was due to the fundamental change in the relationship between Moscow and Washington since the end of the cold war. Before, Russian leaders presented their American counterparts with a threat. Now, they just present them with a bill. 
 As Mr. Yeltsin delicately put it at the closing news conference: "At previous meetings, the nations' leaders discussed primarily the disassembly of confrontational structures, but here in Vancouver we talked about building the new, laying the foundations of a future economy. This was the first economically oriented meeting of the two great powers."
 
Dull by Design
 But this summit meeting was also on the dull side because the two leaders scripted it that way. Mr. Yeltsin made it clear from the moment he stepped off his Aeroflot jetliner that he did not want this meeting to appear to be what it really was: a proud Russian leader coming to the West with tin cup in hand. Because if it was, his opponents back home, already painting him as a lap dog of Western capitalists, would have a field day.
As Mr. Yeltsin straightforwardly remarked when asked if $1 billion in American aid was enough: "Too little is not good because it is not enough to enable you to solve problems, whereas too much also could be bad, because it can be used by the Communists to target us. The opposition will say we are shackled by the West."
Mr. Clinton and his party, sensitive to Mr. Yeltsin's predicament, played along. In what had to be a first for a Russian-American summit meeting, an American briefer actually went out of his way to tell reporters about friction between the leaders in their one-on-one meeting, to make clear back home in Moscow that Mr. Yeltsin was standing tough.
The White House communications director, George Stephanopoulos, told reporters at the evening briefing Saturday that Mr. Yeltsin had brought up "irritants" in the relationship between the two nations, everything from trade problems to the fact that an American submarine recently bumped into a Russian one in the Barents Sea. Mr. Stephanopoulos went out of his way to note that Mr. Clinton had apologized to Mr. Yeltsin for the incident. Hear that Moscow?
 
Emphasis on Equality
 Mr. Clinton, acting like a sensitive nephew who did not want to embarrass his uncle when he comes for a loan, also never deigned to suggest that there was any asymmetry in his relationship with Mr. Yeltsin, or that this summit meeting was focused heavily on one-sided aid.
When reporters asked Mr. Yeltsin whether American aid would make a difference, the Russian President responded, "You know, it's always useful to help a friend, especially if a friend goes through a difficult period."
At that point Mr. Clinton interjected: "I just was going to say, I don't view this as a talk about aid. This is a talk about a long-term partnership."
This stress on parity at times was taken to amusing, but revealing, lengths. When a senior American official briefed reporters this morning about the details of the American aid package for Russia, he began by saying, "President Yeltsin and President Clinton agreed on a series of American initiatives to aid Russia."
Details of the assistance package itself dominated their first two meetings and the old security-foreign affairs agenda seemed almost like an afterthought, reserved for the last session this morning. The United States Government's press handout about the substance of the summit meeting also reflected this turnabout. It began with pages describing the new loans, housing units, energy, environmental programs and trade and investment initiatives that the Clinton Administration would be offering Russia. Tacked on at the end were a couple of pages about the fate of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaties.
Even the local Vancouver newspapers looked at the meeting more like a business convention than something that might affect global stability. The local papers noted that the visiting diplomats and journalists were expected to spend $3 million around town during the two-day gathering, on phones, food and entertainment.
The daily summit newsletter passed out to all the hotels in Vancouver by a local civic booster group, led with the ultimate post-cold-war news story this morning. It read: "Is there life after the Summit for Vancouver's business community once the two days of attention and excitement are over? Experience says yes. Tourism officials estimate that Vancouver received more than $70 million in free advertising world-wide during the buildup to the summit." Cities around the world may soon start bidding for Russian-American summit meetings the way they do for the Olympics.
 
Both a Little and a Lot
 But Mr. Clinton also had his reasons for wanting to keep this meeting, and talk of American aid for Russia, relatively muted. Americans generally like to see their President out leading the free world, but they are not crazy about seeing their President doling out foreign aid, especially in this season of budgetary cutbacks at home. Mr. Clinton has been reading the polls, which are universally negative about lavishing foreign aid on Russia.
Mr. Clinton walked a delicate tightrope during these two days, wanting his $1.6 billion aid package for Mr. Yeltsin to look like a lot in the eyes of his Russian supporters, a little in the eyes of his Russian opponents, a lot in the eyes of America's Western allies, but not too much in the eyes of American voters.
"Both of them needed to low-key this thing," said Robert S. Strauss, a former Ambassador to Moscow. "For Clinton it was wise and for Yeltsin it was wise. Yeltsin could not afford to look like he came running with a tin cup, because he has nothing going for him at home. For Clinton, the duller the better, because he has got to go home and worry about Congress."
What was also striking about this meeting was the way it underscored how much these high-level encounters are no longer the stage for testing the mettle of an American, or even Russian, leader. John F. Kennedy's June 1961 face-off with Nikita S. Khrushchev in Vienna, or Ronald Reagan's encounter with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Reykjavik in October 1986, were singular events that played important roles in defining the leadership stature of both men for history. These old summits were tests of political manhood and the press always asked, who blinked? But today's summits are a test of means and the press asks, who paid?
Indeed, Mr. Clinton repeatedly stressed that the "real news," the real big dollars for Russia, will come not in Vancouver but in two weeks in Tokyo, when the Group of Seven major industrialized nations meet to decide on a multibillion-dollar aid package for Moscow. The $1.6 billion package put on the table here by Mr. Clinton is intended to pressure the Japanese, Germans and financial institutions such as the International Monetary Fund to give much more than they have before. That is a very different kind of leadership test.
 
An 'Investment' in Change
 Nevertheless, while Mr. Clinton clearly understands that he cannot be seen to be lavishing money on Russians at the same time that he is taking it away from Americans, he has shown himself much more willing than President Bush to sell at least some aid for Moscow to the American people.
Mr. Clinton uses the same vocabulary about his aid package for Russia that he uses in the budget debates for his economic program at home. For instance, Mr. Clinton said today that foreign aid to Russia is an "investment" that will help produce "untold billions in new growth to the global economy, new jobs and investment opportunities for Americans -- we are investing today not only in the future of Russia, but the future of America as well."
Hearing that, Mr. Yeltsin got on the bandwagon and declared that this aid was not a "Christmas present" but would "create more jobs in America, a fuller use of American economic potential and plant capacity."
Indeed, listening to Mr. Clinton in the past two days, it has often been difficult to keep straight when he is talking about his economic stimulus package for the United States and when he is talking about the one for Russia. Mr. Yeltsin added to the confusion when he ostentatiously pronounced that the $1.6 billion aid package offered him by Mr. Clinton is going to be referred to in Russian as "Bill Clinton's economic package -- that is what it is going to be called from here on in."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
President Clinton threw his full support to Boris Yeltsin, pledging $1.6 billion in assistance to show "immediate and tangible" support for the Russian President's programs. The package amounts to $1.6 billion, not the $1 billion the Administration had been reporting. The new element is $700 million in credits to enable Russia to start receiving American grain. [Page A1.]
An international trade agreement is being delayed while the Clinton Administration devotes its energy to the North American Free Trade Agreement, the departing head of GATT says. [D1.] 
 Latin America is in revolt against Europe over bananas. The European Community recently adopted a package of quotas and tariffs aimed at cutting by more than half Europe's banana imports from the region. [A1.]
China and South Korea are signing a wave of investment and trade agreements that provide the basis for an important new economic partnership in East Asia. [D1.]
Americans who invested dollars in foreign stocks had cause to be satisfied in the first quarter for the first time in four years. [D3.]
 
The Economy
The Administration has signaled to the nation's airlines that it plans to enforce Federal antitrust laws vigorously, in contrast to the previous Republican administrations. But White House officials say they are not planning to reverse the course of airline deregulation under which carriers have operated since 1978. [D1.]
Policy makers call it conversion, the shifting of military bases and weapons factories to reduced or altered missions. But for most people in weapons industries, conversion is just not working. [A1.]
Most of the top executives at big nonprofit organizations earn six-figure salaries, with one getting nearly $800,000. [A15.]
 
Companies
Martin Marietta faces the monumental task of consolidating its business with the aerospace division of General Electric it bought for $3 billion last year. [D1.]
Directors of General Motors are expected to announce a series of top executive changes today, prompted in part by the need to replace Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua as head of worldwide purchasing. [D4.]
 
The Media Business
The three network morning programs have all added viewers in the last year, and since the first of the year they have done particularly well. Bill Carter: Television. [D7.]
Following in the footsteps of the Creative Artists Agency, another top Hollywood talent agency, International Creative Management, is poised to get involved in advertising. [D7.] The latest bit of wave-making by Creative Artists' superagent, Michael Ovitz, has knocked over some rivals, who vow to wage combat. [C13.]
Television-watching patterns among blacks and whites appear to be growing apart, in a development that may reflect the state of race relations or the greater number of viewing choices. [D7.]
After successfully increasing exports, growers in Florida have contributed $3 million for an advertising campaign that they hope will increase domestic consumption. [D7.]
With Opening Day at hand, a partial lineup of campaigns from around the leagues goes to the plate. Advertising. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Martin Marietta's Defensive Strategy

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md.

 BODY:
For Norman R. Augustine, chairman of the Martin Marietta Corporation, signing up to buy the General Electric Corporation's aerospace division for $3 billion last year was far easier than the monumental task he now faces in consolidating the two businesses under one roof.
That will mean laying off thousands of workers, closing production plants, and selling mediocre operations to achieve the economies of scale that Mr. Augustine promised last November when he agreed to the deal, which creates the world's largest military electronics company. 
 "There will certainly be more layoffs, not so much caused by the merger but by the fact that the defense budget is in free fall," Mr. Augustine said in a recent interview at the contractor's headquarters here.
"Every time they cut $1 million out of the defense budget, about 50 people lose their jobs," Mr. Augustine said. "There are many tragedies that are yet to happen in our industry. There may be a million jobs yet to be lost."
Yet the merger is seen by analysts as a necessary step to guarantee Martin Marietta a cut of what military contracting remains. "A normal part of Martin and G.E.'s life will be layoffs because of the great opportunity to cut overhead," said Phil Friedman, a military industry analyst for Morgan Stanley. "There will be some pain for employees, but Norm Augustine has positioned the company well in terms of the diversified programs it has."
The United States weapons industry, hurt by dwindling Pentagon orders, has entered a new age of consolidation in which military contractors are buying businesses in areas where they can dominate and divesting themselves of the rest.
The Justice Department's approval of the combination last week puts the 57-year-old Mr. Augustine in charge of the largest such consolidation to date. With General Electric's aerospace business, Martin Marietta grows to 94,000 employees, 27,000 of whom are scientists and engineers. Its sales almost double to about $11 billion, including $3 billion in sales from commercial and civil government contracts; its backlog increases to more than $28 billion. Before the merger, Martin Marietta ranked eighth among military contractors, with $6 billion in revenues.
Weapons industry analysts predict that Mr. Augustine will impose cutbacks of at least 10 percent over the next year, as the company eliminates duplication in administrative, research and production costs. That could put another 10,000 aerospace workers -- many of them mid-level managers -- out on the street.
Mr. Augustine said that he had not determined how many jobs would be eliminated as he was awaiting final Government approval of the acquisition. But he said a sizable reduction would be necessary to eliminate overcapacity.
Last spring, before the G.E. deal, Martin Marietta had announced it would cut 6 percent of its work force, or 3,600 of its 60,000 employees.
Mr. Augustine, who worked as an aerospace engineer in southern California nearly 30 years ago, said that he knows firsthand the uncertainty of working in an industry that is highly susceptible to budget cuts.
"There were times when I had no idea if I would be coming back to work the next day," he said. "The only difference was back then if you were laid off by one contractor, you could probably walk right down the street and find work with another one that was starting up a new program."
 
 
Consequences of Budget Cuts
 Those days appear to be long gone. Industry analysts and executives predict that the Pentagon's deep budget cutting will mean that coming layoffs will be permanent.
In the last five years, spending on military supplies -- including everything from Swiss army knives to submarines -- has declined 22 percent, to $161 billion in 1992 from $206 billion in 1987. Some 315,000 military industry jobs have been lost, or 10 percent of the total, and further spending cuts are seen.
As a result, military contractors that consolidate their operations and capitalize on their strengths will be more competitive and ultimately reduce layoffs, Mr. Augustine said. "Job opportunities will be better with a combined G.E.-Martin Marietta than with the two alone," he said.
At the start of the military spending cutbacks in the late 1980s, Martin Marietta decided to concentrate its efforts on so-called "add-on" products like advanced electronics, radar and computer systems that are used to modernize existing planes, ships and weapons systems.
 
Diversified Product Line
 G.E.'s major customer was the Navy, while Martin Marietta is a big supplier to the Army. The combined operation will have a broad customer base and diversified product line that make it less vulnerable to the impending budget cuts.
Martin Marietta's main military products are space equipment and electronics, information and missile systems, including the Titan radar, military and commercial space-launch vehicles and products. From G.E., Martin adds satellites and other space systems, radar and sonar systems, simulation systems, and government technical services businesses.
In the past, the Government thwarted three proposed mergers of military contractors on the grounds that the combinations would leave only one supplier in a particular area, potentially increasing the Pentagon's costs of procuring weapons. That worry did not apply in the case of Martin Marietta and G.E., whose combined operation will be a leader in the missile area, although not the sole supplier.
Having received the Justice Department's approval, Mr. Augustine, who has a reputation for being cost conscious, can begin streamlining. Martin Marietta faces considerable competition in the aerospace electronics field from Hughes Aircraft, TRW and Lockheed. But another challenge will be to continue increasing value for shareholders.
 
 
$750 Million of New Debt
 In adding G.E.'s operations, Martin Marietta assumed $750 million of new debt and was forced to suspend its stock repurchase program because of the acquisition's cost. With the G.E. debt, Martin Marietta's level of debt-to-equity rises to 45 percent, from 19 percent. Mr. Augustine said that the two operations are such big cash generators that he expects the number to fall to about 20 percent in the next three years.
The company has increased its dividend annually for the last 19 years, and Mr. Augustine said that practice would not change.
For 1992, Martin's earnings rose to $345.4 million, or $7.21 a share, from $313.1 million, or $6.30 a share, a year earlier, despite a drop in sales to $5.95 billion, from $6.08 billion. The company's sales to the Pentagon fell about 9 percent in 1992, but sales to civil government customers rose more than 20 percent, surpassing $1 billion.

"There are many tragedies that are yet to happen in our industry," he said. "There may be a million jobs yet to be lost." (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
After the Peace, Finding Customers

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Amid the tidy row houses of College Point, Queens, stands a company that makes minesweeping systems, sonar equipment to track nuclear submarines and a small arsenal of other combat gear.
Hardly growth areas in the post-cold-war era. So the EDO Corporation, a 63-year-old government contractor, is venturing gingerly into bicycle spokes, subway speedometers, golf club heads and filling-station pumps for natural gas-powered vehicles. 
 The trick, still unperfected, is to come up with new products to sell to tens of thousands of disparate customers. Clearly it is a far cry from just filling Uncle Sam's precise prescriptions.
And the stakes are enormous: New York State's defense contracts decreased to $5.43 billion last year from $9.62 billion in 1987. That each $1 billion in contracts provided an estimated 25,000 jobs underlines the urgency behind the company's need to diversify.
 
Search for State Aid
 One of EDO's early moves in diversifying was to seek financial help from New York State. It received $710,000, mainly in loans, with most of the money going for machinery, equipment and renovations.
While many a company might welcome such help, state officials justify the EDO expenditure by saying that they would rather bet limited funds on those with promising projects already under way.
In particular, they say, such loans may be very important to companies that have never done anything but fill Pentagon contracts, and hence have scant relationships with commercial banks for loans of working capital.
EDO was founded by Earl Dodge Osborn, whose fascination with seaplanes led him to begin manufacturing floats in a shed on Flushing Bay in 1925. The company soon numbered among its customers Charles A. Lindbergh, Adm. Richard E. Byrd and Amelia Earhart. It is said to have produced virtually every float used by the Navy and Air Force during World War II. After the war, it diversified into sophisticated electronic equipment, mostly for the military.
EDO's president and chief executive officer, Gerald Albert, said his company got the idea of seeking state aid when the Hazeltine Corporation, a Long Island maker of military antennas, was given $2.1 million to help develop ways to transmit news broadcasts to such things as airliners in flight.
With Pentagon orders dwindling, EDO executives called Albany last May. Within weeks, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was touring EDO's plant. An assistance package was delivered by November.
 
Competition from Utah
 The state moved quickly because Utah was making overtures to the company about moving its headquarters to that state, where it has several divisions and subsidiaries.
"It was partly a retention decision," acknowledged Vincent Tese, director of the New York State Office of Economic Development.
The company was straightforward about its needs. "We would have had to seriously re-evaluate being a major manufacturing presence in New York State were it not for this," Mr. Kaplan said.
Perhaps more important than money has been the state's ability to introduce EDO to the right new customers, particularly the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is in the process of testing EDO's subway speed sensors and may look at other ideas.
"Just getting them in the room with the procurement people at M.T.A. made them realize they could do a lot of things they didn't think were possible," said Brad C. Johnson, the director of the New York State Office of Federal Affairs, who made the introduction.
"I think EDO is going to be a pretty common story," Mr. Tese said.
A happy ending is by no means certain. For one thing, EDO has not yet had to worry about competition. "If we built a vacuum cleaner, we would build the best $20,000 vacuum cleaner in the world," said Ira Kaplan, EDO's vice president and general manager.
But today's need is flexibility, quickness and competitive prices. EDO executives, as well as their counterparts at other contractors, talk about the need to change their culture to adapt to new products and customers.
"It's not just a mindset," said Seymour Melman, professor emeritus of industrial engineering at Columbia University and chairman of the National Commission for Economic Conversion and Disarmament. "It's the way a whole engineering staff has learned to work."
EDO must reverse a decline in net income to $1.5 million last year from $5.9 million in 1989. Its work force has shrunk by more than a third, to 1,000. At the company's Queens headquarters, more than 480 jobs in have been lost in the last four years.
This is not to say that EDO is in danger of failing. Some defense work continues to trickle in, while some earlier big contracts are still being filled. When asked directly, EDO executives readily admit that the state aid is helpful, not critical.
"To be perfectly candid, if you looked at our balance sheet it would be clear we can afford to do these things," said Mr. Albert.
 
Chances of Succeeding
 But the wisdom of such help obviously hinges on a company's chances of succeeding. EDO points to Federal energy and environmental legislation that will make natural gas-powered vehicles much more attractive. The company has already developed and tested storage tanks that weigh two-thirds less than earlier versions.
And ultralight materials it makes for space vehicles seem to work equally well for bicycle spokes, at least judging by EDO's experience at a recent trade show. "If you can take a half a pound off a bicycle, they go wild," Mr. Albert said.
While searching for new directions, EDO's strategy is to listen to the dozen or more proposals that come from inventors and idea peddlers each week. But it listens skeptically and then defers to outside experts it hires. Everything has to relate to the company's technical expertise.
"We're not going to make sneakers or nonsense like that," Mr. Albert said.
