HEADLINE: Connecticut Seeks a Return Of Jobs as Well as Nature

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORWICH, Conn.

 BODY:
The bleak and vacant industrial landscape that stretches along the Shetucket River will never be featured on a Sierra Club calendar, and rats are more likely to be seen than spotted owls. But in Connecticut and a handful of other states, places like this represent a new environmental frontier.
The state wants to clean up the 90-odd years of accumulated pollutants here and in the process is engaged in an unusual example of industrial archeology. But the driving force is not history or ecology; it is economics. 
 With this site, Connecticut is trying to develop a new approach to choosing urban cleanup projects. Although the basic mission of protecting public health is unchanged, the new paradigm factors in the property's economic potential. The dream is not for a return to nature, but for jobs and a new factory.
 
Identifying Sites With Potential
 "Our goal is to try and revitalize the cities," said Connecticut's Environmental Protection Commissioner, Timothy R. E. Keeney. "The key here is identifying the sites with economic potential."
The year-old program, introduced by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. as part of an urban stimulus package, mirrors what environmental groups say is a trend around the nation. Fueled by the arguments of advocates for "environmental justice," who contend that poor urban neighborhoods are often the first to be polluted and the last to be cleaned up, environmentalism is catching on as a tool of economic development.
"There is some sort of a shift going on," said Lois Epstein, an engineer at the Environmental Defense Fund, a group based in New York. "Where originally there was a lot of concern about the health hazards of these sites, people are now looking at these sites more holistically -- everyone has an interest that these properties be used and not turned into dead zones."
At least six states, including New Jersey and Michigan, now have formal systems to speed the cleanup of industrial sites that are dirty enough to raise potential legal liabilities for new owners or developers but not dangerous enough to run afoul of the public health codes. A bill before Congress, submitted by Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, would create a Federal grant system to encourage cleanups.
But Connecticut is taking a more interventionist role, experts say. Under the state's plan, selected sites would be scoured by environmental engineers working under contract with the Department of Environmental Protection, then marketed by the Department of Economic Development. The state would probably bear some of the cost of the cleanup, but in return would have a say in development on the land. As much as $50 million in taxpayer money would be committed this year under an expanded version of the program now before the Legislature.
How it would all fit together in this pilot project on the Shetucket River, however -- even how much it might cost -- remains to be seen. If the pollution at a site is not a threat to the public, for example, then how clean is clean enough for another factory? And how, exactly, will environmental officials apportion the cost between the state and an owner who may not have caused the pollution?
 
'A Lot of Unknowns'
 "I would expect them to be reasonable," said Fred Schimel, a vice president at Household International, an Illinois-based consumer credit company that owns the 55-acre Norwich site. "But there are a lot of unknowns -- a lot of questions remain to be answered."
History also complicates the cleanup. Everything from woolen cloth to gas meters were made on this property since the first mill building was erected around the turn of the century, and all left a sort of vapor trail of man-made abuses, from cleaning solvents to chromium, leached through the decades into the present.
And each of those uses and abuses must be tracked, as much as possible, to determine not only what the pollutants are, but where, and how they may have combined over time. Former employees have been found and interviewed, some even brought to the site to try to recall who did what to the land, and when.
 
Cavalier Attitudes
 "The historical information will help lead us to identify not only what should be sampled, but where the samples should be collected," said Edward Parker, who oversees the program at the Department of Environmental Protection. Sometimes, he said, the folk history of a factory can show the cavalier attitudes about disposal that were common.
"A lot of times what old business and industry used to do is that the guy used to take it out the back door and dump it," Mr. Parker said.
Velvet was manufactured here by a French company until the 1938 hurricane apparently blew the company out of business. During World War II, a shop making airplane propellers was set up as part of the war effort. In the early 1950's, a company tried to weave synthetic cloth out of corn byproducts. Then a company moved in that made ticky-tacky wire ornamentation for clocks and curios. Vacuum bottles were made here, too, for the nation's lunch-box army of blue-collar workers, until that market, too, began to dry up in the 1970's.
 
A Legacy of Pollution
 Test holes have revealed traces of almost all those companies: black partially composted synthetic cloth, degreasing solvents, zinc and copper from the wire-plating process and the entombed remains of three filled-in lagoons that were the settling ponds for the corn processing company, on which vegetation, even 30 years later, does not grow well.
An electromagnetic survey of the land hard along the river, where at least 41 barrels of liquid industrial wastes were found buried in 1980, has shown that it was an impromptu scrap yard. The metal detectors have also found a mass that may be the remains of a 1,542-gallon underground oil tank installed by the United Aircraft Company between 1942 and 1944 and since lost from the maps and believed to have been crushed by later construction.
The state plans to spend $660,000 on research and planning for the cleanup project here.
Still, some Norwich residents and former employees doubt that this property will ever be fully rehabilitated -- not because of the pollution, but because it was never the best land in the first place.
 
'Money Down a Sewer'
 "It's in the flood plain -- I've seen two feet of the water in the basement of the building," said Robert H. Kellogg Jr., who was engineering manager for the wire products company in the late 50's and early 60's. Mr. Kellogg, who is 83, said he believes the whole project is folly. "They're throwing money down a sewer to clean up a sewer," he said in an interview in his home in Niantic.
Mr. Parker at the Department of Environmental Protection said, however, that he believes the forces that once made the Shetucket River site attractive will emerge again when the land is given a clean bill of health. Anyway, he added, the process has to start somewhere.
"We've got old factories gone, vacant, abandoned," he said. "We need to do something."

HEADLINE: G.M. Plans to Shift Officials, Fill Post Vacated By Lopez

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 4

 BODY:
Directors of the General Motors Corporation are expected to announce a series of top executive changes on Monday, prompted in part by the need to replace Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua as head of worldwide purchasing. Mr. Lopez is now the No. 2 executive at Volkswagen A.G.
Following Mr. Lopez's lead, a number of key G.M. executives and managers have defected to VW in recent months, supposedly for higher pay. Several more may follow unless a temporary injunction granted Friday in Frankfurt persuades Mr. Lopez to stop raiding his former employer. 
 If VW does not stop recruiting, it will "ultimately lead to counter-measures," warned David Herman, chairman of G.M.'s Adam Opel subsidiary. He also called on Mr. Lopez to certify that he did not bring any G.M. documents to his new job. Mr. Herman did not disclose what G.M. might do if its demands were not met.
Mr. Herman's saber-rattling suggests that G.M. expects the German government somehow to bring order to an increasingly down-and-dirty struggle among auto makers. "G.M. still thinks that the auto industry is a club," said James Womack, a manufacturing consultant in Cambridge, Mass., "and the members should behave according to certain rules. VW is signaling that it won't play by the old club rules."
Both companies need to transform themselves into lean, responsive, adaptable manufacturers. Mr. Lopez is a proven agent of change, who lopped enormous costs from G.M. in Europe and North America. Clearly, his ability to elicit results and to foster an energetic management style prompted Ferdinand Piech, VW's chairman, to hire him from G.M.
Mr. Lopez has been trying to lure former co-workers from the purchasing department at G.M.'s Adam Opel unit, because he must cut costs at VW quickly and has no time to train new "warriors," as he referred to his G.M. colleagues. Only last week VW posted a $772.9 million loss for the first quarter.
G.M.'s European operations, enormously profitable for the past few years, are slipping badly. Part of the decline comes from economic weakness, but competition is getting tougher as well.

HEADLINE: Antitrust Signal Sent To Airlines

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has signaled to the nation's airlines that it plans to vigorously enforce Federal antitrust laws, in contrast to the previous Republican administrations.
But Administration officials say they do not plan to reverse the course of deregulation under which carriers have operated since 1978. 
 The White House's signal came last week when the Transportation Department forced Northwest Airlines to abandon plans to start three routes in competition with a new airline.
Of the change, the Secretary of Transportation, Federico F. Pena, said: "This Administration has a much different view than the previous Republican administrations about the anti-competitive behavior of airlines in a deregulated environment. Our view is to be more watchful about anti-competitive behavior and to take action on a case-by-case basis whenever appropriate."
 
Competition to Be Fostered
 "This does not mean that we are returning to a reregulated environment," Mr. Pena continued in a telephone interview recently. "We would like to see as many U.S. carriers as possible, and we will take action to foster competition, particularly where we see anti-competitive behavior aimed at eliminating U.S. carriers."
The Administration acted after Reno Air, a Nevada-based line that started flying last July, complained that Northwest was seeking the routes to destroy Reno. Northwest had planned to compete with Reno on four routes, from Minneapolis to Reno and from Reno to Seattle, Los Angeles and San Diego. Northwest dropped its plan for the three routes from Nevada to the West Coast.
The Transportation Department cannot stop a domestic airline from starting a domestic route. But Mr. Pena told Northwest officials he would strongly recommend that the Justice Department take antitrust action if it flew the new routes.
 
Antitrust Enforcement Urged
 Alfred E. Kahn, the economist who was the architect of airline deregulation during the Administration of President Jimmy Carter, said: "I have been insisting for years that enforcing the antitrust laws is not inconsistent with deregulation. On the contrary, once you deregulate, it becomes more important than ever to preserve competition."
But some Congressional leaders fear that the Administration may go to the point of stifling genuine competition. Representative James L. Oberstar, Democrat of Minnesota, said that Northwest's action was so egregious that it deserved the Government's response but that the Clinton Administration should be wary about its application of antitrust laws.
"The question is: How far will they go with this policy?" said Mr. Oberstar, chairman of the aviation subcommittee of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee. "I think they would be well advised to consider the action as appropriate to the Northwest-Reno situation and not a harbinger of a new policy of wide-ranging protection of new entrants."
Secretary Pena, asked to speak to this concern, said that if two carriers sought to reduce prices on established routes in a manner not considered predatory competition, the Government would applaud this as a boon to consumers but that it would not countenance such action if the intent was to destroy a competitor.
 
24 Mergers Permitted
 Many experts agree that the Reagan and Bush Administrations did not vigorously apply the antitrust laws to the airline industry.
"Antitrust was minimally enforced during the Reagan years, and that was particularly true of the airlines," said Prof. Robert Pitofsky of the Georgetown University Law Center, an expert on antitrust law. "There may have been a few cases during the Bush years, but under Reagan and Bush the Departments of Transportation and Justice let 24 airline mergers go through."
Not long after Mr. Clinton was elected, the Justice Department filed its boldest antitrust action in years.
"The major enforcement action we took," said Mark C. Schechter, who was in charge of transportation issues at the antitrust division, "is the price-fixing case we brought last December against the major airlines."
The case involved the computerized exchange of the carriers' pricing intentions, which the department said let the major airlines reach agreements to fix prices. It proposed a consent decree under which a carrier would be required to set prices for future travel but offer those tickets immediately.
The Transportation Department hopes that the airline industry gets the message from its intervention in the Northwest-Reno Air case.
"It was an important change in policy, an important decision," said Patrick Murphy, acting assistant secretary of transportation for policy and international affairs. "The academics have complained that we deregulated without enforcing the antitrust laws," he said. "They say we allowed the law of the jungle. From now on, we're not going to allow certain kinds of behavior to go unexamined."

HEADLINE: In a Texas Senate Race, the Really Influential Parties Are Not on the Ballot

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, April 4

 BODY:
As a political spectator sport, the election to replace Lloyd Bentsen as Texas Senator has turned into the kind of wild free-for-all not seen here since 1961, when 71 people vied for the right to succeed Lyndon B. Johnson.
When the filing deadline for the May 1 open election passed last Thursday, 24 people had signed up, ranging from a candidate who gave his occupation as "honest lawyer" to a heart-transplant recipient who insists a vote for him is a vote for "automatic term limitation" because doctors have told him he has only eight years to live. 
 But as the field narrows to the runoff stage, it is likely to evolve into something else: a sneak preview of the 1994 Congressional elections and a kind of early referendum on Bill Clinton's Presidency. And looming on the sidelines here is a Texan who is not running but whose word could affect the fortunes of those who are: Ross Perot.
 
Interim Senator a Favorite
 The race has already provided memorable spectacles like that of 20 candidates trying to "debate" each other in Austin one night last week with Mr. Perot as the host. But the critical question seems to be not so much who will finish first, but who will come next.
The Democrat selected by Gov. Ann W. Richards to be interim Senator, Bob Krueger, a former Congressman and Texas Railroad Commissioner, is widely expected to lead the field in the voting, but to fall short of the 50 percent he needs to avoid a runoff. In a state of 17 million people and with a ballot of so many names (there are no party primaries to narrow the field in the special election), fewer than 400,000 votes could be enough to qualify someone for second place and a subsequent shot at Mr. Krueger.
The most likely scenario is that one of three Republicans -- State Treasurer Kay Bailey Hutchison and Representatives Joe L. Barton and Jack Fields -- now engaged in a brutal intraparty struggle will wriggle into a runoff. But there are plenty of wild-card possibilities, too, including Richard W. Fisher, a Dallas businessman and former policy adviser to Mr. Perot who says he may spend up to $4 million of his own money on the campaign, and Jose Angel Gutierrez, a former county judge who is the sole Hispanic candidate in this race.
 
Those Not on Ballot
 And even when someone does emerge out of a field that is bereft of any household names to begin with, the truly pivotal figures in the race may not even be on the ballot:
*President Clinton, for whom the race, the first Senate contest since his inauguration, will inevitably become a test of his popularity. He and Vice President Al Gore have already appeared once in Texas with Mr. Krueger, and Mr. Clinton has taken several steps to bolster the interim Senator's prospects. At the same time, the President has willingly countenanced Mr. Krueger's vote against some of the tax increases in his plan.
*The new Republican Party national chairman, Haley Barbour, for whom the race is an obvious precursor to a 1994 Republican effort to recapture Senate seats at the halfway point of Mr. Clinton's term. Party leaders, hoping that one of the three Republican candidates comes out as the challenger to Mr. Krueger, have indicated that they may pour millions of dollars into an anti-Krueger, anti-Clinton campaign.
*Texas's two pre-eminent officeholders and possible future Presidential candidates, Governor Richards, a Democrat, and Phil Gramm, a Republican and Texas's senior Senator, for whom the race is a supreme test of political prestige and strength.
*And Mr. Perot, who received 22 percent of the votes in his home state last fall as an independent candidate for President.
 
Wanting Clinton's Support
 Mr. Perot has carefully declined so far to issue any endorsement in the race, but many of the candidates seem to be falling over themselves to win his support. And if he gives even the slightest indication of leaning in any candidate's direction, it could be enough to push that person into a runoff.
Such a nudge could be particularly important because the race, at least so far, has not produced well defined differences between the contestants. And with the possible exceptions of Mr. Krueger and Mrs. Hutchison, who won a statewide race in 1990, no one seems to have high name recognition.
"The issues are so clouded that the voters are going to have a difficult time distinguishing among the candidates," said George Christian, a Democratic consultant and former top aide to President Johnson who is not advising anyone in this race.
"Everyone's running against Washington," Mr. Christian said. "They're either running a far-right campaign or a Perot-like campaign, but they're all running against Washington."
The courting of Mr. Perot and his followers was abundantly evident last Monday in Austin, where the Perot organization United We Stand America sponsored the forum at the University of Texas. All of the announced candidates at that point showed up except for Mr. Krueger, who sent word that he was in Washington waiting to vote on a jobs bill and fighting for "a new approach to our government."
 
Distancing From Congress
 Representative Barton told the audience that he was the first member of Congress to join United We Stand. Mr. Fields, a seven-term Republican Congressman from Humble, described how he had always kept his primary residence in his hometown north of Houston "so I never became part of the Washington establishment."
Herbert J. Spiro, a former American Ambassador to Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea who is running as a Republican, boasted that his United We Stand membership number is 14510. Roger Henson, an engineer running as an independent, promised "no perks, no PAC's, no pork." And Maco Stewart, a former state legislator from Houston who is the candidate with the transplanted heart, said it guaranteed he would limit his time in Congress.
Mr. Perot said the meeting, in which all candidates were allowed about five minutes to speak, was a variation of his town hall approach to government, but he gave no clue of any preferences. "Be sure to vote and vote your conscience," he told the audience.
In Texas politics, the special election amounts to a major event, just the third switch of Senators since 1961. It was touched off when the popular 72-year-old Mr. Bentsen resigned to become Treasury Secretary.
Democrats are, in fact, hoping for a repeat of the 1961 special election, only with the roles of the major parties reversed. In that election, the Democrats essentially committed fratricide, the party so badly splintered that a Republican, John G. Tower, managed to capture a Texas Senate seat for the first time since Reconstruction.
 
Democratic Unity, Mostly
 This time around, Ms. Richards and other party leaders have more or less gotten Democrats to coalesce around Mr. Krueger, a former Elizabethan scholar and Duke University English professor, one of whose major virtues is that he has no big enemies. Mr. Krueger, who failed in two previous runs for the Senate, got a major break when the Democrat who had emerged as his strongest rival, former state Attorney General Jim Mattox, bowed to party leaders' wishes last month and announced he would not run.
But he may yet find himself up against Mr. Fisher, a wealthy investor who bills himself as both a Democrat and a Perot ally. Unveiling a 30-minute town hall style "infomercial" last month that features him taking questions from an audience, the political novice reiterated his willingness to spend millions of his own money.
"The political process shouldn't be just for rich people," he said. "But if that's what it takes to break it down, I'm willing to spend a significant portion of my net worth to do it." In an interview, he said that never having run for office before was a "redeeming feature" of his candidacy.
On the Republican side, Mrs. Hutchison seems to be the odds-on favorite to make the runoff. She is anti-tax and pro-abortion rights, although some opponents have accused her of flip-flopping on the abortion issue. "She's the best organized, the best known and she has the best record of accomplishment," said David C. Beckwith, once a top aide to former Vice President Dan Quayle who is Mrs. Hutchison's communications director.
But in a such a large field, the votes could splinter so much that someone else could sneak past her, and both Mr. Fields and Mr. Barton can claim strong bases in the Houston and Dallas areas, respectively.
 
Early Polls Questioned
 Mr. Barton, moreover, has made a vigorous pitch to the party's right wing, emphasizing his opposition to taxes, abortion, gun control and, perhaps most stridently, homosexuals in the armed forces.
"That's me on the Phil Donahue show, taking the heat and fighting the liberals," he says in one of his television advertisements.
All told, the ballot will include 10 Republicans, 5 Democrats, 6 independents and 3 candidates from other parties. If no one gets to 50 percent, the State Constitution requires the Governor to set a runoff election for late May or early June.
One thing most candidates agree on is that early polls taken last month were largely meaningless, partly because they came out before anyone conducted major advertising blitzes. They showed Mr. Krueger, Ms. Hutchison and Mr. Mattox, who has since withdrawn, at the top with the others all struggling for name recognition.
And they also agree that there is one other wild card on the ballot, but it isn't a candidate. The election will include a referendum on a major constitutional amendment to alter Texas's school financing system by shifting money from rich districts to poorer ones.
Republicans have generally opposed the amendment while Democrats like Governor Richards and Mr. Krueger, although not Mr. Fisher, are for it. And while polls suggest that most Texans are just beginning to focus on the measure, a strong turnout for or against could have an impact on who makes the runoff.

Some Democrats have feared her as the Republicans' best match for Gov. Ann W. Richards. Supports abortion rights and opposes new taxes. Aiming to capture runoff spot against Krueger and then run unified Republican campaign to beat him.

HEADLINE: Republicans Redux

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4

 BODY:
The stalemate in the Senate is not really about whether spending $16.3 billion will save the economic recovery, as Democrats say. Nor is it fundamentally about the national debt or the folly of taxing and spending, as Republicans maintain.
There is not enough money in the bill to explain the passion displayed on either side. 
 The fight is about Republican power, collectively and also individually.
Collectively, the Republican fight is over being treated as significant players on day-to-day Senate matters and as a serious force on major national issues looming on the political horizon, like health care.
 
A Republican Filibuster
 Individually, it also seems to concern Presidential ambition, as Republican senators seek to claim the leading role in opposition to President Clinton.
The 43 Republicans seem determined to continue their filibuster and keep preventing a vote unless the bill is cut back. Democrats know that, and will talk about cuts. But nobody yet knows how much of a cut.
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said today on the CBS News program "Face the Nation" that the Administration would be "really concerned" if Republican pride was cutting the program in half. He said, "It is not a big package to start with, and there are some things in there that are quite important to the economy and to the President himself."
Negotiations among Senate leaders will resume Monday. Some settlement is likely by Wednesday, so the Senate can turn to raising the statutory limit on the national debt that day, or else Government checks might bounce, and senators would get no spring break.
 
Surprised by Attack
 The Clinton Administration was surprised by the ferocity and persistence of the Republican attack. It tends to dismiss Republican motives as petty. Its readiest explanation is that Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, is being pushed to confrontation by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, in a preliminary round of the 1996 Presidential contest.
That seems to be part of it, but it doesn't explain the unified Republican front. Joining in the filibuster, after all, are Senators who dislike Mr. Gramm and his comrades in confrontation, like Trent Lott of Mississippi and Larry Craig of Idaho, more intensely than they dislike Mr. Clinton or his policies.
The Republican explanation, propounded Friday by Senator Alan Simpson of Wyoming, the party whip, is that Republicans rose up in righteous "indignation" at a series of parliamentary indignities.
Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia and chairman of the Appropriations Committee, did invoke a severe parliamentary approach to bar amendments to the spending bill. But he later withdrew it. By then, Republicans were angry at the method chosen to ram the debt limit bill through when its turn comes. In the Finance Committee at least, that anger seemed intended for show.
 
No Popularity Contests
 Mr. Byrd does not try to win popularity contests, and in trying to pass Mr. Clinton's bill he may have shown more parliamentary than diplomatic skill.
But in fact, the self-portrait Republicans draw of a cooperative, helpful minority suddenly shocked at parliamentary hard ball is not one that Democrats can recall seeing on the Senate floor lately. After agreeing to quick Cabinet confirmations, Republicans have delayed just about every bill that came up.
Mr. Dole has varied those delays strategically. Republicans cut short their obstruction of family leave, a very popular measure. But on the less-noticed "motor voter" bill to ease voter registration, their filibuster won them major concessions.
 
Probing for Weakness
 In fact, throughout the session Republicans have been probing for weakness, looking for opportunities to show the Democrats they matter.
They try to pick subjects where they sense the public is not engaged, and therefore where Republicans do not run a severe risk of being seen as guardians of "gridlock." Mr. Bentsen and George Stephanopoulos, Mr. Clinton's spokesman, tried to make that label stick today, just as Mr. Clinton and Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, had tried Friday. But most senators find no public clamor for, or against, the bill.
For some Republicans, especially veterans of the House where cooperation and even civility between parties is in short supply, fighting the Democrats and appearing on C-SPAN's Senate coverage is an end in itself. Senators Gramm, Lott, Craig and John McCain of Arizona fit that category.
But there is another motive for other Republicans to try to prove to Democrats that they matter.
 
Cause Is Health Care
 Take the suddenly furious John Chafee of Rhode Island. He said Friday a little gridlock was the only alternative to "us being a bunch of doormats around here, who roll over and just let everything go on through."
His cause is health care, and like many of the Republicans who have immersed themselves in that subject with him for two years, he seems doubtful that the Clinton Administration means what it says when it promises to consult seriously.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, who as chairman of the Finance Committee regards Republican help as essential to any serious legislating on health care, said of the minority: "The simple matter is that they have not been consulted. They have the feeling they are not going to be, and they say to hell with it."
 
Few Concessions Likely
 By now each side has made its point, and Mr. Clinton will be back in Washington to decide how much he is willing to give up. His aides insist they are prepared for a few concessions.
Mr. Dole is expected to offer Mr. Mitchell a proposal Monday, retaining money for unemployment benefits and some obvious job-producing elements of the bill. And then, after consulting with the White House, Mr. Mitchell is likely to make a bigger counter-proposal.
Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Byrd can coordinate easily enough with the Administration. But different Republicans may have different standards of what deal is acceptable.
As for Mr. Mitchell, he said today, "We'll do the best we can to pass the President's bill, or as close to it as we can come."

HEADLINE: Ludwig Jesselson, 82, Commodity-Trade Executive

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
Ludwig Jesselson, a philanthropist and retired commodity trading executive who was chairman of the board of trustees of Yeshiva University, died Saturday at Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem. He was 82 and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
Sam Hartstein, the university's director of public relations, said he died after suffering a heart attack in an apartment he maintained in Jerusalem, where he had gone for Passover. 
 Mr. Jesselson was the longtime chairman and chief executive officer of Philipp Brothers, a Manhattan-based commodity-trading company.
In early 1980, not long before Mr. Jesselson's retirement, Philipp Brothers was one of the world's largest marketers of raw materials, bartering more than 150 basic commodities, including steel, crude oil and cement. It was then a division of Englehard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation.
 
Helped Finance Museum
 After stepping down from the Philipp Brothers posts, Mr. Jesselson remained for some years a director of Englehard Minerals and Chemicals and of its successive descendents, Phibro Corporation, Phibro-Salomon and Salomon Inc.
Mr. Jesselson became chairman of Yeshiva's board in 1989 after serving as a trustee since 1961. He and his wife of more than 40 years, the former Erica Pappenheim, helped the university pay for the construction of its museum, for the museum's operating expenses, and for many of the museum's acquisitions.
In 1987, Mr. and Mrs. Jesselson gave the museum a letter written in 1818 by Thomas Jefferson in which the former President condemned prejudice toward Jews and all racial intolerance. Mr. Jesselson, a collector of Judaica and Hebraica, bought the letter in 1986 at Sotheby's in Manhattan for $396,000, which was the highest price paid at auction for any letter or any Presidential document.
In his honor, Salomon Inc. established the Ludwig Jesselson Chair in Economics at Yeshiva University in 1986.
 
Philanthropic Activities
 Mr. Jesselson's philanthropic and volunteer activities included fund-raising for the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of Greater New York and serving as a director of the Riverdale Jewish Center. In addition, he contributed to many nonprofit organizations and activities in Israel and financed several archeological excavations there. He was the retired chairman of the Global Board of Trustees of Bar-Ilan University in Ramat Gan, east of Tel Aviv.
At his death, he was also chairman of the board of the American committee of Shaare Zedek Medical Center, having retired earlier as chairman of its international board.
Morris Talansky, the medical center's executive vice chairman, said yesterday that Mr. and Mrs. Jesselson had provided the money for much of its construction and for the operating expenses of several of its departments.
Over the years, Mr. Jesselson received many honors for his philanthropy, including the Kesher Shem Tov Award of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America.
He was born in southwestern Germany, in the small community of Neckarbischofsheim in what became the state of Baden-Wurttemberg. He went on to attend school in Heidelberg before entering the commodities-trading world as a teen-age apprentice trader in a Berlin company.
Mr. Jesselson emigrated to the United States in 1937. He joined Philipp Brothers in 1938, became one of its prime movers by 1950 and was named its chief executive officer and chairman in the early 1960's.
In addition to his wife, Mr. Jesselson is survived by three sons, Michael and Daniel, both of Manhattan, and Benjamin, of Jerusalem; 13 grandchildren, and a brother, Sigmund Jeselsohn, of Zurich.

HEADLINE: GATT Chief Says U.S. Delays Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, April 4

 BODY:
An international trade agreement that would stimulate the shaky world economy is being delayed while the Clinton Administration devotes political energy and negotiators to the North American Free Trade Agreement, the departing head of the world's free trade body says.
The remarks by Arthur Dunkel, the director general of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which is based here and administers international free trade rules, underscore the problem the Clinton Administration faces as it tries to reach two free trade agreements at the same time. 
 Concessions in the GATT negotiations, for example, could antagonize the textile industry and other business groups in the United States whose support is needed by the Administration for the difficult struggle this fall of winning Congressional approval of the North American agreement.
In an effort to restart the world trade talks, which began in Uruguay in 1986, American and European officials plan to hold several meetings by early June, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, announced last Monday. But in an interview on Friday, Mr. Dunkel discounted Mr. Kantor's efforts.
"The message given is that the Uruguay Round is still very high on the agenda," Mr. Dunkel said, "but the reality is that, of course, if the officials of U.S.T.R. get to their office in the morning they generally have an urgent file on Nafta which comes before the urgent file on GATT, that is clear."
Stephen L. Engelberg, the acting chief of staff for Mr. Kantor, said that Mr. Dunkel was mistaken and that only Mr. Kantor and a handful of other officials were involved in both agreements.
Mr. Engelberg said that Mr. Kantor had spent as much time on the Uruguay Round as on the North American pact. "There is no strategy here to put off anything in terms of negotiations until the Nafta is voted on," he said. Mr. Kantor and several of his aides flew to Ottawa on Friday to discuss the North American pact with Canadian officials and were not available for comment.
The North American pact would eliminate trade barriers among Canada, Mexico and the United States. The international trade pact would reduce import tariffs around the world for GATT's 112 nations and apply free trade rules for the first time to agriculture and services like shipping and insurance.
 
Other Delays Cited
 Mr. Dunkel cautioned that the North American agreement was nonetheless "worth concluding" and said that the European Community's preoccupation with further economic and monetary integration during the last year had also delayed the Uruguay Round.
European officials have been following the North American pact's progress but expressed little sympathy last week for the Administration's predicament. Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's vice president for external economic affairs, said in an interview on Wednesday that quick compromises were needed in world trade talks regardless of the political damage this might cause to the Congressional prospects of the North American pact.
"I think we'll have to get serious agreements going before November, simply because this is not just a bilateral process, we've got to involve the rest of the world and take what they say seriously and produce a package that is acceptable to everybody," Sir Leon said.
Sir Leon also said in the interview that when Mr. Kantor visited Brussels on Monday the two men agreed to try to make trade issues prominent on the agenda when the leaders of the world's seven leading industrial nations meet in Tokyo on July 7 to 9.
 
Getting Japan Involved
 Sir Leon said he hoped that such an emphasis would put new pressure on the Japanese to make fresh offers and play a more active role in the world trade talks. Sir Leon and Mr. Kantor called for such a role by Japan when they first met six weeks ago in Washington. Japanese officials contend that they have been active participants in the Uruguay round.
Key members of Congress and the Administration have been discussing for weeks a possible renewal of 8 to 10 months of the fast-track Presidential negotiating authority needed to conclude a world trade agreement. Such a timetable would allow politically sensitive compromises to be reached after Congress votes on the North American pact, mostly likely in October or November.
A big problem still ahead of the Administration is that a GATT deal at the end of the year, a deadline set by President Clinton, would reach the floor of the House and Senate under fast-track rules shortly before the 1994 Congressional elections. Conventional wisdom in Washington holds that controversial trade pacts are more readily approved in odd-numbered years, when support may be easier to muster.
One key European demand in the world trade talks has been for steep reductions in American tariffs on imported textiles. Yet any concession in this area before the vote on the North American pact could alienate legislators from textile states who might have wanted to support the North American pact, said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a California Democrat who supports both trade pacts and is on the Ways and Means Committee's trade panel.
 
Textile Group's Position
 The American Textile Manufacturers Institute, a Washington-based trade group that represents fabric producers and has a long protectionist history, has enthusiastically endorsed the North American pact.
The agreement would eliminate American restrictions on imports from Mexican clothing producers -- who rely on American fabric. This would give the Mexican producers an advantage over Asian producers, who face strict quotas on shipments to the United States and who tend to cut and sew fabric made in Asia. So the North American pact could help American textile producers.
But Carlos Moore, the institute's executive vice president, said that if the United States made any concessions soon in the world trade talks then "our focus is going to be on defeating that -- and will certainly take away some of our direction, some of our concerted action, on behalf of the Nafta."
Mr. Dunkel officially confirmed today what trade officials had been predicting recently -- that he would step down when the latest extension of his term expires at the end of June. Named to a six-year term in 1980, Mr. Dunkel has won a series of extensions as member nations of the trade group kept hoping that the Uruguay Round might be concluded soon.

HEADLINE: A Strong First Quarter For Foreign Portfolios

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
For the first time in four years, Americans who invested their dollars in foreign stocks in the first quarter instead of here at home had cause to be satisfied.
The quarter was characterized by falling interest rates in many industrialized countries, generally benign swings in the value of the dollar and a Japanese Government-led surge on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the world's second biggest. 
 All these factors helped to raise stock prices outside the United States by nearly 12 percent in dollar terms, according to the Financial Times world index.
 
Overseas Gains
 "On balance, this was a very good quarter for international investors, even dollar-based investors," said Jeffrey Russell, a portfolio manager at Smith Barney's World Funds International Equity portfolio.
Americans who used mutual funds as their ticket overseas did nearly three times as well as those who invested their money at home.
In the first quarter, the 287 world equity funds tracked by Lipper Analytical Services rose by 9.74 percent, while the 1,080 general equity funds that invest in American companies rose by 3.29 percent, slightly less than the 3.7 percent increase posted during the first quarter by the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
"This is the first time in four years that world equity funds have outperformed the domestic ones," said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical.
Much of the gain abroad reflected a strong performance in Japan.
In dollar terms, Japanese stocks rose by more than 18.50 percent in the quarter, a gain that was helped by the strength of the yen against the dollar. (In terms of the yen, Japanese stocks rose by slightly more than 9 percent.)
 
An Artificial Surge?
 The Japanese Government assisted the rally by introducing fiscal stimulus packages and encouraging giant insurance companies to buy shares. Foreign portfolio managers who had lightened up on positions in Japan during the market's long downward spiral provided additional momentum by coming back in once the rally began.
 Despite the strong performance, analysts were left wondering just how much longer Japanese stocks could continue to rise.
"The $64 question is just how real the rally there is," said David Testa, chairman of T. Rowe Price International Funds, with nearly $7 billion under management.
Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company, said he thought the rise in Tokyo was way overdone.
"I think the Japanese market is grossly overpriced," Mr. Metz said. "The powers that be succeeded in getting prices up, but keeping them up there is another matter."
Mr. Metz and others extolled the virtues of other Asian stock markets, including Hong Kong's, which in dollar terms rose by almost 16 percent in the first quarter, and Malaysia's, which was up by more than 7 percent.
 While interest rate cuts in Germany helped to raise prices on the Frankfurt stock exchange by more than 10 percent, and by more than 12 percent on the Paris Bourse, some analysts said even greater returns were likely on European markets.
'It doesn't yet look like a big bull run," Mr. Testa said, "but they are making progress, and even with the weak economic environment there is not a lot of risk in those markets. If the rate cuts continue, we should have a good year in Europe."
Mr. Metz was even more enthusiastic. Short-term interest rates in Germany and France are still higher than long-term rates, he noted, leading to an "enormous" overweighting in short-term investments.
"As interest rates come down, we believe there will be an enormous swing into equities, particularly in France," he said.

HEADLINE: Essay;
In the Cruelest Month

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"April is the cruelest month," wrote the poet T. S. Eliot, ". . . mixing Memory and desire."
In the April that features the first global presidential campaign, Boris Yeltsin is reminding both his compatriots and former superpower competitors of the threat to freedom of revanchist apparatchiks, while fanning the desire "to move from general assurances to pragmatic, specific acts." 
 In this noble enterprise, Bill Clinton has joined what amounts to the Friends of Boris, a network of shallow-pocketed political leaders, cautious entrepreneurs and many of us gung-ho multimedia types. The immediate goal of the new F.O.B.: without appearing intrusive, to help the Russian reformers win the April 25 referendum.
That was the sole purpose of the Vancouver summit. Such outside political aid has its precedents: Khrushchev confessed he tried to help Kennedy defeat Nixon, and Brezhnev later tried to prop up Nixon at a summit after Watergate; in the other direction, Reagan and Bush tried to support Gorbachev against Yeltsin's challenge. The success rate of intercontinental carpetbagging has not been high.
But an unbroken string of flops is no reason not to give the April referendum our best shot. Last weekend's meeting -- more a pep rally than what Churchill called "a parley at the summit" -- should be judged in the light of what it set out to do.
Did it send inspiring pictures home to Russia? Yes; the shot of Yeltsin disdaining an umbrella, that symbol of weakness and appeasement, preferring to stand in the cold Canadian rain hatless and fearless, was as close as he could come to climbing on a tank. (Clinton had to follow suit; only their host, Brian Mulroney, classily stepping down as Prime Minister to preserve his party's national leadership, could afford to take cover like a sensible person.)
And at the joint press conference at the conclusion of their worldwide photo op, Yeltsin came off not as a mendicant but as a proud, forceful statesmen leading a potentially rich country. "These are not Christmas presents," he said of what he called "the Clinton package." Not the Bush-era pie in the sky: "These are real figures that are doable."
The Vancouver meeting was a telegenic campaign event, milked beforehand with a send-off rally of 50,000 Siberians, and presumably to be followed by a welcome-home-Boris, you-did-us-proud rally upon arrival home.
In coming weeks, Russians should be treated to tangible evidence of the trip's results: not another multibillion-dollar promise, but food on the docks and visible deals in the works. The first priority makes business sense: to get Western investors to develop Russia's oil and gas resources.
Before the referendum, Japan should drop its humiliating demand for the return of territory before joining in economic aid; Richard Nixon, an original Friend of Boris, is not on his way to Tokyo this week to sniff the cherry blossoms. The G-7 ministerial meeting in that city will be held April 14, involving the rest of the industrial world in the Russian referendum.
How does the coming show of global support for Yeltsin affect Clinton's image? At past summits, the spin doctors of both sides made their man look good at the expense of the other; this time, however, pundits everywhere were serviced by high-level American spin doctors marveling at the wit, wisdom, dignity and sheer gutsiness of the Russian leader.
Of course, a pitch is also made about the skill and grace of the young American President at his first superpower outing, and it cannot be denied that he did his homework, showed due deference, and made no mistakes at his joint press conference.
But despite the tut-tutted unpopularity of foreign aid, Clinton is expending little political capital in the bipartisan backing of Boris. The summit in the cruelest month was neither a test of diplomatic skill nor an exhibition of national nerve. There may come a day when Clinton has to negotiate strongly from a weak position, or to face down a foreign leader at a tense summit; this was not that day.
Vancouver was an early moment in a momentous political campaign, and Clinton the experienced campaign consultant zeroed in on candidate Yeltsin's central message and his opposition's weakness: "He trusts the Russian people. Boris Yeltsin has put the fate of the government of Russia into the hands of the people of Russia. That is a very great thing."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: In Russia, Employee Ownership Is Succeeding

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Russia's Unnoticed Revolution" (editorial, March 25) applauds the rapidity of Russian privatization, but misinterprets Russia's main method of privatization, employee ownership. 
 You complain that employee and citizen ownership "might produce companies that are ungovernable" and that businesses will be "controlled by no one." Just the reverse is true, as is demonstrated by Russian companies that have been employee-owned for several years, like Moscow Ventilator, Veshky Enterprises and Saratov Aviation. Their profitability, quality and productivity have improved dramatically.
The same is true in the United States. Last year the value of stocks in employee-ownership companies listed on American exchanges rose 23 percent, compared with an increase of only 4.2 percent for the Dow Jones index stocks, according to a recent study by Prof. Joseph Blasi at Rutgers University.
The Russian Parliament understood in the drafting of the privatization legislation that encouraging employees to hold the majority of the common stock is a superior form of ownership.
 
JOHN SIMMONS
Chicago, March 26, 1993
The writer is president of Participation Associates, a management consulting company.

HEADLINE: In Russia, Employee Ownership Is Succeeding;
A Credit Union Link

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Right Stuff for Russia" (Op-Ed, March 24), Senator Bill Bradley suggests that Americans should "reach out generously toward the peoples of Russia, Ukraine and the other republics." Such action is already taking place within the credit union movement. 
 There is a serious lack of consumer financial services in Ukraine and Russia. Credit unions, with their emphasis on self-help, are ideal to help meet these needs.
An association of credit unions of Ukrainian heritage has jumped in to help. American and Canadian credit union executives of Ukrainian descent or birth have made several trips to lay the groundwork. The first Ukrainian interns to be trained in the United States should arrive shortly. The effort is coordinated by the World Council of Credit Unions.
These actions echo those taken over the last three years in Poland. After visiting credit unions in the United States, Canada and Ireland and welcoming educational missions from the World Council, Poles set up their own distinct model of credit union. There are 21 credit unions registered, with 85 more in the pipeline. American credit unions continue to sponsor Polish interns, and have begun signing partnership agreements that commit them to support and share information with a Polish credit union.
The great need in Ukraine is for funds to provide more technical help. A fund-raising campaign is under way among credit union members. The Agency for International Development can help by approving a grant for Ukrainian credit unions as quickly as possible.
Although the number of people involved does not approach those Sena
tor Bradley calls for, the exchange of ideas, people and training has now begun.
 
CHARLENE KOMAR STOREY
Editor, Credit Union News
New York, March 26, 1993

HEADLINE: In Russia, Employee Ownership Is Succeeding;
Student Exchange

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In recent days the importance of continuing and expanding American investment in Russia, despite the internal tensions and uncertainties in that country, was underscored by President Clinton at his first press conference, by Secretary of State Warren M. Christopher, addressing the Chicago Council on Foreign Relations, and by Senator Bill Bradley in "The Right Stuff for Russia" (Op-Ed, March 14). All three make the point that the United States has a vital and strategic interest in helping Russia achieve a stable democracy with a free-market economy. 
 Senator Bradley, in setting goals, states that "there should be 30,000 Russian high school students living with American families for a year, 10,000 Russians in small businesses in towns across America, 10,000 college students at our universities and thousands of former military officers learning modern banking, finance and accounting in the West."
For years, Webster University has been engaged in educational exchange designed to achieve the objectives articulated by Senator Bradley, President Clinton and Mr. Christopher. Since 1990, under an agreement between Webster University and the former Soviet Academy of Sciences and through other initiatives, Russian students have studied at Webster University's campuses in Geneva and Vienna, as well as our home campus in St. Louis; groups of Webster students and faculty members have gone from Geneva to study in Russia, and Russian faculty members have taught at the Geneva campus.
These activities have increased with a new commitment between Webster and the St. Petersburg branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences to help prepare former military officers for managerial and entrepreneurial careers, including a knowledge of modern banking, finance and accounting. The joint venture, known as the Webster Academy, is incorporated in Russia under a board of Russians and Americans. This collaboration is expected to continue irrespective of the outcome of the political tug-of-war in Russia.
American universities will form an important link in uniting nations by trade and commerce, by better cultural understanding and by a common commitment to open markets, an open society and the exchange of ideas.
 
DANIEL H. PERLMAN
President, Webster University
St. Louis, March 26, 1993

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN VANCOUVER: The Overview;
Yeltsin Leaves Talks With Firm Support and More Aid

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, April 4

 BODY:
President Clinton today threw his full political support behind Boris N. Yeltsin in Russia's fateful political struggle and pledged a larger-than-expected $1.6 million in assistance intended to show "immediate and tangible" support for Russia's reforms.
"Mr. President, our nation will not stand on the sidelines when it comes to democracy in Russia," Mr. Clinton pledged in a statement that drew on Walt Whitman to bolster the President's insistence that it was the "high duty" of the world's democracies to rise to Russia's support. 
 "We know where we stand," he said. "We are with Russian democracy. We are with Russian reforms. We are with Russian markets. We support freedom of conscience and speech and religion. We support respect for ethnic minorities. We actively support reform and reformers and you in Russia."
Later, bidding farewell to the Russian President, Mr. Clinton ardently pumped his hand and exhorted Mr. Yeltsin: "Win! Win!"
 
'Democratic Partnership'
 The two leaders addressed a news conference on the conclusion of a weekend summit meeting held against the arresting backdrop of Vancouver's mountains, bays and skyscrapers. In their closing statements, both issued strong declarations of mutual admiration and proclaimed a "new democratic partnership" rich in promise for both nations.
The centerpiece of the summit was the announcement of a package of American aid that was boosted from the $1 billion previously reported to $1.6 billion. The difference was $700 million in long-term, low-cost credits that clear the way for immediate resumption of grain exports that were blocked by Russia's inability to meet its payments.
The package also included increased food and medical assistance. But the elements most strongly stressed by both leaders were those that supported fledgling businesses and a market economy in Russia.
 
Lift Trade Limits, Yeltsin Asks
 At Mr. Yeltsin's bidding, Mr. Clinton also said he would reopen the question of various limitations on trade with Russia left over from the East-West rivalry. These specifically include the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which links most-favored-nation trading status with the emigration of Russian Jews, and restrictions on trade in high technology and strategic minerals.
Mr. Yeltsin said he had complained that "America was still treating us as though we were a Communist country." Mr. Clinton promised that he would issue a "comprehensive" position within days.
Among the new elements of the package was a "Democracy Corps" intended to coordinate the activities of the innumerable private and governmental agencies now trying to assist Russia, and a new Commission on Technological Cooperation in energy and space whose chairmen will be Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin.
Mr. Clinton put special stress on the fact that the package consisted entirely of money that was already allocated and immediately available, in contrast to previous collections of pledges that never materialized. He said it was the first stage of a long-term commitment that he would take up with Congress on his return to Washington.
 
Call for Allies' Help
 The American President said he was also calling on industrialized nations in the Group of Seven "to come forward with their own individual bilateral initiatives" when foreign and finance ministers of the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan meet in Tokyo on April 14-15 to discuss ways of stabilizing Russia's economy and currency.
Also in the spirit of the "partnership" they proclaimed, Mr. Clinton said that he had expressed his regret to Mr. Yeltsin over the collision of American and Russian submarines in the Barents Sea off the Russian coast, and had ordered an investigation into the incident.
The dominant question looming over all the pledges and declarations of the last two days was whether American and Western aid could help Mr. Yeltsin and his program at this critical stage of his struggle with a hostile legislature dedicated to removing him and slowing the drive for a market economy.
Mr. Clinton made clear he was aware of the limits of American influence: "The ultimate responsibility for the success of Russia's new course, of course, rests with the people of Russia. It is they who must support economic reforms and make them work. But Americans know that our nation has a part to play, too, and we will do so."
Mr. Yeltsin ventured no prediction on the value of the summit talks for the next battle he faces, a vote of confidence on April 25. "It is up to us to deal with the referendum," he said. "It is up to us to us to work, to persuade citizens of the Russian Federation that if they do not vote their confidence in us they will be dealing a blow to democracy and rolling back to the past, returning to the Communist yoke."
 
Campaigning in Siberia
 Having come to the summit from a session of the Congress of People's Deputies at which 1,000 hostile legislators came within 72 votes of ousting him, Mr. Yeltsin left directly to campaign in Russia's Far East and Siberia.
But it was evident that the Russian leader had been bolstered by the Vancouver meeting. His delivery determined and strong, Mr. Yeltsin declared that he was "fully satisfied by the results and by the spirit and atmosphere of my encounter with President Bill Clinton."
"We immediately found common language in Vancouver, possibly because we're both businesslike people, and at the same time, to some extent, idealists, both," he said.
Mr. Yeltsin spoke of a "very special relationship" developing with Mr. Clinton, and he hailed the aid offered him as "a very large and wise package, which is going to make history."
 
Shift to the Specific
 "The meeting in Vancouver signals a shift from general assurances of support to Russia to pragmatic, specific, nitty-gritty projects," he said.
Mr. Clinton reciprocated with a strong personal endorsement of the Russian leader. "We have interests and values," he said. "They are embodied by the policies and the direction of President Yeltsin. They are enduring. He is the duly-elected president of Russia. And as long as he is, I intend to work with him and support him, because he reflects those enduring values."
As he had in his first major speech on Russia in Annapolis on Thursday, Mr. Clinton seemed to make special efforts to convince Americans of the historic importance of helping Russia at the current juncture.
He recalled a line from Walt Whitman about the East River: "Flow on, river; flow on." America's support for Russia's course was the same, he declared, a bellow of enthusiastic support for a process that no tyrant could stop.
 
Dramatizing U.S. Support
 The last-minute increase in the American assistance package was evidently intended to give an extra dollop of drama to the announcement, since on its own, the sum of $1.6 billion was not extroardinary.
American officials said Mr. Clinton was determined in the first stage of his effort to help Russia to pledge only money that he was certain he could deliver, to avoid repeating the politically damaging experience of the Bush Administration, which pledged $24 billion and ended up disbursing barely half of that.
"There are no smoke and mirrors here," said a United States official who was directly evolved with designing the package. "We wanted to make the point that these are funds that we have, that we're going to do what we say we're going to do. The President is determined to carry out every single program. We also have a long-term commitment, we'll be looking for Russian ideas that most effectively support reform."
Mr. Clinton said three-quarters of the money would be distributed not Government-to-Government, as in most previous aid packages, but "will go to benefit the emerging private sector in Russia."
 
Resumption of Grain Shipments
 The largest portion of the package, however, would come in the form of resumed American grain shipments in the seven months left before Russia completes its own 1993 harvest.
Shipments to Russia had been halted because of Russia's failure to make its payments to the United States Department of Agriculture's Commodity Credit Corp. The $700 million credit came from the Food for Progress program, which has more liberal conditions and repayment schedules.
In all, the package consited of $690.9 million in grants and $932 million in credits. While all the money was from existing programs and allocations, an American official stressed that no more than half of it would have been spent in Russia if the Administration had not spent the last seven weeks combing through every existing and related program.
Americans said the focus of the package were programs intended to assist areas that Russia had outlined as its priorities: support for private enterprise and a pilot program to build housing for military officers.
The program called for the creation of a "Democracy Corps" to coordinate the thousands of private organizations and the dozen Government agencies now working separately in Russia. This and other similar programs were allocated $48 million.
 
Cooperation on Energy
 American officials said the Commission on Technological Cooperation in energy and space, which would be headed jointly by Vice President Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin, the Russian Prime Minister and a former Soviet minister of the gas industry, was intended to give energy cooperation a priority similar to the arms negotiations of the past.
American oil companies have reported enormous and constant frustrations in dealing with Russian officials, both local and federal.
The Administration further earmarked $50 million for a "Russian-American Enterprise Fund" which would issue direct loans to Russian small businesses and joint ventures; $95 million in privatization support, including for military conversion, and $4 million for the "Eurasia Foundation," a private foundation that finances democratic projects in Russia.
These were other elements in the package:
* An additional $194 million was allocated to food aid, bringing the total for this year to $425 million, along with $30 million more in medical aid.
* $6 million was allocated for a pilot program to built 450 units of housing for Russian officers. Officials said the program would be increased if the demonstration project succeeded.
* In addition to the Gore-Chernomyrdin commission, the package called for a Business Development Committee headed by Commerce Secretary Ron Brown and the Russian Deputy Prime Minister, Aleksandr H. Shokhin, and for the appointment of a full-time "investment ombudsman." The package included extension of $82 million in export-import credits for the Caterpillar Co. to finance sale of pipeline construction machinery, and $150 million in loan guarantees for the Siberian energy exploration by Conoco.
* $38 million was earmarked for programs to increase energy production and reduce pipeline pollution.
* $215 million was provided for dismantling Russia's nuclear arsenal under the Nunn-Lugar bill.
In all, Mr. Yeltsin said the two leaders had discussed 50 different subjects, ranging from the withdrawal of Russian troops from the Baltic states to arms control.

HEADLINE: Serbs' Strategy: War Gets More Than Diplomacy

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 4

 BODY:
In rejecting the peace plan for Bosnia negotiated by the international community, the Serbs have evidently concluded that they have enough military strength on the ground and enough stoicism to withstand whatever is coming.
Though the United Nations is still groping for a way to induce them to sign the draft accord, the Bosnian Serbs have opted for hard facts over diplomacy. After a year of fighting they hold about 70 percent of Bosnia and Herzegovina and their forces are much better armed than their Muslim and Croatian foes. And any notion of Western military intervention is filled with potential pitfalls and could have explosive repercussions. 
 "The international negotiating process is on the rocks and shipwrecked," one Western diplomat here said. "The Serbs have decided that the proposals for Bosnia are unacceptable and that they are going to tough it out and wait for the world to come to its senses."
For the Bosnian Serbs, that would involve an admission by leading Western nations that the notion of a sovereign state of Bosnia and Herzegovina was a mistake now buried in the rubble of a year of civil war in the former Yugoslav republic.
In a formal vote on Saturday by their self-styled parliament, the Bosnian Serbs specifically rejected the outlines of 10 semiautonomous provinces within a sovereign Bosnia proposed in the peace plan by international mediators Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen. But from Radovan Karadvic on down, the Serbs' leaders have in recent days made clear their more fundamental conviction -- that Bosnia should simply be carved into three parts among Muslims, Croats and themselves.
That idea is unacceptable to the United States and other Western nations as well as to the Muslim-led Bosnian Government because it would appear to reward Serbian aggression. In a pattern that their nationalist fighters describe as "ethnic cleansing," Serbs have driven Muslims from wide swaths of the republic.
 
Precedent for Hanging Tough
 Precedent gives the Serbs support in their determination to hang tough and put force before talk. Although fighting in neighboring Croatia largely stopped more than a year ago, the Serbs still hold close to one-third of that former Yugoslav republic's territory, just as they did when the truce began in January 1992.
In that case Serbs did accept a peacemaking process involving the stationing of United Nations troops in four Serbian-occupied areas. But that did not deter the Croatian Serbs from digging in and declaring their own Serbian Republic of Krajina.
Western analysts now expect the Bosnian Serbs to try and circumvent the peace efforts of the United Nations and European Community through direct talks with the other warring parties in Bosnia.
A meeting between the three military commanders is scheduled on Wednesday at the airport at Sarajevo, the capital. In the talks, the Bosnian Serbs' commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, is likely to press publicly for maintaining the tenuous cease-fire.
That would be good public relations and would put the Bosnian Government of President Alija Izetbegovic in a delicate position of being obliged to take up the offensive if it loses patience.
The analysts see some likelihood that the Serbs may try and reach a deal with the Croats to put the Muslims on the defensive in Bosnia. They have some bargaining chips.
The most important thing to the Croats is securing their position around Mostar and other towns in the Herzegovina region and insuring that Serbs do not resume their shelling of the Dalmatian coast. Recently the Serbs lobbed a few shells from Trebinje into the suburbs of Dubrovnik, a Croatian resort that was heavily damaged in the fighting in 1991.
The most important thing to the Serbs is securing a corridor through northern Bosnia connecting Serbia to the big Serbian population around Banja Luka in western Bosnia -- something denied them by a Croatian enclave on the Vance-Owen map. A trade-off on these points appears possible because only the Serbs can offer the Croats security in Herzegovina and the Dalmatian region, and only the Croats can guarantee the Serbs their corridor.
Fundamental to the thinking among the Bosnian Serbs and the Serbian leadership in Yugoslavia is an attitude that any steps the international community is likely to take now to make life here more painful will not in fact make much difference. The only thing that would do so -- Western military force -- has not been used, and the Serbs' calculation is clearly that the same doubts and fears will continue to prevent it for the foreseeable future.
Nine months of crippling United Nations sanctions have already left the Yugoslav economy in ruins, with inflation running at more than 250 percent a month, industrial production down by more than 50 percent last year, and a third of the work force idled. A defiant sentiment has grown that things cannot get much worse, so let the world do what it will.
President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, the dominant politician in what remains of Yugoslavia, knows that if the United Nations tightens sanctions against his Government, which it will consider doing this week, it could play to his advantage, since he would portray it as another flagrant example of the world's injustice toward the Serbs.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Discusses New Sanctions
 WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters) -- Secretary of State Warren Christopher criticized Bosnian Serbs today for "failing to grasp an opportunity for peace" and said he had discussed the possibility of new sanctions against the Serbs with the Russian Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev.
 "We're not at the present time contemplating the use of ground troops in Bosnia," Mr. Christopher said on "This Week," an ABC News program. But he said later that the United States was "certainly giving" its attention to the possibility of lifting an embargo against arms deliveries to the region.
 
 
 
Balkan Update"
 A United Nations convoy carrying food and medicine made its way to Srebrenica, Bosnia, but a Bosnian officer would not permit emptied trucks to be used to evacuate wounded people and refugees, saying such action would further Serbian nationalists' plans to remove Muslims from the enclave.
Relief flights to Sarajevo resumed after a two-week hiatus, but a truce in the capital unraveled further as a Serbian shell killed 2 children and injured 15, and snipers killed at least 5 others.
President Clinton, at a summit meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia, said he would seek tougher United Nations sanctions against Serbia. President Boris N. Yeltsin said Russia would cooperate in working to end ethnic conflicts like the ones that have torn the Balkans.
