HEADLINE: SENATE SUSPENDS EFFORT FOR ACCORD ON CLINTON'S PLAN

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
Nine days into a filibuster and miles from any hint of agreement, Senate Democrats and Republicans abandoned the hunt for a compromise on President Clinton's economic stimulus package tonight, and decided to try again in two weeks.
The Democratic majority leader, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, said he decided to stop talking and send the Senate on a long-postponed vacation after Republicans refused to make an opening offer to resolve differences. 
 His Republican counterpart, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, said the two sides informally discussed a settlement, but that "we didn't think it was the right time" to suggest a compromise.
 
Time for a Breather
 "Some of my members don't want any compromise at all," he said.
Mr. Mitchell put a good face on the break in talks late tonight, saying it would give Mr. Clinton and other Democrats a chance to press the case for the spending package nationwide, and provide both sides a breather in which some compromise might yet materialize.
But in practical terms, the delay underscored the power Mr. Dole and the Senate's 42 other Republicans now hold over the package, which Mr. Clinton calls crucial to a continued economic recovery and the Republicans call both wasteful and extravagant.
Three times in four days, including today, Senate Democrats have tried to break the Republican filibuster against the bill, and three times they have failed to muster the 60 votes they need to end debate. Today, with more senators leaving town almost hourly, the vote to end debate was 49 to 29, 11 short of what was needed.
 
Debt Ceiling Raised
 The Senate will meet briefly on Wednesday to adjourn, then take up the debate anew when it returns on April 19. Each side appears likely to offer new and competing versions of the stimulus package then, and then to make another attempt to shut off debate and conduct a final vote on the measure.
The lawmakers quit tonight about 11:30 after completing the only action that they could agree on: a measure raising the Federal debt ceiling and allowing the Government to sell enough bonds to finance its operations through Sept. 30. Treasury officials had warned that the Government could go bankrupt if the measure was not passed by Wednesday.
Earlier today, Mr. Clinton's top aides had roamed the Capitol, showing new willingness to strike a deal with the Republicans. His budget director, Leon E. Panetta, said after today's vote that the White House was "prepared to offer whatever cooperation is necessary to see that this bill moves," and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, once one of the Senate's top deal makers, showed up later in the day to offer the Democrats advice.
Republican lawmakers said -- and Mr. Mitchell and the White House later flatly denied -- that Senate Democrats had informally floated a compromise involving relatively small cuts in White House spending plans, led by a $1.8 billion allotted to make up deficits in the Pell grant college-aid program. That money must eventually be spent, but it would create no jobs and thus is inconsistent with what Mr. Clinton says is the overarching purpose of his bill.
Whatever the nature of the compromise, Mr. Dole and the Republicans rejected it outright as far too small. Asked at midday what kind of compromise was needed to end the talks, he was succinct: "Big one."
The parties are fundamentally at odds over the proposal. Although both sides agree it is a minuscule amount of money to filibuster over, especially compared with the $1.5 trillion Federal budget, the specifics have been overwhelmed by political and philosophical considerations that defy easy bargaining.
Even the cost of the package is a matter of semantic dispute. Democrats say, accurately, that it approves $16.3 billion in new spending. Republicans add, also correctly, that it allocates $3.2 billion more in road and airport spending previously authorized, but never taken out of special accounts fed by gasoline and air-travel taxes.
 
Legislation at Risk
 The filibuster calls into question the White House's early confidence that one-party government would be a smooth affair. Instead, it now seems clear that any controversial legislation, including most of Mr. Clinton's tax and spending proposals, is at risk unless it can attract 60 votes in a Senate that has only 57 Democrats.
Democrats say the bill and the programs it creates are urgently needed to prop up a sagging economy, and they point to the March unemployment report, which showed a slight decrease in jobs. The package would spend $4 billion for additional unemployment benefits and billions more to create jobs, most of them temporary, for construction workers, manufacturers and inner-city youngsters.
Republicans say the money would be wasted in part on low-priority projects and political pork, including things like a $6 million proposal to capture escaping methane from landfills and cow manure and a proposed allotment for a film on early Louisiana culture. Even worse, they argue, it would raise the deficit because none of the spending would be offset by corresponding cuts in other Federal programs.
The Administration normally might have won over some Republicans with small compromises. But the opposition was calcified early in the debate, when Senate Democrats used parliamentary tactics to prevent Republicans from even offering amendments. That left them with the filibuster option.
Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, one moderate Republican who can occasionally be pried from his more conservative colleagues, said today that he doubted that he or other Republicans could be lured to Mr. Clinton's side this time.
Tonight, Mr. Dole said the Republicans were insisting on a pared-down spending package that would include $4 billion in extended unemployment benefits, about $3 billion in highway and mass-transit money, roughly $1 billion in summer jobs for inner-city teachers and youths and $300 million for childhood immunizations.
Even more troubling for Mr. Clinton and Mr. Mitchell is that the Republicans want all of those programs, save the unemployment benefits, to be offset by new cuts in spending.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Inside the Spending Package"
 
Democrats say the $19.5 billion spending package now in the Senate would give the economy a lift, creating more than 200,000 temporary jobs, even as it helps rebuild national assets like highways and airports. Republicans say the measure is laden with pork-barrel projects and that the economy doesn't need a jolt of more deficit spending. HEADLINE: $32 BILLION BUDGET IS VOTED IN ALBANY AS REVENUES CLIMB

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 5

 BODY:
After the most harmonious round of budget negotiations in four years, the State Legislature approved a $32.08 billion budget today that many lawmakers proclaimed as the start of a fiscal recovery for New York State.
A late infusion of new money, generated at least partly by an economy that is growing faster than originally projected, allowed the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to provide an increase of $330 million to the state's schools over the last school year, to eliminate suggested cuts in Medicaid programs and to kill a number of proposed tax increases. 
 The budget meant good news for many residents of New York City, particularly its schoolchildren, but disappointment for Mayor David N. Dinkins, who said today that the state budget would make the city's budget even more difficult to balance.
 
A Bigger Surplus
 As bills were being passed today, it became clear that negotiators managed to strike a budget deal last week only after Mr. Cuomo disclosed that the state would end the 1992-93 fiscal year with a surplus of about $140 million more than had been projected in early March.
When money suddenly appears to help close a budget deal in Albany, suspicions arise that the cash may not really exist. But Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin and the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, said today that they were confident that the budget would be balanced.
"We didn't go out and find money that's illusory or doesn't exist or is monopoly money," said Mr. Weprin, a Queens Democrat. "It's real money."
Some state officials and Wall Street analysts have suggested that the surplus for the fiscal year that ended on March 31 may climb even higher when the State Comptroller releases a final accounting later this month.
 
An Upbeat Mood
 "The tone we've been hearing is that the tax revenue side appears to be strengthening and that the year-end cash balance will be higher," said George W. Leung, managing director of Moody's Investors Service.
Given that the state had to close a budget gap of nearly $3 billion this year, legislators were reluctant to proclaim that the days of wine and roses had returned. But compared with the last three years, when the state's budget recipe has been equal parts of tax increases, spending cuts and political acrimony, the mood in the Capitol today was notably upbeat.
"This is a real turnaround budget," said Assemblyman G. Oliver Koppell, a Bronx Democrat. "It's not a huge improvement in terms of support for the city or for institutions. But it clearly is the end of the deterioration of support."
Mr. Cuomo, who may run for a fourth four-year term next year, declared in a statement that "New York State is on the way back."
The general fund budget of $32.08 billion passed by the Legislature represents an increase of 3.5 percent over last year's budget and of 1.8 percent over the $31.5 billion proposed by Mr. Cuomo. The general fund consists of money raised by state taxes, fees and other revenues.
The total state budget of $59.99 billion, which includes Federal money, is an increase of 8 percent over last year and of 1.5 percent over Mr. Cuomo's proposal of $59.1 billion.
The budget features a four-year, $21.2 billion transportation program, a constitutional amendment to change the state's debt practices and an increase of 17 cents a pack in cigarette taxes. But Mr. Cuomo and the legislative leaders said the most enduring success may be the change made in education financing.
The state's complex school aid formula was changed to direct more money to districts with high percentages of poor students and high property tax burdens. Because of the new money available, only a handful of districts lost money in the process.
New York City's proportion of the state's total school aid rose for the first time in a number of years, to 35.1 percent from 34.8 percent. Long Island's percentage fell to 12.8 from 13 percent. Districts in upstate New York stayed steady at 52 percent.
New York City officials conceded that the increase this year would be incremental. But they said the new formula should eventually help the city, which has 37 percent of the state's students, to receive an equitable share of state aid.
While city school officials were pleased, Mr. Dinkins was not. He said his budget would be hurt by inaction on Mr. Cuomo's proposal for the state to take over local Medicaid costs, by heavy cuts in probation funds and by the state's demand that the city increase its financing for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
"An initial review of the state budget suggests that it does not make our own decisions easier but, instead, tougher," Mr. Dinkins said.
The money that appeared since Mr. Cuomo proposed his budget in January allowed the Legislature to add significant funds to a variety of programs of particular importance to New York City.
It added $8.2 million to the $10 million increase proposed by Mr. Cuomo for AIDS prevention and treatment programs, meaning an increase of 46 percent over last year's level. It restored almost $25 million the Governor had proposed cutting from the Tuition Assistance Program, meaning there will be no change in eligibility standards for needy college students.
The budget for the State Council on the Arts, which Mr. Cuomo proposed cutting by $2.8 million, now will get an increase of $3.2 million over last year for grants to local arts organizations. The Liberty Partnerships program, aimed at keeping students from dropping out of school, received a $2 million increase instead of the $7.5 million cut proposed by Mr. Cuomo.
Perhaps the best indication of the improved economic climate is that the Democratic-majority Assembly, never known as a friend of commercial landlords, agreed to make changes in the way that the state's gains tax is calculated on the sale of expensive buildings, saving property sellers an estimated $25 million.
As in even the toughest budget years, the legislators found plenty of money for pork. Among the hundreds of additions made by the Legislature to Mr. Cuomo's budget were a $250,000 grant to the National Soccer Hall of Fame in Oneonta and $2,500 to Farmingdale Midget Football.
Those grants are in addition to the $48 million in so-called member items that legislators will appropriate later in the year, with much of the money for favored projects in their districts.
Shortly after the budget was passed, Mr. Weprin and Mr. Marino said in separate news conferences that they would support formation of a commission to study the possibility of giving raises to legislators. New York's lawmakers, who currently make a base salary of $57,500 a year and leadership stipends of between $6,500 and $30,000, are the highest paid in the country. They have not received a raise since 1989.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "HIGHLIGHTS: The 1993 New York State Budget"
 
The budget totals $59.99 billion, including $32 billion in the general fund. Among its highlights, the budget agreement does the following:
 
TAXES - Increases the tax on cigarettes to 56 cents a pack.
 
EDUCATION - Changes school-aid formula togive $330 million more to local school districts, with a higher proportion going to poorer ones.
 
TRANSPORTATION - Calls for spending $20.9 billion over four years, including $10 billion for highways, roads and bridges and $9.56 billion to fully finance the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's capital plan, as well as other money to avert fare increases on subways, buses and commuter railroads in and around New York City.
 
DEBT REFORM - Calls for a constitutional amendment on the ballot, probably in 1995, to change the state's debt practices, eliminating "backdoor borrowing," where the state uses a public authority to finance capital projects rather than direct money.

HEADLINE: EUROPEANS URGED TO PRESSURE SERBS

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, April 5

 BODY:
Lord Owen, the European Community's mediator on the Balkans, called today for "relentless pressure" to be placed on Bosnian Serbs to make them accept a peace plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina, but he cautioned against lifting the arms embargo on Bosnian Muslims.
After briefing community foreign ministers meeting in Luxembourg, Lord Owen said a political solution was still possible in Bosnia, and he criticized a suggestion by Secretary of State Warren Christopher that the arms embargo on Bosnian Muslims might be lifted "quite soon." 
 "I think you've got to be very careful about this idea," he said, recalling a warning by the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, that such a policy could produce "a level killing field."
Interviewed on the NBC News program "Today," Mr. Christopher said the Bosnian Serbs' refusal to accept the peace plan, which has already been signed by Bosnian Muslims and Croats, could lead Washington to go "to our allies and see if we could find a consensus for lifting the arms embargo."
Lord Owen said at a news conference in Luxembourg that delivery of advanced weapons to Bosnian Muslims could backfire if they fell into the hands of Bosnian Croats and Bosnian Serbs.
When the Clinton Administration broached the idea of lifting the arms embargo earlier this year, Britain and France, fearing Serbian retaliation, threatened to withdraw the troops they have sent to Bosnia to guard the delivery of relief supplies.
A senior Western official said London believes if the arms embargo was lifted "the plug would probably have to be pulled" on the relief aid effort.
Lord Owen said, "This is a time to put relentless pressure on the Bosnian Serbs and on the governments of Serbia and Montenegro to come and accept the plan which has been placed before them."
Earlier today, the Western European Union, a 10-nation regional defense group, stepped up pressure on Belgrade by agreeing to send speedboats manned by police and customs officers to patrol the Danube in Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria to tighten sanctions against Serbia.
The move followed persistent reports that barges and other vessels were carrying oil and other necessities to Serbia and Montenegro through the Danube's international waters.

HEADLINE: Philadelphia Climbs Out of Fiscal Depths and Builds by Sharing Sacrifices

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, April 5

 BODY:
This city, long known for incompetent government, has made one of the most stunning turnarounds in recent urban history, experts say. Last week, its leaders announced it would end the year with a balanced budget for the first time in seven years.
Almost as startling, urban specialists say, Philadelphia has ended its prolonged fiscal crisis in just 15 months and has done it with an unprecedented amount of political harmony and public support, in spite of asking voters to absorb a higher sales tax and public employees to agree to wage concessions. 
 "Philadelphia is really showing the rest of America's major cities what you can do without help from the statehouse or the White House," said George Sternlieb, a retired professor of urban planning from Rutgers University. "Hopefully, the macabre burlesque that masqueraded as politics in Philadelphia is over."
 
A City in Collapse
 Flashing back to January 1992, here is where the burlesque stood when the new Mayor, Edward G. Rendell, came on stage:
With the city nearly a quarter-billion dollars in debt, City Hall had run out of virtually everything, from postage stamps for its letters to trousers for its police recruits. Elected officials were bickering, union leaders were refusing to concede anything and Wall Street investors had long since shut off the city's credit. Pennsylvania refused to bail Philadelphia out, and local officials were at loggerheads with a new state agency that was supposed to oversee the city's finances.
Mr. Rendell, a former prosecutor who had been elected Philadelphia's 127th Mayor with 68 percent of the vote in November 1991, took office with what seemed an impossible proposal. He said the city could save $1 billion over five years by freezing the wages of unionized city employees, slashing health-care spending, laying off scores of political appointees and bringing efficiency to city agencies.
This week it no longer seemed impossible. City officials said there would be no deficit in this year's budget, or in the $2.4 billion budget for next fiscal year, which begins July 1. The new administration has been able to achieve about $220 million in savings in its first year and expects to do the same in each of the next four years.
The traditionally fractious City Council has supported the Mayor's budgets and recovery plan with an unprecedented series of unanimous votes.
And last Tuesday, an arbitration panel forced police officers to accept a contract, similar to agreements negotiated last fall with non-uniformed city workers, that freezes wages for three years, eliminates four holidays and reduces the cost of health benefits without reducing care.
 
Wall Street Nods Approval
 Philadelphia's fiscal crisis is not officially over, but experts here and on Wall Street say it is under control and could end as early as the middle of next year. That is when credit-rating agencies will consider giving the city a rating that could guarantee it access to the municipal bond market.
"The only test for the city is to keep up the momentum," said Michael L. Johnston, a vice president of Moody's Investors Service, the credit rating agency on Wall Street.
Mr. Rendell said the fight to save Philadelphia had just begun. For one thing, the city's economy continues to hemorrhage jobs. Last year it lost 17,700, or 2.5 percent of all the jobs in its economy. The planned closing of the Philadelphia Navy Base by 1997, plus other proposed closings of military installations, would cost 17,500 jobs directly and an estimated 40,000 related jobs.
But last week was a time for most Philadelphians, who have felt saddled with inept government for decades, to take a vacation from worry and cynicism and even dare to say something nice about their leaders.
"Ed Rendell has even made me believe that it is possible for government to solve some of these intractable urban problems," said Randall M. Miller, a political analyst and professor of political science at St. Joseph's University here.
 
Coalition With Business
 Nowhere is this sense stronger than among business leaders. Mr. Rendell formed a committee of people from business and universities to recommend improvements, and he promised to use their suggestions. So when the panel reported that 40 percent of the Parking Authority's 750 employees were not on the job at any given time and recommended eliminating many patronage jobs, it resulted in the city administration's laying off 123 political appointees last month, for a saving of $4.6 million a year.
Mr. Rendell gives credit to the City Council President, John Street, who helped mold the recovery program and then led the Council in its series of unanimous votes. "Without him, we wouldn't have made it," the Mayor said.
The Council votes were won with tough and clever politics and public relations. With his two-thirds electoral victory, Mr. Rendell has a powerful mandate from voters to make changes, as do the 6 newly elected members of the 17-member council. The newcomers all campaigned on the need for changes in city government.
Similar pressures were brought to bear on city-employee unions. In his campaign, Mr. Rendell emphasized that 60 percent of the city budget was in personnel costs and that concessions would have to be made. When non-uniformed city employees resisted and went on strike, they were met with resounding public antagonism, and called off their strike after 16 hours.
 
Spreading the Sacrifices
 Mr. Rendell, a Democrat, was born in Manhattan 49 years ago and served as District Attorney of Philadelphia from 1977 to 1985. He ran unsuccessful races for governor and mayor, losing to W. Wilson Goode in the 1987 mayoral primary. Mr. Goode, the city's first black mayor, served two four-year terms and was barred by law from seeking a third term.
Mayor Rendell has retained his popularity by asking for sacrifice across a wide spectrum, said Frederick L. Voight, executive secretary of the Committee of Seventy, a not-for-profit organization that monitors city government.
"The beauty of the plan is that it spreads the pain out so that no one neighborhood is taking it on the chin," he said. "Rather than close a fire house, he cut back on the manning of fire trucks. Rather than close a library or district health center, he curtailed services."
This is not to say there are not voices of dissent. "Recall! Recall!" hundreds of demonstrators chanted at City Hall in January after Mr. Rendell outlined a new round of service reductions.
Fiscal experts say the city's budgets, previously based on wishful thinking and accounting gimmicks, are now realistic. "There are no smoke or mirrors in these budgets," said Bernard E. Anderson, chairman of the Pennsylvania Intergovernmental Cooperation Authority, the state fiscal agency that monitors city finances.
Last year the authority helped put the city on the road to recovery by raising money on Wall Street on Philadelphia's behalf to help the city pay its debts of $225 million and to also finance $250 million for capital improvement projects. The sales tax increase of 1 percent is paying for this borrowing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Edward G. Rendell of Philadelphia, left, has worked with other city officials in producing a balanced budget for the first time in seven years. He spoke with John Street, the City Council President, center, and David L. Cohen, the Mayor's chief of staff, at a budget meeting on Saturday. (Bill Cramer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fujimori Sees a Peaceful, and a Prosperous, Peru

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, April 5

 BODY:
Expressing "not the slightest regret" about seizing expanded powers one year ago today, President Alberto K. Fujimori says his authoritarian moves are rapidly pacifying Peru and setting the stage for a free-market economic boom here in the mid-1990's.
"Today we have 95 percent of the Shining Path leadership behind bars," the Peruvian leader said in an interview on Sunday night. "By 1995, the Shining Path will be completely eradicated as an organized group." 
 "There's a close relationship between the fight against terrorism and the fight to restore economic growth," Mr. Fujimori said. "No amount of foreign aid, no economic plan -- no matter how well designed -- will have a beneficial effect if terrorism is not stopped."
On April 5, 1992, Mr. Fujimori closed courts and the congress, asserting that he needed greater powers to combat corruption, cocaine trafficking and a surging rebellion by the Maoist Shining Path guerrillas. The moves pushed his local public approval rating to 81 percent. But the outside world recoiled in face of the constitutional break.
 
Scores High in Polls
 One year later, Peru's austere leader seemed relaxed and confident as he fielded questions. Today, polls still give Mr. Fujimori approval ratings of 62 to 67 percent, among the highest for any leader in the Americas.
"What has been demonstrated is that here in Peru the people want a strong government that creates social and economic order," he said in the clipped Spanish of a man whose parents immigrated here from Japan in the 1930's. "People want a government that gives security to all the population and that gives guarantees to investors. I am confident that Peru is going to be one of Latin America's most developed nations in a few years."
Endorsing the President's claim to have improved public order, a private human rights group reports that guerrilla attacks nationwide fell from 126 in January to 36 in March. Indicating that 12 years of guerrilla violence is far from ending, however, 11 people -- 7 police officers, 3 soldiers and 1 civilian -- died today in a guerrilla attack near the northern city of Trujillo. On Friday, 12 guerrillas were killed in a battle with soldiers in the Amazon.
On the international front, the inauguration in January of a new Congress thawed aid that had been frozen last year. Last month, with the United States providing crucial financial and political support, Peru repaid debts to the World Bank and to the International Monetary Fund and re-entered the international financial community after a six-year absence.
But Peru's human rights record is expected to cause continued friction with the United States and Europe.
"Peru's already troubled human rights situation has become significantly worse," Americas Watch, a human rights group based in New York, asserted in a report made public today.
The report criticized Mr. Fujimori for closing prisons to international human rights observers, for instituting a "rubber stamp" Congress, for publicly branding human rights leaders as "tools" of terrorists and for allowing the police to kill 39 guerrilla inmates in a prison crackdown last May.
"A series of antiterrorism measures virtually do away with due-process rights for those accused of terrorism, crimes whose definitions have been broadened to encompass peaceful dissent, human rights defense and investigative reporting," the report continued. "Peruvian human rights groups believe that hundreds of innocent Peruvians are now jailed."
Mr. Fujimori defended the antiterrorism decree on Sunday, saying the military courts had allowed his Government in the last six months to try and to sentence to life in prison the top leadership of Peru's two guerrilla groups, the Shining Path and the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement.
"Before April 5, judges freed no fewer than 200 terrorists who returned to committing crimes," he said, echoing a common complaint about the inefficiency of Peru's old court system.
"In 1991, the Supreme Court even declared Abimael Guzman free of any guilt," he continued, referring to the Shining Path's leader, now serving a life sentence in a specially built prison.
Admitting that his Government had suffered from "inertia" on human rights, the Peruvian President promised to improve his country's record. He said that the International Committee of the Red Cross could resume visits to prisoners convicted of terrorist crimes and that he hoped to see convictions for the forced disappearances of prisoners.
Although Peru continues to lead the world in recorded disappearances, the number of prisoners who disappeared after arrest dropped sharply last year, to 112 from 304 in 1991. Mr. Fujimori predicted that the new Congress would approve a law instituting the death penalty for terrorist crimes.
"In the presence of the crimes that these gang leaders commit, I think its application is necessary," Mr. Fujimori said.
Already, he said, the threat of life imprisonment had encouraged 200 guerrillas to desert in the first three months of this year.
 
A Conflict Over Drugs
 On another point of friction with the United States, the cultivation in Peru of the raw material for cocaine, Mr. Fujimori said cooperation between the two countries had "very poor results."
The United States Congress is moving to cut in half a $387 million request by the Bush Administration for antidrug aid to the Andean countries. But Mr. Fujimori said coca leaf production can only be reduced through more aid -- more radar for airborne interception and more highway construction to make profitable the cultivation of legal crops like rice and corn.
"The new American policy sounds like a big mistake," he said.
With terrorism easing, conditions are more attractive for foreigners to invest, Mr. Fujimori said.
Over the next year, the Peruvian Government's plans to auction off state-run mines and electricity and telephone companies. The sales will not only help Peru balance its budget and reduce inflation, now running at 57 percent a year, but will also provide more cash for social spending. In one highly popular program, the President recently started to inaugurate one new school a week.

HEADLINE: Aid Recipe For Russia: Add a Ton Of Savvy

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARATOV, Russia

 BODY:
Charles Bennett, West Point class of 1962, trained as a navigator bombardier on a B-52, preparing to drop nuclear bombs on the Soviet Union. Today, at 54, he is a Peace Corps volunteer in the small city of Kamyshin on the Volga River, teaching Russians how to create small businesses in a market economy.
"I had a military flavor to my life," he said, rubbing a hand over his graying mustache. "The idea was to protect America, kill the enemy and not be friends. But now the big threat is over, and it's a hell of a reversal. Here I am now eating dinner at the tables of people I was willing to turn into dust." 
 Well before the Vancouver summit meeting, President Clinton promised more aid to Russia, including exchanges of retired American business executives and other experts to help Russians make the transition to a market economy. Mr. Bennett is an example of the help that the United States has already provided.
Still military trim, he came from Salem, Ore., one of the first Peace Corps volunteers sent to Russia. Two offices have been set up under the program, which is a result of President Boris N. Yeltsin's visit to Washington last June. The first opened here, with 45 volunteers working in five cities along the Volga River, and the second, in Vladivostok, is the base for 49 volunteers in the Far East.
 
Nuclear Target for U.S.
 Both Saratov and Kamyshin were closed cities, and Saratov, an ICBM center of about 950,000 people with up to 70 percent of its industry military-related, was almost surely an American nuclear target. Mr. Bennett, more than most younger volunteers, is aware of the distance already traveled in the nascent Russian-American friendship, as well as the stakes involved.
"For the younger people, it's a thrill for them to be here," he said. "But they don't understand what it was like. To be ready to punch the button, and now to try to make Russians' lives better, to turn it around enough so it can't be turned around again. There are a lot of assumptions in the West that the ball game is over. But it's not over."
Karen A. Woodbury, 50, the Peace Corps director for western Russia, has been in and out of the organization for the last 15 years, most recently in Mali. "When they offered me Russia," she said, "I almost hung up the phone."
She's been in Saratov since Novemner, setting up with 4 American and 15 Russian staff members. They provided volunteers a three-month language and culture course in a rest house of the SEPO company, a military behemoth now turning out more Saratov-brand refrigerators than sophisticated electronics.
"The strong point is that the volunteers don't work for the Peace Corps, but for local authorities," Ms. Woodbury said. She is aware that Russians were told that the Peace Corps, started by President Kennedy in 1961 as another weapon in the ideological struggle with the Soviet Union, was used to gather intelligence. "Some of the old guard would rather we not be here," she said, "but most people are very receptive."
 
Advice Center Set Up
 The volunteers range from Harry Langerman, 79, a retired businessman, to Asad Haroon, 29, of the San Francisco area, who emigrated from Pakistan at 17 and signed up for the Peace Corps a week after becoming an American citizen. Sworn in on Feb. 13, they are expected to work here for two years, but as volunteers may leave when they like. But they have already been overwhelmed with Russian hospitality and curiosity, hardly surprising in a city that was closed to all foreigners until last year.
The five volunteers in Saratov have set up a small-business advice center on the sixth floor of a government building, living in a hostel in a former Communist Party training center and looking for apartments. They are paid in rubles at roughly the rate of a local employee; they are already struggling to cope with Russia's 25-percent-a-month inflation.
"So we've got to get out of the dollar mode," Mr. Bennett said. "When we pay 250 rubles for a Snickers bar," or about 38 cents, "it's a big decision."
Mr. Bennett, who has been eating a lot of Russian salami and eggs, has already cracked a tooth on a chunk of bone, so he came to Saratov to have it seen to. "Well," he said, "I joined the Peace Corps, not Club Med."
David Robeck, 39, a banker who grew up "a preacher's kid in sin city," Las Vegas, has already moved in with a local family. The mother is a nurse and gives him an evening massage. "They only speak Russian," he said, grinning, "so I can't really say no."
Kristina Gunnill, a New Yorker who worked for Young & Rubicam for 20 years, shook her head. "In the hostel we haven't had any heat or hot water for two days."
Already advising local advertising agencies, she said: "In a way, I felt I was living too well in New York, that my world was trivial. I didn't really need three closets full of clothes. There is an element of spiritual development to it all, no question. I didn't get all the credentials I've got to serve no one but myself. And advertising is the leading edge of the capitalist economy."
It is difficult to scale down to a ruble salary, she said, to general sighs of agreement. "But I haven't had one minute of wondering if it was a bad decision."
 
Expertise Is in Demand
 Richard Gonzalez, an industrial quality engineer from East Lansing, Mich., who worked for General Motors, I.T.T. and Roper, laughed and said he had second thoughts every second. He had come to a point in his career where "I got a lot of recruiting calls, but actually it was for the same old job, just a different city with a different desk," he said.
His expertise is in much demand by Saratov's many foundering factories. "But everything here needs so much attention all at once," he said. "They've all got no raw materials, no product, no market and no clear idea what to build."
Mr. Gonzalez threw up his hands. "You know in America we say, 'It doesn't take a rocket scientist.' Well, I'd never met one. Now I've met hundreds, and a lot of them are driving taxis."

HEADLINE: New York Library Nears Start on Science Center

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The New York Public Library's proposed $100 million Science, Industry and Business Library will provide computer access to worldwide information networks as well as books when it opens in 1995, library officials said yesterday.
At a briefing for contributors and potential contributors, the officials also announced that $59 million of the projected cost had already been raised, before the opening of a formal campaign later this year. The library, which officials said would be the largest public information center devoted solely to science and business, is to be in part of the B. Altman building at East 34th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues. 
 It will be equipped with 100 computer work stations for users to tap into data bases both within and outside the library. There are also plans for an electronic information training center with 26 work stations that will help the public learn how to use data bases. Even the tables in the reading area will be wired to allow users to plug in their own laptop computers, officials said.
 
Round-the-Clock Access
 The library will also offer 24-hour dial-in access for computer users and will provide gateways to the Internet system, a worldwide communications network, as well as electronic journals and electronic bulletin boards.
Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the new chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, who is chairman of the library's fund-raising campaign, said the library would help New York City continue as a center for the financial and communications industries.
He also said the library would help people up the economic ladder by providing easy access to computers and data bases.
"There is a barrier of entry to information technology; you need the hardware and software and an investment of time in training," he said. "We have to overcome those barriers, because computer literacy will be a requirement for a successful career."
The library is to be housed on seven floors in the B. Altman building, a turn-of-the-century structure that has landmark status. Two floors are to be open to the public, with the other five housing 2.5 million books in a research collection. In addition, 80,000 books will be in circulation and 60,000 additional reference works will be available. The library will also contain 110,000 business and scientific journals and periodicals.
 
 
Opening Planned for '95
 Plans for the library were first announced in November 1991. Construction is scheduled to begin in July, and the opening is planned for the fall of 1995.
Officials said they were planning to raise funds from both government and private sources. The city has pledged $10 million and the state $7.5 million, and project officials are trying to raise $7 million from the Federal Government, although only $1.9 million has so far been secured.
The $24.5 million of government financing would be augumented by $25.5 million in long-term debt financed by bonds issued by the State Dormitory Authority. The plan calls for $50 million in private contributions, $14 million of which has been pledged. The largest single private contribution, $7.5 million, was made by Lewis and Dorothy Cullman. He is president of Cullman Ventures Inc., the company that owns Keith Clark, a manufacturer of commercial calendars and diaries.
Marshall Rose, chairman of the New York Public Library, said the new center would ease crowding at the main building at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue. "Right now we have people sitting on the floors waiting to use our equipment," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The B. Altman building at East 34th Street and Fifth Avenue will house the New York Science, Industry and Business Library. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mayoral Rivals Debate Crime Fears and Statistics

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins, a mathematician by training, believes numbers do not lie. So he paused during a recent campaign speech to explain at length, once again, the verity that to him is as plain as day: crime is down in New York.
"Look at the numbers," he implored the audience. "Twenty-seven months of straight decline." 
 The Mayor's frustration is understandable. While he has tried to take credit again and again for the 12 percent decline in reported crime since he took office, his political rivals continue to scoff at the statistics and to insist that his administration has failed to stanch lawlessness.
 
A Dominant Theme
 As the mayoral campaign evolves over the next seven months, the debate over crime is likely to be one of its dominant themes. The crime figures can be expected to be a flash point of dispute among the candidates, but what may count more than the statistics is the public's perception of crime. Mr. Dinkins's challengers, reading their private polls, argue that people do not feel safer, no matter what the Mayor's numbers show.
"He declares victory on crime, and people laugh at him," said Rudolph W. Giuliani, the likely Republican candidate, in a recent interview.
Mr. Dinkins, having won office on a promise to be tough on crime and having weathered a first year as Mayor dominated by a vicious wave of violence, now would clearly like to claim a modest victory and divert the debate in this year's election to education and jobs.
"We know the perception in some quarters may be different," he said almost apologetically in a speech to the Citizens Budget Commission, a private organization. "Without suggesting we are satisfied, people need to know that crime is in fact down. The fact is there is not a crime wave, and crime is down and we have got to some way or other make that point."
 
'Reality on the Streets'
 Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President, who is challenging Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic primary, says Mr. Dinkins is out of touch with the fears of most voters. "People will judge this issue by their everyday lives and what they really feel and not by statistics," he said. "Dinkins is only going to lose on this issue. The reality on the streets is that people are worried about crime."
Mr. Dinkins contends that he has effectively responded to the crisis that confronted him as he took office, when a record 2,245 homicides were reported in his first year in office. He has hired more than 3,000 new police officers at a time when fiscal hardships forced him to cut other agencies and has pressed the Police Department to shift to a "cop on the beat" policing strategy. The result, he asserts, is that the number of major crimes reported to the police has steadily declined in every category for the first time in 36 years.
But Mr. Dinkins's rivals are quick to point out that the drop in crime rates for the last two years comes on the heels of record high numbers. Even with the improvement, they argue, crime in the city stands where it was during the Koch administration.
 
Fewer Arrests
 They also say reports of crime are down in part because the Police Department is arresting fewer people, a consequence of the Dinkins administration's shift to preventive policing practices aimed at deterring crime rather than arresting droves of street-level addicts and drug dealers.
Since Mr. Dinkins took office, arrests for narcotics possession and trafficking have dropped by 31 percent, while arrests for other felonies have declined nearly 17 percent, Police Department statistics show.
Mr. Giuliani and Herman Badillo, the former Congressman from the Bronx who is also challenging the Mayor, have argued that fewer arrests translate into fewer reported crimes because arrested criminals often turn in their colleagues or confess to unreported crimes.
But several criminologists disputed that argument. Hubert Williams, the president of the Police Foundation in Washington, said the drop in arrests could not account for an across-the-board decline in reported crime. That is because some crimes, notably murder and car theft, are almost invariably reported to the police and the number of such reports would not be affected by the overall rate of arrests in the city. "It has to be more involved than that," he said.
Several other crime experts said the city's sustained two-year decline in reported crime must mirror some decrease in actual crime because the amount of crime that goes unreported nationwide has stayed fairly stable for the last 10 years -- about 38 percent of all crimes and about 48 percent of violent crimes, according to Justice Department surveys.
While Mr. Dinkins will never be able to prove his policies have curbed crime, many crime experts said the changes the Mayor has made in the police force are a plausible explanation for at least some of the decline.
In the end, the truth about whether the Mayor has managed to cut crime may not matter in the world of campaigning, political strategists say. Politicians must grapple first with voters' perceptions, and polls have told Mr. Dinkins's challengers that most people are still afraid of crime.
"The crime issue is almost a constant," said Lou Harris, the poll taker. "It kind of lives with people all the time."
He said that for the last decade about two-thirds of New York City voters have consistently ranked crime as their top worry, although other issues like the economy and education have risen in importance in the last year. In general, he said, the public's perception of crime lags far behind statistical trends.
That perception could spell trouble for Mr. Dinkins, Mr. Harris said. Polls indicate that voters most fearful of crime are also those most likely to vote against Mayor Dinkins, especially among white voters. "In that sense, it is a cutting issue," he said. "There is no question that those who feel the most insecure about crime are not voting for the Mayor."
So far, Mr. Giuliani's tactic has been to play down the statistics, arguing that the decreases are too small to make a difference in most people's lives. He also points out that crime in schools, contrary to the citywide trend, has risen sharply. "The real problem for the Mayor is that the numbers he's talking about you just can't declare victory," he said.
Mr. Stein, a liberal on most social issues, has tried to turn the issue to his advantage by criticizing Mr. Dinkins for not having enough drug arrests made to fill city jails to capacity. He would return to a policy popular under Mayor Edward I. Koch of making mass arrests of low-level drug dealers and users, he said.
"These jails he closed I would open and fill them up with the drug dealers," he said.
Mr. Badillo has accused Mr. Dinkins of abandoning some streets in poor neighborhoods to small-time drug dealers. "There is no value to having community policing unless community police are authorized to make street drug arrests," he said.
 
A Green Light?
 Roy Innis, a conservative candidate for the Democratic nomination, said Mr. Dinkins was trying to delude the public. He said making fewer lower-level drug arrests would be a misguided policy that would give a green light to youths considering going into narcotics trafficking.
Suzanne Trazoff, a Police Department spokeswoman, acknowledged that the police have backed off from making mass arrests for trafficking in or possessing narcotics, mostly because the ranks of narcotics officers have been winnowed to put more uniformed officers on the street.
For his part, Mr. Dinkins said of the crime figures: "If they were up in all seven major index categories, I'm sure it would be my fault."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Leslie Fay filed for bankruptcy protection, two months after the apparel maker disclosed an accounting scandal that had made profits out of losses and had masked declining sales. [Page D1.]
General Motors appointed its chief financial officer to take over the duties of Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the aggressive head of worldwide purchasing who left for Volkswagen. [D1.]

HEADLINE: A PLUTONIUM PACT WILL AID DISPOSAL

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
Seeking a new path to East-West disarmament, Russian and American experts have agreed to team up to develop and build a new type of reactor that can burn plutonium from nuclear warheads and turn the deadly bomb fuel into electricity. The $1.5 billion nuclear reactor would be built in Russia and fueled at least partly by plutonium from Moscow's huge stockpile of scrapped nuclear arms.
The initiative, led by General Atomics of San Diego, requires up to $100 million over five years from the American Government, which is studying the general idea of burning plutonium and, separately, whether to support the East-West reactor plan. The small reactor would be cooled by helium and is advertised as immune to meltdown. 
 Until the plan was unveiled yesterday, excess plutonium from Russian nuclear disarmament was largely slated to be stored, leading some specialists to fear it could fall into unfriendly hands. The reactor plan is seen as offering an alternative path of disposal.
 
Issue Pushed for Summit
 An agreement between General Atomics and the Russian Ministry for Atomic Energy to form a reactor-building venture was signed in Moscow Thursday and made public by General Atomics yesterday. Top Russian officials are said to have pushed hard to have the issue discussed this past weekend at the Vancouver summit.
It is not known whether the topic was aired, although President Clinton made clear he favors expanded technical cooperation.
"This reactor offers a very attractive opportunity to destroy weapon-grade plutonium and simultaneously to produce electricity," Neil Blue, chairman of General Atomics, said in an interview.
"The joint venture will provide stabilizing employment of Russian scientists and engineers previously engaged in making nuclear weapons and will contribute to the conversion of Russia's nuclear-weapons industry into a force for peaceful economic reconstruction."
 
Some Are Opposed
 In contrast, Paul Leventhal, president of the Nuclear Control Institute, a private group based in Washington, said he was strongly opposed to any form of plutonium burning.
"We see this as a major diversion in trying to get plutonium out of commerce," he said in an interview. "It's better to turn it into glass and bury it," a reference to the process used for disposal.
The initiative parallels joint plans already under way to burn Russia's vast surplus of uranium, another fuel of nuclear warheads.
Last year, the Bush Administration announced a deal with Russia to buy much of its highly enriched uranium from nuclear arms so it could be diluted into fuel for civilian power plants. That agreement is snarled in bureaucratic red tape.
 
A Nuclear Pioneer
 General Atomics is a pioneer in the nuclear industry with a strong track record of working successfully with the Russians. Last year it became the conduit by which the Federal Government began to tap Russia's scientific talent, hiring more than a hundred Russian scientists to help America harness the vast energy of nuclear fusion.
Now General Atomics says it has a design for a modular, high-temperature, gas-cooled, fission reactor that could burn weapons-grade plutonium, destroying up to 95 percent of the fuel and leaving the residue mired in a radioactive brew highly unattractive for turning back into bomb fuel. Unlike uranium, weapons-grade plutonium cannot be easily diluted into reactor fuel but can be burned directly in its concentrated form.
The new reactor is seen as highly efficient, turning about 50 percent of its generated heat into electricity. Most commercial nuclear power plants have an efficiency of about 33 percent. The reactor's super-heated helium would directly turn a turbine to produce electricity, rather than heating an intermediary such as water to do that work.
The reactor should take ten years to design and build. Its designers say the machine is intrinsically safe because its physical characteristics make it immune to meltdown, the most feared reactor accident.
 
Sealed Off From Surroundings
 The key safety feature is that plutonium fuel, while not chemically dilutable, is broken into billions of tiny bits, each of which is the size of a grain of salt and is covered with a tough ceramic shell that can withstand unusually high temperatures. The grains are repackaged in a way that allows them to serve as a fuel element.
The new reactor is seen as the first of a new generation of small reactors that could be built not only in Russia but around the world.
Reactors that can burn weapons-grade plutonium are now under study by the Federal Department of Energy, the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment and the National Academy of Sciences, a private group that advises the Government.
Dr. Thomas B. Cochrane, a nuclear specialist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private group in Washington, said it was unlikely the Clinton Administration would move rapidly to back the reactor plan since the general idea of burning weapons-grade plutonium was currently being studied intensively.
He added that the idea had merit, but only if burning plutonium from nuclear weapons could be done without spurring the growth of a commercial market in the deadly material.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Marlboro's 2-Fisted Pitch

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Ever see a cowboy try to walk a tightrope? Philip Morris is about to ask the Marlboro cowboy -- perhaps the world's best-known advertising icon -- to perform that daunting feat.
Philip Morris is trying to pull off two seemingly contradictory strategies for its best-selling but troubled Marlboro cigarette brand. The company is promoting Marlboros with cents-off coupons, discounted pricing and merchandise giveaways, which tend to increase sales and market share in the short term at the expense of profitability. At the same time, however, it will continue to run slick, image-building advertisements in the mainstream media to enhance the brand's personality over the long haul.
 
 
Like a Political Candidate
 It's not unlike a candidate who tries to win an election by attacking his or her opponent in a fiery speech in the morning and then pays for warm and fuzzy, mom-and-apple-pie commercials to appear that evening. 
 Philip Morris stunned the consumer marketing world last week when it disclosed an extensive and aggressive promotional program to revive sales of Marlboros, which have wilted under a relentless onslaught from cheaper brands. The promotion will come atop a relentless flood of magazine and newspaper ads, bus shelter posters and store displays, inundating consumers with the latest versions of its famous 29-year-old Marlboro Country campaign, replete with Western imagery from cowpokes to spurs.
Whether the cowboy can keep his footing remains to be seen. "From a strategic standpoint, it's a very gutsy move," Ellen Merlo, vice president of corporate affairs at Philip Morris U.S.A. in New York, said yesterday. "It shows we've made a long-term commitment to our flagship brand and our business."
Ms. Merlo, who formerly served as vice president of marketing services, acknowledged that Philip Morris's ardent pursuit of both strategies at once had its risks.
"But we're committed to doing both," she said, "and I think we're very capable of doing both."
"There may not be a lot of trademarks in the world that could do it," she added. "But Marlboro has such a strong image, we are able to overlay the promotions with our advertising."
Gary Stibel, founder and principal at the New England Consulting Group, a marketing management consulting company in Westport, Conn., agreed with Ms. Merlo's optimism.
"Philip Morris defended the profitability of its cigarette business as long and hard as it could," he said. "Now they've recognized the handwriting on the wall."
His reference was to the way cheaper brands, like Doral, Bucks, Viceroy and Bull Durham, have drastically altered the rules in the nation's $45 billion cigarette market. These brands can cost as much as a dollar a pack less than premium brands like Marlboro.
"You can argue till hell freezes over that they waited too long," Mr. Stibel added. "Still, it's smart. And, rather than pussyfooting around, they're taking aggressive action."
Chris Sutherland, executive director of the Promotion Marketing Association of America, a trade organization in New York, said Philip Morris's radical shift in strategies typified the changes overtaking consumer marketing as a result of the weak American economy.
"It's a new world," he said, citing a recent survey by the association in which 88 percent of senior marketing executives responded that promotions aimed at consumers could help, rather than hinder, the brand-building aspects of television commercials and print advertisements.
"It's no longer either-or," Mr. Sutherland added. "You now see marketers doing both all the time."
Mr. Sutherland emphasized that for promotions and advertising to work in tandem, they must be carefully created and planned to be complementary. "If you design it poorly, the promotion can hurt a brand's equity," he said.
"But guess what, so can bad advertising -- or a bad product."
Ms. Merlo said that as part of Marlboro's sales strategies, a huge promotion that began in January, called the Marlboro Adventure Team, would be extended, offering consumers merchandise like jacket and watches adorned with Marlboro logos in exchange for product codes from packages.
The promotion has already generated orders for 600,000 items of merchandise, she said, as well as more than 300,000 entries in an Adventure Team contest. Estimates are that Philip Morris has already spent up to $200 million on the promotion -- which is believed to be a record sum for such a short-term sales strategy.
And Marlboro's ad campaign, by Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago, will be maintained, and spending will increase this year, Ms. Merlo said. The brand's ad budget is already enormous, with spending reaching an estimated $125 million last year.
Burnett in recent months has been bringing out fresh executions of the familiar Marlboro Country print and outdoor efforts, including revamped designs for ads for Marlboro Lights and regular red Marlboros.
Although Brandweek, a trade publication, reported this week that Philip Morris would introduce later this year a lower-priced filtered version of Marlboro called Marlboro Express, Ms. Merlo described it as only "one of the options we looked at" before deciding last week to proceed with the twin strategies of promotions and ads for existing varieties of Marlboro.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Philip Morris's new campaign will be going in two directions at once: Western image-building continues with price promotions and giveaways.

HEADLINE: Fundamentalism: the 20th Century's Last Ideology

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
Scholars used to dismiss fundamentalism as a fossilized form of old-time religion, destined to dissolve in the acids of science and skepticism.
But from the Iranian revolution and the rise of the religious right in the United States to the militancy of Jewish settlers on the West Bank and the riots that followed a Hindu-led destruction of a mosque in India, events of the past two decades make it clear that religious fundamentalism has done anything but dissolve. As one scholar recently put it, fundamentalism is "dynamic, adaptive and modern," perhaps the last great ideological upsurge of the 20th century. 
 What were once viewed as unrelated religious movements -- indeed, often condemning one another's doctrines -- are increasingly recognized as sharing a set of fundamentalist "family resemblances" that cut across religious traditions. Scholars and policy makers hope that by comparing fundamentalist movements, a new field of study will afford insights into the dynamics that spark militant religious revivals, drive them into politics, fuel their growth or brake their influence.
 
Threats and Outsiders
 No one expects these studies to yield neat "laws" of fundamentalism, and scholars insist that the specific traits of movements as different as Pentecostal Christians in Central America and Muslim guerrillas in Afghanistan should not get lost in a stretch for common denominators.
But when 35 political scientists, sociologists of religion and specialists in Asia, the Middle East and Latin America gathered in Chicago in March for the final session of a five-year examination of fundamentalism, most agreed that there were common threads. Unlike traditional believers, the scholars said, fundamentalists are consciously counterattacking against the threats of secularism and modernity, threats often identified with outsiders.
Most fundamentalists do not reject modernity in principle. Often they embrace the most up-to-date techniques of communications and organization to spread their message. But they may well seize on minor elements of a religious tradition, like a specific way of dressing, to symbolically distinguish the faithful from the uncommitted.
These conclusions emerged from the Fundamentalism Project, a broad effort sponsored by the American Academy of Arts and Sciences that enlisted more than 200 scholars since 1988 to examine fundamentalist movements in seven major religions and across five continents.
Other "family resemblances" outlined by the group, which met at the University of Chicago Divinity School, included moral dualism -- a view of the world as sharply divided between embattled camps of good and evil -- in which fundamentalists see themselves as a divinely called group, set apart from others, bound to a strict code of behavior and frequently subject to a charismatic leader.
The scholars said the "Abrahamic" forms of fundamentalism -- Jewish, Christian and Muslim -- constantly affirm the absolute truth of a sacred text or authoritative tradition. These fundamentalisms also emphasize messianic or millennial beliefs in a miraculous culmination of history, with good reigning triumphantly.
Similarly, some Hindu and Buddhist movements are beginning to create a "synthetic fundamentalism" by highlighting crucial texts or looking toward a coming triumph.
Yet, even after five years of the Fundamentalism Project, not all the scholars were comfortable with stretching a single label from American Protestant adherents of a strictly literal reading of the Bible to politically resurgent Muslim groups in North Africa, Sinhalese Buddhist fighters in Sri Lanka and Hindu nationalists in India.
Some warned that the popular equation of fundamentalism with fanaticism was leading governments to develop an ideology of "anti-fundamentalism," justifying human-rights abuses against religious opponents.
 
Divided Over Strategy
 The group also divided over whether fundamentalist movements aggressively seeking power could be nudged toward moderation by outsiders.
Martin Kramer of Tel Aviv University questioned whether moderate fundamentalists could be disentangled from extremists. "If there is anything we have learned, it is how unpredictable these movements are and how little we know," he said.
Doug Johnston of the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington replied: "I don't accept that fundamentalism is monolithic. There are certain entities you can play to more than others."
The scholars agreed that while fundamentalist movements in many nations have mobilized frustration by denouncing greed and corruption, these movements have proposed only vague remedies of their own and have varied greatly in their support or suspicion of market economics.
"All major religions are capable of supporting both pro-market and anti-market ideologies," said Timur Kuran, an economist at the University of Southern California who gave a skeptical overview of such fundamentalist economic doctrines as "interest-free" Islamic banking, the "Buddhist socialism" of Myanmar, formerly Burma, or the anti-government stance of fundamentalist leaders in the United States.
 
Puzzle, Problem or Peril
 Prof. Samuel Heilman of the City University of New York said the encounters of scholars from around the world, and often from religious backgrounds that have been antagonistic, was itself "a human drama we haven't written about."
But the project did not succeed in integrating fundamentalist representatives themselves in its work, he said.
For most participants in the Chicago meeting, fundamentalism remained at least a puzzle to be explained, if not a problem to be solved or a danger to be parried. For some, however, the years of study may have produced an increasingly critical attitude toward modern secular assumptions.
Nancy T. Ammerman, a sociologist at Emory University who has written several books about American fundamentalists, said she had a greater appreciation of fundamentalists' power "in critiquing the culture, in imagining a world that is different," and in "contesting the powers of those who claim the right to tell the culture's story."

HEADLINE: China Applauds as Its Officials Plunge Into Profit

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YANTAI, China

 BODY:
Happily married, his career flourishing, a 31-year-old midlevel city official named Lu Zhoukui abruptly decided last August to xia hai, or plunge into the sea.
Mr. Lu was not feeling suicidal, and in fact it may have been the best decision he ever made. "Plunging into the sea" is the new slang in China for going into business, and it is becoming a nationwide craze. 
 Tens of millions of Government and Communist Party officials are plunging into the sea. Deng Xiaoping's youngest son has dived in, along with the children of most other top leaders, and the official newspapers are full of praise for the phenomenon.
"From top to bottom, the Government is encouraging us to do business," Mr. Lu said as he sat in the anteroom of his plush new office in this eastern Chinese city. "The only restriction is that the business must be legal."
 
Cash Over Politics
 It says something about the giddiness of the economic and social revolution under way in China that the Communist Party is hailing its officials for abandoning their posts to the temptations of capitalism. More fundamentally, the rush to plunge into the sea reflects the growing sense among China's elite that power and comfort and prestige in the coming years will no longer derive from political position, but rather from hard cash.
One measure of the trend is that the number of registered companies in China soared 88 percent last year alone, rising to 486,000. The registered capital of private enterprises surged 79 percent in the year, to $3.9 billion.
Fragmentary statistics suggest that about one-third of China's 103 million Government employees have leaped into the sea, or at least waded in far enough to get a second, part-time job. Many more Chinese are expected to take the plunge, for the word is getting out that the sea is warm and inviting -- and that almost no one sinks.
Mr. Lu, for instance, started a company in August to engage in everything from running restaurants to placing Chinese laborers in foreign jobs. The company turned a profit of $219,000 in the four months it was operating last year, and this year Mr. Lu is expecting a profit of almost $1 million.
By comparison, his income at his old Government job was $46 a month.
 
Some Troubling Questions
 Nevertheless, the trend toward leaping into the sea raises some troubling questions. Some people worry, for instance, that China is becoming a nation of money-grubbing materialists, in which intellectuals are obliged to sacrifice more important work just to keep up with the Wangs.
There was considerable disquiet when a Beijing newspaper reported that a Communist Party secretary at the Forestry University was selling meat pies on the side. It is not clear which of two items bothered readers more: that the man would stoop to be a vendor or that by doing so he tripled his income.
"I am totally appalled," a commentator wrote in The Guangming Daily News, a newspaper for intellectuals. "I'd like to read the professor's works rather than eat his meat pies."
A broader question is whether those leaping into the sea are unfairly taking advantage of their guanxi, or connections. Good guanxi are paramount in China, for they make the difference in getting bank loans, electricity, running water and tax waivers. Guanxi are often more important than rules.
 
How He Hired Russians
 Mr. Lu, for instance, is about to open a restaurant with Russian waitresses. Many other bars and restaurants around China have lately been forbidden to hire Russians, partly because of concern that some engage in prostitution.
Perhaps Mr. Lu has obtained permission through luck, or through astute preparation. But it cannot hurt that he knows all the city officials, and that calligraphy given to him by the provincial governor is hanging in his office.
"Some of these people going into business worked for many years in Government offices, and they have lots of contacts," said Zhang Huafu, the Deputy Mayor of Yantai. "I can't deny the problem. But because of this problem, we shouldn't oppose the whole idea of people going into business."
The term "plunging into the sea" reflects the sense of daring and uncertainty that is associated with business in China. Much of that is dissipating, but one recurring problem is finding housing.
 
Having to Return Apartments
 Government employees normally get low-cost apartments from the state, and unless they have good guanxi, they often have to return their apartments when they go into business. Private housing is difficult to obtain and extremely expensive.
Wang Quanjie, a 42-year-old engineer in Yantai, is now grappling with the housing question. Mr. Wang, who used to oversee leather factories for the city government, left his job in July with 10 colleagues to form a leather research institute.
Mr. Wang and his friends have done extremely well, winning consulting fees from factories and making back their starting capital of $17,000 five times over. Like most Chinese who plunge into the sea, they raised the money by dipping into savings and by borrowing from friends and relatives. Also like most, they are trying to use their guanxi with friendly officials to get large loans from Government-run banks.
The problem is that the Government gave them a one-year grace period to leave their housing. So the staff has to find new apartments this summer.
"That's a huge headache for all of us," Mr. Wang said. "I've got to figure out how to house all my staff."
 
Quitting Is Avoided
 Partly to avoid losing their apartments, many Chinese leap into the sea without formally quitting their other jobs. They neglect their work, but keep the salaries and housing, knowing that it is very difficult to be dismissed.
A result is that while not enough officials have resigned to create staff shortages, many schools and offices have a very clear shortage of employees concentrating on their work.
Policemen moonlight as pimps. Factory workers wave rags on street corners as an offer to wash cars. University students sell photocopiers and X-ray machines on commission. Professors become corporate consultants, working with such enthusiasm that The Economic Daily complained recently about faculty members who rush out of class when their beepers go off.
As for Chinese journalists, a joke going around says there are now five kinds of reporters. The top tier is made up of those who run a business on the side, and they are followed by those who play the stock market.
The third kind sells advertisements as a sideline, winning a typical commission of 7 to 12 percent from their business departments. The fourth kind freelances for other publications.
"The bottom rank of journalists is the least respected," said a reporter for one of China's most distinguished newspapers. "They're the ones who actually do the work and write the front-page stories."
 
Traditionally Demeaned
 Traditionally in China, Confucianism looked down on business people, and until recently officials and intellectuals disdained commerce as demeaning. Many Chinese also regarded business as risky, because of fears that private enterprises would be confiscated if hard-liners returned to power.
The term "plunging into the sea" apparently originated early in this century in Shanghai but then migrated to Taiwan, where it was a pejorative expression for young women working as prostitutes. The term returned to mainland China last year, and fell into common use only in the last six months.
But on the journey from Taiwan, the meaning of the phrase was twisted to reflect the broader concept of going into business in any way. Now it encompasses moonlighting professors as well as prostitutes.
Because of the traditionally negative associations of engaging in private business, in the early and mid-1980's a hugely disproportionate share of entrepreneurs in China were ex-convicts. They could not get any respectable job and so were forced into business.
 
Ex-Convicts Are Prosperous
 A result is that perhaps in no other country are ex-convicts so prosperous. China often boasts about its low recidivism rates; one reason is that released prisoners -- mostly common criminals, but also some dissidents -- are part of an old-boy network that offers some of the most lucrative jobs in the country. For making useful business connections, Beijing No. 1 Prison is the Harvard Business School of China.
As time passes, fears of a major policy reversal by the hard-liners are diminishing, and so is the scorn for private business.
A well-known writer, Zhang Xianlang, has just started his own holding company, setting up a huge billboard as its first project. And China's most famous movie actress, Liu Xiaoqing, has started the Xiaoqing Industrial and Commercial Company, with interests varying from cosmetics to real estate.
 
Favorite Job Preference
 A survey of young people found that their top job preference was to be an entrepreneur. National Government work ranked 8th out of 16 choices.
All this is very heartening to those who have plunged into the sea, like Wang Qian, who left her Government post last summer to join the private leather research institute in Yantai.
"A few years ago, it would have been tough for somebody in my present situation to find a boyfriend," said Ms. Wang, 24. "Then a woman in business could look for a boyfriend only among other traders."
"But now it's very different," Ms. Wang added, beaming. "People accept the fact that it's a market economy. Anybody will go out with you."
