HEADLINE: The Outlook Is Still Risky For New York Office Space

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
As the American economy heads into what appears to be an ever-more-solid recovery, the New York commercial real estate industry continues to reel from the shocks of the overbuilding of the 1980's and the job losses of the recession.
In a market characterized by vast swathes of empty office space and desperate owners seeking buyers or tenants for troubled buildings, each new report of a big lease, of an offer to buy a distressed building or of a dip in the vacancy rate is analyzed as perhaps the sign of the market's recovery. Each time, anxious owners and other industry insiders ask: is this the crocus that signals the start of spring? 
 Like spring, however, the overall market -- the country's biggest -- still feels a damp chill despite some rays of sunshine.
"We've probably bottomed in vacancy rates, and we've probably bottomed in rent rates on new leases," S. Michael Giliberto, head of real estate research for Salomon Brothers, said. "But we probably haven't bottomed on average rents, and it's not clear we've bottomed in value."
The building boom and economic crunch have left the prime office areas of Manhattan, midtown and downtown, with a total of 57.6 million square feet of empty office space, according to the Edward S. Gordon Company, a brokerage firm. If all that unoccupied territory were put on a flat surface, it would total roughly 1,322 acres, or about half again as large as Central Park.
Despite Manhattan's many "see-through buildings" -- the name given to the partly filled office towers -- and the tentative nature of the economic recovery, Stephen B. Siegel, president of Gordon, is fairly optimistic.
"Yes, we are on the way up," he said. "Rents are beginning to firm up, and certainly concessions on leasing transactions are less generous. But the firming up is extremely tentative and is subject to any economic upheaval that might occur."
What he describes as a pickup in the market started in the second quarter of last year, and has continued through the first quarter of this year, he added. Last year, Gordon's figures show, for the first time in four years more space was rented in midtown Manhattan than was vacated -- 2.4 million square feet more.
But rental prices still show the degree of distress. According to Chris Kraus of Cushman and Wakefield, at the peak of the market in the early 1980's the average effective rent -- including free rent, improvements and the like -- for a good, newer building in midtown was around $35 to $40 a square foot; that figure is now around $25 to $30 a square foot.
 
 
No Dramatic Change
 Even with some of that vacant space being absorbed -- and even with big tenants encountering growing difficulty in finding choice blocks of space bigger than 100,000 square feet in midtown -- the situation has not changed drastically.
Steve Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, said, "The deals that are being done are still marginal deals for owners, so it remains a tenant's market."
The long-term prospects for a recovery in property values depend on basic economic truths: when hiring picks up and new companies start, demand for office space will rise.
But hiring may not expand, given the severity of the recession and factors such as technological advances, increased productivity, the leaner corporation and the fact that the baby boom and the influx of women into the workplace have passed.
 
 
'Musical Chairs'
 "There appears to be no new demand coming into the New York market in terms of growth in industry," said Peter Hauspurg of Eastern Consolidated Properties, a Manhattan real estate investment banking firm. "Most of the trading now is tenants trading up to better properties. But it's just musical chairs."
The magnitude of distress in evident in recent building sales. Mr. Hauspurg said properties are now changing hands, but at deep discounts.
"Prices of commercial buildings have fallen from between 40 to 70 percent," from the peak of the market in the 1980's, he said, depending on their location. Mr. Giliberto's research unit says recent sales suggest that financial institutions' troubled properties are selling at 45 percent to 55 percent of the previous value, and that many would-be sellers prefer to wait and hope that prices will rise.
 
 
Some Arresting Numbers
 Although differences in building make comparisons difficult, some of the numbers are arresting: in 1986, the 67,000-square-foot building at 1 East 57th Street, at Fifth Avenue, sold for about $820 a square foot. In 1992, the nearby 57,500-square-foot building at 3 West 57th Street sold for $298 a square foot, one of the higher per-square-foot sales of the year.
Owners and developers were not the only people left bereft by the crash; financial institutions and other lenders have been watching the value of their real estate holdings and loans plummet.
But despite the crash in prices and the ripples throughout the world of real estate and beyond, John H. Alschuler Jr. of Hamilton, Rabinovitz and Alschuler, a consulting firm, sees some silver lining: office space is available and affordable for expansion or entry into New York, where rents were so prohibitively high for so long.
"Though deeply painful to investors and to the city, the restructuring of the cost base of New York's real estate markets has had the effect of making Manhattan and the boroughs more competitive, which should sustain our long-term growth," he said.

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Planner's Vision of a People-Friendly Arts Plaza on the Passaic

BYLINE: By Glenn Collins

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
SO many people suffer from so much unnecessary agita when they see the word Newark. Larry Goldman knows everything there is to know about that one. He is stepping carefully down Saybrook Place in his cordovan wing tips, dapper, restless, the irresistible force personified.
A visitor sharing that walk sees only the immovable object: a corner of downtown Newark. It is a landscape of forlorn, weedy Park-Fast-All-Day lots ringed in razor wire. There are boarded-up buildings and a doomed, gutted hotel. But this Goldman fellow, his face radiating anticipation as he talks about his vision, sees none of it. As he walks, he is crossing a gloriously verdant public square bordered by umbrella-topped cafe tables. He is watching a polite crowd clustered around a string quartet near a sparkling fountain. He is surrounded by concertgoers hastening toward a performance by Itzhak Perlman. 
 Instead of the phosphoresence of decay, he sees Lincoln Center on the Passaic River. An arts center alive with activity. To fully appreciate the degree of difficulty of his daydream, try taking today's pop quiz: When you see the word "Newark," do you (1) Lock your car doors? (2) Curse yourself for failing to buy the Club? (3) Think of buildings that are burning and/or abandoned? (4) Eagerly await an evening at the Bolshoi Ballet?
If you answered "yes" to the first three questions and "no" to the fourth, Larry Goldman -- Dr. Lawrence P. Goldman, that is -- understands. And he has your number. He vows to win you over to a "yes" on question No. 4, and a "no" on questions Nos. 1 through 3. His track record so far is persuasive in such matters.
How so? Recently Dr. Goldman's team reached a milestone: in the dead grip of a stubborn recession, it raised $100 million of the $150 million needed to further the organization of which he is president: the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. The plan (at first it was described as "scheme") is to build a world-class 2,700-seat multipurpose hall and a 500-seat theater on a 12-acre site in Newark.
Right. Newark. The design includes a people-friendly plaza called Theater Square, which would extend a permanent welcome mat to people in the city and the suburbs beyond.
The money details are not boring. Gov. Jim Florio, not renowned for his support of the arts at budget-cutting time, kicked in $62.5 million. The city donated $10 million, and the Federal Government $1.2 million. So far $26.5 million has come from private contributors, including foundations that carry the name of A. T.&T., Matsushita, Merck, Prudential, Johnson and Johnson, S. I. Newhouse and Warner-Lambert. Not the usual suspects.
"I didn't say he was crazy when he approached me, but I was skeptical that it could be done in Newark," said P. Roy Vagelos, chairman of Merck and Company. "Now I don't think there's any question that it will happen."
Out on Saybrook Place, with a gesture sweeping beyond the wasteland before him, Dr. Goldman says that ground-breaking will occur this summer. The opening? In the 1996 season. "People have stopped asking whether it will get built any more," he said. "Now they ask, 'when it gets built, who's going to come?' "
The answer, market research suggests, is a pool of 650,000 New Jersey arts-lovers who might prefer not to cross the Hudson River. One of them is Dr. Vagelos, a director of the Metropolitan Opera. "It would be very nice to have a truly great performing arts center much closer," he said.
To lure the anxious into Newark, Mayor Sharpe James promises protected streets and Dr. Goldman vows to create, "hands down, the safest and most congenial parking lot on the East Coast." Couldn't hurt. A visitor remembers his own first impression of Newark as a reporter after the disturbances in 1967. A world of rubbled buildings and smoking dreams. Some of the dead zones persist, but Newark cognoscenti have long known about the city's renaissance as well.
The explosion of recent building, bringing thousands of people downtown, is more significant than headlines about stolen cars doing doughnut spins. Only last week a six-plex cinema opened in the riot-scarred Central Ward. And Newark has been designated as (don't laugh) one of America's most livable cities by the United States Conference of Mayors.
The arts center could accelerate that revival. But only if this bow-tied, 47-year-old Princeton-educated urban planner and his power-hitting board of directors can make it happen.
So for now, to walk down Saybrook Place with Dr. Goldman is to span the entire history and future of this city. No exaggeration. Here at the margin of the block, in a tiny park that is a longboat's portage from the Passaic River, is a stone marker celebrating the 1666 landing of Newark's Puritan founders.
The commemorative brass plaque has been ripped out by junkies. The stone has endured. Even as the city. "This monument will be an important part of Theater Square," Dr. Goldman said. And for just a moment, you can see what he does: arts mavens lingering over decaf cappucino. Where only rusty chain-link fence and a forgotten monument had been.

HEADLINE: OTHER VOICES;
'There's Just a Lot of Pressure'

 BODY:
The following text was taken from more than 20 hours of discussions with teen-agers from the New York City region. Excerpts appear with each article.
Q What are the biggest problems facing young people?
 
EMMA KRAMER-WHEELER , 16, Brooklyn (Edward R. Murrow High School): Lack of direction.
BERNARDO VASQUEZ , 17, Manhattan (A. Philip Randolph High School): If you don't have the right guidance . . . then you end up going the wrong way.
Q What kind of help is available in terms of institutions, like schools or churches ----
WUBNESH HYLTON , 19, Brooklyn (Hunter College): Not school.
EMMA Most of the guidance counselors are these 60-, 70-year-old women who sit in their offices or go to lunch. And don't do anything else.
Q What about churches or synagogues?
WUBNESH I don't know any young people who go to church.
Q Why don't young people go to church?
WUBNESH Because churches don't do anything. They serve no purpose. They're just like a big fashion show, hands clapping and foot stomping.
JUAN RIVERA , 18, Brooklyn (Bushwick High School): I'm a big part of my church. . . . I run the sports program there. . . . I've developed a relationship with just about everyone there. . . . And I found out more about myself.
Q Do you know people who are giving up? For instance, the suicide rate has gone up dramatically for young people.
EMMA I think a lot more people give up in less dramatic ways also. People just go into their shells. There's just a lot of pressure.
Q Do you think life is tougher now than it was for your parents' generation, or even 10 years ago?
BERNARDO Economically is it tougher? Maybe because there are less factory jobs. There might be more opportunities in professions . . . then I have it harder, because racism is rising again.
Q What has been the impact of AIDS and crack on your generation?
WUBNESHWell, crack, I see it affecting more of the older generation. Young people were selling it, but young people don't really use it because they know it's not like a party recreational drug, because you die too quick.
JUAN I know someone who has AIDS and she's taking care of herself. She's about 26.
EMMAIt's amazing to me that not everybody knows this, but it can kill you.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Sales Abroad Set Record

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Private investors overseas bought a record $31 billion of Treasury bonds and notes last year, with much of the demand coming from buyers in London and the return of the Japanese.
Private purchases in the fourth quarter, at $20 billion, also set a record. 
 The data, compiled by R. H. Wrightson & Associates, show that after two years of being net sellers, Japanese investors were "modest" buyers of notes and bonds by the second half of last year. But, Louis Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson, said the buying probably did not have much impact on the market.
 
 
Buying in London
 The largest buyers for Treasury bonds and notes were investors who bought through the London market. That buying, he said, "certainly helped the market; it helped absorb some of the increased Treasury issuance."
There are data for total purchases by private investors overseas, but they are not broken down by country. So Wrightson has to use other data -- including official buying by central banks and statements from the Treasury and foreign governments -- to reach its conclusions about private foreign purchases.
The totals for private and official buying show $24.2 billion of purchases of bonds and notes in London last year, the highest amount ever and about four times the 1991 total. As for Japan, the 1992 total was $9.5 billion in net buying, in contrast to the net selling of $4.1 billion in 1991 and $15.5 billion in 1990. Still, that is well under the $21.8 billion of net buying in 1988.
 
 
Impact of Foreign Buying
 The impact of foreign buying can be seen in the performance of the yields on the 30-year bond and the 10-year note at the end of 1988 and the beginning of 1989. The buying by the Japanese helped to pull the yield on the 30-year bond to below that of the 10-year note, the opposite of the usual relationship.
In December 1988, for example, the yield on the 30-year bond was 8.99 percent, while the yield on the 10-year note was 9.14 percent, or 15 basis points, higher. (A basis point is a hundredth of a percentage point.) In March 1989, the 30-year yield was 9.09 percent, compared with 9.28 percent on the 10-year note.
Mr. Crandall noted that the Japanese bought both notes and bonds, but that the size of bond purchases was so large compared with the total sold that yield relationship was reversed. Since the Japanese became net sellers in 1990 and 1991, the relationship between the bond and the note has reversed, with the yield on the 30-year bond now about 90 basis points higher.
The Japanese sold Treasury securities in 1990 and 1991 because they needed to bring cash home to offset huge losses when the Tokyo stock market crashed.
While the foreign buying through London appears to be close to the size of the Japanese buying, Mr. Crandall said the London buying was more evenly spread among maturities, so it had not had a skewing impact.
 
 
Treasury Market
 Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed yesterday in light trading as traders and investors marked time, waiting for the release of two inflation measures at the end of the week.
But traders were also getting ready for a down-to-the-wire debt ceiling ritual because Congress has failed to approve an increase in the Government's borrowing limit.
In late trading, the price of the 30-year bond was up 13/32 , to 1018/32 , as the yield fell to 7.02 percent, from 7.05 percent on Friday. The price increase managed to erase less than half of the loss on Friday, after the March employment data apparently made many investors decide that the economy was strong enough to prevent inflation from declining below the 3 percent rate of last year.
As usual, the debt ceiling is the hostage of political infighting, this time in the Senate, where Republicans have blocked approval of President Clinton's economic stimulus program, contending that it is too large and that some of its spending is wasteful. But the crux of the battle is that the Republicans, who have 43 of the 100 members, want to have a stronger role in policy. Because the Democrats need 60 votes to end a filibuster, the Republicans have leverage if they stick together.
The stalemate forced the cancellation of the regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills yesterday and the auction of $14.25 billion of one-year Treasury bills last week.
The Treasury says it will bump up against the current borrowing ceiling of $4.145 trillion tomorrow. At the same time it runs out of borrowing authority, the Treasury estimates that it will also run out of cash to pay bills and government checks, like Social Security. The Treasury has asked for an increase that would temporarily raise the borrowing limit to $4.37 trillion, enough to accommodate expected borrowing through Sept. 30, the end of the fiscal year.
The Government has not defaulted before, although it has managed to delay approval of a borrowing increase until the last minute. And traders in the bond market do not expect the worst to happen this time.
"They don't want that on their heads," said Joel Kazis, managing director for government trading and sales at UBS Securities.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Sinks Against Yen, Despite Bank of Japan Effort

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted broadly lower yesterday, hitting another record low against the Japanese yen despite a further attempt by the Bank of Japan to stem the American currency's decline.
Activity was light as traders searched in vain for news that might change the market's generally bearish sentiment toward the dollar. Participants were awaiting further clues in two important inflation reports due for release later this week.
 
 
Gold Prices Slip
 Gold prices retreated after last week's rally. Gold for current delivery, which rose $8.70 an ounce over the last four trading sessions on New York's Commodity Exchange, fell $1.40 to close at $339.50. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $339.10 an ounce, off 90 cents from late Friday. 
 Dealers said the intervention by the Japanese central bank, which came during overnight trading in Tokyo, was bigger in scope than its move on Friday to support the dollar.
But the move failed to spur a rebound in the dollar, which repeatedly hit postwar lows against the yen last week amid apparent support by the major industrialized nations for a stronger yen as a way to cut Japan's huge trade surplus.
The dollar continued to slip against the German mark, as traders found little new in remarks by the Bundesbank's president, Helmut Schlesinger, that the bank would continue to cut German interest rate cuts slowly and gradually.
 
 
Third Consecutive Record Low
 The dollar closed in Tokyo at 113.83 yen. In London, the dollar was quoted at 113.55 yen. By late afternoon in New York, it had slipped to 113.70 yen from late Friday's 113.75 yen, its third consecutive record low.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.5210, from $1.5175 late Friday. But late yesterday afternoon in New York, the pound fetched $1.5210, slightly less than late Friday's $1.5220.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.5950 marks, down from 1.5975; 1.4770 Swiss francs, down from 1.4780; 5.4125 French francs, down from 5.4400; 1,586 Italian lire, up from 1,584, and $1.2623 (Canadian), down from $1.2641 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
They Came and Saw And They Learned

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
ASIDE from debating who might be the new national champion, the multimillion dollar question here last night was whether Chris Webber of Michigan would turn pro this spring. Would the Five X's be broken up?
There was a feeling among some that if Michigan had won, Webber was history; if the Wolverines lost, he might stay and try again until they won it. 
 Others felt that win or lose, Webber was leaving. In two seasons, he had proven himself, outgrown the field and, in any event, wouldn't risk suffering a third heartbreak. After losing by 20 points to Duke as a freshman in the national championship game, Webber sat and wept uncontrollably.
Last night, as a sophomore, Webber capped a riveting 23-point, 11-rebound performance by grabbing a rebound off a missed Carolina foul shot, then streaking down the left sideline with Michigan trailing, 73-71, and with 11 seconds left in the game.
Then he stopped, appeared to slide and signaled for a timeout that Michigan didn't have.
Technical foul. Loss of ball. End of comeback. Loss of game.
End of career?
After the game, Webber, obviously distraught again, spoke at a news conference but did not address his basketball future. His teammate and best friend, Jalen Rose, wondered if such a proud player would want to end his career on such a dismal note.
"You don't expect somebody to make a decision off one game," Rose said. "He'll do all right. he's going to feel down about himself, like we all would in such a situation. But if it weren't for Chris Webber, who knows where we'd be?"
Still, the questions persist: Will Webber return next season, not to the Fab Five but to a hungry team twice denied?
Or will he jump feet first into the rapidly evolving world of pro basketball -- a world built by Magic and Bird, redefined by Jordan and now being reconfigured by Shaq.
It's a difficult world to resist. Especially now.
National Basketball Association people say that should Webber come out this season, he will be a first or second pick.
When you analyze the current situation, the dismal economy, dismal prospect for jobs, there is no defensible position for advising someone to turn down a million dollars. Especially once its's determined that a "million" is a legitimate possibility. The National Collegiate Athletic Association should see to it that an athlete can put himself in the draft without losing eligibility.
Of course, there's an instinctive reflex against an athlete exchanging education for silver and gold rather than following the solid road to a degree. The problem is whether the athletes are even able to get everything a university has to offer academically.
When Anfernee Hardaway of Memphis State declared himself eligible for the draft, his coach, Larry Finch said, "Amen." But while Finch said he didn't have a problem with players leaving early, he added, "I'd like for it to be a real hardship, versus just chasing the money."
In fact, the idea of "going hardship" began with Spencer Haywood, a former Olympian and All-Pro player whose suit against the N.B.A. in 1970 opened the pro draft to underclassmen. Haywood at first had to actually prove that remaining in school was a hardship, but that no longer is required.
Perhaps one day our system of education will become as effective as our sports system in preparing young people for the future.
Think about it: Our scholastic sports system has become so refined that it can produce young people who, after four years of high school and two to three of college, can embark on a professional career.
The academic process, by comparison, is in the Stone Age.
In any event, the N.B.A., is being replenished with great young players: Kenny Anderson, Harold Miner, Shaquille O'Neal, Jimmy Jackson, Chris Jackson.
Webber and Jamal Mashburn, who has already announced his plan to enter the draft after three years at Kentucky, are sharp young athletes with a strong sense of direction. Are they ready for professional basketball? Definitely. The critical question is the extent to which they are ready for the ups and downs of the pro life.
This seems to be a far more critical issue than whether or not to leave school early for hefty sums of money and the prestige of making an N.B.A. team.
In a way it would be nice to see Webber back. He is growing, as a player and as a person by such leaps and bounds that one would like to see him -- and his teammates Jalen Rose, Ray Jackson, Jimmy King and Juwan Howard -- as a senior team at Michigan.
In an ideal world, with all things being equal, Webber perhaps would stay, earning his degree in four years and savoring the relative innocence of campus life.
In this world, where muscle reigns, it becomes increasingly imperative to get what you can while you are able.
Heaven can wait.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
For Openers, Gooden and Key Close Down the Batters

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, April 5

 BODY:
On a chilly April day when emotions were intense because the Indians remembered two of their athletes who died young, it would have been possible to ignore the developments that unfolded for the Yankees as they started the 1993 baseball season. Possible, but not probable.
Maybe the Yankees will gaze back on this opening day sometime in July or August and realize how perfectly their season started in an impressive 9-1 victory over the Indians. But if they want to reminisce on this day with a smile, instead of a frown, the Yankees must continue getting performances like the bushel they received on this 36-degree day. 
 From Jimmy Key twirling eight innings of three-hit baseball in his Yankee debut, to Matt Nokes smacking a three-run homer, to Pat Kelly discovering he was the New York second baseman four hours before the first pitch and responding with a two-run homer, to Danny Tartabull initiating the 16-hit rampage with a homer off Yankee nemesis Charles Nagy, it was a stylish way to begin. It was the first time in 31 years that the Yankees had homers from three players on opening day.
 
Everything Works
 The game -- played before 73,290, the second-largest opening-day crowd in American League history -- was a blueprint for how the Yankees must perform if they want to seriously challenge in the American League East. Key and the other starters must be superb, Tartabull and Nokes must provide power, Kelly and Spike Owen must ignite the bottom of the batting order as they did today with three hits each and Wade Boggs and Don Mattingly must hit and hit. This afternoon, everything meshed neatly for the Yankees. Today, everything they did was gorgeous.
"I'm proud of our club today," said Manager Buck Showalter. "It was a lot of fun as far as the game was concerned. It was a tough emotional day."
With the opportunity for both teams to be distracted as the Indians presented the uniform jerseys of Tim Crews and Steve Olin, who were killed in a boating accident last month, to their widows and parents before the season opener, the Yankees, especially Key, remained very much in focus. After the service for the two pitchers, Key returned to the bullpen to throw more. What a shrewd move.
Key was poised, precise and professional and was also the main reason the game lasted an economical 2 hours 18 minutes. He threw 71 pitches in his eight innings, did not walk a batter, struck out three and retired the last 11 batters he faced before John Habyan handled the ninth. As a replacement for the injured Melido Perez, Key also made friends with his freezing fielders by keeping the contest moving at a crisp pace.
"Awesome and outstanding," said Owen. "He works very fast, he moves the ball around the plate and he knows what he is doing out there. On a day like today, you don't want to be standing out there for 15 minutes."
Boggs, a former foe who is now a friend, said: "You just bang your head against the wall when he pitches. He frustrates you. He doesn't just throw, he pitches. He's one of the best."
 
Just Doing His Job
 Key refused to let the cold or the sight of the families of two fallen pitchers affect his first game with the Yankees. Although Key called the service touching, he also said, "Once I'm between the lines, I do my job."
After Tartabull's opposite-field homer in the second inning pushed the Yankees ahead, 1-0, Key was sharp in the third. The Indians had tied the game on Sandy Alomar's sacrifice fly and had Glenallen Hill on first base with the top of their batting order to contend with. Before the Indians could whisper rally, Key induced the speedy Kenny Lofton to hammer into a second-to-short-to-first double play.
That was about as dangerous as it got for Key. Kelly's run-scoring single in the fifth made it 2-1 and Nokes hit a three-run homer to ignite a five-run sixth and transform the game into a rout. It was a shocking blast because he smoked it off Nagy, who had retired Nokes in 16 of 17 career times at bat. Actually, it was a day for reversing trends because the Yankees beat Nagy after being humbled by him on three different occasions last year.
Yes, it was a game the Yankees will cherish. Although the day brought sadness, the Yankees managed to begin the season with enough positives to last a week. The trick for them now is to make pitching, power and sturdy defense reappear as the year progresses. As Kelly noted, "It's one game out of 162."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 GEORGE STEINBRENNER walked on the field before the game to speak with players and was almost beaned by DON MATTINGLY's batting-practice line drive to left field. He also happily congratulated the team in the clubhouse. . . . The Yankees have won seven of their last eight season openers. . . . JIMMY KEY, who was the ninth different opening-day starter for the Yankees in nine years, is now 4-0 with a 2.42 e.r.a. in first-game assignments.

HEADLINE: Tank Parts, Off the Shelf

 BODY:
As the Pentagon slims down to fit a much diminished threat, it won't be buying weapons at the same expansive rate. The resultant downsizing and consolidation in defense industries pose a tough puzzle for the Pentagon: how to preserve technological know-how and a skilled labor force against the possibility of resuming defense production.
The best answer is to try to turn defense and civilian producers into a single industrial base. That can't be done without a long-overdue reform of Pentagon procurement practices. 
 Consider the problem of tank production. The Army already has enough M1 Abrams tanks, the most capable in the world, in its inventory. Since the useful service life of a tank is about 30 years, and the oldest Abrams tank will be 15 in 1995, the Army won't have to begin replacing them until 2010 at the earliest.
One alternative, according to a Congressional Budget Office study, is a makework contract to produce 120 tanks a year, just to maintain the capacity to manufacture new tanks in 2010. But that costs a lot -- $3.8 billion from 1994 to 1998 -- and the Army doesn't need the tanks. Moreover, the tank of the future may have a ceramic engine and stealth technology that current plants can't make.
Another option is to upgrade older M1 models, turning them into M1-A2's. Congress has gotten the Army to begin doing that. But that, too, is expensive -- at least $2.2 billion for just the next five years.
The most sensible option is to mothball key production facilities -- at a five-year cost of just $200 million. Restarting the plants and getting them up to full speed would take six years and $1 billion. If the Red Army should somehow revive in the meantime, older but still serviceable M-60 tanks can be taken out of mothballs.
What about the 18,000 suppliers of tank parts? Many can convert to civilian production. But conversion is a partial answer at best. Defense contractors, long accustomed to meeting the requirements of a single customer, the Pentagon, are often ill prepared to satisfy consumer demand. And they can't always find compatible products that would allow them to shift back to tank-making.
What's needed is a more thoroughgoing reform of defense acquisition. Instead of designing tank parts to its own specifications, the Pentagon could purchase them just like any private company. Students of the problem now believe that could even improve the quality of weapons. In the fast-moving world of computer chips central to the operation of many weapons, for example, off-the-shelf technology is often more advanced and reliable than the chips produced to Pentagon specifications. By the time those specifications have been drawn up and met, superior chips may be on the market.
The shift to more purchasing of commercially available components would make it unnecessary to maintain much of a separate defense industrial base. It would also generate enormous savings. Some $50 billion a year goes to overhead -- to pay Pentagon and industry bureaucrats and accountants who draw up the specifications and do the paperwork to police them. That's about 40 percent of the total acquisition budget, and it could rise to 70 percent if steps to deregulate defense purchasing are not taken soon.
The Carnegie Commission on Science, Technology and Government has urged such a change. Its chairman, William Perry, now Deputy Secretary of Defense, is in a position to get on with the job.

HEADLINE: Now It's Bill Clinton's Package

 BODY:
Stepping out from the large foreign policy shadow of his predecessor, President Clinton now assumes the risks, and courts the dividends, of embracing a Russian leader who's in deep political trouble at home. It's the right move -- an unstinting bid to encourage the best possible outcome, even while beginning to hedge against the worst.
"From here on in," Boris Yeltsin declared at the closing press conference in Vancouver Sunday, it's going to be called "Bill Clinton's economic package." Russia's first democratic politician appreciated the large political bet Mr. Clinton had just placed on him and on the future of Russian reform. 
 Support from Washington and other Western capitals can improve Mr. Yeltsin's prospects only at the margin. But with Russia's opposing forces closely balanced as the April 25 referendum nears, the margin may matter mightily. Mr. Clinton is right to mobilize all the Western support he can.
The $1.6 billion package announced Sunday is the first of two installments expected from Washington. The second will consist of new Congressional appropriations and, probably, changes in cold-war laws restricting Russian trade. A far larger, multinational effort will be unveiled when foreign and finance ministers from the world's richest nations meet in Tokyo next week.
Bill Clinton's package is meant to help Mr. Yeltsin, but is designed in a way that could nurture elements of reform even if the reformist Russian President should fall. Mr. Clinton has prudently begun unbundling three separate American interests -- markets, democracy and denuclearization.
Previous aid packages made the transfer of funds largely contingent on economic reform. Money that might have helped woo key constituencies, like the military, unintentionally became hostage to obstructions by anti-reform elements in Parliament. As a result, much of the aid pledged by the Bush Administration and other Western governments still remains undelivered. And much of what was delivered was not spent in ways ordinary Russians could appreciate.
Mr. Clinton made a virtue of these past delays. His first installment is entirely based on already appropriated money, allowing speedy disbursement. He has also channeled this money in politically conspicuous ways, for example into housing and training for demobilized military personnel, medical supplies for hospitals and food for needy mothers and children. Washington will also try to speed up spending under the Nunn-Lugar Act to help dismantle nuclear weapons.
Mr. Yeltsin's survival is the best assurance of America's interests. His enemies in Parliament have already made plain they would recklessly expand the money supply, purge reformist ministers and retain the Soviet-era Constitution.
In foreign policy, they would at a minimum press a more nationalist agenda, raising tensions with Ukraine, Georgia and the Baltic countries and chilling cooperation with the U.S. on issues from Bosnia to the Middle East. At worst they might drag their feet on arms control, raising global tensions and diverting some American resources from economic construction back into defense.
Even in the worst case, of course, no one expects cold-war adventurism, five-year plans or Stalinist repression to return. Some elements of reform would probably survive, and probably warrant American encouragement. Still, Bill Clinton's package recognizes Mr. Yeltsin's special virtues -- even as it acknowledges America's continuing interests should he fall.

HEADLINE: How One National Health System Collapsed;
Rationing's No Panacea

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Readers of "Those Who Pay Health Costs Think About Drawing Lines" (The Week in Review, March 28) will get the impression that rationing medical care is a realistic health policy option. It is not. "Rationing" is a buzzword, a provocative idea -- not a realistic or workable proposal.
Rationing would not save money without a fixed budgetary limit on total spending for health. Otherwise, any saving from a prohibition on the use of a particular technology would easily be offset by increased use of other technologies that were not prohibited. Furthermore, there are almost always cases in which a proscribed procedure would be unequivocally helpful and cost-effective, although it might be only marginally helpful in most other cases. 
 Even in capped health-care systems like Britain's, there is no absolute prohibition on the use of technologies that might be medically helpful.
We need to reform our health-care system first, capping total costs and eliminating the perverse incentives and dysfunctional structural features that produce excessive overhead costs and profligate use of medical resources. It would then remain to be seen whether or not such reform would significantly slow the rate of medical cost inflation or simply produce a onetime saving. Despite claims to the contrary, no one really knows.
 
ARNOLD S. RELMAN, M.D.
Boston, March 29, 1993
 
The writer, professor of medicine and social medicine at Harvard Medical School, is former editor in chief of the New England Journal of Medicine.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Clinton's Health-Care Plan: A Push to Sell Peace of Mind

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's new health-care policy is still in development, but the packaging has already begun.
So far, the drive for health-care reform has been a discussion among policy makers, conducted in an arcane and highly theoretical language of "managed competition" and "global budgets." But sometime in May the plan will go public, and the President Clinton's political advisers are now deep in the world of focus groups and polling data, preparing for the day. 
 The strategic imperative, these advisers argue, is clear: This must be seen as a plan that helps the middle class, an important new benefit program that is as broad-based and significant as Social Security. Like Social Security, it will be presented as a plan that brings working Americans a fundamental peace of mind: They will never again have to worry about losing their health insurance.
"The primary sales pitch has to be, 'This is real insurance, unlike what you have now,' " said one political aide to the President, who like many interviewed spoke on condition that he not be identified. "The whole purpose of insurance is selling peace of mind. And there is no peace of mind with a policy you can lose when you lose your job, or get kicked off of when you get sick."
This theme will cover what are expected to be some of the important elements of the plan: some forms of cost control, a basic benefits package that is guaranteed all Americans, the portability of health insurance from one job to another and the coverage of 37 million Americans now uninsured.
 
Risks of Status Quo
 As the adviser suggests, the coming campaign will highlight the risks of the status quo, costs spiraling out of control and huge holes in the system. According to those close to the planning, Clinton advisers have found in their focus groups (representative groups of voters chosen to test policies, issues and themes) that people are already intensely aware of the strains in their coverage.
They know, for example, how their deductible has changed in recent years and have kept track of their out-of-pocket costs for health care. They talk about running into uninsured people in emergency rooms who have conditions that could have been headed off with primary care. The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, taken last week, found that nearly 6 in 10 of those earning $30,000 to $50,000 a year had some experience in their household with cutbacks in health benefits in recent years.
"They know how bad the devil they know is," said James Carville, a Clinton strategist now working on health care. "And it appears to me they're willing to take a chance on the devil they don't."
 
Fears to Be Confronted
 In short, the Clinton team once again seems to be preparing to depict a simple struggle between change and the status quo with a simple question: "Which side are you on?"
Still, most advisers acknowledge, they have to confront the fears people have about restructuring the system: fears of waits for medical care, rationing, limits on the right to choose one's own physician and job losses resulting from a requirement that small businesses provide insurance to their workers, an issue that is considered something of a sleeper.
"No matter what our plan is," one White House official said, "the status quo types will say we're advocating government interference, that health care could be rationed, that we're going to deny people their choice of doctor, and that the quality of health care is going to suffer."
The doctor-patient relationship is clearly an area of some sensitivity. Stan Greenberg, the President's poll taker, now under contract to the Democratic National Committee, declined to discuss the findings of his focus groups but offered a hint of the argument to come. "Our goal is to maintain the essential relationship between patients and doctors," Mr. Greenberg said, "to in fact unfetter it from the red tape and all the things that have kept doctors and nurses from focusing on care."
 
Checking With the Doctor
 Another aide, who spoke on condition he not be identified, said he was wary of "doctor-bashing," despite the medical profession's image problems. This aide says that people will turn for advice to their own doctors.
The most recent New York Times/ CBS News Poll found that most people did have a doctor whom they considered their own; this was particularly true among the elderly, nearly 90 percent of whom felt connected with one or more physician. Most people polled drew a clear distinction between doctors as a group and the doctor they knew.
One of the most difficult parts of the White House campaign may be the taxes necessary to pay for the health-care program. With the basic decisions on financing not yet made, strategists said it was hard to talk about the politics of it. But the President's aides are clearly leaning toward "sin taxes," particularly on cigarettes, although that may be only the most politically palatable parts of the financing solution.
Like the taxes in the budget plan, these costs will be presented as fairly shared for the greater good. This is shaping up as another exercise in middle-class populism. But this campaign will make the effort around the budget plan look modest, say many close to the planning.
 
A New Vocabulary
 The public education job it will require, they say, is stunning. People have a frame of reference for talk of deficits, spending cuts and stimulus measures; the health-care package will bring a new vocabulary, as well as new entities like regional health-insurance purchasing cooperatives.
Already, one Democrat close to the planning predicted that the phrase "managed competition," describing the blend of market forces and government regulation that the White House endorses, may go. "It ain't exactly, 'The only thing we have to fear is fear itself,' " Mr. Carville said.
Another aide said: "This is going to call on all of Clinton's skills, as a teacher, a communicator, a talk-show host. You'll see lots of town hall meetings, lots of long-format media. If a network will give us an hour, two hours, to explain this thing in detail, we'll take it."
The advisers are talking about an intensive round of appearances by President Clinton, Hillary Rodham Clinton and members of the Cabinet. They are talking about television time, long and short, and a vast distribution of videotapes about the plan. The Democratic National Committee will coordinate a grass-roots effort on behalf of the plan, aware that the struggle over health care will be waged largely Congressional district by Congressional district.
Each of those districts has its own hospitals and doctors, extremely attentive audiences for the health-care plan, with opinions of great detail. "The Texas Medical Center is in my district, and it's the No. 1 employer in Houston," said Representative Mike Andrews, a Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee. "I'll bet if you went around the country to different cities, you'd find health care a big economic engine."
 
Who Are the Villains?
 The grass-roots campaign is expected to build on the work of advocacy groups like Families U.S.A. One Democrat close to the planning said the effort could range from door-knocking to petition drives, from call-ins to members of Congress to the formation of electronic speaker bureaus that will carry the Clinton plan to local television and radio shows.
The villains, in the Clinton script, may once again be those interest groups that howl against one part of the plan or another. As was the case with the Clinton budget plan, opponents will likely be cast as special interests. "Every attack that comes to this plan, they'll say, 'Let's consider the source,' " said one political adviser. Drug companies were the earliest target.
"It's easy to demagogue the issue," said Michael Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, which represents for-profit hospitals. "If their strategy is going to be that anyone who opposes part of the bill is a special interest, we've got to be ready to have a public debate back home."

HEADLINE: RUSSIANS INVITED TO HELP IN DESIGN OF SPACE STATION

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
Seeking to cut the costs of the nation's most expensive space project, the White House has ordered NASA to work with the Russians in designing a smaller and cheaper space station. The move could bring to a decisive end decades of cold war rivalry and signal a new era of cooperation in space.
In announcing the cooperative plan yesterday, NASA disclosed that the Clinton Administration had told the agency to cut the price tag for building the station by as much as two-thirds. 
 The Russians have previously suggested several cooperative ventures and are expected to welcome this overture warmly. NASA experts say the contribution by Russia to the effort may include use of its 20-story Energia rocket, the world's most powerful, to put the station into orbit, instead of the nation's fleet of space shuttles. The shuttle fleet has recently been grounded by technical glitches, among them an aborted launching yesterday.
 
Merging the Stations?
 Also under consideration is the physical merger in space of a new Russian station with the planned American one, the joint outpost housing up to nine astronauts.
"With the end of the cold war this kind of cooperation is inevitable," said John E. Pike, head of space policy for the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington. "The only way to get a low-cost station is to build it with the Russians."
The cooperative plan could serve several purposes for Mr. Clinton. By continuing the space station he keeps contractors happy, by involving the Russians he lends support to the troubled presidency of Boris N. Yeltsin, and by trimming the space station budget he may reduce the Federal deficit.
 
Secrecy in Redesign
 In February, Mr. Clinton ordered a redesign of the 350-foot-long Space Station Freedom, saying its $31 billion cost was too high given the nation's economic woes. Since then, the redesign effort have been vague and at times wrapped in secrecy.
In a statement yesterday, NASA said that Dr. John H. Gibbons, the White House science adviser, told the agency's station-redesign panel on Saturday that the United States and its partners in the station -- the Europeans, Japanese and Canadians -- had decided to give "full consideration" to use of Russian hardware in the revamped station. The hardware, he said, would include the Russians' Mir space station "and other Russian systems and technology." He did not spell out the other technologies, although NASA recently studied the Energia rocket.
To expedite the possible use of Russian hardware, Dr. Gibbons said, the Russians themselves will be asked to take part in the redesign effort.
The NASA Administrator, Daniel S. Goldin, said yesterday in the statement that Russian participation will be coordinated by the East-West Space Science Center at the University of Maryland under the leadership of Dr. Roald Z. Sagdeev, an Russian scientist now living part time in the United States.
Vladimir Derbenev, a spokesman at the Russian Embassy in Washington, applauded the announcement.
"Our general feeling is that the more Russia is involved in this project the better," he said in an interview.
Space News, a weekly industry newspaper, said Monday that high Russian officials, in a March 16 letter to the NASA Administrator, detailed a plan for a cooperative space station that would house three astronauts by 1997 and nine astronauts by the year 2000. Under that plan Russia would merge an upgraded Mir station with the outpost planned by the United States.
The newspaper added that the plan had won serious consideration from the Federal Government and prompted it to ask the international partners in space station Freedom to endorse Russian participation in the outpost's redesign. It also reported that some partners, especially Japan, were cool to the request for Russian participation.
The reaction within NASA could be similar. Some officials at the agency favor autonomy, but others feel that in a time of budget constraints that a partnership with old rivals is necessary for the survival of the project.
 
3 Options for Station
 Again quoting Dr. Gibbons of the White House, NASA spelled out the revamped station's budgetary goals, saying that three financial options in the redesign process were being weighed for 1994 to 1998. The low option is $5 billion, the middle option is $7 billion and the high option is $9 billion for the five-year period, Dr. Gibbons was quoted as saying.
Sarah Keegan, a NASA spokeswoman, said in an interview that a comparative figure for the defunct space station Freedom was $14.6 billion. The low option, therefore, if adopted, would slice away about two-thirds of the previously budget.
The final recommendations of the space-station redesign panel are to go to the White House by June. The 50-person panel is headed by Dr. Joseph F. Shea, a NASA official.
The low option of $5 billion over the five-year construction period would be far less than the $8 billion already spent on station design studies and the fabrication of prototype hardware. The station project was begun by President Ronald Reagan in 1984.
Space Station Freedom would have been carried piecemeal on 18 or so shuttle flights, at a cost of about $1 billion each, adding a large hidden cost to the outpost's advertised $31 billion price.
In contrast, NASA experts calculate that huge Energia rockets, for about $500 million each, could place a similar station in four or five flights, sharply cutting the overall cost.
Last month, Dr. Gibbons, the White House science adviser, explained the need for a outpost redesign by comparing the space station Freedom to an insatiable gnome in an electronic arcade game.
"It was going to eat everything that NASA had," he said, referring to the program's budgetary appetite.

HEADLINE: Drop Seen in Old-Age Disability, Challenging Idea of Fading Health

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
The common assumption that old age in America brings with it unremitting deterioration is being challenged by a new study that shows disability rates among the elderly decreasing during the 1980's.
Findings by three Duke University researchers, Kenneth G. Manton, Larry S. Corder and Eric Stallard, being published in the forthcoming issue of the Journal of Gerontology, have generated a whirlwind of discussion. Demographers were taken aback by the extent to which the disability rates had shifted. 
 While many researchers said they were waiting to see Dr. Manton's work duplicated by other demographers, they also said that the shift made sense, particularly in light of the increase in commonplace surgical techniques -- like cataract removal and joint replacement -- that allow disabled older people to resume the normal activities of daily life.
 
Education Is Factor
 Another factor in the decline in disability rates may be the higher educational levels of those now entering retirement. Several studies, including those by a University of Pennsylvania sociologist, Samuel Preston, have found that higher levels of education go hand in hand with higher incomes, which are associated with better nutrition and health care.
"Education has lifelong implications, from having access to medical care to likelihood that you will take good care of yourself throughout your life," said Cynthia Taeuber, a demographer specializing in the elderly for the Federal Census Bureau.
Eileen Crimmins, a professor of gerontology at the University of Southern California, said that while it would be important to replicate Dr. Manton's findings a belief was emerging that the idea of old age as a time of steady deterioration should be replaced by the notion that the health of old people, like that of young people, goes through phases, for better or worse.
"Now, more and more people believe there's an ongoing change in both directions," she said. "Sometimes people get better, sometimes worse. Some things can get better while others get worse."
 
Effect on Policy Questions
 The Manton study showed that, while the population of those past their 65th birthday increased by 14.7 percent from 1982 to 1989 -- to 30.9 million from 26.9 million -- the chronically disabled elderly population increased by just 9.2 percent.
Over all, the proportion of the elderly population reporting no disabilities rose from 76.3 percent in 1982 to 77.4 percent in 1989.
The new findings, which have been circulated in academic forums for more than a year, have obvious relevance to the discussions under way in President Clinton's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, several experts said.
"Manton's research findings are quite germane to the question of how many Americans will need long-term care in the future," said Alan Garber, an associate professor of medicine and economics at Stanford University.
Until recently, he said, it was standard to assume that elderly people whose life was prolonged by medical intervention would live longer but that the extra time would mostly be spent in a disabled and dependent state.
Dr. Garber and others say Dr. Manton's study modified that thinking somewhat. As baby boomers age, Dr. Garber said, "no matter what, we'll need more long-term care." But lower disability among the elderly may slow the increase in demand for costly nursing home care.
A companion study by the Duke researchers, just published in the journal Gerontology, shows that the number of elderly people requiring personal assistance declined by 10 percent from 1982 to 1989, even as the number of elderly was increasing. At the same time, the number of people using mechanical aids but living independently, without personal assistance, increased by 5 percent.
Richard Suzman, director of demographic studies at the National Institute of Aging, said in an interview that "the general consensus" among gerontologists once held that increased life expectancy would mean that an individual could expect that a longer fraction of the years after retirement would be spent dependent on someone else for basic needs like taking a bath, getting dressed or going to the toilet.
The extent of an older person's disability is usually gauged by measuring how many such tasks a person can manage independently. The new findings, which are based on raw data from Dr. Suzman's National Long-Term Care Survey, are particularly surprising, he said, because "we find that the improvement in health seems to be greatest for those 75 and over and as great at 85 and over as it is 75 and over." He added, "This is a big change in terms of expectations."
Dr. Manton cautioned that his findings did not change the underlying facts about aging or mean that future elderly populations can expect to be as healthy, on average, as their children or grandchildren. "We've not talking about all these people jumping up and running 100-yard dashes," he said.
 
Trend Is Unclear
 But he said the study indicated a substantial possibility for increasing older people's activity.
"For a lot of people with problems primarily related to joints, vision or sensory function, you could have biomedical intervention or nutrition therapy and have a larger potential for improvement," Dr. Manton said.
Dr. Suzman said it was impossible to say whether the decline in disability rates would be an enduring trend.
"We won't know till be get more data. There were three points in time in this study," he said, referring to the survey dates -- 1982, 1984 and 1989. "The effect seems to be stronger in the 1984-to-1989 period."
The most important part of the study, Dr. Suzman said, was the suggestion that disability was not an inevitable part of aging, and that it might be possible to find a way to slow or prevent such loss of function.
"If we can get our hands on those, you've got a much better chance of affecting the future course of the demography of the older population, in terms of its functional capacity," he said. "It means that demography ain't necessarily destiny."

HEADLINE: U.S. Urges Radon Curbs in New Houses

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed voluntary guidelines calling on builders to install protective measures in hundreds of thousands of new houses in more than a third of the country to prevent radon, an invisible and odorless radioactive gas, from seeping in.
The E.P.A. also published a new information pamphlet warning people of radon's potential to cause lung cancer and urging buyers to require sellers to test houses for radon, just as they are for termite damage, before a sale can be completed. 
 The agency said today that it regarded radon as being among the most serious environmental threats to public health, accounting for 7,000 to 30,000 cases of lung cancer each year in the United States. But that view has been disputed by a growing number of scientists, some of whom said today that the money the agency expected the public to pay for reducing radon in houses was out of proportion to the risk posed by the gas.
The agency said the construction standards were voluntary and subject to change after a public-comment period of 60 days. Agency officials said that if the standards were put into effect, they would urge states and local governments to write them into law and building codes.
 
Costs Estimates Vary
 The agency said that some of the standards were already included in local building codes and the cost of putting them into effect would be less than $100 million. But some agency economists and builders said the cost of new construction standards and testing requirements for radon could be as much as $1 billion to $2 billion a year nationwide.
Testing for radon in a house costs $15 to $50, and taking steps to remove radon in existing homes by venting the gas outside the houses can cost up to $3,000, building contractors said today. Installing measures to prevent radon in new homes can cost $500 to $1,000, builders said.
Taken together, the actions represent a new and politically risky step by the E.P.A. to expand its authority to protect people from a potential environmental hazard in their homes. In the agency's 23-year history, most of its efforts to reduce environmental threats to health have focused on limiting or eliminating pollution from industry, automobiles, sewage treatment plants and toxic-waste sites.
 
Data Seen as Clear
 Much of the $140 billion spent on environmental protection in the United States each year is borne directly by industry or indirectly by taxpayers. By proposing the radon guidelines, the E.P.A. is asking homeowners to bear the cost of protection, thus exposing the agency to much more widespread pressure from the public to defend its position that radon is a serious danger.
An agency spokesman said Carol M. Browner, the E.P.A. Administrator, was briefed about the agency's action today and raised no objections. Ms. Browner was unavailable for comment today because of an illness.
Stephen D. Page, the director of the agency's radon division said that the scientific data on which the action today was based clearly indicated that radon in homes was a threat. Those data are largely an accumulation of studies conducted on miners who developed lung cancer at far higher rates after being exposed to concentrations of radon 50 to 100 times higher than people were exposed to in their houses.
"Radon has been identified by the Surgeon General and other national and international health organizations as a serious environmental health threat," Mr. Page said. "And this is a threat that people can do something about, unlike a lot of other environmental problems. People can take action in their own homes to prevent the problem."
 
Questions About Risk
 But scientists inside and outside the Government question the risk from radon in houses. Dr. Jan A. Stolwijk, a professor of epidemiology and public health at Yale University, said that the low levels of radon that people are normally exposed to in their homes do not pose an exceptional risk of lung cancer, particularly for people who do not smoke. And for those who smoke, he said, exposure to low levels of radon is a minor factor in their already high chances of developing lung cancer resulting from smoking.
"If I'm worrying about lung cancer, I have a much better way of clearly lowering my risk than spending a lot of money preventing radon from entering homes," said Dr. Stolwijk in an interview today. "And that is to stop smoking. If the E.P.A. wants to wipe out lung cancer, they would be much more effective if they banned cigarettes."
Some scientists said today that the differences of opinion between the agency and independent researchers may make the radon issue a test case for a new approach to environmental policy urged by such outsiders. The new approach would weigh the theoretical potential for health damage against the economic and social costs for eliminating the threat.
"We have more data about the effects of radon than just about any other carcinogen that we know about," said Dr. Jonathan M. Samet, a professor of medicine and a radiation health specialist at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque. "We know how many people might die at which level of exposure. What we lack is the decision-making mechanism to decide at what level of risk we're comfortable and how much we should pay for it."
In Washington, Charles Field, a vice president of the National Association of Home Builders, which represents contractors who build more than one million new houses a year, said that he had not studied the guidelines but that they appeared to be reasonable.
But outside Washington, several builders said they were concerned.
"We already can't build houses at an affordable price so that the people who build them, the carpenters, can buy them," said Eugene Graf, a home builder in Bozeman, Mont.
Under the authority of a radon protection law passed by Congress in 1988, the E.P.A. has been expanding its efforts to reduce Americans' exposure to the radioactive gas, which is produced from the decay of uranium in soil. Because the law gives the agency's radon division only the authority to advise the public and not to issue regulations, a fifth of the division's $17 million budget is devoted to education materials.
Since 1988, the Government has advised all homeowners to test for radon, but several surveys have found that only 5 percent have done so.
Mr. Page, the radon division director, said the new standards for construction were aimed at the 1,000 or so counties across the country that are believed to have the highest potential for radon to seep into houses. Those counties are primarily in New England, New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, the upper Midwest and through the northern Rocky Mountains.

HEADLINE: Fear Gives Los Angeles Race an Edge

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 6

 BODY:
Two weeks before Angelenos vote for a new mayor, an extraordinary possibility is emerging: the leading candidate in this heavily Democratic and liberal city is a New York-born Republican who vows to put more police officers on the streets, trim the rest of local government and turn over many city services to private enterprise.
He is Richard Riordan, a 62-year-old lawyer, self-made millionaire, philanthropist and long-time power broker here who has never held public office. Mr. Riordan, who lives alone in a book-cluttered mansion in the exclusive Brentwood section, says he wants the job because "all my life I've been a rescuer." 
 Though he avoids any racial overtones in his campaign, the hard-charging Mr. Riordan has benefited from the fear that is sweeping the city as two racially charged trials converge: the expected conclusion this week of a Federal trial of four police officers in the Rodney G. King beating and the beginning, on Monday, of a trial of three black men in the beating a white trucker last year.
The beating of the trucker occurred in rioting that followed the acquittal of the officers on state charges in the King beating. It is widely believed that renewed violence could strengthen Mr. Riordan, whose motto is "Tough Enough to Turn L.A. Around."
With a campaign financed by $3 million of his own money, earned primarily through investments, Mr. Riordan has flooded the city with advertisements and slick mailings. And while there are no public opinion polls yet to document the prediction, his opponents agree he is almost certain to come in at least second, possibly first, in a field of 24 candidates in the April 20 election.
 
Largely White Electorate
 His most likely opponent in a June 8 runoff is Michael Woo, a 41-year-old City Councilman who is a Los Angeles native. Mr. Woo is a liberal Democrat and as a Chinese-American is representative of the multi-ethnic melange that is Los Angeles today.
In such a runoff, Mr. Riordan would face an uphill but not impossible fight. Though Los Angeles is overwhelmingly Democratic and two-thirds of its residents are black, Hispanic and or other minorities, the electorate is still two-thirds white, concentrated in the San Fernando Valley and the West Side, where even liberals are arming themselves against possible racial disorders, and where the recession has hit hard.
"I am stunned by the possibility in this day and age that the next mayor may be another white male establishment figure, and a Republican, in a minority-majority city," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political analyst at the Claremont Graduate School in suburban Pomona. "But the arithmetic is such that it cannot be ruled out. If the turnout is low, the voters more likely to turn out are the Riordan voters."
If Mr. Riordan wins, it would mean the final dissolution of the powerful but frayed alliance among blacks, Jews and downtown business interests that kept Mayor Tom Bradley in office for 20 years.
 
Other Candidates
 None of the other candidates has caught on yet. Among them are Assemblyman Richard Katz from the San Fernando Valley, who portrays himself as a Democrat tough on crime; Nick Patsaouras, a businessman and Transportation Commissioner whose plan to revive the city is heavily based on broadening public transit; Joel Wachs, a City Councilman from the San Fernando Valley with strong backing from the arts community, and Linda Griego, a businesswoman and former Deputy Mayor who has gotten financial support from women's groups.
"This is a classic example of money being the mother's milk of politics," said Jay Severin, Mr. Wachs's campaign consultant. "Riordan's doing all the right things. It's very tough to compete with him."
Though the election is technically nonpartisan, Mr. Riordan is the only Republican in the field. His strategy is to make the runoff by consolidating the 29.8 percent of voters who have registered as Republican, then seek to broaden his appeal later. The literature he sends to Republican households stresses his ties to Republicans like Ronald Reagan. His latest television commercial uses the word "tough" six times in 30 seconds.
And though he promises to "kick out the politicians who have led us into decline," Mr. Riordan has long been a major contributor to most of California's leading politicians, including Mayor Bradley, a Democrat, and Gov. Pete Wilson, Republican.
A Roman Catholic, he says he supports a woman's right to choose an abortion, but he gives to anti-abortion groups.
A major plank in Mr. Riordan's platform is to put 3,000 more police officers on the streets without raising taxes. He proposes paying for them by renting out Los Angeles International Airport to private operators rather than have the city run it.
 
A Neighborhood Campaign
 His appeal was apparent at a picnic lunch for volunteers Saturday afternoon in a park in the Westwood area. The nearly all-white crowd voiced approval as he outlined his plans to fight graffiti and crime, to break up the Los Angeles Unified School District and to fight illegal immigration. "We have to put tremendous pressure on the Federal Government to keep illegal aliens out of this country," he said.
Among the volunteers were Janice and Roland Behny, residents of the Hancock Park neighborhood, a mostly white area near downtown. "We've had people murdered in front of our house," said Mr. Behny, a sales manager for a publishing company. "The savages are taking over the city."
Then Mr. Riordan went knocking on doors on an street of neatly manicured $1 million homes in Westwood, visiting mostly Republican households, where there was palpable fear of crime.
But in an interview, Mr. Riordan said he did not pander to racial fears, and pointed out that he had donated thousands of dollars to set up educational programs for minority youngsters and was the only white member of a leadership group called 100 Black Men.
 
Bundle on Contradictions
 Crime, he said, is not the exclusive concern of affluent whites. "It's intolerable that a mother has to tell her child in South-Central Los Angeles to duck behind cars when there is shooting," he said. "The issues throughout the city are the same."
A bundle of energy and contradictions, Mr. Riordan has bought his way into Los Angeles politics with a combination of charm, determination and money. After graduating from Princeton University and the University of Michigan Law School, he came here in 1956 to join a law firm. Through investments, he turned a moderate inheritance into a fortune estimated at more than $100 million.
He became a venture capitalist, engaging in restructuring insolvent companies and in leveraged buyouts financed by junk bonds issued by his friend Michael Milken, recently released from prison after serving a term violating securities law.
In an interview, Mr. Riordan, who is divorced from his first wife and separated from his second, said he wanted the job because, "I care." He vows to work for $1 a year as Mayor.
"All my life I've been a rescuer," he said. "There is a vacuum of leadership. I am going to fill it."
But even Mr. Riordan's admirers wonder what kind of mayor he would make. "He gets things done by cutting through red tape" said Mary Nichols, who served with him on the city's Recreation and Parks Commission. "But within city government, there is a tremendous amount of detail. I'm not sure if he would not get bored with it pretty fast."

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Tougher Sanctions on Yugoslavia

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 6

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is seeking United Nations Security Council approval for three additional sanctions against the Yugoslav federation of Serbia and Montenegro to further tighten the economic embargo imposed last year.
It has suggested imposing a maritime exclusion zone along the Adriatic coast of Yugoslavia as part of its drive to strengthen the new and tighter trade embargo the Security Council is expected to approve next Monday. The vote comes after Bosnian Serbs rejected the international plan for ending the civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina last week. 
 Such an exclusion zone, which diplomats say could be enforced by NATO warships, means civilian cargo vessels would be banned from Yugoslavia's 12-mile-wide territorial waters in order to strengthen the economic embargo imposed last spring. This embargo has proved decidedly leaky so far, though the European Community and the United States are both now helping neighboring countries police it more effectively.
The United States has also suggested eliminating a proposed 15-day grace period before the new sanctions take effect so that they would come into force as soon as the Security Council approves them. It also wants to extend a proposed freeze on all of Yugoslavia's overseas financial assets to include buildings and land.
The Security Council agreed on Monday to postpone until next Monday a vote on a resolution tightening the economic embargo on Yugoslavia. The embargo was imposed last year to prevent the Serbian Government of President Slobodan Milosevic from assisting Bosnian Serbs in their fight against Croats and Muslims. The decision to delay the vote was apparently taken as a result of the Vancouver summit meeting last weekend between President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. But the United States also said it needed more time to seek ways of tightening the proposed new sanctions even further.
After the Serbian parliament of Bosnia and Herzegovina voted last Friday to reject the peace plan drawn up by the international mediators, Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, and accepted by Muslims and Croats, the Security Council started discussing moves to reinforce its existing blockade against the Yugoslav federation. Earlier, the Council had voted to authorize NATO warplanes to enforce its ban on all flights over Bosnia and Herzegovina. Although the move has little military significance, it is resented by the Serbs as a sign of the Council's determination to press them harder to make peace.
The existing draft resolution, prepared before the United States offered its latest proposals, bans all shipments of goods across Yugoslavia to other destinations, tightens restrictions on the movement of ships along the Danube River, freezes Yugoslav financial assets overseas, impounds Yugoslav ships, planes, trucks and rolling stock outside the country, and reduces the number of border crossing points into Yugoslavia.
The aim is to sharply increase economic pressure on Yugoslavia, where inflation is running at hundreds of percentage points a month, and thereby force President Milosevic to use his influence with Bosnian Serbs to make them sign the Vance-Owen peace initiative.
In Washington today, Mr. Clinton called the war in the Balkans "the most difficult, most frustrating problem in the world." But he ruled out any unilateral action by the United States, saying that, in coordination with the United Nations, there are "lots of other things we can do to make life more uncomfortable for the Serbs and I wouldn't rule those out."
However, the prospect of an even tighter blockade of Yugoslavia is causing growing political and economic difficulties for several countries, including some that are members of the Security Council. It is embarrassing for President Yeltsin at a time when he is locked in a domestic power struggle with hard-line nationalists who are sympathetic to the Serbs. The parliament has already adopted one nonbinding resolution asking the Government not to impose new sanctions on Yugoslavia.
