HEADLINE: Administration Calls the Principal Medicare Trust Fund Troubled

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration warned today that the principal trust fund for Medicare, which finances hospital care for 35 million elderly and disabled people, would run out of money in 1999 if Congress does not act.
The report by the Medicare trustees underlines a problem facing the Administration. President Clinton is drafting an ambitious proposal to overhaul the nation's health-care system and guarantee coverage for all Americans, at an estimated cost of $30 billion to $90 billion a year. Administration officials have said they want to expand coverage of long-term care and begin covering the costs of prescription drugs. 
 But, as the trustees reported today, the Government does not have the means to pay for the health-care commitments it has already made.
The financial condition of Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund has deteriorated since April of last year, when Government actuaries predicted that it would be exhausted in the year 2002.
 
Fund Is Called 'Unsustainable'Troubled
 The trustees said today that the Medicare hospital program was "unsustainable in its present form." They did not say how the Government could control Medicare costs or increase revenues to keep the program in operation.
In the past, Congress has invariably taken action to prevent depletion of the Medicare trust fund, by raising taxes or limiting payments to hospitals and other health-care providers. Lawmakers made clear today that they would not let the program go broke.
To worry that the trust fund will run out of money is "like worrying that Mexico is going to invade us," said Representative Pete Stark, chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health. "It's a possibility, but they've shown no indication."
But one trustee, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said: "These new estimates show a significant worsening in the economic health of the Medicare program. They reflect many of the problems that we see across the board in our health-care system today, and they are another demonstration of the need for systemwide change."
A major goal of Mr. Clinton's overall health-care plan is to control medical costs. In the last decade, Medicare has adopted fee schedules for hospitals and doctors to slow the growth of Medicare spending, and by most accounts these measures have been effective. But Medicare outlays continue to rise for many reasons, including an increase in the number of beneficiaries, a general increase in the amount of care each beneficiary receives and greater use of costly technology.
 
Action Urged Now
 Three of the five trustees are Cabinet officers. The others are not Government employees and are supposed to represent the public interest. The public trustees urged Congress to "address the need for fundamental reform" of Medicare as part of its effort to revamp the health-care system. But they did not make detailed proposals.
In an interview, Stanford G. Ross, one of the public trustees, said: "We want Medicare considered as part of President Clinton's health-care reform initiative. We don't want it postponed to a later stage."
In a separate report, the Administration said that one of the Social Security trust funds, which pays retirement and survivor benefits, would be in sound financial condition for about 50 years. But it said that another Social Security trust fund, which pays disability benefits, would run out of money in two years.
To deal with this problem, the Administration suggested reallocating payroll taxes so that some of the money earmarked for retirement benefits would be deposited in the disability trust fund. Congress would need to pass legislation to make such a change. But there is no need to increase the overall Social Security tax rate, and the reallocation of money would not cause immediate damage to the retirees' trust fund, the trustees said.
Under current law, the employer and the employee each pay a payroll tax of 5.6 percent for old-age and survivors insurance and 0.6 percent for disability insurance. The tax is applied to the first $57,600 of earnings. The trustees' proposal would change the tax rates to 5.325 percent and 0.875 percent, respectively. With this change, the trustees said, the retirement fund would run out of money in the year 2037, seven years earlier than expected under current law.
Analyzing the future of Medicare, the trustees observed that there are now four workers for each Medicare beneficiary. By the middle of the next century, they said, the ratio will be 2 to 1. But, they warned, Medicare's hospital insurance trust fund will run out of money "even before the major demographic shift begins to occur."
 
Studies Say Payments Dropped
 Part B of Medicare, which pays for doctors' services, has its own trust fund. Beneficiaries pay premiums that cover about one-fourth of the cost. The Federal Government pays for the remainder each year with general revenues.
The trustees observed that outlays for this part of Medicare increased 60 percent in the last five years, to $50.8 billion last year, from $31.7 billion in 1987, and they said the growth "shows little sign of abating."
The trustees, besides Dr. Shalala and Mr. Ross, are Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich and David M. Walker, an accountant.
Despite the growth in Medicare payments to doctors, two recent studies conclude that doctors actually got less in 1992 than they were entitled to receive under the new Medicare fee schedule.
The Physician Payment Review Commission, which advises Congress on payment of doctors under Medicare, said the Bush Administration miscalculated several factors used in paying doctors. The Government assumed that doctors who got lower Medicare payments would perform more services, partially offsetting the loss of income, and it assumed that doctors who got higher payments would perform the same number of services. In fact, the commission said, doctors getting higher payments performed fewer services, so the Government paid them less than it had expected.
Another study, by William C. Hsiao of Harvard University, concluded that "the current Medicare fee schedule yields too little net income to most physicians," in part because it does not adequately account for the doctors' expenses. Dr. Hsiao's study, published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine, was noteworthy because he was an architect of the Medicare fee schedule.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IS SEEKING JOBS PLAN ACCORD

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
Bruised by a battering from Congressional Republicans, President Clinton cast about today for a face-saving compromise to rescue his job-creating spending plan while trying to shame his opponents into retreat.
As Senators and Representatives on spring recess tested their constituents' reaction to the Republican filibuster that blocked passage of the $19.5 billion economic stimulus package, Mr. Clinton conceded he must now "address some of the legitimate expressed objections" to his plan. But the President also stepped up his efforts to paint Republicans as politicians who prize partisan victory more than the national interest. 
 "You know, we have a system in this country where people, all of whom have jobs, the minority of the senators who all have jobs, can literally thwart majority rule," Mr. Clinton said today at a news conference with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.
But there seemed to be little evidence that the filibuster that has stymied the President is abating, even as Mr. Clinton continued his tough talk about the motives of the Republicans.
 
Democrats Are Worrying
 And some Democrats are worried that the President could sustain lasting political damage if the opposition party continues to prove that it can block his plans so early in his term.
White House advisers insisted that the Republicans have now overplayed their hand and will soon be overwhelmed by the communications skills of a President who can now turn his attention to selling his economic plan after weeks of focusing on foreign policy. They reject the notion accepted by Republicans, some Congressional Democrats and Ross Perot, the intractable independent commentator, that Americans are more concerned about the deficit than about jobs or Washington gridlock.
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, did not leave the field of political counterattack to Mr. Clinton today. He issued a sharply worded statement while campaigning on behalf of Republican candidates in Ohio that accused the President of hiding behind accusations of gridlock.
"When the President talks about 'compromise,' " the statement read, "I hope he means we'll start paying for his spending programs, just as the American people are demanding."
 
Compromises in the Works
 Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, is assembling a compromise proposal that both sides expect will be a shrunken version of the President's package of public works projects and Federal programs, aides to both sides said. And Senator Dole is preparing his own version of a Republican alternative, which includes less spending as well as corresponding budget cuts.
Mr. Mitchell, who was traveling in Maine, said that whatever happened to the stimulus package should not be considered an omen about Mr. Clinton's future legislative initiatives.
"It is a total fiction by the so-called analysts and pundits in the press that how this is resolved will determine the actions of the Republicans to the President's program." he said in a telephone interview. "They're against the President's program."
But no one on either side of the continuing dispute would predict which effort could or would win enough votes to break off the filibuster when Congress returns.
"Everybody's banking on the notion that Republicans care as much as Democrats about breaking this gridlock," said Susan Brophy, a legislative affairs assistant to the President.
Some White House advisers conceded that Mr. Clinton's economic plan, which would also increase some taxes and cut some programs to reduce the deficit, had lost ground with the public. That view was supported by a New York Times/CBS News poll conducted last week. In that survey, 45 percent of the 1,368 people polled said the plan would help the nation, down from the 53 percent who said the same thing one month earlier.
In the same poll, the number of people who said they found the economic plan to be "fair to people like you" dropped from 59 percent last month to 48 percent this month.
"When they come back, we'll see whether they really care about putting people to work or whether this is all just political posturing to prove that a minority can paralyze the Federal Government," Mr. Clinton said of the Republicans. "It's just more gridlock, and I think that people will rebel against it."
The cost of the package is also a matter of semantic dispute. Democrats say, accurately, that it approves $16.3 billion in new spending. Republicans add, also correctly, that it allocates $3.2 billion more in road and airport spending previously authorized, but never taken out of special accounts fed by gasoline and air-travel taxes.
 
Recriminations in Senate
 One measure of the political anxiety now gripping the White House is that Senate Democrats have already begun muttering recriminations over the Administration's handling of the Republican offensive.
While the Senate Democrats lead the charge for a compromise, many have begun accusing the White House of a victor's arrogance as well as a misunderstanding of Senate politics.
"This is ominous for a lot of other things," said an aide to a prominent Senate Democrat. "If the Republicans are in a position this early in his term to take on a guy who's just been elected, after their own guy had been resoundingly rejected, that's not a good sign for when the tough votes come."

HEADLINE: Rising Yen Rings Alarms in Tokyo

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 6

 BODY:
For most of the last two months, the Japanese yen has been edging up in value to its strongest level of the postwar era, sending waves of anxiety through the Government and the business world.
The dollar fell to 113.40 yen at one point here on Friday, closing at 114. Some experts say it could plummet soon to 100 yen, less than half its value a decade ago. 
 On Monday, the dollar slipped to 113.70 in New York, its third consecutive postwar low. Today, the dollar recovered a bit, rising to 113.85 yen in New York. [Page D18.]
 
 
Fragile Recovery
 The dollar's steep drop has set off alarms here, with some experts arguing that the rising yen threatens the Japanese economy's fragile recovery and could undermine markets from Tokyo to Wall Street. But after a month of fretting, others are concluding that the stronger yen could ultimately prove an economic boon, giving Japanese consumers price breaks from cheaper imports they have long been denied.
Japan's soaring trade surplus and a sharp decline in the country's overseas investments are believed to be among the reasons for the yen's strength. The dollar has lost around 8 percent of its value against the yen this year, and that decline is already having a big impact on corporate policies.
The Toyota Motor Corporation is said to be preparing to slice some $700 million from its production costs in the next few months; the Sharp Corporation has said it will move all its personal computer production out of Japan to lower costs, and the Daiei Corporation, a leading retailer, has said that for the first time it will substitute less expensive imported suits from China for some Japanese-made suits.
The yen's rise comes as a harsh blow to Japanese exporters in particular, because Japanese goods are becoming more expensive for Americans and other foreigners. But it helps American companies, which is why the Clinton Administration has largely supported the movement.
 Less demand for Japanese goods is expected to force manufacturers to take stern measures to reduce their costs and to improve their efficiency, difficult steps at a time when profits have been battered by an economic slowdown. The Industrial Bank of Japan has estimated that the stronger yen could reduce economic growth as much as half a percentage point this year.
The uncertainty over exchange-rate movements also disrupts Japanese investment plans overseas. Some experts worry that the unease could encourage a flight of Japanese capital from America back to Japan. The value of American securities has already dropped sharply in terms of the yen, in many instances below what the investors paid for them.
 
'One Big Risk'
 "The one big risk is a chain reaction of fear if Japanese investors decide they have to get out of dollar assets," Richard Koo, a senior economist at the Nomura Research Institute, said. "At these exchange rates, all the dollar-denominated paper they own is under water, and there is already some inclination to sell now before the exchange rate gets worse. That could become scary."
Japanese Government officials had clearly supported the yen's appreciation at first for political reasons: the currency's rise is expected, over time, to reduce Japanese exports and increase imports, thus reducing the huge trade surplus, helping American exporters and improving relations with the trade hawks in the Clinton Administration, including President Clinton. But the speed of the yen's recent rise has been unnerving.
"The pace of the Japanese currency's rise is a little too fast," Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said last week.
Yoshiro Hayashi, the Finance Minister, said, "This is contrary to my basic belief that exchange rates should be stable and reflect economic fundamentals."
But among economists and business leaders, some anticipation is mixed with the anxiety. Initially, most of them believe, the yen will remain strong, causing pain for exporters. But in the longer term, the surging currency will strengthen Japanese industries, some economists argue.
"The exporters are definitely going to be hurting," said Robert Alan Feldman, an economist here with Salomon Brothers Asia. "But the effect on inflation is very positive. That will have a number of benefits."
For instance, the strong yen will help produce lower interest rates in Japan, along with lower inflation, Mr. Feldman said. It will also spur quicker action by the Government to stimulate the economy with a big public works program, he suggested. Mr. Miyazawa said last week that he was planning a supplemental spending package of more than $90 billion this year to jump-start the economy.
"The real impact is on the Government," Mr. Koo said. "It is going to have to act with some heavy stimulus. That's why this is generally very good."
 
Long-Term Assessment
 Masaru Hayami, the chairman of the Nissho Iwai Corporation, one of Japan's largest trading companies, and the head of the Japan Association of Corporate Executives, argued in a recent essay that the pain among big exporters would largely be salutary.
Consumers will enjoy lower costs, and manufacturers will be forced to streamline their operations, Mr. Hayami said. At the same time, the costs to industry of imported goods, like raw materials, energy and parts, will decline.
"Though the strong yen may be painful for industry in the short term, this period will further strengthen industry and prove beneficial in the long term," he argued. "The stronger yen will enhance the quality of life."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Health-Care Takeover A Test For Deal Makers

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
In a takeover battle reminiscent of the 1980's, two veteran merger and acquisition gunslingers are squaring off for a showdown.
The Lifetime Corporation, a Boston-based nursing concern, said yesterday that Gleacher & Company, the boutique headed by Eric J. Gleacher, a former merger and acquisitions chief at the Morgan Stanley Group, would be its financial adviser in weighing a takeover offer by Abbey Healthcare Group Inc. 
 Abbey, a Costa Mesa, Calif., home-health-care company that is much smaller than Lifetime, is being advised by Frederick McCarthy, a one-time deal maker at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.
Lifetime said yesterday that it would "explore alternatives" to Abbey's latest offer of $261.3 million, or $27.50 a share in cash and stock, raised from an initial $23.50 last month. Lifetime's board said the possibilities included selling the company or other unspecified "value enhancing" moves.
 
 
A More Reasonable Bid
 "Abbey can get in line," along with other would-be buyers, said Anthony H. Reeves, Lifetime's chairman. It was not clear who the others might be, but Mr. Reeves reiterated that keeping his company independent would benefit shareholders.
Mr. Reeves suggested two weeks ago that $30 a share might be a more reasonable opening bid.
Lifetime shares reached a 52-week high of $25.875 yesterday before closing at $25.25, up $1.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Abbey shares rose 25 cents to close at $17.75 in over-the-counter trading.
Lifetime reported $885.6 million in 1992 sales and net income of $5.2 million after restructuring charges in what one analyst called "a tough year" for the company.
 
 
British Deal Failed
 Analysts said Lifetime might try to sell several noncore businesses to add luster to its stock. They include Office Angels, a British office-temporary agency; ASB Meditest, which tests insurance and job applicants, and a temporary nurse register for hospitals.
Michael J. Sinclair, a co-founder of Lifetime, who left in 1991 with $6.3 million in severance pay, was part of a group that negotiated to buy Office Angels. When the deal foundered in a British economy that was dogged by double-digit unemployment, Lifetime took a $43 million write-off in 1991.
Mr. Reeves of Lifetime said yesterday that Office Angels was now profitable and growing, with about $4 million in 1992 pretax operating profit. "If we restated it today, it would bring $40 million back on the balance sheet," he said.
Abbey reported net income of $10.4 million on sales of $249 million in 1992, up from $227 million the year before.
 
 
One-Stop Shopping
 Timothy M. Aitken, Abbey's president, "did a good job of turning the company around after it went public at $12.50 a share early last year," said Tom Schreuer, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company.
Helen T. O'Donnell, at Paine Webber Inc., said that Abbey's main lines are home respiratory care, medical equipment like wheelchairs, and a small home infusion business that supplies drugs and nutrition intravenously. If combined with Lifetime's vast home nursing network, she said, Abbey could offer "one-stop shopping" to large insurers and other health-care buyers.
Mr. Aitken has criticized "lucrative" executive pay packages at Lifetime. Mr. Reeves said the compensation was justified because the company had exceeded five-year financial targets set after he joined it in 1986.
But Carl Sherman, a health-care analyst at Dillon, Read & Company, said Lifetime was just "a big rent-a-nurse company."
Robert M. Mains, at the First Albany Companies, said Lifetime had staggered through several public relations "disasters." They include the failed Office Angels deal that involved Mr. Sinclair and a $5.7 million write-off for a slow-growing home infusion business.

HEADLINE: German Bank's Chief Stresses Go-Slow Policy

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 6

 BODY:
Despite the recession that has gripped Germany and most of Europe, the German central bank will continue a policy of lowering key interest rates only when it is convinced that such action will not set off inflation or jeopardize the strong position of the mark, the bank's president said today.
In an interview in his 12th-floor office at the Bundesbank's headquarters here, the official, Helmut Schlesinger, made clear that the bank would move cautiously in its policy of reducing short-term interest rates gradually.
 
A Matter of Credibility
 "We have to be careful that we do not endanger the credibility of the Bundesbank's anti-inflationary policy," he said. 
 "As we see maneuvering room opening up, we will use it," Mr. Schlesinger said, indicating that the bank did see reasons for loosening credit. "There are some indications that we'll have such maneuvering room," he said -- "for example, less rapid growth in the money supply, and a certain moderation in wage settlements."
Germany's money supply grew last year by 9.4 percent, well above the Bundesbank's targets of 3.5 to 5.5 percent, and inflation is currently at a 4.3 percent annual rate, high by German standards.
"We have moved cautiously," Mr. Schlesinger added, "but we have been able to bring rates down in small increments, using the maneuvering room we have without negative consequences for the capital markets or for the exchange rate."
His remarks were in line with a steady stream of recent pronouncements from the German bank, which, under pressure from France, Britain and the United States, has lowered the discount rate -- the rate it charges commercial banks for loans -- from 8.25 percent last September to 7.5 percent in mid-March.
 
Cross-Border Effect
 France, where the newly elected conservative Government has pledged to continue tying the franc closely to the mark in anticipation of an eventual European currency union, has had to keep its own rates higher. French money market rates now exceed 10.5 percent, compared with a range in Germany of 6.9 percent to 8.2 percent.
The new French Prime Minister, Edouard Balladur, announced after his appointment last week that the Government would make the French central bank independent of political authority, like the Bundesbank is. Mr. Schlesinger welcomed that decision.
"The most important thing the French Government said concerns its own policy, not the policy of the Bundesbank," he said. "I think now, after the election and the formation of the new Government and its statement of policy, that the chances are much better than before that France can lower the interest-rate differential against the mark."
 
A Decision Not to Act
 He conceded that rate reductions in the short term would be easier for France if Germany also kept cutting its benchmark rates. "We've done it to some extent," he said. But at its most recent meeting last Thursday, the Bundesbank's central bank council, which includes the seven governors and the governors of the nine German regional banks, left key rates unchanged.
The second major German interest indicator, the Lombard rate, which acts as a ceiling on money-market rates, has remained at 9 percent since February.
Over the years, the German central bank's principal preoccupation has been with inflation, which reached such catastrophic levels in the 1920's that it destroyed the currency of the Weimar Republic, impoverishing and embittering many Germans, and contributing to Hitler's rise to power.
Such memories do not disappear. In 1990, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government borrowed heavily to pay for the costs of German reunification rather than raise taxes. This set off a degree of inflation, and the Bundesbank acted to brake it by raising short-term interest rates.
All indications are that the bank will continue its cautious approach after Mr. Schlesinger retires on his 69th birthday in September. He is expected to be succeeded then by his deputy, Hans Tietmeyer, who is 61.
In addition, the Government and the Social Democratic opposition recently agreed to impose a 7.5 percent surcharge on all taxes starting in 1995, and to make billions of marks in budget cuts to reduce a swollen deficit.
 
Too Large a Deficit
 The deficit, in German terms, is now so high -- about 4 percent of the gross national product -- that, Mr. Schlesinger said, the nation could not join in a common European currency under terms of the monetary-union treaty agreed to by leaders of European Community nations at Maastricht in December 1991.
"We haven't fulfilled the criteria now," Mr. Schlesinger said, "but the first qualifying test comes in 1996. So we have a chance to meet the criteria by then, or in 1998, which would be the next pass."
The expectation, he said, was that the Government deficit would be reduced to about 2.5 percent of the gross national product after 1995.

HEADLINE: As No. 2, an Ebullient Point Person for Education

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Madeleine M. Kunin is wasting no time mourning what could have been.
A transition team adviser who is widely believed to have narrowly lost the top spot at the Environmental Protection Agency, Ms. Kunin is now Deputy Secretary of Education, talking with confidence and conviction about her new tasks. 
 "If there was ever a time when the Federal Government can play a better role, this is it," she said recently over crepes and apple cobbler in the Department of Education's dining room. "We're almost at a second stage now. The first stage, rallying people to the cause, the previous administration did succeed in doing that. Now we have to get down to the hard work of making it happen."
Ms. Kunin's share of that work already seems formidable. She is the Education Department liaison with the White House and other agencies on many of the new Administration's major initiatives: national service, youth apprenticeship programs and welfare reform.
She talks familiarly about the elements of the department's upcoming big education bill and its general goals: to set high standards of excellence, make sure good schools are the rule and not the exception and insure that all students have an equal chance to learn.
 
Not Chafing as No. 2
 If it is hard for the 59-year-old former Governor of Vermont to be No. 2, she is not letting on. "He's a very unusual politician," she said of Richard W. Riley, the Education Secretary. "The usual sense of who gets credit for what is totally absent. I feel I'm very much part of the agenda and engaged in it."
She chooses her words with the care of a seasoned politician, but she does not seem studied or slick. Correct and measured as she is, an unmistakable passion creeps in when she talks about education. "Very often in government we fix things that have gone wrong," she said. "But the most effective across-the-board strategy for improving lives is still education, an old-fashioned idea upon which this government was founded."
Like so many immigrants of her generation, Ms. Kunin (pronounced KYOO-nin) draws her belief in the power of education from her own experience. "Education did open up all those possibilities in my life," she said. "I have to feel very strongly -- we have to do the same things for young people."
 
Fled the Holocaust
 Born in Switzerland in 1933, she, her brother and their widowed mother fled for the United States in June 1940, when Hitler's conquest of France brought him too close to their country for comfort. In Italy, she and her family fought for a place on the last ship carrying Jews that was allowed to leave Genoa, squeezing with 3,000 other passengers into 900 berths.
Relatives met them in New York, and the family settled in Forest Hills, Queens, later moving to Pittsfield, Mass.
Her mother supplemented a small inheritance from her late husband by taking in boarders and working as a seamstress and French tutor. The young Madeleine started out speaking no English, but became the first member of her family to graduate from college, with a degree in history from the University of Massachusetts.
She deftly avoided a question about whether her experience made her skeptical about the merits of bilingual education or multiculturalism. "One has to be careful not to draw parallels too quickly," she said. "As a child, I wanted to shed my immigrant past as quickly as possible. As an adult, I'm now fully appreciating its richness.
"There is a lot to be said for validating the immigrant experience. We haven't figured out in this country how to get the right balance. The challenge is to become part of the mainstream while continuing to respect the original culture. We have to be careful in protecting people's interests we don't shortchange them in the long run."
After college in Massachusetts, Ms. Kunin got a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University, but in the late 1950's, few newspapers would hire women. She said her interviewer at The New York Times, hearing she had worked as a waitress, offered her a job in the cafeteria. She finally landed a job as a reporter at The Burlington (Vt.) Free Press. A year later, she married Arthur Kunin, a doctor, and left work to raise a family. The couple have four children.
In 1970, when her husband was on sabbatical, they went to Switzerland, where she watched Swiss women fight for the right to vote. That experience with injustice, coupled with her early memories of Nazi-dominated Europe, pushed her toward politics.
"What I gleaned from that is that inaction or silence is also a decision," she said. In 1972, she was elected to the Vermont House of Representatives. Ms. Kunin was elected lieutenant governor in 1978, and after losing a bitter race for governor in 1982, she won the governorship in 1984. With the recession eroding her popularity, she decided not to seek a fourth two-year term in 1990.
As the first woman to serve as Vermont's Governor, she was often pressed to define how women govern differently, if they do. At first, she faced criticism for a style of leadership and decision-making that she thought consensual and others mistook for weak. But now, she believes, there are so many more women in government that women and men can be less self-conscious.
"As more women are there, it is more difficult to stereotype women," she said. "A lot of stereotypes don't hold, but having said that, you can still make some observations. Most definitely, we are still newcomers very often to the establishment we're entering and that does give you a greater perspective. You bring different life experiences to the process."
She is writing a political memoir that includes reflections on women and governing, to be published this year by Knopf.
 
Agenda Cost Her Support
 As Governor, she was best known for environmental measures that required land-use planning, established hazardous-waste programs and toughened standards for air and water pollution. These cost her some support in her home state when the economy turned sour, but also won her prominence as an environmentalist and put her in the running to head the environmental agency.
She also concentrated on education, including providing kindergarten for all children, raising teacher salaries, creating early childhood programs and revising state aid formulas to direct more money to poor school districts.
Because she and Mr. Riley are both former governors, she said she believes they are prepared for Federal jobs in a field in which states have the most influence because they pay most for education.
"I think I bring experience of having dealt with issues from a state perspective, a real sense of what works and what doesn't," she said. And she suggests that the Federal Government, despite its relatively limited role in education, can focus national attention on education, showcase those programs that work, offer technical assistance and help narrow the gap between rich and poor schools.
"The true exception should be the school that's in trouble," she said. "Sometimes we have accepted mediocrity. I sense that people are impatient with that and disturbed by it. We are beginning to measure ourselves against global standards, enabling the American people to accept higher standards, higher demands, and to ask that of our children."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Make Up Losses From Friday Plunge

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The price of Treasury bonds jumped three-quarters of point yesterday and the yield dropped back below 7 percent. Traders said the market was proving resilient after Friday's sharp selloff on inflationary fears, but they suspected that Treasury yields were still locked in a trading range and not headed to new lows.
"We're still squarely in a trading range, in a very confined trading range," said Michael Moran, a managing director at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. 
 He said that the jump over 7 percent Friday, which came with a drop in the price of more than a point, had made the 30-year bond attractive again. But he also suggested that buying interest would probably dry up if the yield moved down several basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
The yield on the 30-year bond ended at 6.96 percent yesterday, down from 7.02 percent Monday. The price was up 25/32 , to 1021/32 . With yesterday's price rise, the 30-year bond had made up all that it lost in Friday's plunge and then some. Treasury notes were up only moderately in comparison.
Traders said that prices were moved by rumors about a major speculator buying 30-year bonds, shifts in trading strategies and talk, which seems to arise regularly, that the Treasury will issue a smaller amount of 30-year bonds in the next quarterly auction in May.
But the focus was still on the reports on producer and consumer prices that are to be issued tomorrow and Friday. Traders and investors want to see if these two reports confirm their fears that the rate of inflation will not decline this year below 1992's 3 percent rate and may, in fact, increase a little. Friday, which is Good Friday, is a bond market holiday.
Last Friday's employment report for March accentuated these concerns because it showed that the economy, while growing slower than the near 5 percent pace at the end of last year, was still moving ahead at a speed that could make it difficult for the inflation rate to fall this year.
Mr. Moran said that some people might have been feeling a little less worried about inflation yesterday. This was reflected in the fall of the yield on the 30-year bond and also on the 10-year Treasury note, which dropped to 6.07 percent from 6.11 percent on Monday. And the feeling may have been helped by a fall of a point and a half in the Commodity Research Bureau index of commodity prices, another barometer of inflaltion.
But Mr. Moran also said that in light trading during a four-day week ahead of an important economic report, it does not take much to move the market. And he said that inflationary fears "can be rekindled in a hurry with a bad number" on Thursday or Friday.
 
Report on Bond Auctions
 One of the reasons it was difficult to read too much significance into yesterday's market move was that part of it seemed to be based on a report early in the morning that the Treasury then sought to deflect.
Stone & McCarthy Research Associates reported that a Treasury staff study was going to recommend a 50 percent cut in the size of the auction of the 30-year bond, which was $9.25 billion in February, and elimination of the seven-year note auction. The details the firm reported were similar to those in a proposal made by the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee as a way to cut borrowing costs and reduce the deficit.
Ward McCarthy, a managing director of the firm, noted that his firm's report included all kinds of caveats, including the firm's opinion that the proposal was not a good idea. But it still seemed to move the market, where many traders believe ardently that a cut in available supply of a bonds or notes would result in an increase in value and price of the securities outstanding.
Prices still rose after the Treasury reiterated the comments of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, who has said there would be no radical change in the mix of the Treasury borrowing and that the seven-year note would not be eliminated.
 
Debt Ceiling Rise
 On another front, there was a little sigh of relief now that Congress has approved a temporary increase in the Government debt ceiling to $4.37 trillion. While traders expected Congress to take action before today's deadline, it allowed the market to get back to its normal routine as the Treasury resumed its regular auctions.
The approval of the increase in the borrowing limit is expected to accommodate Government borrowing through Sept. 30, the end of fiscal year 1993. The delay forced the cancellation of the one-year bill auction last week and the regular weekly three-month and six-month Treasury bill auction Monday.
With the ceiling raised, the Treasury held the one-year bill auction yesterday, where the average discount rate came in at 3.24 percent, the highest since February, and scheduled the three-month and six-month bill auction for today. The Treasury also sold $17.1 billion in a 15-day cash management bills. The average discount rate was 3.07 percent.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auctions of one-year bills and 15-day cash management bills:

HEADLINE: In an Urban Version of Horse-Trading, Owner of Daily News Stands to Gain

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
New York City is trying to persuade Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News, to build a new printing plant in the Bronx, while at the same time Mr. Zuckerman is pressing the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for changes in his plans to develop the Coliseum site at Columbus Circle.
While Mr. Zuckerman and city officials say the printing plant and the Coliseum development are not connected, Dinkins administration officials are trying hard to persuade Mr. Zuckerman to build his plant in the city. Mr. Zuckerman has said he would be interested in building in the Harlem River Rail Yards project in the South Bronx if he can get loan guarantees and other incentives from the city. 
 The city's eagerness for The News plant presumably strengthens Mr. Zuckerman's hand in negotiations over what had been planned as an apartment, office and retail complex on the site of the Coliseum complex at Columbus Circle. Mr. Zuckerman is reported to be trying to scale back and delay the troubled project.
The two sets of talks with Mr. Zuckerman over his newspaper's planned printing plant and his planned development are made even more delicate by their timing, in advance of the mayoral campaign, and by the potential for a clash of interests between the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the Columbus Circle site. The negotiations were reported in The New York Observer last week.
 
Link Is Denied
 City officials confirmed that they were talking with Mr. Zuckerman. But Jennifer Kimball, a spokeswoman for Barry F. Sullivan, the Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, said there is no official link between the printing plant and the Coliseum.
Mr. Zuckerman, when asked about the Coliseum and the printing plant, said, "There's really nothing yet to talk about."
Mr. Zuckerman, through Boston Properties, is under contract to buy the 3.4 acres on Columbus Circle for $338.6 million. He announced his plans for a 2.1-million-square-foot project in 1985, but in 1987, Salomon Brothers, which was to have been the main office occupant, pulled out. After widespread criticism and court challenges, Mr. Zuckerman scaled the development back twice and the price of the land went down each time; the last legal challenge to the plan ended in June 1992.
Since then, Mr. Zuckerman has been free to build, but the 16 percent vacancy rate in midtown office space has made it clear that if the project were built at the designed size now, it might not be profitable. The M.T.A. has also had the right either to schedule a final closing of the sale of the property or to collect a letter of credit worth $33.8 million, or 10 percent of the purchase price, if Mr. Zuckerman does not close on that date. Meanwhile, the Coliseum can be used only for short-term activities, and it pulls in little revenue for the M.T.A.
Councilwoman Ronnie M. Eldridge, who represents the area, said Mr. Zuckerman "not only wants to not deliver the letter of credit, but he also wants to have an extension of at least two years, retain the exclusive right to develop the plan and at the same time to change the project and make it smaller, which incidentally is what we want, but will mean less revenue for the M.T.A. and for the city.
"He also wants not to have any long-term lease arrangements for the use of the Coliseum, and to receive a financial-benefits package for the plant in the Bronx," she said. "So I think he's asking for a lot, and I think it's too much."
John Cunningham, a spokesman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said talks with Mr. Zuckerman over reorganizing the Columbus Circle plan are "intensive" and added, "We expect them to conclude fairly soon."
While the M.T.A. would like to get revenue out of the Coliseum site -- either through the sale of the property or at least for temporary rentals -- its interests may be subordinated to the city's desire to keep Daily News jobs.
After The New York Times closed its printing plant in Carlstadt, N.J., earlier this year, a spokeswoman for Mr. Zuckerman said he was considering seeking to acquire the plant. But yesterday Morri Berman, a spokesman for Mr. Zuckerman, said: "The Carlstadt site is no longer under consideration."
In November, The New York Times announced that it would build a $280 million printing plant on city-owned land in College Point, Queens. The city and state granted a package of tax incentives, low-cost energy and other benefits worth a total of $29 million over the course of a 35-year lease.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
American to Be Head of Economist's Parent

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
Directors of the Economist Newspaper Ltd. will today promote Marjorie M. Scardino, currently the president of its North American operations, to chief executive of the parent company in London, the publication said yesterday.
Mrs. Scardino, 46, is the first American, as well as the first woman, to head the company that publishes the 150-year old Economist. 
 She will replace David S. Gordon, who announced his resignation on March 31 to become chief executive of Independent Television News.
A week ago, The Economist named Bill Emmott, its business affairs editor, as its 15th editor. Mr. Emmott replaces Rupert Pennant-Rea, who is leaving to become deputy governor of the Bank of England.
 
Circulation Has Jumped
 Since 1985, when Mrs. Scardino joined The Economist as head of the North American publication, circulation of the New York-based North American edition has risen to 225,000, an increase of 110 percent.
Advertising revenue for the North American edition has also risen sharply despite the industrywide slump. In 1992, the magazine ran 2,743 advertising pages, surpassing the three American news weeklies, Time, Newsweek and U.S. News & World Report.
The North American edition, which is printed in Virginia, includes the same material as other editions of The Economist distributed around the world. The only difference is the arrangement of material and, occasionally, different covers.
Mrs. Scardino is also deputy chairman of the Economist Intelligence Unit, the company's business information subsidiary, which publishes newsletters and reports about a wide range of business activity around the world. She will join the company's board when she assumes her responsibilities in London on May 4.
The Economist, which was founded in 1843, calls itself a newspaper and not a magazine because in 19th-century England many newspapers had the look of magazines. The Economist Ltd. is partly owned by the Financial Times Ltd., which in turn is owned by Pearson P.L.C.
Beth Maher, vice president of circulation and marketing for The Economist in New York, said Mrs. Scardino was among three candidates considered for the top job. The others were the worldwide advertising director, David Hanger, and the company's marketing director, Helen Alexander.
Before joining The Economist, Mrs. Scardino was a partner in a law firm in Savannah, Ga. Before that, she was publisher and founder of The Georgia Gazette, along with her husband, Albert Scardino.
Mrs. Scardino was on her way from London to New York yesterday and could not be reached for comment.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Speculation About a German Rate Cut

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar bounced off recent lows in light trading yesterday as a steeper-than-expected increase in German unemployment stirred speculation that Germany was ready to cut interest rates again.
Meanwhile, the Japanese yen fell from its newest postwar high against the dollar. Market participants cited an unconfirmed rumor that the Bank of Japan intervened further to support the United States currency. They also pointed to position-squaring ahead of the Good Friday holiday. 
 Gold retreated for the second consecutive day. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell $1.60 an ounce to close at $337.90. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $337.50 an ounce, also off $1.60.
 
 
Western German Jobless
 The German Government reported that the number of jobless in western Germany jumped by 56,000 in March, higher than market expectations. Other figures showed western German industrial output falling a worse-than-expected 2.2 percent in February.
The data reignited talk that Germany's central bank was preparing to cut interest rates from current high levels as a way to stimulate the economy. Also stirring speculation was a meeting this week between Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany and Prime Minister John Major of Britain.
"Any time the two get together you have to think about German rate cuts," Jack Stapleton, senior corporate dealer at Standard Chartered Bank, said.
The American currency would benefit from lower German rates because they would make dollar-denominated investments seem more attractive.
 
 
Gain in Tokyo
 The dollar closed in Tokyo at 114.28 yen, up 0.45 yen from Monday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 113.95 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was quoted at 113.85 yen, up from its postwar low of 113.70 reached late Monday.
The dollar also rose against the British pound. In London, sterling fell to $1.5140, from $1.5310 late Monday. By afternoon in New York, the pound fetched $1.5150, less than late Monday's 1.5210.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, were: 1.6110 German marks, up from 1.5950; 1.4875 Swiss francs, up from 1.4770; 5.4580 French francs, up from 5.4125; 1,591.00 Italian lire, up from 1,586.00, and $1.2585 (Canadian), down from $1.2623 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: The Yields at Banks Show a Slight Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Average yields at banks across the nation on money market accounts and certificates of deposit for the week beginning today are down slightly from the previous reporting period and a little lower than those offered in the New York market.
Robert K. Heady, publisher of The Bank Rate Monitor, said deposit yields were down despite inflationary pressures indicated in the most recent economic numbers. 
 "Even as we enter into April, traditonally a heavy rollover month for certificates of deposit, we see little evidence that banks are doing much to stem any outflow of deposits or much promoting to capture I.R.A. money," he said. "They will likely lose some depositors to stocks and bonds."
The Treasury's three- and six-month bill auction was postponed this week from its usual Monday and was rescheduled for today. The auction is often regarded as a harbinger of rate changes at banks. Yesterday, the Government auctioned a one-year bill whose sale had been postponed on Thursday because Congress had failed to pass legislation to increase the Federal debt ceiling.
Yesterday's 52-week bill auction produced an average rate of 3.24 percent, up sharply from last month. But the rate at today's three- and six-month auction is expected to slip, since most of the upward movement in interest rates recently has been in the longer maturities.
In the latest survey by The Bank Rate Monitor, weaknesses in yields were evident in commercial bank money market accounts, where the average yield slipped a basis point, to 2.36 percent, and in the savings banks' six-month certificates of deposit, which dropped 3 basis points, to 3.05 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, again among the banks making the sharpest adjustment in deposit yields, raised the yield on its three-month certificate of deposit by 10 basis points, to 2.38 percent. Home Savings of America dropped the average yield on its money market account by 5 basis points, to 2.63 percent, while Anchor Savings lowered its six-month certificate by a large 35 basis points, to 3.05 percent.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Buying Sallie Mae is a bet that Congress won't dismantle it

BYLINE: By Leslie Wayne

 BODY:
It's hardly a stock for the faint of heart, but several analysts are, oh-so-tentatively, looking favorably at the shares of the Student Loan Marketing Association, better known as Sallie Mae.
Sallie Mae's shares have been on a roller-coaster ride of late -- mostly down. "I've aged two years in the last two months," said Gary Gordon, an analyst at Paine Webber. Added David Hochstim, an analyst at Bear, Stearns, "This is the stock that gave me the flu." 
 No wonder. On Feb. 1, Sallie Mae was at $74 a share. Yesterday, it closed at $46.75, up 62.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.
Such free falls aside, some analysts say Sallie Mae may be a stock for hardy investors willing to take a chance on the whims of Washington and on future interest rates.
What's behind the drop in Sallie Mae is a concern that the Government may phase out Sallie Mae entirely. Founded in 1972 to help finance higher education, Sallie Mae is a Government-sponsored enterprise that buys student loans from banks. Currently, it has about $24 billion in its loan portfolio. In 1992, Sallie Mae earned $393.9 million, an increase of 14 percent. The company has also gained a reputation for spending and fancy offices. Its chief executive, Lawrence A. Hough, earns $1.1 million, along with stock options and retirement perks. These extras were estimated to add up to $1 million in 1991.
Sallie Mae has come under fire, especially from the Clinton Administration, which has proposed phasing it out by 1997. The Administration bases this view on a study by the General Accounting Office that $1.3 billion a year could be saved by replacing Sallie Mae with a program of direct Government loans from colleges to students. But other studies have questioned the saving and raised doubts about the ability of the Government to run the loan program more efficiently than the private sector.
Analysts have said buying Sallie Mae is like buying an option -- taking a chance Congress will retain the program. They estimate the "phase-out" value of Sallie Mae at around $50 a share. And if the program is kept -- Sallie Mae does have powerful allies on Capitol Hill -- the potential is significant. Low interest rates have contributed to Sallie Mae's strong financial performance of late, making its cost of funds significantly lower than what student borrowers pay to retire loans. If low rates continue, so may Sallie Mae's profit growth.
Analysts believe that Congress, once it examines the numbers and issues involved, will decide to retain Sallie Mae. "I'm sticking with buy," Mr. Hochstim of Bear, Stearns said. "I'm optimistically and naively believing that Congress and the Administration will behave rationally and not phase in direct loans."
The Sallie Mae bulls are encouraged by a recent Congressional Research Office report saying that no money would be saved by eliminating Sallie Mae and that administrative costs would be high under Government management. Although universities have not weighed in on the subject yet, analysts feel they may look dimly at anything that could stick them with potential student loan losses and high administrative costs.
Peter Treadway of Smith Barney believes the stock is fairly priced at current levels. "Obviously it's not for widows and orphans," he said, adding that even if direct lending were passed, Sallie Mae might remain as a loan servicer.
The proposed phase-out of Sallie Mae has already been taken up in the House, but there will be much more politicking before the final Clinton budget package -- with or without the Sallie Mae phase-out -- emerges this summer. For Sallie Mae shareholders, that means the roller-coaster ride will continue.

HEADLINE: Albany Allocates Funds For Historical Society

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
The New York State Legislature has approved a $6.3 million appropriation for the New-York Historical Society, the first step in a plan to rescue that beleaguered institution.
The money, part of the state budget package approved by the Legislature on Monday, is contingent on several factors, one of which is an equal contribution from New York City. 
 "It's do-able," said Barbara J. Fife, New York City's Deputy Mayor for Planning and Development, when asked if the city would match the sum. "It's a question of how we spend our money, but I would think the city will recognize this as a new need."
The legislation also makes the state's contribution dependent on the historical society's submitting an acceptable "financial stabilization and development plan describing the steps it will take to achieve financial self-sufficiency, protection of its libraries and collections and expansion of its services to the public."
Of the state's $6.3 million appropriation, $5 million is for capital improvements, chiefly repairs to the roof of the society's landmark building at Central Park West and 77th Street. An additional $1.3 million is for operating expenses through the end of fiscal 1994.
The plan to save the financially troubled society, drawn up last month by a special advisory committee and lobbied for in both Albany and New York City by officers of the society, includes the development of real estate and the selling of enough artworks and other materials to build a $40 million endowment for the institution.
Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat and a member of the Standing Committee on Tourism, Arts and Sports Development, said he would use a public hearing on Thursday to question the society's plan to sell items from its collecton. The hearing is scheduled for 10:30 A.M. in the Assembly Hearing Room of the New York State Office Building at 270 Broadway, in lower Manhattan.
The society has narrowly survived two close brushes with bankruptcy over the past four years. As a result of the most recent financial crisis, numerous staff members have been dismissed, the art galleries have been closed and the library -- given a temporary reprieve when the trustees reached into their own pockets last month -- remains open only from Wednesdays to Fridays.
Wilbur L. Ross, the chairman of the society's advisory committee, called the State Legislature's appropriation "wonderful."
"We are extremely grateful," he said.

HEADLINE: Quiet Revolution in Canadian Wine

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario

 BODY:
CANADIAN wine was almost an oxymoron until a few years back.
A wine industry had been active since the mid-19th century but was best known for something called Baby Duck, a sweet, fizzy concoction that tasted like ginger ale with a kick and made the rounds surreptitiously at high school proms. 
 Some other products were of the "block and tackle" variety, so named after a member of the Ontario Legislature described their effects: "You drink a bottle, walk a block, and you can tackle just about anyone."
Now, after a quiet viticultural revolution in which lesser quality grapes more suitable for juice and jam have been displaced by great thoroughbreds like chardonnay, riesling and pinot noir, Canadian wine is suddenly winning international prizes, is being reviewed in the wine press and is being sold in restaurants in New York, Paris and Tokyo.
Taking a leaf from France and its Appelation d'Origine Controlee, producers here have established their own strict guidelines. A Vintners Quality Alliance sticker on a bottle guarantees that all of the grapes are from a specific area and that a panel of wine makers and sommeliers have attested to the wine's quality.
Although less than 10 percent of the country's production merits the V.Q.A. label, at some wineries the figure is as high as 40 percent, and the influence of the system is growing. Sales of V.Q.A. wines nearly doubled last year, despite the recession and increased competition from freer trade with the United States and the rest of the world.
Peter Gamble, the executive director of the Vintners Quality Alliance and a former wine maker himself, said that to enforce the new quality standards, lesser-quality grapes were actually outlawed for wine making five years ago. "It's been an astounding transition," he said.
The Wine Spectator, one of the most influential trade journals, published a special report last June entitled "Ontario Wines Come In From the Cold." Thomas Matthews, The Spectator's New York bureau chief, wrote that Ontario's wine makers, who account for 90 percent of Canada's production, were taking advantage of a favorable climactic niche to produce "racy wines that can achieve elegance and breed."
"As an emerging wine area, Ontario is quite promising," he said in an interview earlier this year.
The largest part of Ontario's wines come from the Niagara peninsula, which at 43 degrees north latitude is more southerly than all the wine regions of France, but roughly the same latitude as Northern California and the Chianti region of Italy.
The Niagara peninsula, which stretches between Lake Erie and Lake Ontario, has two features that grapes seem to like: an escarpment or ridge to the south that is a barrier against disruptive continental winds, and Lake Ontario to the north, which moderates temperatures.
Among the viticultural revolutionaries are people like Donald Ziraldo, 44, a agriculture graduate of the University of Guelph in Ontario, and Karl Kaiser, 51, who started learning his wine making at age 13 in the vineyards of a Cistercian monastery in his native Austria.
They teamed up to buy a small vineyard in the early 1970's and, ignoring expert advice, replaced the lesser-quality native labrusca grapes with pinot noirs, rieslings and chardonnays.
"We were determined to show that Ontario had the proper climate and soil to become a credible wine region," Mr. Ziraldo said earlier this year.
In 1975, their newly formed Inniskillin winery -- its name is derived from the Inniskilling Fusiliers, a famous Irish regiment in the Niagara region during the War of 1812 -- received the first Ontario Wine License granted since 1929.
Now Inniskillin owns 60 acres of vineyards, produces 120,000 cases a year and plans $1.7 million in general improvements. Its wines are available across Canada as well as in the United States, Britain, France, Denmark, Japan and Hong Kong.
Ice wine, a sweet dessert wine made of grapes left to freeze on the vine, is a specialty of Inniskillin and most other Niagara wineries. Inniskillin's ice wine won the Grand Prix d'Honneur in the June 1991 Vin Expo competition in Bordeaux, a feat for any winery, let alone one from Canada.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald Ziraldo at his Ontario winery, Inniskillin. (Elisavietta Ritchie for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 561 words

HEADLINE: Sex and Consequences

 BODY:
A country with one of the world's highest standards of living is not a country in which one expects to find a remarkable number of people afflicted with sexually transmitted diseases. But according to a study by the Alan Guttmacher Institute, 56 million Americans are infected with them, and at least one of every four can expect to be.
Such age-old scourges as gonorrhea and syphilis do significant damage, but the widest impact comes from incurable viral diseases, which get far less public health attention. Some 31 million Americans are believed to have genital herpes, while 24 to 40 million are infected with the virus that causes genital warts. 
 Poverty, ignorance and the attendant lack of medical care are partly responsible for the rising rates of sexually transmitted disease; so is the tragic trade of sex for drugs. But a major reason so many Americans are prey to S.T.D.'s, as they are called, is that they are Americans. Which is to say: They initiate sexual intercourse early, marry late and divorce often. During the periods when they're not married, and sometimes when they are, many will have several sexual partners (adult Americans average seven over a lifetime) and will be inconsistent in their use of condoms.
Although public health programs concentrate on adult males, women and teen-agers are hardest hit. Two-thirds of those who contract S.T.D.'s are under 25; a fourth of them are teen-agers. Women are more susceptible to infection and thus more apt to suffer the consequences -- chronic infection, infertility, spontaneous abortions, damaged babies -- for life. Condom carelessness is particularly risky for women, to whom these diseases are easy to transmit and in whom they're difficult to diagnose. Just one act of unprotected intercourse with an infected partner, and a woman has a 50 percent likelihood of contracting gonorrhea.
The classic venereal diseases, syphilis and gonorrhea, are most prevalent among the poor, but chlamydia, which infects far more Americans each year, cuts across the economic spectrum. Often it causes pelvic inflammatory disease, which in turn can lead to ectopic pregnancy, infertility and chronic pelvic pain. And if the emotional cost of a venereal disease is high, so is the price of a cure or semi-cure. In 1990 the costs of treating pelvic inflammatory disease and related ectopic pregnancies and infertility added up to $4.2 billion.
Perhaps it is the focus on AIDS that has made Americans forget about their vulnerability to other venereal diseases. But lack of information played a part, too. Because medical emphasis has been on treatment rather than prevention, people may not realize that some of the ailments are literally incurable.
Public health programs need to be redirected -- to help women and teen-agers and to target diseases that are currently neglected but afflict millions of Americans. Even more important, the nation needs more prevention and education programs to persuade people to avoid risky sexual encounters and use condoms. To reduce the risk is the most cost-effective way to cut the disease rate. For incurable viral diseases, prevention is the only approach that can work.
Americans, as this country learned too late to prevent many deaths, can't afford to be ignorant about AIDS. They can't afford to be ignorant about other S.T.D.'s either.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
